courses.description: Special topics in botany.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 1-15 Credits
courses.description: Overseas Studies

courses.name: Essential Cell Biology 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the basic concepts of molecular cell biology in prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems including experimental strategies and methodology. This course is intended for those interested in plants.

courses.name: Plant Ecology 3 Credits
courses.description: Principles of ecology at scales ranging from individual plants to landscapes. Emphasis is on species, ecosystems and environmental programs in Florida.

courses.name: Introduction to Business 1 Credit
courses.description: Introduces the business world by focusing on various disciplines within business and management. Also introduces personal and professional development opportunities that enhance career preparedness.

courses.name: Special Projects 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Projects related to business as approved by the college.

courses.name: Leading Organizations 4 Credits
courses.description: Provides a Strategic Foundation for Leadership Practice in a Variety of Professions. Increases the Capacity to Lead With and Without Authority, Across Boundaries, and From Any Political or Organizational Position.

courses.name: Effective Career Management in Business 4 Credits
courses.description: Systematically designed course based on the cognitive information processing theory for career problem solving and decision-making. Delivered via modularized multimedia instructional materials. The course is designed to inform students about career planning and management interventions and to accommodate students at different levels of decidedness about their career aspirations.

courses.name: Professional Writing in Business 3 Credits
courses.description: Teaches business students fundamental written communication skills focusing on those areas central to professional writing in business. (C) (WR)

courses.name: Professional Speaking in Business 3 Credits
courses.description: Teaches fundamental oral communication skills necessary for succeeding in a business setting including presentations and speeches, interpersonal skills and interviewing.

courses.name: Writing and Speaking in Business 4 Credits
courses.description: Online content teaches business students the fundamentals of both written and spoken communication, enabling them to express their ideas effectively and efficiently and to prepare them for the demands of the business workspace. (C) (WR)

courses.name: International Business 4 Credits
courses.description: Exposes the business environments (culture, politics, laws and economics) encountered in other parts of the world; to the tools and skills necessary to analyze the potential of other countries as locations for production, distribution and marketing; to how managing and integrating international operations in many parts of the world differs from the domestic focus of many business courses; and to the broad perspective required of successful managers working in international business.

courses.name: Business Case Analysis 2 Credits
courses.description: Introduces case analysis and prepares students for national and international case competitions.

courses.name: Individual Work 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Reading and/or research in business administration.

courses.name: Independent Study 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Reading and research in business administration.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Business 0-4 Credits
courses.description: Provides an opportunity for firsthand, supervised research in business. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application in business.

courses.name: Special Topics 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Variable content provides an opportunity for in-depth study of topics not offered in other courses and topics of special current significance.

courses.name: Professional Development Module 2 Credits
courses.description: Presents techniques for outstanding presentation and public speaking skills. Includes a significant service learning component whereby students apply presentation techniques developed in the classroom via business-oriented instruction in the K-12 school system.

courses.name: Internship in Business Administration 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Applied work in business administration that requires several papers and reports.

courses.name: International Studies in Business 1-18 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: Honors Thesis 1 Credit
courses.description: A thesis is required for the awarding of the magna cum laude or summa cum laude designation. To qualify for the thesis option, students will normally have completed 90 semester credits of coursework (exceptions may be made by the honors coordinator of the student's major department) and must have at least the 3.6 grade point average required for magna cum laude designation at the time they enroll. The thesis will be reviewed by at least one faculty member chosen by the honors coordinator from the student's major department.

courses.name: College Study Skills 1 1-3 Credits
courses.description: A developmental course designed to assist students who may be having difficulty in their college-level coursework or those who simply wish to improve basic skills essential for college success. The course begins with an individual self-assessment followed by topics such as motivation, time management, active reading, memory, note taking and test taking. Students will also develop a career portfolio for their final lesson.

courses.name: Job Strategies 1 Credit
courses.description: Interactive course covering all aspects of a successful job search, long-term career planning and success in the professional environment. Enrollment is restricted to juniors and seniors.

courses.name: Biology for Engineers 3 Credits
courses.description: Principles and engineering applications of biology. Principles and applications of biochemistry, genetics, microbial systems, animal systems, ecological systems and global systems. (B) (WR)

courses.name: Introduction to Biomolecular Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces bio-related careers in chemical engineering and emphasizes the link between biology and chemical engineering as well as the interface between them.

courses.name: Biomolecular Cell Mechanics 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers the biomolecular basis of cell mechanics and cell motility, emphasizing quantitative models and systems-biology approaches.

courses.name: Dynamics of Cellular Processes 3 Credits
courses.description: Confocal florescence microscopy, techniques for imaging macromolecular dynamics and interactions inside living cells, models of intracellular diffusion, models of ligand-receptor binding, interplay between binding and transport, modeling and analysis of experiments. Examples from literature include mRNA transport, nuclear pore dynamics, cytoskeletal dynamics, imaging motor proteins and transcription factor dynamics.

courses.name: Computer Model Formulation 4 Credits
courses.description: Solutions of scientific and engineering problems using digital computers. Formulation of models for describing physical processes, numerical analysis and computer programming. (M)

courses.name: Professional Development of Chemical Engineers 1 Credit
courses.description: Introduces the Chemical Engineering profession and a wide range of careers, including chemical, energy, pharmaceutical, semiconductor, and food industries, as well as graduate and professional school pathways. Provides resources to build successful professional careers, including best practices for interviewing, oral presentations, and teamwork. Also discusses professional codes of conduct and ethical decision-making.

courses.name: Material and Energy Balances 4 Credits
courses.description: Formulation and solution of material and energy balances utilizing physical/chemical properties of matter as applied to analyzing unit operations systems.

courses.name: Process Thermodynamics 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces fundamental principles of classical thermodynamics. Applications to modeling and analysis of physical and chemical processes undergoing change.

courses.name: Fluid and Solid Operations 3 Credits
courses.description: Characteristics of laminar and turbulent flow, mechanical energy balance, flow through packed beds and fluidization of solids, design of pumping systems and piping networks and metering of fluids.

courses.name: Energy Transfer Operations 3 Credits
courses.description: Steady state conduction in solids and heterogeneous materials, transient conduction, convection heat transfer, heat transfer during boiling and condensation, radiation heat transfer, design of heat-transfer equipment and heat exchange networks.

courses.name: Elementary Transport Phenomena 3 Credits
courses.description: Flux law and conservation equations of mass, energy and momentum; steady and unsteady states as applied to physical and chemical processing; macroscopic and microscopic analysis.

courses.name: Phase and Chemical Equilibria 3 Credits
courses.description: Application of thermodynamic principles to systems of variable composition, including the study of phase and chemical equilibria.

courses.name: Fluid and Energy Transfer Operations Laboratory 2 Credits
courses.description: Laboratory work in unit operations involving heat and momentum transfer. (WR)

courses.name: Process Control Theory 3 Credits
courses.description: Analysis and automatic control of process systems in chemical engineering.

courses.name: Process Control Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Laboratory work associated with ECH 4323.

courses.name: Separation and Mass Transfer Operations 3 Credits
courses.description: Theory, design, and evaluation of diffusional and staged mass transfer processes including distillation, absorption and extraction, leaching, and membrane separations. Computer-aided design methods.

courses.name: Separation and Mass Transfer Operations Laboratory 2 Credits
courses.description: Laboratory work in unit operations involving mass transfer. (WR)

courses.name: Chemical Kinetics and Reactor Design 4 Credits
courses.description: Homogeneous and heterogeneous reaction kinetic modeling and data analysis. Analysis and design of ideal batch, mixed, plug and recycle reactors. Heterogeneous catalysis and reactor design.

courses.name: Heterogeneous Chemical Kinetics Reactor Design 2 Credits
courses.description: Theories of catalytic reactions of adsorbed species at solid surfaces, development or rate expressions with heat and mass transport properties through porous catalyst materials for design of heterogeneous chemical reactors.

courses.name: Process Economics and Optimization 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the principles of process economics including specifications and costing of equipment, operations costing and economic evaluation of processes.

courses.name: Process Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Preliminary design of convention chemical processes including process specifications, sitting and layout, equipment sizing, utility and manpower needs, safety and hazard analysis, environmental considerations and economic evaluation. Planning techniques for detailed engineering, construction and startup.

courses.name: Chemical Process Safety 3 Credits
courses.description: Laboratory and process safety analysis which emphasizes prevention and mitigation. Application of chemical engineering principles to assessing hazards and risk.

courses.name: Materials of Chemical Engineering 2 Credits
courses.description: Relations between microscopic structure and macroscopic mechanical, thermal and electrical properties of organic and inorganic solids. Engineering applications, including corrosion.

courses.name: Processing of Complex Fluids 3 Credits
courses.description: Principles involved in quantitative adoption of chemical engineering unit operations and unit processes for the analysis and design of systems involving complex fluids.

courses.name: Special Problems in Chemical Engineering 1-6 Credits
courses.description: Study of chemical engineering problems as identified by the student and instructor.

courses.name: Integrated Product and Process Design 1 3 Credits
courses.description: The first part of a two-course sequence in which multidisciplinary teams of engineering and business students partner with industry sponsors to design and build authentic product and processes, on time and within budget. Working closely with industry liaison engineers and a faculty coach, students gain practical experience in teamwork and communication, problem solving and engineering design, and develop leadership, management and people skills.

courses.name: Integrated Product and Process Design 2 3 Credits
courses.description: The second part of a two-course sequence in which multidisciplinary teams of engineering and business students partner with industry sponsors to design and build authentic product and processes, on time and within budget. Working closely with industry liaison engineers and a faculty coach, students gain practical experience in teamwork and communication, problem solving and engineering design, and develop leadership, management and people skills.

courses.name: Practical Work in Chemical Engineering 1-5 Credits
courses.description: One term industrial employment, including extra work according a pre-approved outline. Practical engineering work under industrial supervision as set forth in college regulations.

courses.name: Internship Work Experience 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Practical internship work experience under approved industrial supervision, as set forth in college regulations. A maximum of 3 credits from ECH 4948 and ECH 4949 can count towards the Chemical Engineering degree. For example, a student who has earned 1 credit of ECH 4949, can only have 2 credits of ECH 4948 count towards the degree.

courses.name: Co-op Work Experience 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Practical co-op work experience under approved industrial supervision, as set forth in college regulations. A maximum of 3 credits from ECH 4949 and ECH 4948 can count towards the Chemical Engineering degree. For example, a student who has earned 1 credit of ECH 4948, can only have 2 credits of ECH 4949 count towards the degree.

courses.name: Special Topics in Freshman Engineering 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Laboratory, lectures or conferences cover selected topics in engineering.

courses.name: Engineering Directed Independent Research 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research with a faculty advisor or postdoctoral or graduate student mentor. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Prep for Success 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Freshman success course that includes academic preparation in calculus, chemistry, student success, and technical communications.

courses.name: Chemistry for the Liberal Arts 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides non-science majors with a basic understanding of the substances and chemical transformations central to our lives. Introduces chemical concepts and principles help the student better understand the role and impact of modern chemistry in society. (P)

courses.name: Introduction to Chemistry 2 Credits
courses.description: Introductory readiness course in general chemistry for those with weak yet satisfactory backgrounds in high school chemistry and algebra. (P)

courses.name: Basic Chemistry Concepts and Applications 1 3 Credits
courses.description: The first half of the CHM 1030/CHM 1031 sequence. A terminal sequence for non-science students that presents chemistry from a medical/nursing perspective. Topics in inorganic chemistry and properties of both ionic and covalent compounds. (P)

courses.name: Basic Chemistry Concepts and Applications 2 3 Credits
courses.description: The second half of CHM 1030/CHM 1031 sequence. Topics in organic chemistry and biochemistry. (P)

courses.name: General Chemistry 1 3 Credits
courses.description: The first semester of the CHM 2045/CHM 2045L and CHM 2046/CHM 2046L sequence. Stoichiometry, atomic and molecular structure, the states of matter, reaction rates and equilibria. A minimum grade of C is required to progress to CHM 2046. (P)

courses.name: General Chemistry 1 Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Laboratory experiments designed to reflect the topics presented in CHM 2045. (P)

courses.name: General Chemistry 2 3 Credits
courses.description: The second semester of the CHM 2045/CHM 2045L and CHM 2046/CHM 2046L sequence. Students who completed CHM 2045 or equivalent at another institution should consult a chemistry advisor before registering for this course. Acids and bases, additional aspects of chemical equilibria, thermodynamics, electrochemistry, complex ions and descriptive chemistry. (P)

courses.name: General Chemistry 2 Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Laboratory experiments designed to reflect the topics presented in CHM 2046. (P)

courses.name: One-Semester General Chemistry 4 Credits
courses.description: Designed for entering (not transfer) students who wish to move more quickly into advanced coursework. Electronic structure and bonding, gases, liquids, solids, kinetics, equilibria, acids and bases, thermodynamics, oxidation-reduction, metals and non-metals.

courses.name: One-Semester General Chemistry Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Laboratory experiments designed to accompany CHM 2047.

courses.name: Honors General Chemistry 1 for Majors 3 Credits
courses.description: First semester of the CHM 2050/2045L and CHM 2051/2046L sequence. Stoichiometry, atomic and molecular structure, the states of matter, reaction rates and equilibria.

courses.name: Honors General Chemistry 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Second semester of the CHM 2045/CHM 2045L and CHM 2051/CHM 2046L sequence. Open to students with superior performance in CHM 2045 or its equivalent. Acids and bases, additional aspects of chemical equilibria, thermodynamics, electrochemistry, complex ions, descriptive chemistry and instructor-chosen topics. (P)

courses.name: Accelerated General Chemistry Laboratory 2 Credits
courses.description: A cross-disciplinary, inquiry-based curriculum that focuses on major themes and concepts in chemistry with an emphasis on their application in modern, quantitative life sciences research. Equivalent to CHM 2045L and CHM 2046L or CHM 2047L.

courses.name: Chemistry for Engineers 1 3 Credits
courses.description: The first semester of the CHM 2095/CHM 2096 sequence. Topics include stoichiometry, energy and thermodynamics, atomic and molecular structure, the states of matter, reaction rates and introduces chemical equilibria. All topics are taught in an engineering case-study context. (P)

courses.name: Chemistry Lab 1 for Engineers 1 Credit
courses.description: Laboratory experiments designed to complement CHM 2095.

courses.name: Chemistry for Engineers 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Second in a two-semester sequence. Topics include chemical equilibria, acid-base and solubility equilibria, entropy, free energy, electrochemical devices, solution dynamics, and descriptive inorganic and organic chemistry. All topics taught in an engineering case-study context. (P)

courses.name: Chemistry Lab 2 for Engineers 1 Credit
courses.description: Laboratory experiments designed to complement CHM 2096.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Organic Chemistry 3 Credits
courses.description: An elementary course embracing the more important aspects of organic chemistry. Intended for students in programs requiring only one semester of organic chemistry. Not intended for pre-med, pre-dentistry or pre-vet students.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Organic Chemistry Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Organic laboratory experiments to accompany CHM 2200.

courses.name: Organic Chemistry 1 3 Credits
courses.description: The first half of the CHM 2210/CHM 2211 sequence intended for majors and preprofessional students. A study of the structures, syntheses and reactions of organic compounds.

courses.name: Organic Chemistry 2 3 Credits
courses.description: The second half of the CHM 2210/CHM 2211 sequence intended for majors and preprofessional students. A study of the structures, syntheses and reactions of organic compounds.

courses.name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory 2 Credits
courses.description: Organic laboratory experiments designed to accompany CHM 2210/CHM 2211 or CHM 3217/CHM 3218.

courses.name: Organic Chemistry 1 for Majors 3 Credits
courses.description: First half of the CHM 2212/CHM 2213 sequence for chemistry majors. A study of structures,  synthesis, and reactions of organic compounds,  with emphasis on mechanism and spectroscopy.

courses.name: Organic Chemistry 2 for Majors 3 Credits
courses.description: Second half of the CHM 2212/CHM 2213 sequence is for chemistry majors. Study of structures,  synthesis, and reactions of organic compounds, with emphasis on mechanism and spectroscopy.

courses.name: Introduction to Analytical Chemistry 3 Credits
courses.description: Principles involved in quantitative analysis. Topics include acid-base equilibria and titrations, precipitation and complex formation, oxidation reduction and statistical treatment of data. Introduces spectrochemical and electrochemical methods of analysis and chemical separations.

courses.name: Analytical Chemistry Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Laboratory experiments designed to accompany CHM 3120.

courses.name: Organic Chemistry/Biochemistry 1 4 Credits
courses.description: A rigorous, one-semester overview of the structure, properties and reactions of organic compounds. This is the first half of a two-semester sequence in biochemistry. Students are expected to take CHM 3218 after completing CHM 3217.

courses.name: Organic Chemistry/Biochemistry 2 4 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the basic concepts of biochemistry and molecular biology from the structural and mechanistic perspective of organic chemistry.

courses.name: Physical Chemistry for the Biosciences 3 Credits
courses.description: Thermodynamics, electrochemistry, transport, chemical kinetics and molecular structure with emphasis on biological systems.

courses.name: Inorganic Chemistry 3 Credits
courses.description: Basic theoretical concepts involved in inorganic chemistry. Periodic trends, chemical bonding, structure and reactivity.

courses.name: Inorganic Chemistry Laboratory 2 Credits
courses.description: Synthesis and characterization of inorganic and organometallic compounds.

courses.name: Advanced Biochemistry and Chemical Biology 4 Credits
courses.description: Secondary metabolism and biosynthetic pathways, bioinorganic chemistry, protein folding and trafficking, cellular signaling, replication and translation from a chemist's perspective. Applications in bioanalytical chemistry and in molecular and cell biology.

courses.name: Instrumental Analysis 3 Credits
courses.description: Concepts of instrumentation for chemical analysis. In-depth examination of spectrochemical and electrochemical methods and chemical separations.

courses.name: Instrumental Analysis Laboratory 2 Credits
courses.description: Laboratory experiments designed to accompany CHM 4130.

courses.name: Electronics and Instrumentation 3 Credits
courses.description: Principles of operation of instrumentation, optimization of instrumental conditions, and interpretation of instrumental data for qualitative and quantitative analysis. Application of electronic principles necessary to code for automated electronic measurements in chemical research.

courses.name: Organic Spectroscopy 2 Credits
courses.description: Characterization and identification of organic compounds by spectral methods including IR, UV, NMR and mass spectrometry.

courses.name: The Organic Chemistry of Polymers 2 Credits
courses.description: Classification of polymerization types and mechanisms from a mechanistic/organic point of view. The structure of synthetic and natural polymers and polyelectrolytes. Reactions of polymers and practical synthetic methods of polymer preparation.

courses.name: Laboratory in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology 2 Credits
courses.description: Introduces experimental techniques in biochemistry, especially those used in DNA isolation and manipulation, protein purification and enzyme kinetic studies.

courses.name: Chemical Aspects of Cellular Control 3 Credits
courses.description: Control of information, materials and energy within cellular systems. Examples taken from the biochemistry of plants, bacteria and higher organisms.

courses.name: Introduction to Enzyme Mechanism 3 Credits
courses.description: Principles of enzyme structure, isolation and purification and principles of the physical chemistry of enzyme/substrate interactions. Overview of concepts of biological catalysis, including transition state theory, descriptions and examples of mechanisms of biochemical catalysis, survey of co-factors, and catalytic antibodies, ribozyme structure and catalysis.

courses.name: Physical Chemistry: Thermodynamics and Kinetics 4 Credits
courses.description: Gas laws, kinetic theory, classical and statistical thermodynamics and applications to solutions, phase equilibria, chemical equilibria and electrochemistry.

courses.name: Physical Chemistry Laboratory 2 Credits
courses.description: A series of laboratory experiments designed to accompany CHM 4411.

courses.name: Physical Chemistry: Chemical Bonding and Spectroscopy 4 Credits
courses.description: Introduces quantum theory, atomic and molecular structure, chemical bonding and spectra, chemical reaction rate laws and mechanisms, and statistical and collision theories of reaction rates.

courses.name: Biophysical Chemistry Laboratory 2 Credits
courses.description: Laboratory experiments to demonstrate basic concepts of the physical chemistry of biological systems.

courses.name: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces advanced concepts of modern inorganic chemistry. Major themes include application of group theory to structure and bonding, molecular orbital treatment of reactivity, fundamental organometallic chemistry and introduces vibrational and electronic spectroscopy.

courses.name: Bioinorganic Chemistry 3 Credits
courses.description: From an inorganic perspective, introduces the structure and function of a variety of metalloproteins and metalloenzymes, concentrating on systems containing transition metals. Emphasizes the role that metal ion(s) play in the function of the biomolecules.

courses.name: Individual Problems 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Double registration permitted. An assigned reading program or development of an assigned experimental problem.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Laboratory or literature investigations of chemical problems of current interest.

courses.name: Special Topics 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Special Topics

courses.name: Supervised Teaching 1-2 Credits
courses.description: Supervised teaching, usually at the general chemistry level. Required is a superior record at UF in the course in which the student will assist and evidence that the student's own progress will not be delayed.

courses.name: Interdisciplinary Junior Honors 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Special topics restricted to those in the university-wide honors program. (WR)

courses.name: Secrets of Alchemy 3 Credits
courses.description: Multi-disciplinary exploration of the history of alchemy, the precursor to modern chemistry. Studies the multi-dimensional relationships with philosophy, religion, and the natural sciences from antiquity to the modern era. Recreation of alchemical recipes in the teaching lab enhance the course content.

courses.name: Cross-Disciplinary Laboratory 1 3 Credits
courses.description: First course in a two-semester inquiry-based laboratory focusing on major themes and concepts in biology, chemistry and physics with an emphasis on their integrated applications in modern, quantitative research. Satisfies course requirements for BSC 2010L, CHM 2045L and PHY 2053L.

courses.name: Cross-Disciplinary Laboratory 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Second course in a two-semester inquiry-based laboratory focusing on major themes and concepts in biology, chemistry and physics with an emphasis on their integrated applications in modern, quantitative research. Satisfies course requirements for BSC 2011L, CHM 2046L and PHY 2054L.

courses.name: Research Methods 3 Credits
courses.description: The tools scientists use to solve scientific problems, including use of experiments to answer scientific questions, design of experiments to reduce systematic and random errors, use of statistics to interpret experimental results and deal with sampling errors, mathematical modeling of scientific phenomena and oral presentation of scientific work.

courses.name: Beginning Chinese 1 5 Credits
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing. Materials are designed for learners with no prior exposure to the language. Those with native background or education for four years or more in a Chinese speaking country must take a placement test before enrolling in any Chinese language class.

courses.name: Beginning Chinese 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Intermediate Chinese 1 5 Credits
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Intermediate Chinese 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Chinese for Heritage Learners 1 4 Credits
courses.description: For those with significant bilingual speaking and listening backgrounds. Emphasis is on recognition of the characters and writing, and pronunciation and speaking.

courses.name: Chinese for Heritage Learners 2 4 Credits
courses.description: To consolidate the foundation built in Chinese for Heritage Learners 1, to expand vocabulary and to introduce more complex grammatical structures. Emphasis is on reading and writing. Those who successfully complete CHI 2341 are eligible for CHI 3410.

courses.name: Chinese Calligraphy 3 Credits
courses.description: Introductory study of the origin, composition, development, variations and aesthetic styles of Chinese characters with laboratory sessions for appreciating and practicing calligraphic skills. (H and N)

courses.name: Advanced Chinese 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures. (S and N)

courses.name: Advanced Chinese 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures. (S and N)

courses.name: Business Chinese 3 Credits
courses.description: Development of language skills and protocol issues used in Chinese business environments. Acquire vocabulary, phrases, and sentence patterns essential for business transactions and develop oral presentations, business cards, and resumes.

courses.name: Fourth Year Chinese 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces and analyzes the documentary prose style used in Chinese newspapers and media. By studying a variety of short texts students develop skill in listening, speaking, reading and writing about issues commonly encountered in Chinese newspaper editorials and in television news programs, debate roundtables, or TV documentaries.

courses.name: Fourth Year Chinese 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Solidifies and improves students' knowledge of advanced Chinese through literature as a continuation of CHI 4050. Emphasizes formulating strategies to learn the difference between written language and spoken language and approaches meaningful writing with an eye toward careful examination of authentic writing samples.

courses.name: Structure of Chinese 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to phonological, grammatical and discourse structures of Mandarin Chinese, with an emphasis on its contrastive aspects with the English language. (S and N)

courses.name: Individual Study 1-5 Credits
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course. Includes all individual study courses offered by the Chinese section.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Language or Linguistics 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Language or Linguistics. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Language or Linguistics.

courses.name: Special Topics in Chinese Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in Chinese studies.

courses.name: Senior Thesis 3 Credits
courses.description: Select a Chinese faculty member to act as director for an independent research project that culminates in the preparation of an honors thesis.

courses.name: Internship 1-6 Credits
courses.description: Gain practical experience that enhances classroom learning.

courses.name: Chinese Literary Heritage 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces pre-modern Chinese literature in translation. Topics chosen from classical poetry, short stories, novels and drama. Emphasis is on the interplay between orthodox values and the folk tradition. All readings in English. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Pre-Modern Chinese Fiction in Translation 3 Credits
courses.description: Pre-modern Chinese narrative from its philosophical and historical origins to the fiction at the turn of the 20th century. Emphasizes the 16th and 17th centuries when Chinese vernacular fiction flourished. (H and N)

courses.name: Modern Chinese Fiction in Translation 3 Credits
courses.description: A survey of modern Chinese fiction in translation. Samples are from the early 20th century through the contemporary era and include writers of the early Republic, the P.R.C. and Taiwan. Focus is on fiction as a vehicle for social change. All readings in English. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Tales of the Strange in Medieval Chinese Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces traditional Chinese tales of the strange and primary sources that contributed to their development. Also covers cross-cultural literary theories of the fantastic and uncanny; interdisciplinary literary, discourse, and narrative theories; and three common medieval Chinese worldviews.

courses.name: Chinese Film and Media 4 Credits
courses.description: Examination of Chinese cinema and other forms of media such as television, music and print culture in a broad sociopolitical and historical context. An interdisciplinary approach with a diversity of readings and multimedia tools incorporated into discussions.

courses.name: Chinese Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to Chinese culture with emphasis on its philosophy, language, society, art and people as a whole. All readings in English. (H and N)

courses.name: Chinese Martial Arts Fiction 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of Chinese martial arts fiction from earliest times to the present day. Discusses the literary pleasure of watching violence, the relationship between violence and the law, gender ambiguity of woman warriors, the imperial and (trans)national order of martial arts narrative, and the moral and physical economy of vengeance.

courses.name: Taoism and Chinese Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to the general history and culture of Taoism in ancient and modern China: its thoughts, belief systems, cultural influences, practices and rituals.

courses.name: Hong Kong, Taiwan, and the New Global Cinema 4 Credits
courses.description: Overview of Sinophone film in Hong Kong, Taiwan, and the broader sphere of Chinese diaspora. Addresses film history, culture, and aesthetics.

courses.name: Dream of the Red Chamber 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the intellectual and social life of traditional China through the 18th century epic novel, Story of the Stone. Also studies interpretive theories of the novel, both Chinese and Western. All readings are in English. (H and N OR S and N) (WR)

courses.name: Journey to the West 3 Credits
courses.description: Exploration of traditional Chinese religious culture, cultural history and literacy expression through a 100 chapter novel known as Journey to the West, or Monkey.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in English Translation 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in English Translation. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in English Translation.

courses.name: Classical Chinese 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to classical Chinese prose with texts drawn mainly from early histories and philosophical writings (500 BC - AD 100). Emphasis on reading comprehension, grammar analysis and translation.

courses.name: Classical Chinese 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of CHW 4120 focusing on classical Chinese prose with texts drawn from early historical and philosophical texts to belles-lettres of the medieval era and later periods. Emphasis on reading comprehension, grammar analysis, and translation.

courses.name: Readings in Chinese Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces advanced language students to a sampling of Chinese writers. Materials chosen from classic or modern/contemporary Chinese literature rotated across semesters. All readings in Chinese. (H and N)

courses.name: Newspaper Chinese 3 Credits
courses.description: Development of ability to understand and translate the documentary prose style used in Chinese newspapers and academic journals. Introduces literary function words and grammar structures, with comparison to the vernacular. Most readings in the simplified character form used in the PRC; all readings in Chinese. Applications for research on modern China.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Target Language 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Civil Engineering Estimating 3 Credits
courses.description: Design of systems for estimating and cost control of human-machine productivity for civil engineering projects. Analysis of cost factors required for optimization of engineering-investment efficiency.

courses.name: Construction Equipment, Methods and Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Theory and practice of construction operations, equipment utilization and construction methods. Analysis of costs. Optimizing crew and equipment. Heavy equipment costs. New emphasis on planning and executing a construction project.

courses.name: Construction Engineering Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Simulation of comprehensive construction project involving all phases of planning, scheduling and control from start to finish, which involves making major decisions. Oral presentation required at the end of course.

courses.name: Soil Mechanics 4 Credits
courses.description: Physical properties of soils, compaction, flow of water through soil, distribution of stress within soil and consolidation. Laboratory.

courses.name: Geotechnical Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Subsurface exploration settlements analysis, slope stability, earth pressure and an introduction to foundation design.

courses.name: Retaining Wall and Embankment Design 3 Credits
courses.description: The application of soil mechanics to the design and analysis of various types of retaining structures and earthen embankments.

courses.name: Foundation Engineering Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Comprehensive design of geotechnical system, focusing on design of complete project and utilizing CAD programs. Designs, drawings and oral presentations through group effort.

courses.name: Mechanics of Engineering Structures 4 Credits
courses.description: Introduces structural load, equilibrium, shear and bending moment diagrams, structural analysis software, classical methods for displacement determination, method of consistent deformations, slope deflection method, moment distribution method.

courses.name: Analysis and Design in Steel 3 Credits
courses.description: Elastic and plastic theories of design, design of members subjected to tension, compression, flexure and torsion. Design of connections and rigid frames.

courses.name: Analysis and Design in Reinforced Concrete 3 Credits
courses.description: Ultimate strength analysis and design of reinforced beams and columns, working stress design for flexure, design of footings and retaining walls.

courses.name: Introduction to Civil Engineering 1 Credit
courses.description: Introduces the broad field of civil engineering.

courses.name: Computer Methods in Civil Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Review of computer programming. Numerical methods as applied to civil engineering problems and civil engineering software.

courses.name: Civil Engineering Materials 4 Credits
courses.description: Studies the principal materials used for engineering purposes with special attention to mechanical properties and their importance to the engineer. Hands-on experience in testing of civil engineering materials.

courses.name: Introduction to Sustainable Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of the principles of sustainability as they relate to civil and environmental engineering issues. Discussions and projects facilitate a basic understanding of the production-consumption model and life cycle assessment.

courses.name: Experimentation and Instrumentation in Civil Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Fundamentals and applications of measuring systems commonly used in civil engineering. Topics include recording techniques, strain, force, displacement, flow, temperature, humidity and PH measurements.

courses.name: Civil Engineering Cost Analysis 3 Credits
courses.description: Analysis of civil engineering proposals, utilizing time-value and related factors. Feasibility and optimum life comparisons. Utility rate derivation, utility/cost method.

courses.name: Civil Engineering Practice 4 Credits
courses.description: Fundamentals of civil engineering professional practice: project management, construction delivery processes, business concepts, public policy, administration, diversity and equity issues in civil engineering, and leadership.

courses.name: Machine Learning Applications in Civil Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Leverage machine learning state-of-the-art techniques and tools to solve Civil Engineering problems. Apply fundamentals of data analytics and machine learning techniques to real-world tasks and gain essential knowledge and programming skills (using R) in data preprocessing, feature selection, model comparison, hyperparameter tuning, and machine-learning interpretation. Includes case studies and applications for hands-on experience.

courses.name: Applied Data Science in Civil and Environmental Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the workflows of data science applications, covering the state-of-art techniques in data acquisition, data processing and management, analytics and modeling, and visualization. Critical application of data science concepts and techniques in complex socioeconomic and environmental contexts. Basics of problem formulation and major ethical considerations of applying data science in practice.

courses.name: Pavement Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Function and material requirements of different elements of flexible and rigid pavement systems; characterization of soils, materials, traffic loads, and environment for design; flexible and rigid pavement design; new developments.

courses.name: Public Works Engineering and Management Practices 3 Credits
courses.description: Public works profession, organization, administration, and management of operating divisions with emphasis on role of engineer.

courses.name: Transportation-Water-Materials Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Simulation of a design project experience through the completion and presentation of a comprehensive roadway project design. Students work in multi-disciplinary groups to complete a system design that includes traffic, materials, hydrologic and geotechnical considerations.

courses.name: Special Problems in Civil Engineering 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Selected problems or projects in the student's major field of engineering study.

courses.name: Structures-Geotechnical-Construction Comprehensive System Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Simulation of a design office experience through the completion and presentation of a comprehensive building design. Students work in multi-disciplinary groups to complete a system design that includes structural, geotechnical and construction management considerations.

courses.name: Co-op Work Experience 1 Credit
courses.description: Co-op work experience in a related field.

courses.name: Hydrodynamics 4 Credits
courses.description: Classification and properties of fluids, hydrostatics, and conservation of mass, momentum and energy in fluid flow. Potential flow, similitude and physical modeling. Laminar and turbulent pipe flow. Introduces turbomachines.

courses.name: Hydraulics 3 Credits
courses.description: Fundamental equations for pipe and open conduit flow. Development of design oriented formulas for pipes and open channels. Introduces hydrology.

courses.name: Urban Stormwater Systems Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Surface-water system design including: time of concentration, peak runoff rate, open-channel flow, gravity storm sewer, culvert, stormwater pumping, filtration systems, hydrograph generation, flood routing, site layout, site grading and permitting.

courses.name: Water Resources Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Study of water resources engineering applications including hydrology and statistics, groundwater, hydraulic machinery, dams and reservoirs, water quality, water quality modeling, water and waste-water treatment and water law and institutions.

courses.name: Engineering Directed Independent Research 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research with a faculty advisor or postdoctoral or graduate student mentor. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Prep for Success 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Freshman success course that includes academic preparation in calculus, chemistry, student success, and technical communications.

courses.name: Water and Wastewater Treatment 3 Credits
courses.description: Design of water and wastewater treatment units.

courses.name: Transportation Engineering 4 Credits
courses.description: Overview of the significance of highway transportation to the social and economic underpinnings of society. Introduces road vehicle performance, geometric design of highways, traffic flow and queuing theory, highway capacity and level of service analysis, traffic control and analysis at signalized intersections, and travel demand and traffic forecasting.

courses.name: Urban Transportation Planning 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of the four-step urban transportation planning process; includes analytical techniques for estimating future travel demand and state-of-the-art approaches.

courses.name: Traffic Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: General review of the fundamentals of traffic engineering with emphasis on field studies and data analysis.

courses.name: Highway Capacity Analysis 3 Credits
courses.description: Provide students with detailed instruction on the procedures defined within the 2010 Highway Capacity Manual (HCM), including analytical chapters for uninterrupted and interrupted flow.

courses.name: Transportation Systems Analysis 3 Credits
courses.description: Systems analysis in transportation planning and engineering, including supply, demand, equilibrium, evaluation and decision analysis.

courses.name: Transportation Facility Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Simulates a comprehensive design of a transportation facility, specifically an arterial-freeway interchange. Utilizes state and national-level design manuals in preparation of standard plans. Applies the theoretical background gained in supporting classes, in areas such as traffic analysis, roadway design, roadway drainage, and pavement design. Some review of this material is provided, as well as introduction of several new concepts. Emphasizes teamwork skills and technical communication skills.

courses.name: Democracy in Theory and Action 3 Credits
courses.description: The birth and evolution of democracy and its revival—democracy in theory and action. The lively dialogue between ancient democracy and modern through a comparative analysis, tackling some of the most pressing issues, such as limits of political participation and free speech, the role of the press/media, and elitism in politics.

courses.name: Gardens to Read and Visit 3 Credits
courses.description: Investigation of gardens as cultural artifacts in literature and art to discover the extent to which gardens are sites of comfort as well as contest, through analysis of the tension between the experience (“to visit”) and the representations (“to read”) of gardens in written and visual forms.

courses.name: Medicine, Science, and the Dawn of Reason 3 Credits
courses.description: This interdisciplinary course invites students to examine the passage of humanity into the era of Reason and the Development of Medical Science and Ethics. As part of the “Nature and Culture” theme, it presents a historical narrative on the passage of humanity from superstition to the era of scientific inquiry

courses.name: The Glory That Was Greece 3 Credits
courses.description: A broad cultural view of the classical Greek world. Greek sources are read in translation. (H and N)

courses.name: The Grandeur That Was Rome 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides a multi-faceted introduction to the culture of Rome. Primary source material is read in translation. (H and N)

courses.name: Classical Antiquity and Sustainability 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines classical antiquity, applying methods and theories of sustainability to explore the impact of the ancient Greeks and Romans on their environment and focusing on the distribution of wealth, social stratification, land use and classical representations of the natural world. (H)

courses.name: Athens in Topography and Monuments 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the topography and monuments of ancient Athens to understand social, historical, economic and religious institutions.

courses.name: Greece Today and Yesterday 3 Credits
courses.description: An interdisciplinary course examining various aspects of ancient and modern Greek life and culture. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Pompeii: An Archaeological Laboratory 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the material remains of a Roman town through an examination of the excavated finds: architecture, wall-paintings and inscriptions. (H and N)

courses.name: Ancient Egypt 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the civilization, culture and monuments of ancient Egypt from prehistoric times to the New Kingdom and Late period. (H and N)

courses.name: Introduction to Hieroglyphics 3 Credits
courses.description: A beginner's course in Egyptian hieroglyphics of the Middle Kingdom. Also designed for students with no former instruction in ancient languages.

courses.name: The Athenian Democracy 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies ancient Athens from c.650-322 BCE, with attention to the political, social and cultural institutions of the democracy, drawing on primary sources and modern theory to explain democratic changes from the archaic to the classical period. (H)

courses.name: Classical Greece 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the social, political and cultural developments of classical Greece from the Persian Wars to the death of Alexander (500-322 BCE). (H)

courses.name: Sport and Recreation in the Ancient World 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines literary and archaeological sources to determine the social, economic, political and cultural importance of games in the ancient Mediterranean world from the time of Homer to the fall of the Roman Empire.

courses.name: Gender and Sexuality in Classical Antiquity 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores perceptions of the masculine and feminine in Ancient Greece and Rome, discussing these stereotypes in their political, social, economic and cultural contexts. (H)

courses.name: Classical Archaeology 3 Credits
courses.description: Illustrated lectures on archaeology, its process of discovery and methods. History of major archaeological exploration in Mediterranean lands compared with extant literary information. (H and N)

courses.name: The Ancient City: Greek Cities 3 Credits
courses.description: Development of the cities of classical Greece from Minoan centers through Byzantium. All aspects of city life are covered: design, building techniques, culture and ideas. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: The Ancient City: Roman Cities 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the cities of the Roman Empire from the founding of Rome to the establishment of Constantinople as the Eastern capital. Emphasis on life in imperial Rome and in European and North African cities. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: AI in Antiquity and Today 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines AI’s origins in ancient Greece and compares it to AI’s acceptance and use in modern society. Pairs discussion of Greek and Roman philosophical and other literary texts on the soul and identity and the boundaries between the natural and artificial with emerging societal issues related to AI, including gender, racism, and slavery.

courses.name: Special Topics in Classical Civilization 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines various aspects of Greek and Roman culture based on the ancient sources, literary and archaeological. (H and N)

courses.name: Individual Study 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Reading, conference and reports. All work in will be in translation.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Classical Civilization 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Classical Civilization. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Classical Civilization.

courses.name: Classics Capstone Seminar 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces scholarly literature on a significant topic in classics. Students will write a research paper showing proper use of primary and secondary sources on the topic.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 1 1-15 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: English Vocabulary from Greek and Latin 3 Credits
courses.description: Historical study of the origins, development and lexicography of English vocabulary with emphasis on elements derived from Greek and Latin. (H)

courses.name: Survey of Roman Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Critical study of the development of Roman literature. Includes readings from Plautus, Cicero, Catullus, Vergil, Ovid and Tacitus, read in translation. (H and N)

courses.name: Greek Drama 3 Credits
courses.description: The classical Greek theater, archaeological remains of important theaters and selected plays of Aeschylus, Sophocles, Euripides, Aristophanes and Menander. All works are read in translation. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Ancient Greek and Roman Epic 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the origin and development of the ancient Greek and Roman epic traditions in the political and social context of the Mediterranean region and Near East from the first millennium BCE through the first century CE. (H)

courses.name: Myths of the Greeks and Romans 3 Credits
courses.description: Development, importance and influence of Graeco-Roman mythology. The main Greek and Latin literary sources are read in translation. (H and N)

courses.name: Religions of the Graeco-Roman World 3 Credits
courses.description: Development, importance and influence of Greek and Roman religion and cult practice. The main literary and epigraphical sources are read in translation. (H and N)

courses.name: Classics and Science Fiction 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies science fiction's origins in Greek and Roman texts to investigate the influence of Greco-Roman literature on modern works of science fiction.

courses.name: Ancient World in Film 4 Credits
courses.description: Examines film and television characterizations of the ancient world and how these accord with known facts through historical and archaeological evidence. Viewing of selected movies along with background readings, lectures, and discussion.

courses.name: Legendary Rome 3 Credits
courses.description: The myths and history associated with Rome's early foundation stories and examination of works of literature about Rome's foundation in their political, social and cultural contexts.

courses.name: Special Topics in Classical Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines various aspects of Greek and Roman literature with focus on special genres (e.g., historiography), periods (e.g., the age of Augustus) or subjects (e.g., slavery). (H)

courses.name: Individual Study 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Reading, conference and reports. All works are read in translation.

courses.name: Greece in the European Context in the 20th Century 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of Greek politics, society and culture in the 20th century.

courses.name: The Literature of Byzantium 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of major genres of Byzantine literature (Patristic literature, oratory, historiography, chronicle, hagiography, hymnography, epic poetry) from the years CE 330-1453. (H) (WR)

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Modern Greek Language and Literature 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Beginning Ancient Greek 1 4 Credits
courses.description: The basics of ancient Greek grammar, morphology, syntax and vocabulary.

courses.name: Beginning Ancient Greek 2 4 Credits
courses.description: The basics of ancient Greek grammar, morphology, syntax and translation, with special attention to irregular verbs.

courses.name: Accelerated Beginning Ancient Greek 1 5 Credits
courses.description: This course and its sequel, GRE 1131, constitute the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language.

courses.name: Accelerated Beginning Ancient Greek 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language.

courses.name: Beginning Modern Greek 1 5 Credits
courses.description: This course and its sequel, GRK 1131, constitute the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language.

courses.name: Beginning Modern Greek 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language.

courses.name: Intermediate Modern Greek 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Readings in modern Greek literature, history and culture. (H and N)

courses.name: Intermediate Modern Greek 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Additional readings in modern Greek literature, history and culture. (H and N)

courses.name: Modern Greek Literature Since 1830 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced study of representative modern Greek prose, poetry and drama in the original from independence (1830) to the present. The course combines the study of the modern Greek language with readings, analysis and discussion of major literary works.

courses.name: Individual Work in Modern Greek 1-4 Credits
courses.description: For advanced students who seek independent work not offered in another course. Must be arranged individually with Greek faculty.

courses.name: Intermediate Greek Prose 3 Credits
courses.description: Readings selected from Attic Greek prose authors designed to aid students in the transition from grammar to connected prose passages.

courses.name: New Testament Greek 3 Credits
courses.description: Reviews grammar and forms. Readings from several books of the New Testament. (H and N)

courses.name: Survey of Greek Literature 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies representative texts from various periods of Greek literature. (H and N)

courses.name: Greek Drama 3 Credits
courses.description: Selected plays of Aeschylus, Sophocles or Euripides.

courses.name: Plato 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies Plato's Meno and Apology. (H and N)

courses.name: Greek Lyric Poetry 3 Credits
courses.description: Translation and analysis of Greek lyric poetry, from Archilochus to Bacchylides. (H and N)

courses.name: Homer and Greek Epic 3 Credits
courses.description: Translation and analysis of selections from Homer's Iliad and Odyssey. (H and N)

courses.name: Greek Historians 3 Credits
courses.description: Translation and analysis of selections of Herodotus, Thucydides, Xenophon and Plutarch. (H and N)

courses.name: Greek Orators 3 Credits
courses.description: Translation and analysis of selections from Lysias, Demosthenes and Isocrates. (H and N)

courses.name: Individual Work 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Reading, conference and reports.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Greek Language and Literature 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Studies in Greek Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced study of a particular author, genre, period or subject.

courses.name: Beginning Latin 2 3 Credits
courses.description: The second part of the sequence for those with little or no background in Latin.

courses.name: Beginning Latin 3 3 Credits
courses.description: The third part of the sequence for students with little background in high-school Latin.

courses.name: Beginning Latin 1 4 Credits
courses.description: The first of a 3-semester sequence for students with little or no background in Latin. Others enrolling in the course will be required to take it for an S/U grade.

courses.name: Accelerated Beginning Latin 1 5 Credits
courses.description: This course and its sequel, LAT 1131, constitute the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language. Students are expected students to have little or no background in Latin. Others enrolling in the course will be required to take it for an S/U grade.

courses.name: Accelerated Beginning Latin 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language.

courses.name: Introduction to Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the important role literature has played in individuals' lives and in society, presenting a range of literary styles and genres, from different countries and historical periods. Special attention paid to development of critical skills of analysis and interpretation. (H)

courses.name: Introduction to Vergil 3 Credits
courses.description: Readings in Vergil's Eclogues, Georgics and/or the Aeneid, with emphasis on introducing Vergilian style, diction poetic techniques and basic genre differences. Review of Latin grammar and syntax. (H)

courses.name: Readings in Latin Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines various aspects of Roman life through readings in Latin literature (with a focus on either special subjects, authors, genres or periods) and a review of Latin grammar. (H)

courses.name: Latin Love Poetry 3 Credits
courses.description: Translation and interpretation of selected poems of Catullus and a thorough review of Latin grammar. (H and N)

courses.name: The Ancient Novel 3 Credits
courses.description: Readings from Petronius, Apuleius or the Historia Apollonii Regis Tyri. (H and N)

courses.name: Roman Drama 3 Credits
courses.description: Translation and analysis of the comedies of Plautus and Terence or the tragedies of Seneca. (H)

courses.name: Roman Elegy and Lyric 3 Credits
courses.description: Selected poems of Catullus, Horace, Tibullus, Propertius or Ovid. (H and N)

courses.name: Roman Satire 3 Credits
courses.description: Translation and analysis of the Roman satirists Horace, Persius, Juvenal or Martial. (H and N)

courses.name: The Roman Historians 3 Credits
courses.description: Readings in Latin from one of the Roman historians: Sallust, Caesar, Livy or Tacitus. (H and N)

courses.name: Medieval Latin 3 Credits
courses.description: Readings from Medieval Latin 350 - 1200 A.D. (H and N)

courses.name: Cicero 3 Credits
courses.description: Essays, speeches and letters of Cicero. (H and N)

courses.name: Vergil and Roman Epic 3 Credits
courses.description: Translation and analysis of selections from Vergil's Aeneid in the light of his epic techniques and the spirit of the Augustan Age. (H and N)

courses.name: Studies in Latin Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: A rotating topics course providing in-depth study of a particular author (e.g., Suetonius), genre (e.g., didactic poetry) or period (e.g., The Silver Age).

courses.name: Special Study in Latin 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Readings, conferences and reports.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Latin Language and Literature 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Personal Growth 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the concepts and techniques in psychology that apply to personal growth and development. All students have the opportunity to participate in research projects or alternative experiences. (S)

courses.name: Abnormal Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: The varieties of disordered experience and conduct, and their contribution to an understanding of more effective personal and social adjustment. Includes the neuroses, psychoses and psychosomatic and conduct disturbances. (S)

courses.name: Introduction to Clinical Research 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Hands-on, faculty-supervised research experience in an area of interest. Introduces current research techniques, including the design and development of clinical research projects and data analysis. Three hours of laboratory work or other research activity (e.g., literature searches, grant preparation, recruitment of study participants, etc.) are required for each credit.

courses.name: Eating Disorders 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of the causes and treatments associated with the full range of recognized eating disorders, including anorexia, bulimia and binge eating disorder, as well as a variety of subclinical forms of problematic eating behaviors and their surrounding factors and issues.

courses.name: Introduction to Clinical Child/Pediatric Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Survey and exploration of the science and practice of clinical child/pediatric psychology, including application of clinical science to problems faced by children and their families. Course also emphasizes assessment and intervention methodologies related to child behavior and health.

courses.name: Introduction to Clinical Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Survey and exploration of contemporary roles of clinical psychologists. Course also emphasizes the integration of science and practice when solving problems of individuals, families and groups.

courses.name: Introduction to Health Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Survey and exploration of the science and practice of clinical health psychology. Course also emphasizes application of the biopsychosocial model of health and illness to health promotion, disease prevention and the treatment and rehabilitation of existing illness and disability.

courses.name: Introduction to Neuropsychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Survey and exploration of the science and practice of clinical neuropsychology. Course also emphasizes discussion of major neuropsychological disorders and the mechanisms underlying higher cognitive function.

courses.name: Clinical and Behavioral Neuroanatomy and Lab 4 Credits
courses.description: Provides students with lecture and laboratory study of the human central nervous system and behaviors. Students will gain knowledge for engaging in basic clinical problem solving by laying a foundation of neurophysiological and neuroanatomical principles.

courses.name: Machine Learning Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers foundational machine learning concepts with an emphasis on applying these concepts to real-world data through programming exercises and assignments using the relevant tools, libraries, and frameworks such as Python, Scikit-Learn, Tensorflow, and more.

courses.name: Theory and Practice of Multimedia Production 3 Credits
courses.description: Combines the traditional media production pipeline and software engineering processes to synthesize an approach geared for the production of works incorporating both artistic and computational elements.

courses.name: Introduction to Digital Arts and Sciences 3 Credits
courses.description: Synergy between art and computing through a programming-oriented exploration of fundamental concepts in multimedia.

courses.name: Interactive Modeling and Animation 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces programming and data structures for interactive two-dimensional multimedia applications. Representing form and transforms in two dimensions, capturing user actions and driving application behavior interactively. Graphical interfaces, image processing, automata and basic artificial intelligence.

courses.name: Introduction to Computer-Aided Animation 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces topics related to computer-aided animation. Rigging for forward and inverse kinematics. Skin weighting. Morph targets. Expression-driven animation, rigid-body and particle simulation.

courses.name: Introduction to Computer-Aided Modeling 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces topics related to computer-aided modeling. Polygonal mesh, NURBS and subdivision surface meshes. Materials and shading networks. Lighting, shadows and rendering.

courses.name: Artificial Intelligence for Computer Games 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the use of A.I. in computer games. Topics include general A.I. knowledge, path finding, movement, tactics and planning, strategy, state machines, learning, dialogue, and emotions.

courses.name: Generating Expressiveness in Intelligent Agents and Avatars 3 Credits
courses.description: Methods to create expressiveness in physical and virtual agents; anthropomorphism and interactivity in human-robot interaction; intent versus intelligence; affect, emotion, and personality; expressiveness in human-like agents versus nonhuman-like agents; uncanny valley effect.

courses.name: Malware Reverse Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to the theory and practice of software reverse engineering applied to the analysis of malicious software (malware). Students will learn techniques of static and dynamic analysis to help identify the full spectrum of the behavior of code that is presented without documentation or source code and to identify possible remediation and avoidance techniques. The course will use a large number of software tools employed by malware and computer forensic analysts.

courses.name: Deep Learning for Computer Graphics 3 Credits
courses.description: This undergraduate course covers deep learning basics, related math and the fundamental theory and application of AI algorithms most popular in the field of computer graphics. Programming assignments will help students develop GPU programming skills while implementing concepts learned in lectures and readings using deep learning APIs on a GPU cluster. Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for colorizing black and white movies is an example.

courses.name: Artificial Intelligence and Heuristics 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces artificial intelligence concepts. Heuristic search, clause form logic, knowledge representation, reasoning and inference, overview of computer vision, planning, natural language, Lisp and Prolog. (M)

courses.name: Natural Language Processing 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to the essential concepts, principles, and techniques of Natural Language Processing (NLP). Practical application and theoretical concepts are examined. Topics include information extraction, language construction, grammars, disambiguation, as well as system modeling, classification, and evaluation.

courses.name: Computational Structures in Computer Graphics 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the major topics in computer graphics: display and output technology, two and three dimensional manipulations; space curves and surfaces, hidden surface removal and shading models.

courses.name: Introduction to Data Science 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the basics of data science including programming for data analytics, file management, relational databases, classification, clustering, and regression; lays the foundation for big data applications ranging from social networks to medical and business informatics.

courses.name: Introduction to Computer Organization 3 Credits
courses.description: Organization of computing systems. Logical basis of computer structure. Machine representation of instructions and data, flow of control, and basic machine instructions. Assembly language programming. (M)

courses.name: Computer Architecture 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces computer architecture and system organization including virtual memory supports cache, pipeline, vector processing, multiprocessor and RISC architecture.

courses.name: Embedded Systems 3 Credits
courses.description: Design of efficient and trustworthy embedded and cyber-physical systems consisting of hardware, software, firmware, sensors, and actuators. Covers fundamental issues related to modeling and specification, design space exploration, hardware-software partitioning, synthesis and compilation, real-time operating systems, and application-specific optimizations targeting area, power, performance, temperature, energy, and security.

courses.name: Introduction to Software Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Topics include software planning, specifications, coding, testing and maintenance. Gain experience in the team approach to large system development. (M)

courses.name: Computer Engineering Design 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Reinforce basic computer engineering skills; design, produce, and report on a computer engineering project, meeting defined specifications and using a structured design methodology and project management.

courses.name: Computer Engineering Design 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Selected capstone design projects involving engineering applications in the various areas of computer engineering.  Must be taken prior to the semester of graduation .

courses.name: Computer and Information Science and Engineering Design 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Preparatory skills are developed for CISE Design 2 for Computer Engineering students. Teams design, produce and report on a software prototype, meeting defined specifications and using a structured design methodology and project management.

courses.name: Software Testing and Verification 3 Credits
courses.description: Concepts, principles and techniques of software testing and verification. Strengths and limitations of black-box and white-box testing methods; techniques for proving the correctness of programs.

courses.name: Human-Computer Interaction 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the major topics in the study, planning and design of the interaction between people and computers. Topics include interface design (principles, theories and guidelines), virtual environments, interactive devices and collaboration.

courses.name: User Experience Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces methods and tools used in User Experience Design (UXD): the early stages of software design focused on meeting user needs. Key concepts include user research, contextual design, design thinking, ideation, iterative design, prototyping, and design documentation. Projects utilize software tools used in the industry.

courses.name: Natural User Interaction 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the design, development and evaluation of Natural User Interaction (NUI) technologies (e.g., non-keyboard and mouse technologies such as touchscreen interaction, gesture interaction, speech interaction, etc.). Discussion of the hardware-to-software NUI pipeline and key considerations when developing NUI software, including existing platforms, toolkits and APIs used to create NUI software.

courses.name: Human-Centered Input Recognition Algorithms 3 Credits
courses.description: Human-centered methods for the design and evaluation of intelligent algorithms for recognizing user input in advanced modalities such as gesture, handwriting, speech, and more. Algorithms and modalities vary; implement and extend an existing algorithm, evaluating it on user input data collected from real people.

courses.name: Computer and Information Science and Engineering Design 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Involves completing a significant CEN-related project. Coordinate with the instructor and a project advisor, prepare a detailed technical report and deliver an oral presentation.

courses.name: Math, Art and Computing 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces interdisciplinary computer science topics. Logic, discrete structures, algorithms and automa. Exploration of topics relating mathematics and computing to art, music and nature. (M)

courses.name: Computers and Modern Society 3 Credits
courses.description: Impact of computers on society. Discussion includes specific cases from many areas, but does not include problem solution. Does not teach how to use the computer but instead gives an understanding of the implications of computers.

courses.name: Legal and Social Issues in Computing 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the history, the myth, the ethics, the law, and the risks of computer-based technology in modern society. Emphasizes critical analysis of hypotheticals and case studies. Published material is supplemented with online references.

courses.name: Introduction to Bioinformatic Algorithms 3 Credits
courses.description: Uses Compeau and Pevzner’s active learning approach from their textbook, Bioinformatics Algorithms, to cover fundamental topics in genomics, machine learning, and biological data science, striking a unique balance between practical challenges in modern biology and fundamental algorithmic ideas.

courses.name: Introduction to Web Development and Design 3 Credits
