courses.name: Economic Development of Latin America 4 Credits
courses.description: A critical assessment of Latin American political economy and economic development. Topics covered include economic history from the colonial period forward; commodity price cycles and balance of payment fluctuations; import substitution industrialization; international indebtedness; trade liberalization; inflation stabilization policies; poverty eradication difficulties.

courses.name: Economic Development 4 Credits
courses.description: Examines different theories of economic growth and development of low-income and middle-income countries. Covers microeconomic and macroeconomic models relevant to understanding development and analyzing various policy proposals. Analyzes history and empirical evidence of global economic growth and development.

courses.name: Africa in the Global Economy 4 Credits
courses.description: Examines the African continent position globally, looking both at the challenges as well as at the options available to African nations to get a fair and better deal in the global economy. Main topics: international trade and global value chairs; WTO rules and negotiations especially with regard to agriculture; aid to Africa; economic reforms, the World Bank and IMF; the debt crisis; migration and African Diaspora.

courses.name: African Economic Development 4 Credits
courses.description: Deals with the most pressing issues facing Sub-Saharan African countries in their quest for socioeconomic development. Although the focus is on contemporary issues and forthcoming challenges, more or less recent historical facts will be reviewed whenever necessary to shed light on the present. Main topics include economic growth, politics and institutions, international trade, agricultural and industrial development, poverty and inequality, access to basic social services, the environment, and gender issues.

courses.name: Special Topics 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Topics vary.

courses.name: Human Growth and Development 3 Credits
courses.description: Life-span survey of human growth and development beginning at conception and ending with death. Provides the opportunity to apply general principles in appropriate educational settings.

courses.name: Child Development for Inclusive Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines psychological theories and research on typical and atypical development and their application in general education classrooms that include children with sensory, mental, emotional, and learning disabilities, as well as gifted and talented children.

courses.name: The Young Adolescent 3 Credits
courses.description: Development of the young adolescent between the ages of ten and fifteen.

courses.name: The Adolescent 3 Credits
courses.description: The special role that the adolescent plays in total development. Emphasis is on the psychological development of the adolescent in the school.

courses.name: Educational Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the application of psychology to the problems of education in a variety of educational settings. Also examines the theoretical and applied aspects of learning, motivation, human development, personality, and measurement and evaluation.

courses.name: Educational Research Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Addresses the Basic Tenets of Educational Research Design, Including Quantitative, Qualitative, and Mixed-Method Approaches to Investigating Educational Phenomena; Learn the Information Needed to Understand the Educational Research Process.

courses.name: Special Topics 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Topics vary.

courses.name: Cognition in Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines cognitive science that explains learning in educational contexts. Specifically, reviewing memory, attention, thinking, and problem solving in classroom or applied settings. Pays special attention to the connections between research and everyday phenomena; designed to help students apply course material to enhance their lives.

courses.name: Measurement and Evaluation in Education 3 Credits
courses.description: The basic principles and methods of measurement, evaluation and test construction.

courses.name: Program Evaluation in Educational Settings 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview to the skills and methods required to assess the effectiveness and impact of educational programs and institutions. First presents program evaluation in the broader setting of the social sciences, followed by evaluation readings and activities tailored specifically to educational settings.

courses.name: Survey Research Methods in Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of the theory and application of survey research methods, with special emphasis on conducting survey research in educational settings. Presents the full process of survey research, including design, implementation, analysis, and data management.

courses.name: Individual Work 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Explore areas of inquiry under faculty guidance in psychological, social, philosophical foundations of education, research, or measurement.

courses.name: Education Undergraduate Research 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Supports mentored scholarship work that enables engaging in the research process of posing questions, collecting and analyzing data, drawing evidence-based conclusions, and communicating the results to others. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application, depending on the topic.

courses.name: Introduction to Education Policy 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces education policy and analysis that explores the history and purpose of education policy, key federal and state policies impacting K12 and higher education, and theoretical and conceptual approaches to policy analysis.

courses.name: Cognitive and Educational Science in AI 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines cognitive and education science concepts that underpin the field of Artificial Intelligence and explores how AI integrates into educational contexts. Enhance conceptual understanding of what makes AI tools work and increase the ability to use those tools in an increasingly AI-rich educational environment. This non-programming course does not require advanced AI or computer science knowledge.

courses.name: Special Topics 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Topics vary.

courses.name: Individual Work 2-4 Credits
courses.description: Topics vary.

courses.name: Career and Life Span Planning 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers presentations, discussions, and experiential activities for making effective life plans and adjustments.

courses.name: Family and Community Involvement in Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines existing models and practices for enhancing family-school-community interaction with emphasis on communication, conflict resolution, and climate-building skill development.

courses.name: Introduction to Trauma and Crisis 3 Credits
courses.description: Develop knowledge about trauma and crisis and increase awareness of the effects of trauma on individuals, families, groups, and communities, and the process of recovery. Also develop knowledge about careers affiliated with assisting survivors of trauma and crisis through their recovery. Students will disclose personal reflections related to the information covered in the course on trauma and crisis.

courses.name: Student Development in a University Setting 2 Credits
courses.description: Examines factors affecting student growth and development in the university setting, current problems facing students, and the use of group processes and leadership training in solving problems and facilitating growth.

courses.name: Alcohol and Drug Abuse 2 Credits
courses.description: General information of effects and problems associated with alcohol and other drug abuse.

courses.name: Stress and Anxiety Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of theories and methods of stress and anxiety control and reduction.

courses.name: Interpersonal Communication Skills 3 Credits
courses.description: Application of basic principles of interpersonal communication with emphasis on the affective dimensions. Gives attention to using basic counseling strategies and psychological techniques as an aid to effective communication.

courses.name: Teaching Diverse Populations 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys educational demographics, foundations of prejudice, elements of culture, political and philosophical roots of diversity and commonality, exceptionalities, and barriers to cultural understanding and diversity in the classroom. A minimum of 30 hours of field experience is required with 15 hours in a diverse setting. See also: EDF 1005 and EME 2040. (D and S)

courses.name: The Young Child 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies growth and development during infancy and early childhood. Laboratory includes observation and participation in nursery school and kindergarten.

courses.name: Introduction to Educational Measurement and Evaluation 2 Credits
courses.description: Surveys principles and methods of educational measurement with an emphasis on evaluation and diagnosis of students in school settings.

courses.name: Education Undergraduate Research 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Supports mentored scholarship work that enables engaging in the research process of posing questions, collecting and analyzing data, drawing evidence-based conclusions, and communicating the results to others. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application, depending on the topic.

courses.name: Intro to Early Childhood Educa 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of the profession of early childhood education for all children from age 3 through grade 3, including legal bases, ethical guidelines, professional expectations, historical and cultural perspectives, organization, programming, developmentally appropriate principles and evidence-based practices. Considerations for diversity guide all aspects of the course.

courses.name: Science of Early Childhood Development and Learning 3 Credits
courses.description: Explore the science of early childhood health, well-being, development, and learning from transdisciplinary, child- and family-centered, and developmental equity perspectives. Uses an eco-bio-developmental model to frame and integrate early childhood principles and practices. Applies the 3Rs (relationships, repetitions, and routines) of early childhood.

courses.name: Language and Literacy Development in Early Childhood 3 Credits
courses.description: Understand the foundations of language and literacy development in young children, from age 3 to grade 3. Includes a focus on the development of oral language, vocabulary, phonological awareness, and word-reading skills.

courses.name: Families as a Context for Early Childhood Development and Learning 3 Credits
courses.description: Learn how the family unit functions within an ecological context for early childhood development and learning. Connections between the child, family, and broader supports for family capacity building will be identified through a developmental equity lens in order to enhance family partnerships.

courses.name: Families, Diversity, and Multicultural Considerations in Early Childhood 3 Credits
courses.description: Role of family and influence of community on development and learning of young children in diverse society.

courses.name: Foundations of EC Systems and Supports 3 Credits
courses.description: Gain foundational knowledge about the transdisciplinary field of early childhood studies through exploring the intersections among health/mental health, early care and education, and family support systems. Emphasizes practices used within and across these systems to support thriving children (birth to 5-years old) and their families.

courses.name: Early Childhood Math, Science, and Technology 6 Credits
courses.description: Techniques and methods for teaching preschool to third grade mathematics and science with appropriate technology integration. Topics include processes of problem solving, reasoning, communication, and inquiry related to instruction and teaching methodology. Appropriate use of technology to amplify the learning experience and develop digital citizens and computational thinkers.

courses.name: Supporting Early Childhood Learning and Development 3 Credits
courses.description: Learn about organizing frameworks that guide practices to support learning and development for children ages birth to five years old. Emphasizes learning and development in the early childhood years with attention to practices, policies, and structural supports to address cultural, language, and ability diverse young children.

courses.name: Supporting Early Childhood Health and Wellbeing 3 Credits
courses.description: Learn how the eco-bio-developmental framework applies to young children’s health and well-being. Identify levels of need related to health and well-being of young children and transdisciplinary coordinated services and supports that are available to support young children’s health and well-being.

courses.name: Practicum in Early Childhood Education 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Field experience in pre-service early childhood education.

courses.name: Early Childhood Science and Social Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Integrated curriculum course for science and social studies from the perspective of constructivist theory. Designed to promote understanding of similarities in ways in which children construct basic science and social studies concepts.

courses.name: Integrated Humanities, Social Studies, and the Arts 3 Credits
courses.description: This integrated curriculum course develops students’ understanding of appropriate curriculum and instruction in social studies, humanities and arts for children preschool through grade 3. Emphasis is on content and methods to meet goals in each of the three areas, as well as meaningful interdisciplinary learning experiences that meet multiple goals.

courses.name: Inclusive Early Childhood Curriculum, Teaching and Assessment I 3 Credits
courses.description: Develop an understanding of appropriate curriculum, teaching, and assessment for young children in preschool through grade 3, across the developmental domains and academic disciplines. The first in a two-course sequence.

courses.name: Inclusive EC Curriculum II 3 Credits
courses.description: This course will develop students’ skills in implementing appropriate curriculum, teaching and assessment for young children in preschool through grade 3, across the developmental domains and academic disciplines. This course is the second in a two-course sequence.

courses.name: Social-Emotional Learning and Behavior Support in Early Childhood 4 Credits
courses.description: Multi-tiered model approach to use of developmentally appropriate and evidence-based practices for promoting children's social-emotional learning, self-responsibility and self-regulation in early childhood programs. Practices build from focus on development of positive relationships, to environmental arrangements, to specific teaching practices, to use of individualized interventions based on functional assessment.

courses.name: Practicum in Early Literacy 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides an opportunity to practice and demonstrate competence in early literacy assessment, instruction, and intervention in an early childhood classroom setting. Apply literacy knowledge and skills with PreK - Grade 3 students. Includes both small-group and whole-class instruction.

courses.name: Internship in Early Childhood 3-6 Credits
courses.description: Students demonstrate application of knowledge and skills acquired throughout their educator preparation program in a supervised early childhood setting.

courses.name: Impact of Disabilities: Home, Community and Workplace 3 Credits
courses.description: How disabilities impact the lives of individuals who have disabling conditions and how the presence of individuals with disabilities enhances diversity in a variety of settings. The impact of disabilities in home, community and work environments. Physical, cognitive and emotional/behavioral disabilities are considered. (D and S)

courses.name: Introduction to Special Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of special education characteristics and definitions of disabilities, the referral process, and service delivery models. Information on the history of, legal basis for, and contemporary issues in special education.

courses.name: Early Childhood Special Education Curriculum 3 Credits
courses.description: Content knowledge in developing and implementing individualized educational programs for the pre-kindergarten child with disabilities, including developmentally appropriate curriculum; methods, interventions strategies, teaming approaches, inclusion, and mainstreaming issues; and approaches and techniques for serving the child and the family.

courses.name: Teachers and Learners in the Inclusive School 3 Credits
courses.description: Characteristics of, identification of and teaching practices for exceptional children in mainstream education. Designed for general education majors, both elementary and secondary.

courses.name: Exceptional People in School and Society 3 Credits
courses.description: Persons with disabilities and people from other diverse groups and the services they need from school and society for success. Consideration of the abilities, causes, and educational implications.

courses.name: Social Perspectives on Disability 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers issues relevant to people with disabilities, their families and others with whom they have contact through community, employment or other settings. Specifically, historical views of people with disabilities and current disability-related issues are examined. Provides a framework for understanding disabilities and disability-related issues within cultural contexts.

courses.name: Assessment in Early Childhood Special Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Use of informal and formal evaluation techniques to develop individualized educational programs for young children with disabilities and individualized family support plans for infants and toddlers with disabilities and their families. An emphasis is the implementation of a multidisciplinary team approach in the assessment of young children.

courses.name: Core Teaching Strategies 3 Credits
courses.description: Helps pre-service teachers develop instruction that provides diverse learners meaningful access to the school curriculum, and assist them in becoming self-regulated learners.

courses.name: Core Classroom Management Strategies 3 Credits
courses.description: Helps pre-service teachers learn classroom management strategies that develop a positive classroom community for students with disabilities and other diverse learners. Learn organizational and management strategies to assist students in managing their behavior.

courses.name: Educational Programming for Infants and Toddlers with Disabilities 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of issues, trends, and best practices in the education of infants and toddlers who are at-risk or disabled (birth to three).

courses.name: Disabilities in Community and Employment 3 Credits
courses.description: In-depth look at aspects of the community and work experiences for adults with disabilities and the individuals who interact with them. Effective practices that foster accepting and supportive environments that ensure successful life outcomes are discussed.

courses.name: Differentiated Instruction 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides pre-service teachers with information and expertise related to instruction that effectively meets the academic needs of all students in inclusive settings.

courses.name: Disabilities: Legal Aspects and Policies 3 Credits
courses.description: Development and enactment of laws and policies designed to protect the rights of persons with disabilities. Examines The Americans with Disabilities Act as well as other significant legislation contributing to policies affecting this population. Examines disability legislation/policy on local, state, national, and international levels.

courses.name: Family Focused Involvement in Early Childhood Special Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Professional skills working with families of young children with disabilities, including understanding of family systems theory, assessing family strengths and needs, developing individual family support plans (IFSP) or individual educational plan (IEP), and enhancing communication and counseling skills. Understanding families from diverse cultures.

courses.name: Multicultural Issues in Early Childhood Special Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Cultural and linguistic diversity among young children with disabilities and their families.

courses.name: Seminar on Disability 3 Credits
courses.description: Identify and analyze current disability issues and literature on the integration of individuals with disabilities in the workplace, post-secondary education, community, and adult life. Students complete a culminating activity investigating a disability topic or applying disability-related knowledge to their academic discipline or anticipated professional practice.

courses.name: Individual Study 1-6 Credits
courses.description: In-depth study of a problem that relates to preparation as a special education teacher. The project must be approved and supervised by department faculty. (WR)

courses.name: Children Youth with Multiple Disabilities 1-3 Credits
Language Acquisition 3 Credits
courses.description: Child language development and use as it influences classroom practice and literacy development. Study of oral language development of children from birth through age eight.

courses.name: Developing Academic Skills 2 Credits
courses.description: Equips students with the tools that enable them to become independent learners with focus on testing and study skills, library research, and organized composition skills; introduces analytical thinking.

courses.name: Psychology in the Schools 3 Credits
courses.description: This course introduces undergraduate students to the practice and profession of school psychology. The foundations of school psychology practice are explored including, assessment and intervention in academic, social, emotional, and behavioral domains. The course emphasizes school psychologists’ promotion of social justice and equity for all students in school settings.

courses.name: Student Teaching in Art Education 4-12 Credits
courses.description: Student-teaching classroom experience in art.

courses.name: Clinical Rotations Across Diverse Elementary School Contexts 2 Credits
courses.description: Engage in clinical rotations across diverse elementary school contexts and participate in seminars with university supervisors. Students will apply, extend, and reflect on the concepts, questions, theories, and models studied in university-based teacher preparation courses.

courses.name: Individual Study 1-3 Credits
courses.description: In-depth study of a problem that relates to teacher preparation. The project must be approved and supervised by a department faculty member.

courses.name: Internship in Elementary Education 1-6 Credits
courses.description: Teacher candidates will gain competence in the planning for, teaching, and assessment of diverse students in school settings. Candidates collaborate with a mentor teacher to practice using various models of co-teaching and a variety of equity pedagogy instructional strategies to support the learning of all students.

courses.name: Integrated Teaching in Elementary Education 2 Credits
courses.description: This field component is an intensive experience completed during the integrated semester in language arts and social studies in the inclusive classrooms.

courses.name: Introduction to Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of education, teaching and schools; a survey of historical, philosophical and social foundations; and an orientation to professional education and the code of ethics. Thirty hours of field experience is required. This is the first of three prerequisite core courses for those who plan to be teachers. EDF 2085 and EME 2040 continue the sequence.

courses.name: International and Comparative Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the political, economic, and cultural contexts of schooling in various parts of the world; introduces theoretical perspectives and comparative methods for interpreting the significance of educational policies and practices in light of globalization.

courses.name: History of Education in the United States 3 Credits
courses.description: Development of American schools and major problems in American education. Emphasizes the relationships among the schools, intellectual movements, and social institutions.

courses.name: Social Foundations of Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Educative effects of social structures and social values and the issues involved in appraising these effects, including the resulting social demands upon schools.

courses.name: Sociological and Historical Foundations of Education 3 Credits
courses.description: A sociological and historical analysis of schooling in American society. Aims of education are examined in relation to social structures, institutions and values; subcultures; social stratification; school law; and democracy and the sociology of the teaching profession.

courses.name: Anti-Black Racism in Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Engage in the active process of identifying and eliminating racism in educational spaces by changing systems, organizational structures, policies and practices, and attitudes by using an antiracist approach. Through antiracist readings and strategies, learn to interrogate and dismantle racism, white supremacy, power, and privilege within educational institutions, classrooms, and teaching practices.

courses.name: Schools on Screen: American Education in Popular Media 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores how the movies and television have portrayed educators and students over time; investigates the ways in which those representations have helped to shape popular impressions of American schooling.

courses.name: Critical Issues in Education 1 Credit
courses.description: Explores the broad field of education in a variety of traditional and nontraditional contexts. Introduces enduring issues in educational systems in the US and examines organizations and career fields focused on addressing these issues.

courses.name: Equity Pedagogy Instructional Strategies 3 Credits
courses.description: An overview of how to plan instruction using Universal Design for Learning and Culturally and Linguistically Sustaining Pedagogy. These foundational approaches to instruction will help future teachers focus on the strengths of learners who come from diverse backgrounds, particularly those with a range of abilities, as they design learning environments to meet students' needs.

courses.name: Equity Pedagogy Foundations 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the foundational concepts of race, class, ability, and sexuality as they impact schools and the children served in them. Students will examine the ways their own history and experiences have shaped their view of schools, schooling, and the children they will teach throughout their careers as educators.

courses.name: Global Issues in K - 12 Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of current global issues and strategies for incorporating them into the K - college curriculum.

courses.name: Studying Equity Pedagogy 3 Credits
courses.description: Teacher candidates will engage in the process of teacher inquiry as they focus on becoming an antiracist teacher and cultivating skills to advocate for themselves, their students, and the profession of teaching.

courses.name: Experiential Learning in Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides an opportunity to engage in experiential learning, as demonstrated by service learning, internship, undergraduate research, study abroad, school or industry liaison projects, or other projects approved by the instructor. Requires 150 hours in an approved experience.

courses.name: Elementary and Secondary Curriculum 3 Credits
courses.description: Purposes, organization, curriculum, and issues of elementary and secondary schools, and roles of educators.

courses.name: Rethinking Discipline and Classroom Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Exploring classroom management as it currently exists in schools, developing the skills to work within this system while simultaneously challenging and disrupting common practices that have adversely affected many school children including Black and Brown students, students whose first language is not English, immigrant students, students with ability differences, LGBTQ students, and students who live in poverty.

courses.name: Equity Pedagogy Applications 3 Credits
courses.description: The application of pedagogical frameworks (Universal Design for Learning and Culturally and Linguistically Sustaining Pedagogy) in the implementation and assessment of instruction in the elementary classroom. Teacher candidates will examine minoritized identities (i.e., race, ability, gender and sexuality, etc.) and the ways these identities intersect with one another to impact how children experience schools and schooling.

courses.name: Individual Study 1-6 Credits
courses.description: Individual Study

courses.name: Education Undergraduate Research 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Supports mentored scholarship work that enables engaging in the research process of posing questions, collecting and analyzing data, drawing evidence-based conclusions, and communicating the results to others. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application, depending on the topic.

courses.name: Special Topics 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Topics vary.

courses.name: Senior Seminar Education Sciences 2 Credits
courses.description: Capstone course in the Education Sciences major for students to reflect on their Experiential Learning placement and the entire degree program to identify professional competencies to address critical issues in education and explore career services as they prepare for jobs and/or graduate school.

courses.name: Introduction to Educational Technology 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces computer productivity (word processing, databases, spreadsheets, painting, drawing, layouts); multimedia (media design, digital video, presentation); communications (internet, Eric); educational software (computer-aided instruction, public domain software); interactive media (linked environments, one-to-many, presentations using electronic tools); reference materials (electronic encyclopedia, atlases, clip art, libraries, internet); instructional applications (techniques); and ethical.

courses.name: Issues and Trends in Educational Technology 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the field of educational technology and its history and allows an exploration of current topics and trends in educational technology research and application.

courses.name: Design and Development of Educational Multimedia 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the principles, methods, and tools for the design and development of multimedia applications, including incorporation of sound, animation, still images, video, and other media in educational technology.

courses.name: Technology-Enhanced Learning Environments 3 Credits
courses.description: Analyzes how people learn in technology-enhanced environments, outlines how the design of technology-enhanced systems can support or undermine learning, and considers critical issues for instructors, designers, and learners in the digital age.

courses.name: Distance Education Research and Practice 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the concepts, technologies, and issues related to the analysis, design, development, implementation, policy-making, and evaluation of distance education courses and programs. Create an online module based on design principles and quality guidelines.

courses.name: Instructional Development for Teaching and Learning 3 Credits
courses.description: Design and develop instructional materials using emerging technologies. Topics include programming, authoring packages, design principles, and development procedures. Development includes web-based and mobile-based authoring and programming activities.

courses.name: Integrating Technology in the Elementary Curriculum 3 Credits
courses.description: Prepares elementary majors to effectively use technology in teaching and learning.

courses.name: Integrating Technology into the Secondary Curriculum 3 Credits
courses.description: Gain experience with curriculum design and course development, which assumes use of technology.

courses.name: Introduction to Instructional Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the processes, methods, and techniques involved with systematic design on instruction. Topics include needs assessment, goal analysis, learner and context analysis, performance objectives, assessment instruments, instructional strategies, development procedures, formative and summative evaluation.

courses.name: Effective Teaching and Classroom Management in Secondary Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Basic strategies for curriculum planning, instruction, classroom organization, and student behavior management.

courses.name: Individual Study 1-4 Credits
courses.description: In-depth study of a problem that relates to preparation as secondary education teachers. The project must be approved and supervised by a department faculty member.

courses.name: Children's Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces genres of children's literature, critical response theory, strategies for critically evaluating books for instructional and aesthetic purposes, and strategies for generating personal, critical and aesthetic responses to literature from diverse and inclusive student populations.

courses.name: Language Arts for Diverse Learners 3 Credits
courses.description: Analysis of content, materials, and methods for teaching language arts in an inclusive elementary school classroom.

courses.name: Language Arts for Diverse Learners in Early Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Focuses on the early developmental levels of writing and different definitions of writing, including writing as composing, writing as spelling/encoding and writing as handwriting. Addresses instructional strategies appropriate for teaching young children to write and explores instructional approaches from different theoretical perspectives.

courses.name: Explorations Teaching Secondary Mathematics and Science 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces prospective teachers to teaching secondary mathematics and science (grades 6-12).

courses.name: Mathematics Content for Elementary Teachers 3 Credits
courses.description: Analysis of the content and methods necessary to effectively teach content from the number, algebra, and geometry strands of mathematics in the inclusive elementary classroom. Provides pre-service teachers with the underlying content and pedagogical content knowledge necessary to effectively teach mathematics.

courses.name: Teaching Mathematics in the Inclusive Elementary School 3 Credits
courses.description: Analyzes content, materials and methods of teaching mathematics in the inclusive elementary classroom. Prepares the future teacher of mathematics for facilitation of instruction to meet the needs of all children, including children with disabilities.

courses.name: Teaching Elementary Mathematics Lab 1 Credit
courses.description: An inquiry-based math lab to accompany MAE4310. Focused on hands-on activities related to foundational concepts in elementary mathematics, with an emphasis on family/community experiences, equity and social justice issues, and relationships to science, technology, engineering, and/or the arts.

courses.name: Student Teaching in Music Education 9-10 Credits
courses.description: Student teaching in selected classrooms of public schools. Special seminars and continuous evaluation of teaching experiences.

courses.name: Teaching Word Identification and Fluency in Elementary Reading 3 Credits
courses.description: Examine theory and practice for teaching reading in the elementary grades, K-6. Emphasis is on the word recognition and fluency strand within reading development. The purpose of this course is to provide students with theoretical and practical knowledge and experiences to build literacy teaching skills for elementary school.

courses.name: Teaching Language and Meaning Construction in Elementary Reading 3 Credits
courses.description: Examine theory and practice for teaching reading in the elementary grades, K-6. Emphasis is on the language and comprehension strand within reading development. The purpose of this course is to provide students with theoretical and practical knowledge and experiences to build literacy teaching skills for elementary school.

courses.name: Teaching Reading in Primary Grades 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies constructivist theory of how children learn and the sociopsycholinguistic theory of language learning. Focuses on how children construct knowledge about and learn to use written language.

courses.name: Emergent Literacy and Beginning Reading Instruction 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides students with knowledge to support emergent literacy in young children and teaching beginning reading in the early primary grades. Designed to provide students with theoretical and practical knowledge and experiences that prepare them to teach in a variety of applicable educational settings.

courses.name: Content Area Literacy 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the fundamental knowledge necessary to teach basic reading skills in the elementary school classroom.

courses.name: Reading in the Intermediate Grades 3 Credits
courses.description: Theory and practice for teaching reading in grades 3-6; develop expertise in literacy strategy and instruction in the classroom. Instruction is always embedded in the context of current educational policies. Become familiar with current research on reading, recent educational policy development, and issues of teaching in a diverse society.

courses.name: Practicum in Reading 2 Credits
courses.description: Demonstrate knowledge and skill in implementing evidence-based instructional practices in reading in a field placement. Students will collect and analyze assessment data, plan instruction based on information from data, implement effective instruction, and monitor students’ progress.

courses.name: Elementary Science Content 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of integrated science content essential for developing K-6 science curriculum. The course includes science-specific pedagogy and translation of the science content knowledge into grade specific activities aligned with the national science content standards for K-12 and the Next Generation Sunshine State Standards.

courses.name: Elementary Science Methods for the Inclusive Classroom 3 Credits
courses.description: Materials and methodology related to teaching the concepts and processes of science. Prepares pre-service teachers to teach science concepts and processes to all children, including those with disabilities.

courses.name: Elementary Science Methods Lab 1 Credit
courses.description: An inquiry-based science lab to accompany SCE4310. Focused on learning lab procedures and safety practices, conducting scientific investigations, and deepening understanding of core science concepts required to teach science to elementary children.

courses.name: Knowing and Learning in Mathematics and Science Teaching 3 Credits
courses.description: Investigates theories of knowing and learning in mathematics and science and implications for teaching secondary mathematics and science. (S)

courses.name: Classroom Interactions in Mathematics and Science Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of principles for teaching middle and secondary school mathematics or science through an exploration of the role of content, pedagogy, curriculum, and technology as they promote learning and impact equity.

courses.name: Project-Based Instruction in Math and Science Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of project-based instruction as an investigative and collaborative teaching approach in mathematics and science education.

courses.name: Informal STEM Practice 3 Credits
courses.description: This course is for students who are interested in learning about informal STEM education, including that practiced at museums, science centers, aquaria, zoos, and parks. The online portion will involve weekly lectures, readings, and discussions. The internship may occur at any approved physical or virtual venue of the student’s choosing.

courses.name: Research Internship in STEM Education 3 Credits
courses.description: This course is designed for advanced undergraduate students who are interested in gaining experience in STEM educational research. The course consists of a seminar and an internship. The seminar will involve weekly readings, learning activities and discussions. The course also includes an internship that is sponsored by a faculty member.

courses.name: Apprenticeship in Secondary Mathematics and Science Teaching 4-6 Credits
courses.description: UFTeach capstone experience which applies previously learned techniques and theoretical perspectives of mathematics or science education within a secondary school classroom setting.

courses.name: Social Studies for Diverse Learners 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies goals, methods and evaluation procedures for social studies curriculum in elementary schools (K - 6).

courses.name: ESOL and Reading for Teachers 3 Credits
courses.description: Develop an understanding of literacy teaching and learning, with a dual focus on native speakers of English and English language learners; focuses on methods and materials used to support the development of proficient and critical adolescent readers in academic content areas.

courses.name: ESOL Foundations: Language and Culture in Classrooms 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines issues of language and culture relevant to school-age learners of English as a Second Language (ESOL).

courses.name: ESOL Curriculum, Methods and Assessment 3 Credits
courses.description: Extends the understanding of ways that language and culture affect second-language learners' participation and learning in elementary classrooms. Create appropriate and challenging curriculum content, materials and assessments to create meaningful and equitable learning environments for native English speakers and second-language learners.

courses.name: ESOL Strategies for Content Area Teachers 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of the issues relevant to English as a Second Language (ESOL) learners and develops the skills to teach ESOL students in content area classes.

courses.name: Computer Engineering Design 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Reinforce basic computer engineering skills; design, produce, and report on a computer engineering project, meeting defined specifications and using a structured design methodology and project management.

courses.name: Computer Engineering Design 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Selected capstone design projects involving engineering applications in the various areas of computer engineering.  Must be taken prior to the semester of graduation .

courses.name: Electronic Circuits 1 4 Credits
courses.description: Fundamentals of electronic circuits and systems. Laboratory.

courses.name: Solid-State Electronic Devices 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the principles of semiconductor electron device operation. Laboratory.

courses.name: Introduction to Machine Learning 4 Credits
courses.description: Covers introductory topics in pattern recognition and machine learning and use of these methods towards a variety of real world applications. The focus of this course is to be introduced to basic machine learning concepts and how to use associated state-of-the-art machine learning tools.

courses.name: Introduction to Biophotonics 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the principles of optics, lasers and biology, the interaction of light with cells and tissues, and various optical imaging, sensing and activation techniques and their applications in biomedicine.

courses.name: Resonant MEMS 3 Credits
courses.description: Fundamentals of resonant micro-electro-mechanical systems (resonant MEMS) and their applications.

courses.name: Bioelectrical Systems 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers the theoretical and quantitative perspective of bioelectrical signals reflecting the activity of the brain, the muscles, and the heart. Examines bases of modeling, measuring, processing and analyzing bioelectrical signals and systems, as well as common clinical applications. Laboratory.

courses.name: Electronic Circuits 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Design-oriented continuation of EEE 3308C; feedback, op amp circuits and applications, digital electronics.

courses.name: VLSI Circuits and Technology 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to VLSI circuit technology and manufacturing. Fabrication, device models, layout, parasitics, and simple gate circuits.

courses.name: Future of Microelectronics Technology 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys state-of-the-art microelectronics technology and prospects for future technologies. Topics include nanoscale MOSFETs, strained Si, high-k gate dielectrics, carbon nanotubes, molecular electronics and single-electron devices.

courses.name: Microelectronic Fabrication Technologies 3 Credits
courses.description: Principles of microelectronic device fabrication. Emphasis on the fundamentals of microfabrication processing and microelectronic device process flows.

courses.name: Radio Frequency Integrated Circuits 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Fundamental RF theory (such as resonant circuits, matching, noise and transmission lines), radio operation and design of key RF circuit blocks (such as amplifiers, mixers, and oscillators).

courses.name: Introduction to RF Circuits 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to radio frequency (RF) fundamentals and related circuits with topics of impedance matching, Smith Chart, s-parameters, waveguides, resonators, filters, active devices, and amplifiers.

courses.name: Mixed Signal IC Testing I 3 Credits
courses.description: Fundamentals of testing IC devices and systems: test specifications, parametric training, measurement accuracy, test hardware, sampling theory, digital signal processing based testing, and calibrations. Circuit analysis and design with analog and mixed-signal systems. Labs on testing passive components, LDOs, Op-amps, DACS/ADCs, Mixed-Signal ICs LabVIEW and the National Instruments Savage Tester.

courses.name: Modern Memory Device Technologies 3 Credits
courses.description: State-of-the-art volatile and nonvolatile memory device technologies and their limitations. Emerging memory device technologies, including those that could be adopted by industry in the next decades due to their potential performance, density, power and cost advantages.

courses.name: Introduction to Nanodevices 3 Credits
courses.description: Physical principles of modern solid-state devices and their applications, quantum mechanics and fundamentals of nanoelectronics.

courses.name: Introduction to Quantum Computing 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces quantum computing concepts and hardware implementations in a self-contained manner and discusses fundamentals of quantum mechanics. Also introduces important concepts of superposition and entanglement, hardware realization of quantum computing technologies, and quantum computing algorithms.

courses.name: Real Time Digital Signal Processing Applications 4 Credits
courses.description: Real world digital signal processing (DSP) tasks are presented and solved in a lab environment that utilizes a Floating Point DSP and a development simulation and hardware emulation tool. Laboratory.

courses.name: Automated Hardware/Software Verification 3 Credits
courses.description: Develop modeling, formal specification, and automated verification skills for analyzing complex hardware and/Or software systems. Hands-on experience with model checking tools.

courses.name: Introduction to Hardware Security and Trust 3 Credits
courses.description: Fundamentals of hardware security and trust for integrated circuits. Cryptographic hardware, invasive and non-invasive attacks, side-channel attacks, physically unclonable functions (PUFs), true random number generation (TRNG), watermarking of Intellectual Property (IP) blocks, FPGA security, counterfeit detection, hardware Trojan detection, and prevention in IP cores and integrated circuits.

courses.name: Acoustics 3 Credits
courses.description: Governing equations for wave theory of sound; Character of plane acoustic waves and 3-D acoustic fields; Sound transmission/reflection at an interface between two media; Waves transmission/attenuation inducts; Low frequency approximations (lumped-element modeling) and transducers; sources of sound.

courses.name: Physical Attacks and Inspection of Electronics 3 Credits
courses.description: Focuses on the physical inspections, physical attacks, reverse engineering, counterfeit detection, etc. of electronics from the device to system level using advanced microscopy, failure analysis techniques combined with image analysis and machine learning. In additions, students will also learn about the associated countermeasures.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Machine Learning 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of machine intelligence and the role of machine learning in a variety of real-world problems. Probability and statistics to handle uncertain data. Topics covered include: learning models from data in both a supervised and unsupervised fashion, linear models and non- linear models for classification, and linear dimensionality reduction.

courses.name: Neural Signals, Systems, and Technology 3 Credits
courses.description: Biophysical principles of neural signaling; characterization of neural circuits and systems; technology design principles for interfacing with biological neural systems; overview of clinical and consumer applications for neurotechnology and artificial intelligence.

courses.name: Introduction to Electrical Engineering 2 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the profession of electrical engineering. Presents career development and enhancement, professional codes of conduct, ethics, entrepreneurship, intellectual property, professional societies. Projects provide hands-on experience with soldering, MATLAB programming, and microcontrollers.

courses.name: Physics of Electrical Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the fundamental physics underlying components and devices and their application to electronics, power, and wireless.

courses.name: Circuits 1 4 Credits
courses.description: Basic analysis of DC and AC electric circuits. Laboratory.

courses.name: Circuits 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Continuous-time signals and linear systems: Fourier series and transforms, frequency, response, Laplace transform and system function, analog filters; emphasis on electrical circuits. Sampling.

courses.name: Introduction to Signals and Systems 4 Credits
courses.description: Continuous-time and discrete-time signal analysis including Fourier series and discrete-time and discrete Fourier transforms; sampling; discrete-time linear system analysis with emphasis on FIR and IIR systems: impulse response, frequency response, and system function; MATLAB-based programming for Signals and Systems.

courses.name: Basic Electric Energy Engineering 4 Credits
courses.description: Analysis and modeling of power system components. Magnetic circuits, energy conservation, transformers, and AC and DC rotating machines. Laboratory.

courses.name: Remote Sensing in Engineering: Science, Sensors and Applications 3 Credits
courses.description: Remote sensing theory, systems and applications using information obtained from the visible/near infrared, thermal infrared and microwave regions of the EM spectrum.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Electromagnetic Fields 3 Credits
courses.description: Transmission lines, vector analysis, electrostatics, magnetostatics, time-varying fields, plane waves.

courses.name: Digital Logic and Computer Systems 4 Credits
courses.description: Overview of logic design, algorithms, computer organization and assembly language programming and computer engineering technology. Laboratory.

courses.name: Programming for Electrical Engineering 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Develops computer skills and the art of writing sound computer programs using examples and exercises relevant to electrical and computer engineering.

courses.name: Data Science for ECE 4 Credits
courses.description: Analysis, processing, simulation, and reasoning of data. Includes data conditioning and plotting, linear algebra, statistical methods, probability, simulation, and experimental design.

courses.name: Electrical Engineering Design 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Teams design, produce, and report on a hardware prototype, meeting defined specifications and using a structured design methodology. Includes project management, hardware prototyping, and project reporting.

courses.name: Power Electronic Circuits 3 Credits
courses.description: Circuit topologies, analysis, design and simulation of electronic circuits such as power supplies, and motor drives.

courses.name: Fundamentals of RF and Power Electronic Devices 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces important semiconductor device technologies for high speed electronics, power electronics, and energy harvesting applications.

courses.name: Power System Analysis 3 Credits
courses.description: Development of power system equivalents by phase network analysis, load flow, symmetrical components, sequence networks, and fault analysis.

courses.name: Power System Protection 3 Credits
courses.description: Power systems protection analytical methodologies and algorithms. Analyzes different methods for equipment and systems protection and discusses wide-area monitoring techniques, which allow real-time operation and control. Introduces cyber-physical security approaches for the smart grid and realizes numerical construction of protection methods considering realistic engineering hypothesis.

courses.name: Smart Grid for Sustainable Energy 3 Credits
courses.description: Survey of power grid operations and markets for students with interest in power systems and/or sustainable energy. Characteristics of traditional and new energy resources; how resources impact the grid; control on many time-scales; how the power grid and power markets of tomorrow will differ from those of today.

courses.name: Computational Photography 3 Credits
courses.description: Fundamentals of computational photography, sensing, imaging and illumination.

courses.name: Applied Magnetics and Magnetic Materials 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces magnetism, magnetic materials, and magnetic devices; offers a balance of theory and application from an applied engineering perspective.

courses.name: RF/Microwave Passive Circuits 3 Credits
courses.description: Radio frequency (RF)/microwave passive components and circuits such as transmission lines, waveguides, couplers, filters, and resonators.

courses.name: Optical Communication Systems 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces electromagnetic waves, dielectric waveguides and fibers, propagation characteristics of fibers, characterization methods, LEDs and laser diodes, photodetector optical receivers and communication systems.

courses.name: Laser Theory and Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the field of semiconductor optoelectronics and the physics of optoelectronic devices including the interaction of photons with electrons and holes in a semiconductor leading to the realization of optoelectronic devices such as photon amplifiers, LEDs, diode lasers, electro-absorption modulators, and detectors, including their design and application-specific characteristics.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Photonics 3 Credits
courses.description: Reviews electromagnetic fields and waves, energy bands in semiconductors, p-n junctions and optical properties of semiconductors. Fundamentals of optical modulators and waveguides and photonic applications.

courses.name: Antenna Systems 3 Credits
courses.description: Electromagnetic field theory and its application to antenna design.

courses.name: Electromagnetic Fields and Applications 3 Credits
courses.description: Rigorously develops the properties of electric and magnetic fields. Maxwell’s Equations form the foundation for understanding the fundamental nature and application-driven aspect of static and dynamic fields and their derivation from scalar and vector potentials. Fields in media is examined along with energy considerations and propagation effects.

courses.name: Lightning 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces lightning discharge processes. Electromagnetics relevant to lightning measurements. Applications for determining lightning charge, current, location and characteristics. Lightning protection.

courses.name: Communication Systems and Components 4 Credits
courses.description: Theory of communication and applications to radio, television, telephone, satellite, cellular telephone, spread spectrum and computer communication systems. Laboratory.

courses.name: Noise in Devices and Communication Systems 3 Credits
courses.description: Origin, characterization and measurement of random noise. Calculation of signal-to-noise ratios and probability of errors in communication systems.

courses.name: Audio Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces audio and sound engineering that includes the underlying theory of acoustics, electronics and signal processing; demonstrates modern audio engineering practice as applied to music, home audio, recording and sound reinforcement.

courses.name: Introduction to Radar 3 Credits
courses.description: Basic principles of cw and pulsed radar; angle, range, and Doppler tracking; accuracy and resolution; signal design.

courses.name: Computer Communications 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the principles and practice of computer networking, emphasizing data communication, and the lower layers of the OSI and TCP/IP protocol architectures.

courses.name: Wireless and Mobile Networks 3 Credits
courses.description: Senior-level study of wireless and mobile networks. Investigates telecommunication architectures and protocols for wireless sensor networks and wireless embedded systems; Wi-Fi and wireless local area networks; mobile ad-hoc networks; next generation cellular systems and satellite networks.

courses.name: State Variable Methods in Linear Systems 3 Credits
courses.description: Development of state-variable approach to linear continuous-time and discrete-time systems with emphasis on the design of feedback control systems.

courses.name: Control of Biological Systems 3 Credits
courses.description: The automatic control principles that govern critical processes in human biology are explored. Through the development of mathematical models of biological systems, the course creates an understanding of metabolic, immunologic, and genetic processes. Applications include the manufacture of vaccines, monoclonal antibodies, cancer treatments, insulin, and many others.

courses.name: Linear Control Systems 4 Credits
courses.description: Theory and design of linear control systems.  Laboratory.

courses.name: Intelligent Machines Design Laboratory 4 Credits
courses.description: Design simulation, fabrication, assembly and testing of intelligent robotic machines. Laboratory.

courses.name: Digital Design 4 Credits
courses.description: Advanced modular logic design, design languages, finite state machines and binary logic. Laboratory.

courses.name: Digital Computer Architecture 4 Credits
courses.description: The use of electronic digital modules to design computers. Includes the organization and operation of computers, hardware/software trade-offs and design of computer interfacing. Laboratory.

courses.name: Reconfigurable Computing 3 Credits
courses.description: Fundamental concepts at advanced undergraduate level in reconfigurable computing based upon advanced technologies in field-programmable logic devices. Topics include general concepts, device architectures, design tools, metrics and kernels, system architectures and application case studies.

courses.name: Advanced Systems Programming 3 Credits
courses.description: Develop a deep understanding of operating system concepts and systems programming fundamentals and gain hands-on experience in systems programming by using Pthreads as well as implementing Linux device drivers and testing/verifying systems code for deadlock and race-freedom.

courses.name: Principles of Computer System Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Broadly introduces the main principles and abstractions for engineering hardware and software systems. Includes in-depth studies of their use on computer systems across a variety of designs, be it an operating system, a client/server application, a database server or a fault-tolerant disk cluster.

courses.name: Microprocessor Applications 4 Credits
courses.description: Experience in the elements of microprocessor-based systems, hardware interfacing and software design for their application. Laboratory.

courses.name: Microprocessor Applications 2 4 Credits
courses.description: Implementation of a Real-Time Operating System on an ARM Cortex M processor to create more robust and complex microprocessor applications. Introduction to IoT applications.

courses.name: Foundations of Digital Signal Processing 3 Credits
courses.description: Analysis and design of digital filters for discrete signal processing, spectral analysis and fast Fourier transform.

courses.name: Programming for Electrical Engineering 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Fundamentals of data structures and algorithms, including lists, queues, stacks, divide-and-conquer, dynamic programming, trees, tables, graphs and recursive techniques. The role of specific data structures in electrical engineering applications.

courses.name: Cross Layered System Security 3 Credits
courses.description: Develop an understanding of the principles of computer security, as it crosses layers of abstraction (application, operating system, hardware, and network). Learn the challenges of building secure computer systems with examples and hands-on assignments. Current research on these challenges will be discussed. Students will review and present conference papers.

courses.name: Individual Problems in Electrical Engineering 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Selected problems or projects in the student's major field of engineering study.

courses.name: Integrated Product and Process Design 1 3 Credits
courses.description: First part of two in which multidisciplinary teams of engineering and business students partner with industry sponsors to design and build authentic products and processes, on time and within budget. Working closely with industry liaison engineers and a faculty coach, students gain practical experience in teamwork and communication, problem solving and engineering design, and develop leadership, management and people skills.

courses.name: Integrated Product and Process Design 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Second part of two in which multidisciplinary teams of engineering and business students partner with industry sponsors to design and build authentic products and processes, on time and within budget. Working closely with industry liaison engineers and a faculty coach, students gain practical experience in teamwork and communication, problem solving and engineering design, and develop leadership, management and people skills.

courses.name: Electrical Engineering Design 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Selected design projects involving engineering applications in the various areas of electrical engineering.  Laboratory.

courses.name: Special Topics in Electrical Engineering 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Special courses covering selected topics in electrical engineering.

courses.name: Practical Work in Electrical and Computer Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: One term industrial employment, including extra work according to a pre-approved outline. Practical engineering work under industrial supervision, as set forth in the Herbert Wertheim College of Engineering regulations.

courses.name: Co-op Work Experience 1 Credit
courses.description: Practical co-op engineering work under approved industrial supervision.

courses.name: Special Topics in Freshman Engineering 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Laboratory, lectures or conferences cover selected topics in engineering.

courses.name: Engineering Directed Independent Research 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research with a faculty advisor or postdoctoral or graduate student mentor. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Prep for Success 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Freshman success course that includes academic preparation in calculus, chemistry, student success, and technical communications.

courses.name: Technical Drawing and Visualization 3 Credits
courses.description: Two- and three-dimensional graphical methods of visualizing and communicating features of projects for construction involving parcel boundaries, topography, drainage, site modeling, site development, structures, buildings and objects using both traditional and computer-aided drafting and design techniques.

courses.name: Problem Solving Using Computer Software 3 Credits
courses.description: Problem-solving introduction and thorough exploration of word processing, spreadsheet management, data analysis, graphical display of data, and multimedia presentations. The problem-solving approach also aids students in their specific majors through software applications requiring major-specific professional communication skills in written, graphical, and presentation forms. (M)

courses.name: Computer Programming for Engineers 2 Credits
courses.description: Computer programming and the use of computers to solve engineering and mathematical problems. Emphasizes applying problem solving skills; directed toward technical careers in fields employing a reasonably high degree of mathematics. The programming language used depends on the demands of the departments in the college. Several languages may be taught each semester, no more than one per section. Those required to learn a specific language must enroll in the correct section. (M)

courses.name: Computer Programming for Engineers Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Optional laboratory for COP 2271. Required for ISE majors. (M)

courses.name: Python Programming for Engineers 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction for those who have little experience in programming and have been looking to obtain hands-on learning experience in the Python programming language. Encourages developing problem solving and computational thinking skills in an engineering field and emphasizes a reasonably high degree of mathematics.

courses.name: C++ Programming for Engineers 3 Credits
courses.description: Introductory course for those who have little experience in programming and have been looking to obtain a hands-on learning experience to the C++ programming language. Developing problem solving and computational thinking skills in an engineering field is encouraged in this course and emphasized with a reasonably high degree of mathematics.

courses.name: Elements of Electrical Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the theory and practice of electrical engineering for those not majoring in electrical engineering. Discusses circuits, machines, electronics and systems.

courses.name: Artificial Intelligence Fundamentals 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of Artificial Intelligence (AI), approaching the concept from its origins to expectations for the future; focuses on various AI technologies, how to build Machine Learning models, and how to apply AI tools to solve real world problems. Some concepts are types of AI and Machine Learning, Hacking and the IoT, AI today and its outlook for the future.

courses.name: Elements of Dynamics 2 Credits
courses.description: Dynamics of particles and rigid bodies for rectilinear translation, curvilinear motion, rotation and plane motion. Also includes principles of work and energy, and impulse and momentum.

courses.name: Special Topics in Freshman Engineering 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Laboratory, lectures or conferences cover selected topics in engineering.

courses.name: Engineering Design & Society 2 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to emphasizing the human-centered design process to address societal challenges. Explore solid modeling, introductory programming, sensors, data acquisition, and 3D printing as maker tools for engineering prototyping. In a team environment, utilize multidisciplinary approaches, project management, and written and oral communication skills to create societal-based designs.

courses.name: Engineering Entrepreneurship 3 Credits
courses.description: Engineering Entrepreneurship introduces engineering students to the concepts and practices of technological entrepreneurial thinking and entrepreneurship. Using lectures, case studies, business plans and student presentations, the course teaches life skills in entrepreneurial thought and action that students can utilize when starting technology companies or executing research and development projects in large companies.

courses.name: Engineering Innovation 3 Credits
courses.description: Engineering Innovation introduces students to the concepts of innovative thinking and innovation practices. Using lectures, case studies, team exercises and guest speakers, the course teaches life skills in innovative thought and action that students can use in careers ranging from starting companies to executing research and development projects in large companies.

courses.name: Engineering Directed Independent Research 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research with a faculty advisor or postdoctoral or graduate student mentor. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Special Topics 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Covers selected, rotating topics in engineering.

courses.name: NSF Fellowship Preparation 1 Credit
courses.description: Overview of fellowship preparation pertaining to intellectual merit and broader impacts.

courses.name: Engineering Internship/Co-op 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Practical Internship/Co-Op Work Experience Under Approved Industrial Supervision.

courses.name: Integrated Product and Process Design 1 3 Credits
courses.description: A two-semester-course sequence in which multidisciplinary teams of engineering students partner with industry sponsors to design and build authentic products and processes—on time and within budget. Working closely with industry liaison engineers and a faculty coach, students gain practical experience in teamwork and communication, problem solving and engineering design, and develop leadership, management and people skills.

courses.name: Integrated Product and Process Design 2 3 Credits
courses.description: A two-semester-course sequence in which multidisciplinary teams of engineering and business students partner with industry sponsors to design and build authentic products and processes—on time and within budget. Working closely with industry liaison engineers and a faculty coach, students gain practical experience in teamwork and communication, problem solving and engineering design, and develop leadership, management and people skills.

courses.name: International Studies in Engineering 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: Introduction to Engineering 1 Credit
courses.description: Introduces the 11 departments that offer undergraduate degrees at UF. Students break into groups of 20, rotating weekly through each department. During these visits, students participate in hands-on experiments to help them make informed decisions about career alternatives.

courses.name: Fundamentals of the New Engineer 1 Credit
courses.description: Fundamentals of the New Engineer introduces students to key attributes of 21st century engineering leaders and innovators. Student learn concepts and practice of engineering leadership and innovation through study of the “Attributes of a New Engineer”; Creativity, Leadership, Integrity, Professional Excellence, and Service to the Global Community.

courses.name: Engineering Ethics and Professionalism 1 Credit
courses.description: Provides an interactive study of ethical theory and the development of professionalism; review case studies of ethical conflicts in engineering practice. Also covers engineering codes of ethics to resolve theoretical situations through application of ethical codes.

courses.name: Engineering Leadership 3 Credits
courses.description: Engineering Leadership introduces engineering graduate students to the concepts, theory and practice of engineering leadership; effective written and oral communications and presentations; engineering leadership characteristics, individual differences and self-awareness; developing and building teams; managing change, conflicts, and crises; and understanding real-world ethics and core values.

courses.name: Divergent Thinking 3 Credits
courses.description: Acquire divergent thinking skills to support the engineering design process. Emphasizes the importance of practices such as observing, questioning, learning, and experimenting; Stresses cultivating an openness to new experiences In order to generate ideas and devise solutions to complex design problems.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Engineering Project Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides a comprehensive understanding of how to plan, optimize, and efficiently manage projects (or tasks) to implement products, services, or developments. Includes building the structure, processes, components, and linkages with a team for successful project delivery within schedule, budget, and quality requirements.

courses.name: Applied Engineering Project Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Applied Engineering Project Management expands on foundational project management practices to include complex as well as new project delivery concepts. Topics include project acquisition; negotiation skills; advanced risk planning and management; program management; project life cycle models and their applicability; and diagnostics and remedies for problem projects.

courses.name: Advanced Engineering Leadership Development 3 Credits
courses.description: Further develops the leadership framework and capabilities; involves a case study-based instructional approach that reviews and applies strategic leadership concepts and knowledge critical to the success of engineering-based companies that operate in a highly uncertain and volatile business environment.

courses.name: Elements of Thermodynamics and Heat Transfer 3 Credits
courses.description: Applications of first and second laws of thermodynamics to closed and open systems. Steady one-dimensional conduction, lumped parameter analysis, convection, radiation. Intended for non-mechanical engineering students.

courses.name: Survey of American Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces some of the major writers, issues and forms found in the history of American literature. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this survey. (C or H) (WR)

courses.name: Issues in American Literature and Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces some of the most important issues that arise in the study of American literature and culture. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of the topic. (C or H) (WR)

courses.name: American Literatures 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Selected texts from 1865 to the present, in diverse historical and cultural contexts, usually organized around a theme or several themes.

courses.name: Surveys in American Women's Literatures 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys traditions in American women's writings, covering a wide range of texts or focusing on a single theme, genre, period, literary movement or cultural tradition. Topics may include women's writings about feminism, family, work, nationalism or social justice; women's autobiography, poetry, experimental prose or domestic fiction; 19-century literature by women, contemporary women's poetry or colonial women's writing; realist, postmodern or sentimental fiction by American women; African American, New England, Native American, Southern or working-class writing; Chicano, Latina or lesbian literary traditions. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Variable Surveys of American Literatures 3 Credits
courses.description: The rich cultural traditions found in American literature. Topics may include gay and lesbian, Jewish American, Chicano/a, Latino/a, Native American, Southern and other literatures. Refer to department website.

courses.name: African American Literature 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys the development of African American literature from its beginning to 1945.

courses.name: African American Literature 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys the development of African American Literature from 1945 to the present.

courses.name: Asian American Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics or survey focus on the major issues, movements or themes in the study of Asian American literature and culture from the beginnings to the present. Topics may include Kung Fu films, cultural nationalism and feminism, model minorities, Angel Island literature, Asian Americans in film and media, and several major authors.

courses.name: Studies in American Literary Forms 3 Credits
courses.description: Study of genre, such as the novel, detective novel, political novel, historical novel, utopian fiction or Western; drama; short story; sermon traditions; African American cultural forms, African American folklore; long poem, lyric, philosophical poem, oral poetry; nature writing, autobiography, captivity narrative; narratives of exploration; political oratory; postmodernism; coming-out stories; humor. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Studies in American Literature and Culture Before 1800 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics focus on one or more of the major issues, movements, forms or themes in the study of American literature and culture before 1800.
