Topics may include narratives of exploration and encounter, Puritan and/or Enlightenment writings, captivity and slave narratives, traditions of spiritual autobiography, post-colonial approaches to colonial rhetoric and poetry, and/or in-depth studies of selected writers. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Studies in Nineteenth-Century American Literature and Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics focus on the major issues, movements, forms or themes in the study of American literature and culture before 1900. Topics may include the American Renaissance, literature and abolition, African American novels and poetry, romance and romanticism, race and sexuality, the rise of the short story, realism, naturalism, representations of the city, representations of the South, tropes such as the Noble Savage or the American Girl, and/or in-depth studies of selected writers. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Studies in Twentieth-Century American Literature and Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics focus on one or more of the major issues, movements, forms or themes in the study of 20th-century American literature and culture. Topics may include Modernism, Post-Modernism, the Harlem Renaissance, Depression-era literature, American writers in Paris, consumer society, American fiction since 1945, poetry, Civil Rights literature, rhetorics of imperialism, and/or several major authors. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Studies of Genders and Sexualities in American Literature and Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics focus on one or more of the major issues, movements, forms or themes in the study of American literature and culture. Topics may include masculinity and femininity in literature, lesbian possibilities in popular culture, feminism and womanism, traditions of gay self-representation. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Major Figures of American Literature and Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: In-depth focus on one major author, such as Dickinson, Twain, Faulkner, Hurston, or Morrison. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Studies in American Literature and Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics examine issues, movements, forms or themes that cross traditional period boundaries. Topics may include the city and the country in American fiction, Southern masculinity, reading and literacy in America, representations of class and religion in American literature, the body and technology, American regionalisms, the Pragmatist tradition, and nature and eco-criticism in American letters. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Race and Ethnicity 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics examine issues, movements, forms or themes related to race and ethnicity in American literature. Topics may include Pacific Rim cultures in America, Chicano-Latino literature, the Black Arts Movement, constructing Native America, border-crossing and migration, post-war Jewish fiction, literature and the psychology of prejudice, comparative representations of racial and ethnic experience, representing whiteness, literatures of assimilation and multi-racial identities.

courses.name: Beginning Fiction Writing 3 Credits
courses.description: Beginning writing fiction workshop which starts with the basics. Read a lot of fiction (authors can't be a fiction writer without reading shelves of fiction) and write stories to be discussed.

courses.name: Beginning Poetry Writing 3 Credits
courses.description: Workshop that concentrates on the basics of reading and writing poetry (writers must read, and readers must be critics). Write poems and discuss some in workshop.

courses.name: Fiction Writing 3 Credits
courses.description: Continues instruction in basic techniques of voice, plot and character, while introducing advanced ones. Students read a lot of good stories and write a few themselves. Samuel Johnson said, "No man but a blockhead ever wrote, except for money." Juniors or seniors who have not taken CRW 1101 or CRW 1301 must have strong composition skills. (C) (WR)

courses.name: Poetry Writing 3 Credits
courses.description: Writing poetry may become an addiction. This workshop continues with matter-of-fact techniques and some fancy ones as well. Students write poems and read some difficult and thrilling poetry of the past and present. By the end, students may be able to say, with Humpty Dumpty, I can explain all the poems that ever were invented - and a good many that haven't been invented just yet. Juniors or seniors who have not taken CRW 1101 or CRW 1301 must have strong composition skills. (C) (WR)

courses.name: Advanced Seminar in Fiction Writing 3 Credits
courses.description: Small workshop for students who have made their way out of beginner's workshops with sanity intact. Now the work gets more difficult, more deranged and more delightful. Emerson said, "People do not deserve to have good writing, they are so pleased with bad." Admission by manuscript review during advanced registration (refer to department website); by prerequisite during drop/add.

courses.name: Advanced Seminar in Poetry Writing 3 Credits
courses.description: More reeling and writhing," as Lewis Carroll said. An intense workshop for a small group of poets who have stared at the Pacific with a wild surmise. Like Balboa - or was it Cortez? Admission by manuscript review during advanced registration (refer to department website); by prerequisite during drop/add.

courses.name: Creative Nonfiction 3 Credits
courses.description: Creative writing workshop which introduces genres of creative nonfiction (e.g. memoir, personal essay, travel writing) and provides training in those genres. Appropriate for, but not limited to, English majors.

courses.name: Senior Advanced Workshop in Fiction Writing 3 Credits
courses.description: For students who want to trouble the literary editors and readers of the future. Many members of this class have gone on to graduate school in writing. Ants eat everything that is written, said an explorer. This is a workshop for ants. Admission by manuscript review during advanced registration (refer to department website); by prerequisite during drop/add.

courses.name: Senior Advanced Workshop in Poetry Writing 3 Credits
courses.description: George I said, "I hate all Boets and Bainters." For battle-scarred veterans of previous workshops who now want the full treatment, this is a small workshop for serious poets who want to write their names in water, as long as they are also in the Norton Anthology. Students often go from this class into MFA programs in poetry. Admission by manuscript review during advanced registration (refer to department website); by prerequisite during drop/add.

courses.name: Multimodal Writing and Digital Literacy 3 Credits
courses.description: Teaches digital literacy and digital creativity. Compose and convey creative, well-researched, carefully crafted information through digital platforms and multimodal documents. Also promotes digital writing and research as central to academic, civic, and personal expression.

courses.name: Topics for Composition 3 Credits
courses.description: Instruction in expository-argumentative writing related to one special topic selected by the instructor. Readings include variable genres from different disciplines. (C or H) (WR)

courses.name: Technical Writing 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys the forms and methods of communication used in business, industry and government, including informal and formal reports, letters, resumes, and proposals.

courses.name: Professional Communication 3 Credits
courses.description: Professional writing course relevant in business, industry, government and other institutional settings. Covers major elements of organizational communication with emphasis on composition of letters and memos, reports, proposals and manuals. (WR)

courses.name: Advanced Exposition 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced composition course in methods of exposition: definition, classification, comparison and contrast, analysis, illustration and identification. (WR)

courses.name: Advanced Argumentative Writing 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced composition concerned with the writing of argument and critical analysis. (WR)

courses.name: Hypermedia 3 Credits
courses.description: The study and production of digital media, with emphasis on the World Wide Web.

courses.name: Professional Editing 3 Credits
courses.description: How to perform different levels of editing on a range of professional texts, including both printed and online texts as well as both technical and literary ones.

courses.name: Advanced Professional Writing 3 Credits
courses.description: Administrative communication, professional papers, research reports, proposals and other major professional documents, depending on the needs of the students who must have developed communication skills. (WR)

courses.name: Overseas Studies 1-15 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: Writing through Media 4 Credits
courses.description: This media studies equivalent of ENC 1102 explores the practices of literacy in the context of popular culture, including cinema, television, advertising, popular fiction, and journalism.

courses.name: Introduction to Popular Film 3 Credits
courses.description: Designed for non-majors seeking humanities credit in the areas of film and popular culture. Introduces the study of contemporary movies through attention to film form and structure, film genres and attention to popular culture. Students are expected to see new movies off campus. (H)

courses.name: Film Analysis 4 Credits
courses.description: Introduces thinking and writing about the cinema by means of film theory and history. (C or H) (WR)

courses.name: English: College Honors 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Writing about novels, short stories, film and cultural studies primarily by American and British authors. Text and assignments are chosen to match the abilities of honor students. (C or H) (WR)

courses.name: The Theory and Practice of Modern Criticism 3 Credits
courses.description: An intensive introductory study of 20th-century theory.

courses.name: The Theorists 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies one or more theorists, contemporary or historical.

courses.name: Advanced Grammar: Analysis and Application 3 Credits
courses.description: An extensive and sophisticated study of grammar, as well as a practical appreciation of its rhetorical purposes.

courses.name: The Movies as Narrative Art 4 Credits
courses.description: Examines movies as a mode of storytelling by emphasizing the difference between verbal and visual narration, and relation to contemporary thought and values.

courses.name: Introduction to Film: Criticism and Theory 4 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the principal theoretical and critical issues raised by the first century of the cinema.

courses.name: History of Film, Part 1 4 Credits
courses.description: History of film from its beginnings to the introduction of sound.

courses.name: History of Film, Part 2 4 Credits
courses.description: History of film from the introduction of sound to 1960.

courses.name: History of Film, Part 3 4 Credits
courses.description: History of film from 1960 to the present.

courses.name: Psychological Approaches to Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Use of various psychological concepts to the application of literary study. Refer to department website.

courses.name: History of the English Language 3 Credits
courses.description: Origins of the English language and its development from Old English to the present. Students should have completed an introductory linguistics course (LIN 2000, LIN 2001 or LIN 3010). Refer to department website.

courses.name: Race and Ethnicity in Film 4 Credits
courses.description: Critical and historical study of films and videos by and about people of color in the Americas, Africa, Australia and Europe.

courses.name: Film Studies 4 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics provide in-depth study of film genres, notable film directors, and other significant topics on subjects related to film.

courses.name: Women and Film 4 Credits
courses.description: Studies the roles and function of women in mainstream and alternative cinema, including study of feminist film criticism and theories of gender.

courses.name: National Cinemas 4 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics study of the films of historically important national cinemas, such as American, French, German, Italian, Russian, Japanese.

courses.name: Film and Video Production 4 Credits
courses.description: Seminar on the independent and experimental uses of small-format film and video production.

courses.name: Television and Electronic Culture 4 Credits
courses.description: Explores the development of new modes of thought, forms of art, popular culture, and social practices based on the electronic technology of video and computers.

courses.name: Advanced Film and Video Production 4 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics focus on one or more advanced aspects of film and video production, including such topics as editing of film and video or the production of 16mm films.

courses.name: Queer Theory 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of major concerns, methodologies and texts in queer theory, illuminating the theoretical insights, assumptions and implications of various constructions of gender, sex and sexuality.

courses.name: Independent Study 1-3 Credits
courses.description: For advanced students who desire to supplement the regular courses by independent reading or research under guidance.

courses.name: Topics in Collaborative Research 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides supervised research in English in a group context, with emphasis on collaborative learning using variable content and methods.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in English 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in English. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in English.

courses.name: Honors Seminar 3 Credits
courses.description: Open to English majors who have maintained an overall junior/senior level GPA of 3.5. Small seminar classes study topics in English and American literature or film.

courses.name: English Internship 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Admission requires a written proposal of appropriate work experience from the student and a written acceptance for employment from the employer, including designation of a supervisor. Successful completion requires a written summation of the work experience from the student and a written evaluation of performance by the supervisor.

courses.name: Department Seminar 3 Credits
courses.description: Seminar offered on a space-available basis allowing department majors to develop their individual programs of study while focusing on a common topic.

courses.name: Honors Thesis Project 3 Credits
courses.description: Student selects an English faculty member to act as director for an independent research project that culminates in preparation of an honors thesis. An abstract and one copy of the thesis must be delivered to 101 Academic Advising Center by the semester deadline specified by the Honors Office.

courses.name: Survey of English Literature: Medieval to 1750 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces some of the major writers, issues and forms found in the history of the period. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this survey. (C or H) (WR)

courses.name: Survey of English Literature: 1750 to the Present 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces some of the major writers, issues and forms found in the history of the period. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this survey. (C or H) (WR)

courses.name: Introduction to Shakespeare 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the pleasure and wisdom of Shakespeare's plays. Various approaches are used: movie versions of the plays, staging of scenes from the plays and discussion. (H)

courses.name: Special Topics 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics focus on major issues and themes in British literature and culture.

courses.name: The British Novel: 18th Century 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers a wide range of eighteenth-century British novelists, from Aphra Behn, Daniel Defoe, and Samuel Richardson to Henry Fielding, Frances Burney, and Jane Austen. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of each course; refer to department website.

courses.name: The British Novel: 19th Century 3 Credits
courses.description: Includes works by such novelists as Austen, Dickens, Gaskell, Brontë, Eliot, Hardy. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of each course; refer to department website.

courses.name: The English Novel: 20th Century 3 Credits
courses.description: Includes works by such writers as Conrad, Lawrence, Joyce, Forster, Woolf, Greene and Waugh.

courses.name: Twentieth-Century British Poetry 3 Credits
courses.description: General study of the most prominent British poets of the 20th Century with particular emphasis on Yeats, Lawrence, Graves, Eliot, Sitwell, Dylan Thomas and Ted Hughes.

courses.name: Medieval English Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys representative works of the Middle English period such as Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, Pearl, Malory's Morte D'Arthur and selections from medieval drama, lyric poetry, mystical writings and writings by and about women.

courses.name: The Age of Dryden and Pope 3 Credits
courses.description: Selections from the best works of such writers as Dryden, Congreve, Addison, Swift and Pope.

courses.name: The Long Eighteenth Century: Themes and Interpretation 3 Credits
courses.description: Rotating topics courses on eighteenth-century British literature, with an emphasis on themes rather than genres. These include but are not limited to literature's engagement with social issues, material history, and the history of ideas. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this course; refer to department website.

courses.name: The Long Eighteenth Century: Imaginative Genres 3 Credits
courses.description: Rotating topics courses on eighteenth-century British literature, focusing on imaginative genres; especially genres other than the novel, such as drama, poetry, and non-novelistic prose fiction. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this course; refer to department website.

courses.name: Victorian Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Selections from Tennyson, Browning, C. Bronte, Wilde, G.M. Hopkins and Arnold. Examines the beliefs and paradoxes of Victorian culture through the poetry, fiction, drama, visual arts and critical theory of representative figures. Investigates the social and cultural assumptions which underlie the artists' approaches to their themes as well as the themes themselves. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Renaissance Literature: 16th Century 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics in Tudor literature and culture, 1485-1603. Focuses on or combine topics such as the development of literary genres; the works of single or paired authors; the social institutions and material conditions of textual production; thematically organized studies of cultural relations between literary and nonliterary texts; issues of gender, religion, nationhood and race; and writing in the emergence of an English literature. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Renaissance Literature: 17th Century 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics in Stuart Literature and Culture, 1603-1700. Focuses on or combine topics such as the progress of literary genres; the works of single or paired authors; the social institutions and material conditions of textual production; thematically organized studies of cultural relations between literary and nonliterary texts; issues of gender, religion, nationhood and race; and writing in the era before, during and after the English Revolution. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Twentieth Century British Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics on major works of drama, poetry or prose from twentieth-century Britain. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Major Figures of British Literature and Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: In-depth focus on one or two major cultural figures, such as Marlowe, Austen, Scott, Eliot, Dickens, Yeats, Smith, Ishiguro, Kureishi, etc.

courses.name: Chaucer 3 Credits
courses.description: Reading and critical study of Chaucer's poetry with emphasis on the Canterbury Tales and Troilus and Criseyde, in addition to some attention to the minor works.

courses.name: Shakespeare 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies selections from Shakespeare. Topics include tracing Shakespeare's dramatic career, concentrating on one or several genres including histories, comedies, tragedies and romances; developing the history of Shakespeare reception; approaching Shakespeare through performance, including acting and directing; and approaching Shakespeare through feminist, materialist or psychoanalytic methods.

courses.name: Introduction to Morphology 3 Credits
courses.description: Theory of word structure, derivation and inflection, with examples and problems from a variety of languages. Includes the position of morphology in grammar, the relationship between morphology and grammar, typology, cultural and conceptual categories, and predictions of various theories of morphology. May be taught in conjunction with a graduate course that bears the same title.

courses.name: Introduction to Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the important role literature has played in individuals' lives and in society, presenting a range of literary styles and genres, from different countries and historical periods. Special attention paid to development of critical skills of analysis and interpretation. (H)

courses.name: Survey of World Literature: Ancient to Renaissance 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces some of the major writers, issues and forms found in the history of the period. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this survey. (C or H, and N) (WR)

courses.name: Survey of World Literature: 17th Century to Modern 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces some of the major writers, issues and forms found in history of the period. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this survey. (C or H, and N) (WR)

courses.name: The Forms of Narrative 3 Credits
courses.description: A close reading and critical analysis of representative forms and styles of narrative, to improve the student's ability to study narrative structures and theories of narrative. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Studies in Poetry 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics provide in-depth study of genre such as the lyric, epic or sonnet, or of developments in periods of literature such as the medieval, American or African. Emphasis on refining the ability to read and analyze texts carefully and accurately. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Studies in Drama 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics provide in-depth study of genre such as comedy or tragedy, or of developments in periods such as the Elizabethan, Jacobean or Restoration. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Studies in Modern Drama 3 Credits
courses.description: Representative selections from continental, British and American playwrights. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Jewish Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics in the Jewish literary experience, from the biblical narrative and classical tales to Yiddish and Hebrew literature, the modern European novel, and American Jewish fiction. (H and N)

courses.name: The Age of the Avant-Garde 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the revolutionary experimentalist aspects of modern and contemporary culture, such as cubism, surrealism, structuralism, and conceptualism.

courses.name: The Bible as Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Literary analysis from the Hebrew and Christian Bibles, with emphasis upon poetry and narrative. (H and N)

courses.name: Women in Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Critical and thematic study of women in literature that may include fiction, poetry or drama in English, American or world literature. Refer to department website. (D and H)

courses.name: Interdisciplinary Topics in Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Interdisciplinary variable-topics study of the vital relationship between literature and other creative arts, other humanistic disciplines or the sciences and technology. Refer to department website.

courses.name: World English Language Literatures 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics focus on one or more of the diverse English language literary traditions, including those of Ireland, Scotland, India, Nigeria, the Caribbean, Canada and Australia. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Caribbean Literature in English 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics focus on the critical and analytical study of representative Caribbean authors writing in English. Refer to department website.

courses.name: African Literature in English 3 Credits
courses.description: Critical and analytical study of representative Black-African authors writing in English, notably Achebe, Awoonor, Ngugi, Aidoo, Soyinka, Armah, Ekwensi, Mphalele and p'Bitek'. (H and N)

courses.name: Postcolonial Literature, Culture and Theory 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics explore the issues, questions and themes raised in the rich literature, culture and theory that emerge as a response to and in contestation of the experiences of the colonial and postcolonial worlds. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Comics Studies 4 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics provide an opportunity for the in-depth study of comics genres, notable comics writers and illustrators and other significant topics on related subjects.

courses.name: The Folktale 3 Credits
courses.description: Reading folktales, myths and legends, particularly those told orally by ethnic, indigenous and emigrant cultures within the USA. Attention is paid to critical theory and the scholarly study of the folktale. In addition, the use of the folktale by creative writers and teachers is discussed.

courses.name: Children's Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Designed to arouse a genuine interest in children's books and to aid the student in obtaining a critical knowledge of the literature.

courses.name: Literature for Young Children 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores kinds and qualities of literature for the younger child, examining the child's first experience with literature in oral forms, then moving on to picture and story books and poetry.

courses.name: Literature for the Adolescent 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the types of literature read by adolescents, with emphasis upon the criteria for the choice of good books and upon developing a familiarity with the many books available.

courses.name: Golden Age of Children's Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Origins and evolution of the Anglo-American tradition in literature for young readers, 1720-1920, with an emphasis on the Victorian era. Authors may include Defoe, Scott, Cooper, Dickens, Alcott, Twain and Stevenson.

courses.name: Issues and Methods in Cultural Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the issues and methodology used in cultural studies. Students will be encouraged to explore a number of methods by which culture is analyzed, understood and disseminated. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Feminist Theories 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces a variety of analytic, theoretical and interpretive approaches under the general rubric feminist theory. Course concentrates on current issues in literary and cultural studies, but also discusses other disciplines as well.

courses.name: Variable Topics in Literature and Language 3 Credits
courses.description: Proseminar of variable content providing an opportunity for the in-depth study of various topics such as the literature of war and peace, of death and of courtly love. Refer to department website.

courses.name: Reading and Writing Content Area 1-7 Credits
courses.description: Covers the fundamentals of beginning college writing and critical reading skills.

courses.name: Advanced Public Speaking 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies principles and methods of selected forms of public speaking for various purposes, audiences and contexts.

courses.name: Rhetorical Criticism 3 Credits
courses.description: Critical analyses of rhetorical elements and processes in oratorical and non-oratorical forms.

courses.name: Agricultural Honors 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Various courses offered. (WR)

courses.name: Agricultural Ecology 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the study of ecology from an agricultural perspective. Emphasizes ecological principles with examples and applications from agriculture.

courses.name: Exotic Species and Biosecurity Issues 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies US policies and programs affecting agricultural biosecurity as applied to current agricultural and extension and regulatory programs. Emphasizes policies and procedures used to detect and report non-indigenous species. Develop the analytical capabilities to assess the consequences of agricultural biosecurity threats.

courses.name: Consequences of Biological Invasions 3 Credits
courses.description: Non-native species invasions and environmental effects of these invaders. Students will develop analytical capabilities to assess the consequences of biological invasions.

courses.name: Challenges in Plant Resource Protection 3 Credits
courses.description: Applied training in the regulatory aspects of plant protection, using real-world case studies, scenarios and issues.

courses.name: Bugs and People 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction for lower-division students who want to learn popular information about insects and associated organisms.

courses.name: The Insects 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces insect biology, insect-organism interaction, and insect association with humans. Features discussion of basic biological principles using insects as examples.

courses.name: Practical Beekeeping 3 Credits
courses.description: Establish colonies of European-derived honey bees and manage them to be healthy and productive. A hybrid approach combines online lectures and in-person field experiences.

courses.name: Using Insect Research to Understand the Nature of Scientific Engagement 3 Credits
courses.description: A classroom undergraduate research experience (CURE) which bridges the divide between the classroom and the science laboratory and prepares for advanced opportunities in entomological science. become part of an entomology research team, collecting publishable data on insect evolution, ecology, and systematics.

courses.name: Principles of Entomology 2 Credits
courses.description: Introduces principles of insect study, including insect structure, insect development, evolutionary insect history and its ecological significance. (B)

courses.name: Principles of Entomology Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Provides practical laboratory experience working with insects, dissecting insects and preparing lab reports. Insect collection is required. (B)

courses.name: Life Science 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces insects and their interactions with humans and the environment.

courses.name: Biology and Identification of Urban Pests 3 Credits
courses.description: Biology, behavior, ID and damage recognition of insect and vertebrate pests.

courses.name: Principles of Urban Pest Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Methods of controlling household, structural and occasional pests with emphasis placed on cockroaches, termites and fleas.

courses.name: Urban Vertebrate Pest Management 2 Credits
courses.description: The biology, ecology, health risks, exclusions and control of vertebrate pests in the urban environment.

courses.name: Insect Behavior 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides a theoretical and empirical overview of insect behavior, ranging from physiology underlying behavior to the evolution of behavioral diversity. Focuses on recent and current research on insect behavior, the diversity of approaches for studying it, and how this knowledge can be applied to solve human challenges.

courses.name: Turf and Ornamental Entomology 3 Credits
courses.description: Biology, identification and management of arthropods that infect turfgrass and ornamental plants in urban landscape and in nurseries and greenhouses.

courses.name: Introduction to Tropical Entomology 3 Credits
courses.description: Natural history, ecology and behavior of tropical insects in natural and agroecosystems. Designed for students without previous experience in tropics.

courses.name: Tropical Entomology Field Laboratory 2 Credits
courses.description: A 10-day trip to a tropical country to study the insect faunas of natural and agroecosystems. Each student is assigned a field project.

courses.name: Spider Biology 2 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the biology of spiders and their relatives, with an emphasis on their ecology, behavior, and evolution. Learn to identify the members of approximately 20 common spider families as well as several common Florida species.

courses.name: Spider Biology Lab 1 Credit
courses.description: Provides practical experience working with spiders, including field collection techniques, identification and curation of spider specimens, and observing spider behavior. Requires spider collection.

courses.name: Insect Classification 3 Credits
courses.description: Classification of major families of adult insects with emphasis on their identification, habitat and niche. A properly curated collection is required. (B)

courses.name: Insect Ecology 3 Credits
courses.description: This course is an introduction to ecological concepts with emphasis on insects. The relationships of insects with their biotic and physical environments, along with the roles of insects in nature, will be emphasized. The basics of ecological research will be covered.

courses.name: Insect Ecology Lab 1 Credit
courses.description: Introduces ecological methods and analysis with an emphasis on insects. Emphasizes methods to explore relationships of insects with their biotic and physical environments, along with the roles of insects in nature. Also covers the basics of ecological research.

courses.name: Ecology of Vector-Borne Disease 2 Credits
courses.description: Introduces critical components of vector-borne disease systems and basic concepts inherent to disease ecology. Focuses on vector-borne diseases of humans and wildlife and how aspects of the environment and host/vector biology influence disease transmission. Topics include epidemiology, transmission models, and emerging diseases.

courses.name: Ecology and Conservation of Pollinators 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines interactions between animals and the plants that they pollinate, current threats to pollinator populations, and the conservation of pollinators worldwide; explore these topics through readings, discussion, and a field research project.

courses.name: Insects and Wildlife 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces insects and other arthropods and their relationships with wild vertebrate animals.

courses.name: Termite Biology and Control 2 Credits
courses.description: Taxonomy, identification, behavior, ecology and methods of control for the economically important termites in the New World.

courses.name: Urban Pesticide Application 1-6 Credits
courses.description: Practical work experience in urban pesticide application; study pest management problems on campus and in residences.

courses.name: Behavioral Ecology and Systematics 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces behavioral ecology and systematics of insects. (B)

courses.name: Social Insects 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides an overview of social insect biology in the context of comparative social evolution. Topics include the diversity of social behaviors in insects, evolutionary origins of sociality, kin recognition, caste systems, communication in social groups, and impacts of social insects.

courses.name: Honey Bee Biology 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides an in-depth look into the fascinating world of honey bee biology. Explore topics including honey bee sociality, taxonomy, biogeography, behavior, anatomy, physiology, reproduction, nutrition and genetics. Additionally, these topics will be discussed via the paradigm of the honey bee superorganism.

courses.name: Beekeeping I 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the biology of honey bees and the craft of apiculture by exploring the life cycle of honey bees, biogeography, and evolution of beekeeping. Discusses equipment, techniques, management practices, pollination ecology, economic practices, and current issues within beekeeping.

courses.name: Beekeeping II 3 Credits
courses.description: Provide more depth on topics introduced in ENY 4573, including beekeeping styles, colony stressors, and yearly management. Also explores issues affecting the beekeeping industry including integrated pest management, pests/diseases, African bees, commercial pollination, queen production, bee removals, and pesticides.

courses.name: Mosquito Identification 3 Credits
courses.description: Intensive, hands-on training on morphological features and the identification of adult and larval mosquito species that occur in North America.

courses.name: Mosquito Biology 3 Credits
courses.description: This modular course covers six critical areas of mosquito biology; classification, natural history and ecology, physiology, population dynamics, mosquito-borne diseases and control of mosquitoes. Students will understand the fundamental processes governing mosquitoes and mosquito-borne diseases.

courses.name: Medical and Veterinary Entomology 2 Credits
courses.description: Presents the major insect, mite, and tick vectors of disease to humans and animals. Topics includes arthropod-transmitted diseases, the interaction between pathogens and the arthropod vector, and the mechanical damage that a parasite inflicts on its host.

courses.name: Medical and Veterinary Entomology Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Identifying mosquitoes, ticks, lice, fleas and other disease vectors. Insect collection required. (B)

courses.name: Forensic Entomology 3 Credits
courses.description: The role of arthropods in decomposition, in criminal and civil investigations and the increasing importance of science on society. Material and discussions deal with death and some may consider course images and concepts disturbing.

courses.name: Molecular Biology of Insects and Nematodes 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides foundation knowledge of molecular biology, with emphasis on scientific discoveries from insects and nematodes. Presents information on the current innovations and trends of molecular technologies (e.g. high throughput sequencing, different types of omics, genome editing by CRISPR).

courses.name: Supervised Extension Experience in Entomology and Nematology 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic extension experiences in entomology and nematology under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.name: Problems in Entomology 1-5 Credits
courses.description: Problems in any field of specialization in entomology and nematology.

courses.name: Supervised Research in Entomology 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in entomology under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Honors Thesis Research in Entomology 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Independent research in entomology leading to an honors thesis. Student will be mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Special Topics in Entomology and Nematology 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Special topics in Entomology and Nematology.

courses.name: Insect Pest and Vector Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers the principles and practices used in pest and vector management, and also emphasizes the arthropod pests affecting crop and ornamental plants, humans and livestock.

courses.name: Landscape Integrated Pest Management: Ornamentals and Turf 3 Credits
courses.description: Landscape pest pressure is influenced by many factors. The development of sound integrated pest management plans for landscapes focuses on identification of abiotic factors, weeds, insects, mites, pathogens and nematodes that occur on Florida landscape ornamentals, turfgrass and palms.

courses.name: Principles of Nematology 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces nematology, including studies of morphology, life histories and control of the major nematode parasites of plants. Also includes studies of the bionomics of certain soil nematodes and nematode parasites of vertebrates and arthropods. (B)

courses.name: Problems in Nematology 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Selected problems for study, research or discussion in nematology.

courses.name: Supervised Research in Nematology 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in nematology under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Honors Thesis Research in Nematology 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Independent research in nematology leading to an honors thesis. Student will be mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Energy and Environment 3 Credits
courses.description: Consideration of the energy basis for humans and nature, including principles of energy analysis, systems ecology, and public policy.

courses.name: Environmental Chemistry 4 Credits
courses.description: Provides the fundamental knowledge needed to solve pollution problems specific to environmental systems by focusing primarily on thermodynamic equilibrium and kinetic principles associated with both natural and engineered systems.

courses.name: Ecological Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Application of ecological and engineering principles to natural resource management and problem solving.

courses.name: Environmental Planning and Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Principles and practices of environmental planning. Planning for and designing sustainable communities and regions. Exploration of quantitative methods for the evaluation of environmental impacts and analysis of carrying capacity of economic development. Exploration of theories of spatial and temporal organization of systems of humanity and nature.

courses.name: Wastewater Microbiology 2 Credits
courses.description: General concepts in microbiology and cell biology with major emphasis on the role of microorganisms in polluted environments. (B)

courses.name: Water Chemistry 3 Credits
courses.description: Kinetics and equilibrium of aqueous chemistry including acid-base, complexation, precipitation and redox equilibria. (P)

courses.name: Phase Partitioning in the Environment 4 Credits
courses.description: A study of the fate of organic pollutants in the environment through application of principles of organic chemistry and chemical thermodynamics, including phase partitioning between environmental media.

courses.name: Industrial Ecology 3 Credits
courses.description: Linkage of industrial activity with environmental and social sciences. Corporate environmental management and environmental ethics. Resources, laws and economics. Environmental account. Industrial products and processes and life cycle assessments. Case studies of corporate environmental policies.

courses.name: Public Health Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Application of engineering principles to protect public health. Areas covered include water supply, waste treatment, air pollution, radiological health, occupational health, milk and food sanitation, vector control, solid wastes, and housing hygiene. (P)

courses.name: Engineering Directed Independent Research 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research with a faculty advisor or postdoctoral or graduate student mentor. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Prep for Success 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Freshman success course that includes academic preparation in calculus, chemistry, student success, and technical communications.

courses.name: Sustainable Nanotechnology 3 Credits
courses.description: Increase in production and use of engineered nanomaterials (ENMs) raises concerns on their potential impacts on the environment and human health. The sustainable development of nanotechnology requires knowledge of life cycle and environmental fate/implications of ENMs. Focuses on linkages between ENMs properties and environmental implications.

courses.name: Introduction to Environmental Engineering 1 Credit
courses.description: Introduction to topics in environmental engineering, including water and air quality, sustainable materials management, and ecosystems.

courses.name: Core 2: Fundamentals of Environmental Engineering 4 Credits
courses.description: Fundamentals of environmental engineering, including water, air, materials, and ecological resources. Environmental laws and regulations that motivate environmental engineering practice. Theoretical approaches for quantifying fundamental environmental processes, interactions, impact, and risks. Build knowledge and relevant skills in topics that bridge disciplines, including statistics, thermodynamics, microbiology, and organic chemistry.

courses.name: Core 1: Introduction to Environmental Systems 4 Credits
courses.description: Introduces environmental systems, including water, air, materials, and ecological resources with motivating case studies across topics and fundamental definitions, laws, and theories in environmental engineering sciences. Build a knowledge base and relevant skills in topics that bridge disciplines, including statistics, thermodynamics, microbiology, and organic chemistry.

courses.name: Computational Methods in Environmental Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Numerical modeling techniques and their application to environmental engineering. Use of personal computers and spreadsheets to solve numerical models. Solution techniques include numerical methods and their implementation using R.

courses.name: Engineering Ethics and Environmental Justice 2 Credits
courses.description: Intended for Environmental Engineering majors. Lectures and discussion on topics in ethics and environmental justice as related to environmental engineering.

courses.name: Core 5: Environmental Engineering Practice 4 Credits
courses.description: Utilize fundamental and applied concepts in environmental engineering practice, including applications of ecological engineering, air pollution control, waste facilities design, and advanced water treatment processes. Build a knowledge base and relevant skills in topics that bridge disciplines, including statistics, thermodynamics, microbiology, and organic chemistry.

courses.name: Environmental Analysis 4 Credits
courses.description: Theory and laboratory techniques for the analysis of air and water pollutants and basic concepts of ecosystems structure and analysis.

courses.name: Elements of Atmospheric Pollution 3 Credits
courses.description: Sources, effects and regulation of air pollutants. Meteorology and dispersion of pollutants. Sampling and analysis of gaseous and particulate air pollutants. Photochemical air pollution and mobile sources. (P)

courses.name: Air Pollution Control Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Principles of particulate and gaseous emission control; design and operation of particulate and gas control equipment to meet federal emission standards.

courses.name: Solid Waste Containment Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Design fundamentals of solid and hazardous waste landfills, waste piles, monofills and surface impoundments. Regulations, site requirements, sizing, liner design, leachate and gas management system design, operations and closure.

courses.name: Solid and Hazardous Waste Management 4 Credits
courses.description: Generation of solid and hazardous wastes. Collection, methods, equipment, costs and disposal. Rules, regulations and management systems for proper control of solid and hazardous wastes. Evaluation of engineering systems to minimize costs and regulatory problems. (P)

courses.name: Solid Waste Systems Design 3 Credits
courses.description: A capstone design experience focusing on the design of solid waste management systems such as landfills, waste-to-energy facilities, compost operations, recycling facilities and hazardous waste treatment/storage/disposal facilities.

courses.name: Nutrient Control and Water Reuse 3 Credits
courses.description: Biological and physicochemical processes for advanced treatment of municipal wastewater. Reuse guidelines and applications.

courses.name: Stormwater Control Systems 3 Credits
courses.description: Chemical, physical, biological and hydrologic aspects of rainfall runoff and control through unit operations and processes (UOPs). Stormwater physical and chemical loads. Interactions between hydrologic processes, water chemistry, sediment transport, infrastructure materials and UOPs for treatment and reuse.

courses.name: Water Treatment Process Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Design of selected water treatment processes including disinfection, air stripping, adsorption, ion exchange and membrane processes.

courses.name: Potable Water System Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Design of conventional water treatment operations, including reactor design, coagulation, flocculation, mixing, sedimentation, filtration, softening, disinfection and sludge management.

courses.name: Core 3: Processes in Environmental Engineering 4 Credits
courses.description: Theoretical and applied knowledge in environmental engineering processes across the air, water, and solid phases. Quantitative tools for describing materials and energy flows and transformations. Build a knowledge base and relevant skills in topics that bridge disciplines, including statistics, thermodynamics, microbiology, and organic chemistry.

courses.name: Core 4: Environmental Engineering Applications 4 Credits
courses.description: Application of fundamental concepts and laws to design, assess, and predict outcomes in environmental engineering systems handling water, air, materials, and ecosystems. Build a knowledge base and relevant skills in topics that bridge disciplines, including statistics, thermodynamics, microbiology, and organic chemistry.

courses.name: Environmental Hydrology 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Surface and atmospheric hydrology. Hydrologic processes controlling streamflow events. Practical application to stormwater management.

courses.name: Environmental Hydrology 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Subsurface hydrology. Properties of porous media governing flow and chemical transport in the subsurface. Environmental site evaluation methods.

courses.name: Water and Wastewater Treatment 3 Credits
courses.description: Design of water and wastewater treatment units.

courses.name: Wastewater System Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Detailed design and layout of gravity wastewater collection systems, pumping facilities, force mains, and a wastewater treatment plant. Emphasis on the preparation of design drawings and estimating costs.

courses.name: Environmental Hydrology 4 Credits
courses.description: Atmospheric, surface, subsurface hydrology and interactions as part of the water cycle. Properties of natural and anthropogenic surfaces and porous media governing flow and transport.

courses.name: Environmental Resources Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Theory and application of engineering economics and systems analysis to the design of environmental management systems.

courses.name: Environmental Engineering Design 1 3 Credits
courses.description: First semester of a two-semester capstone design experience where environmental engineering seniors work in teams on an actual project. Projects encourage creativity, innovation, curiosity, and educational foundation to solve complex real-world problems.

courses.name: Environmental Engineering Design 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Second semester of the capstone design experience where environmental engineering seniors work in teams on an actual project. Projects encourage creativity, innovation, curiosity, and educational foundation to solve complex real-world problems.

courses.name: Individual Studies in Environmental Engineering Sciences 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Selected problems or projects in the student's major field of study.

courses.name: Integrated Product and Process Design 1: Environmental Engineering Sciences 3 Credits
courses.description: The first part of a two-course sequence in which multidisciplinary teams of engineering and business students partner with industry sponsors to design and build authentic products and processes-on time and within budget. Working closely with industry liaison engineers and a faculty coach, students gain practical experience in teamwork and communication, problem solving and engineering design, and develop leadership, management and people skills.

courses.name: Integrated Product and Process Design 2: Environmental Engineering Sciences 3 Credits
courses.description: The second part of the sequence in which multidisciplinary teams of engineering and business students partner with industry sponsors to design and build authentic products and processes-on time and within budget. Working closely with industry liaison engineers and a faculty coach, students gain practical experience in teamwork and communication, problem solving and engineering design, and develop leadership, management and people skills.

courses.name: Special Problems in Environmental Engineering Sciences 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Special problems in environmental engineering science.

courses.name: Environmental Engineering Internship/Co-op 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Practical internship/co-op work experience under approved industrial supervision. (S/U)

courses.name: Elementary Organic and Biological Chemistry 3 Credits
courses.description: Elementary organic chemistry and biochemistry for students in the agricultural technical curricula. This is a terminal course and is not part of any sequence.

courses.name: Introduction to Ecosystem Restoration 4 Credits
courses.description: Restoration theory and planning, disturbed land reclamation, woodland/wetland/river restoration, invasive species, community involvement, and monitoring, and emphasizes plant selection, establishment and maintenance.

courses.name: Introductory Medicinal Plants 3 Credits
courses.description: Survey series of plants across the globe used in traditional and modern medicines to improve human health; learn about ethnobotany, several examples of plant-derived drugs and their metabolite classes at a basic level for non-experts along with underlying scientific evidence. Hands-on-activities demonstrate medicinal properties of plant extracts and tours of medicinal plants around UF main campus and greenhouses to experience live plants.

courses.name: Introduction to Plant Molecular Biology 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces plant molecular biology and genetic engineering, emphasizing plant genes and genomes, transformation of plants and basic molecular biology.

courses.name: Residential Landscape Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Basics of residential landscape design including preparation, evaluation and implementation of simple landscape plans. Emphasizes the use of ornamental plants for functional and aesthetic improvement of home environments. Expect to attend one or two Saturday field trips.

courses.name: Advanced Residential Landscape Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Sustainable landscape design concepts and practices to create regenerative and resilient residential landscapes that demonstrate advanced design skills and knowledge.

courses.name: Plants, Gardening and You 1 Credit
courses.description: A non-majors overview of environmental horticulture that emphasizes the art and science of growing, installing and maintaining plants used to enhance and improve the human environment indoors and outdoors. Gain familiarity with the science and the industries associated with environmental horticulture.

courses.name: Survey of Orchids 1 Credit
courses.description: Overview of the complexities of the orchid family, how selected genera are produced and the potential these plants offer to commercial nursery operators and hobbyists for profit or enjoyment.

courses.name: Sensory Gardening 2 Credits
courses.description: Hands-on, multidisciplinary approach to environmental horticulture delivered through the context of the human senses. Class activities, assignments, and projects enhance awareness and understanding of how horticulture relates to the natural and built world, as well as the ways in which people perceive those worlds.

courses.name: Turfgrass Culture 4 Credits
courses.description: Comparisons of turfgrass for their landscape and recreational uses. Covers growth characteristics, method of propagation, and basic management requirements, including control of important pest problems.

courses.name: Introductory Nursery Management 4 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the principles of planning, organizing and managing nursery operations. Emphasizes interactions between growing medium components, plant nutrition and irrigation. Nursery layout, growing structures, materials requirements and business practices are covered. Weekend field trips may be required.

courses.name: Palm Short Course 1 Credit
courses.description: Overview of how palm plants grow and how to diagnose and interpret problems with palm plants.

courses.name: Environmental Plant Identification and Use 2 Credits
courses.description: Identification, growth characteristics, culture and use of common landscape and greenhouse plants. Materials include trees, shrubs, vines, ground covers, lawn grasses and floriculture crops. Emphasizes temperate plants. Taught off campus.

courses.name: Environmental Plant Identification and Use 3 Credits
courses.description: Combines lecture and laboratory for identification, growth characteristics, culture and use of common landscape and greenhouse plants. Materials include trees, shrubs, vines, ground covers, lawn grasses and floriculture crops. Emphasizes temperate plants. Taught on UF campus. (B)

courses.name: Environmental Plant Identification and Use Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Introductory, upper-division environmental laboratory course. Identify commonly used landscape plants, their use and their characteristics. Taught off campus.

courses.name: Public Gardens 2 Credits
courses.description: Operation and management of public gardens, including community and amusement parks, nature preserves, botanical gardens, arboreta, and zoological gardens. Explore issues relevant to principles and practices of management and psychological and sociological benefits of gardens and green spaces.

courses.name: Public Gardens Laboratory 2 Credits
courses.description: First-hand observation and evaluation of public gardens and parks to illustrate the management of such, as was discussed in ORH 3773. Consists of field trips to various botanical gardens, zoos and amusement parks.

courses.name: Florida Native Landscaping 3 Credits
courses.description: An upper-division, environmental horticulture course designed to introduce students with a plant science background to the nomenclature, effective utilization and design elements of plants native to Florida.

courses.name: Golf and Sports Turf Management 2 Credits
courses.description: Strategies involved in golf course and athletic field operations, including development of management cultural practices, adherence to environment regulations, personnel management and budgeting. Students may be expected to attend Saturday field trips.

courses.name: Ornamental Landscape Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Provide foundational knowledge and the skills needed to successfully manage and maintain residential and commercial landscapes. Additionally, provides students with a greater understanding of the landscape management industry and familiarizes students with sustainable landscape management techniques.

courses.name: Arboriculture 4 Credits
courses.description: Introduces urban trees: biology, management requirements, design of urban spaces for trees, site modifications and construction techniques, tree selection, installation techniques, establishing trees in adverse sites, tree pruning and related tree management practices. A written tree management plan is required.

courses.name: Nutritional Management of Nursery Crops 3 Credits
courses.description: Techniques for determining, interpreting and managing the nutritional status of container grown greenhouse and nursery crops. Includes water quality, substrate physical and chemical parameters, irrigation and fertilization practices.

courses.name: Greenhouse and Nursery Crop Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Principles and practices used for commercial production of economically important environmental horticulture crops.

courses.name: Greenhouse and Nursery Crop Culture Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Advanced hands-on laboratory growing a wide range of greenhouse plants through the application of crop cultural practices discussed in lecture.

courses.name: Orchidology 3 Credits
courses.description: Principles and practices involved in the production of orchid plants and flowers, including nomenclature, breeding, seed culture, harvesting and handling.

courses.name: Annual and Perennial Gardening 2 Credits
courses.description: Identification, selection, use and management of annuals, perennials, vines, ornamental grasses and ground covers in the landscape. Hands-on care for plants in the outdoor laboratory. Learn the irrigation, fertilization, pruning and cultural needs of these popular plants. Laboratory complements lecture.

courses.name: Annual and Perennial Gardening 3 Credits
courses.description: Identification, selection, use and management of annuals, perennials, vines, ornamental grasses and ground covers in the landscape. Hands-on care for plants in the outdoor laboratory. Learn the irrigation, fertilization, pruning and cultural needs of these popular plants. Laboratory complements lecture.

courses.name: Annual and Perennial Gardening Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Taxonomy of ornamental landscape annuals and perennials. Site evaluation, diagnostics, preparation, installation and maintenance of the color portion of commercial and residential landscaping.

courses.name: Landscape Plant Establishment 2 Credits
courses.description: Techniques for selecting and installing plants, building decks and patios, walls, trellises, landscape lighting, irrigation, water gardens and other landscape elements. Prepare balance sheets, bid specifications and contracts and perform landscape installations from completed landscape plants.

courses.name: Supervised Extension Experience in Environmental Horticulture 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic extension experiences in agricultural and life sciences under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.name: Independent Study of Environmental Horticulture 1-5 Credits
courses.description: Three topics for independent study: a research investigation and review of literature, drafting of proposal, conducting an experiment, collection of data, summation and interpretation of results and preparation of a report; a library or studio assignment, including analysis of several sources of information on a specific topic with a written evaluation and list of conclusions; or assist in teaching a laboratory of selected courses in environmental horticulture.

courses.name: Supervised Research in Environmental Horticulture 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in environmental horticulture under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Honors Thesis Research in Environmental Horticulture 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Independent research in environmental horticulture leading to an honors thesis. Student are mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Special Topics in Environmental Horticulture 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Topics of current interest concerning environmental plants.

courses.name: Professional Seminar in Environmental Horticulture 1 Credit
courses.description: A senior-level course for students seeking career opportunities in environmental horticulture. Special emphasis is placed on the expectations of and the relevant issues facing the landscape plant production, landscape management and turfgrass industries. Field trips and attendance at selected commercial trade shows are mandatory.

courses.name: Practical Work Experience 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Practical work must be a new experience and related to student's field of study. A written and oral report is required.

courses.name: Introduction to Horticultural Therapy 3 Credits
courses.description: Examine the profession and practice of horticultural therapy including its history, current state, and relevant literature and theories. Explore people/plant relationships, therapeutic methods and benefits, and populations served, as well as being introduced to existing programs and the role of therapeutic gardens.

courses.name: Plant Propagation 2 Credits
courses.description: Principles, practices and physiological aspects of the propagation of horticultural and agronomic crops by cuttage, graftage, seedage, micropropagation and other methods.

courses.name: Plant Propagation Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Methods of propagating by seeds, bulbs, divisions, layering, cuttings, budding, grafting and micropropagation in a hands-on environment.

courses.name: Techniques in Horticultural Therapy 3 Credits
courses.description: Examine the effectiveness of horticultural therapy across a diverse range of client populations, programs, and environments, and the physical, cognitive, and psychosocial implications. Explore therapeutic, vocational, and social modalities employing plants, as well as task analysis, activity analysis and tool and site adaptations.

courses.name: Program Management in Horticultural Therapy 3 Credits
courses.description: Learn to develop, manage, and evaluate horticultural therapy programs in diverse environments. Explore strategies for program proposals and funding, along with recruitment of clients and required regulations and documentation. Discuss staff and volunteer management, as well as plant materials, gardens, and other program resources.

courses.name: Genome Editing and Plant Biotechnology 3 Credits
courses.description: Plant biotechnology is one of the most prolific and influential areas of the plant sciences. This upper level undergraduate course will be focused on modern biotechnological tools and applications that have resulted in great advances for agriculture and society.

courses.name: Micropropagation of Horticultural Crops 4 Credits
courses.description: Lectures and laboratory exercises emphasizing the practical application of plant tissue culture for the clonal propagation of horticultural crops. Emphasis on aseptic technique, culture methodology and micropropagation systems development.

courses.name: Practical Work Experience 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Practical, hands-on experience in the plant sciences through a paid internship in the industry. This must be a new experience and related to the student's field of study. One month of full-time work is required for each credit.

courses.name: Plant Science Capstone 3 Credits
courses.description: Identify a problem or topic in plant sciences and develop a poster presentation about this problem or topic. This course discusses the following topics: how to develop a hypothesis, how to complete a reliable literature review, the importance of peer review and how to present results and findings.

courses.name: Introduction to Environmental Science 3 Credits
courses.description: Delivered from a systems perspective, an interdisciplinary approach explores contemporary environments that are comprised of both human and non-human elements. Explores physical, chemical, and biological processes to understand pressing environmental challenges and cultural values, attitudes, and norms expressed by individuals and populations around the globe. (B) (N) (P)

courses.name: Environmental Science 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Assess environmental issues arising from human-nature interactions, including biodiversity loss, overpopulation, degradation of ecosystems, and concerns associated with energy and water use. This interdisciplinary approach integrates natural and social science perspectives to explore causes, impacts, and solutions to these issues.

courses.name: Environmental Science Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Hands-on experience in data collection and analysis for environmental science and management.

courses.name: Critical Thinking in Environmental Science 3 Credits
courses.description: Develops critical thinking and communication skills in the practicing environmental scientist. Students analyze the strengths, limitations and strategies of arguments regarding environmental science, policy and management, and craft arguments consistent with the scientific method.

courses.name: Supervised Extension Experience in Natural Resources and Environment 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic experiences in natural resources and environment under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.name: Individual Study in Environmental Science 1-3 Credits
Supervised Research in Environmental Science 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in environmental science under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Honors Thesis Research in Environmental Science 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Independent research in environmental science leading to an honors thesis. Student will be mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Special Topics in Environmental Science 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Special topics in environmental science.

courses.name: Environmental Science Internship 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Employment or volunteer work in a natural resource- or environment-related business or government agency, with job description related to field of study and written work report of each term's activities.

courses.name: European Experience: a Humanities Perspective 3 Credits
courses.description: Introductory interdisciplinary study of contemporary Europe from an arts and humanities perspective. (H and N)

courses.name: European Experience: a Social Science Perspective 3 Credits
courses.description: Introductory interdisciplinary study of contemporary Europe from a social science perspective. (N and S)

courses.name: Spices, Dumplings, and Coffee: Food Customs in Europe 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies agriculture, geography, and culture from the perspective of food production, customs, and health in European countries.

courses.name: Greece During the Second World War 3 Credits
courses.description: A broad history of Greece during WWII, including the German occupation of Greece, the resistance movement in Greece, and the fate of Greece immediately following the end of WWII.

courses.name: Athens through History 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces students to the history of Athens from its earliest settlement in the Bronze Age up to the present day and explore the Athens' contribution to western society.

courses.name: The Balkans: History, Culture, Politics 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to the history, politics, and the culture of the Balkans from the late 1700s to modern times. Focuses on the history of the countries of former Yugoslavia, Greece, Bulgaria, and Romania.

courses.name: Professional Development: Going Global 1 Credit
courses.description: Explores fellowships, internships, graduate schools, and career pathways for students interested in European and international jobs more broadly.

courses.name: European Cinema 4-12 Credits
courses.description: A study of films of one or more of the historically important national cinemas in Europe. The course is taught in English.

courses.name: Culture and Society in Europe 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Examines central issues in one or more of the various cultures and societies in Europe.

courses.name: Greece and Turkey: Myths and Misconceptions 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the major political, historical, and cultural aspects of the animosity between Greeks and Turks. Aims to dispel common myths and misconceptions.

courses.name: Soccer Culture Europe 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines how soccer reflects and shapes continental, national, political, and social culture of modern Europe.

courses.name: History of Turks 3 Credits
courses.description: Broad historical study of the Turks in world history. Emphasizes the Ottoman Turks, the Young Turks, and various upheavals in Turkey alongside social and cultural topics including gender, daily life, workers, and migrations.

courses.name: Istanbul, Not Constantinople: A Global City 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines Istanbul as a global city in historical perspective, including pre-modern political, religious, and military exchanges, modern cultural norms and politics, and the individuals who have shaped the city throughout history.

courses.name: The Other Europe and European Identity 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the construction of “European Identity” in relation to groups, regions, and religions which have been posited as Europe’s “Other.” Introduces a multidisciplinary analytical framework for understanding stereotypes and collective identity.

courses.name: Urban Cultures in Europe 3 Credits
courses.description: Interdisciplinary introduction to the construction of urban spaces in Europe, from the 19th century through today. Examines how urban space structures social and cultural experience.

courses.name: Culture in Crisis: the European Avant-Garde between the Wars 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the ideology and aesthetics of the major movements of the 20th century avant-garde, focusing on developments in Paris, Berlin, Prague and Moscow. (H and N)

courses.name: Islam and Turkey 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores what Islam is and what Turks believe that it is. Also explores Islamic sources, Turkish conversions, Turkish mysticism, and Islamist politics. Explains these topics through the prism of original sources and emphasizes ways cultural forces contribute to the making of modern Islam.

courses.name: Secret Police under Communism 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of the secret-police forces and the political use of terror in the Central-European countries of Germany, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Poland, Romania, and Bulgaria between 1945 and 1990.

courses.name: Socialist Control and Resistance in Eastern Europe After 1945 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the political, intellectual, social and cultural history of Eastern Europe from 1945 to 1990 and discusses ways in which the Soviet leadership manipulated the governing and legal systems of the Easter European Communist countries.

courses.name: European Diplomacy: Power and Principles 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the history of European diplomacy and the critical junctures in its development. Analyzes the distinctive features of the European diplomatic style. Provides an overview of the most contemporary European diplomatic problems.

courses.name: Migration in Europe 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines migration in Europe, examining topics ranging from the first modern refugee crisis in the aftermath of World War I and the Russian Revolution to contemporary debates about immigration in the European Union.

courses.name: Directed Readings in European Studies 1 Credit
courses.description: Rotating readings on a country, region, or current issue in Europe.

courses.name: Undergraduate Seminar in European Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Intermediate rotating topics course on various European issues. (H)

courses.name: Applied European Language 1 Credit
courses.description: An enhancement section designed to accompany and complement area studies courses offered in other departments. Readings and discussions are in a continental European language to enable students to develop specific vocabulary and fluency related to the content of the companion course and to provide them with an international perspective on the issues of the main course.

courses.name: European Less Commonly Taught Languages 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Rotating topics course to facilitate language instruction for European lesser/least commonly taught languages. Instruction is in a European language to enable students to develop relevant competencies in speaking, writing, listening, and comprehension.

courses.name: Politics and Institutions of the European Union 3 Credits
courses.description: History of institutions and theoretical interpretations of European Union (EU) from its origins to present, including some general European history and background of EU's member status.

courses.name: European Union and Its Enlargement 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the European Union's enlargement process and politics, and on the domestic politics of the applicant countries.

courses.name: European Economic Integration: Politics and Policy 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the political economy of European Union (EU) economic integration from an interdisciplinary perspective.

courses.name: Turkey and the EU: History, Present and the Future 3 Credits
