courses.description: The dynamics and developments in Turkish politics with regard to Turkey's EU path. Understand the challenges the EU faces at present with Turkey, as this country's candidacy highlights the unresolved issues facing a more integrated EU.

courses.name: European Union in Crisis 3 Credits
courses.description: Critical and historical approach to the meaning and implication of recent crises in the European Union (EU) by establishing the common occurrence of crises in the history of the EU, examining the unique challenges posed by each crisis, and discussing the future of EU integration following recent crises.

courses.name: Individual Work 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Reading and discussions in advanced topics of European studies.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in European Studies 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Special Topics in European Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced variable-topics course on European issues.

courses.name: JMCE Seminar: EU in Practice 1 Credit
courses.description: Advanced variable topics explore practical applications of policies and theories discussed in academic coursework, and taught by EU practitioners. Transitions students from academic theory to practical application of skills and knowledge.

courses.name: JMCE Seminar: the EU Today 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced variable topics on current European Union issues from multiple disciplinary perspectives. Taught by visiting EU scholars. Can be repeated with change in content up to 6 credits.

courses.name: Internship in European Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Internship with an organization, company, institution, or government entity with 60% or more focus on Europe. Up to three credits of internship credit can be used toward the European Union or East-Central European Studies minor or certificate.

courses.name: Seminar in European Union Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced topics related to the European Union.

courses.name: Overseas Study in Europe 1-6 Credits
courses.description: Advanced course on European issues taught during study abroad in Europe.

courses.name: Beginning Hungarian 1 5 Credits
courses.description: This course and its sequel, HNG 1131, constitute the basic sequence in Hungarian.

courses.name: Beginning Hungarian 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Second semester of basic sequence in Hungarian.

courses.name: Elementary Hungarian: Review and Progress 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Alternative to HNG 1130, for students who have some experience in Hungarian. Reviews basic grammar and improves reading, writing and listening skills.

courses.name: Elementary Hungarian: Review and Progress 2 3 Credits
courses.description: An accelerated one-semester coverage of HNG 1130 and HNG 1131 for students with some experience in Hungarian.

courses.name: Intermediate Hungarian II 3 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study. Goal is to further develop speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills.

courses.name: Intermediate Hungarian 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Build on Hungarian language skills, including reading, writing, speaking, and listening.

courses.name: Beginning Turkish 1 5 Credits
courses.description: This course and its sequel, TUR 1131, constitute the introductory sequence in Turkish.

courses.name: Beginning Turkish 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Second semester of the introductory sequence in Turkish.

courses.name: Intensive Beginning Turkish 5 Credits
courses.description: An intensive introduction to Turkish, using the proficiency method. This course is equivalent to, and substitute for, the UF's first-year Turkish sequence (TUR 1130 / TUR 1131).

courses.name: Intermediate Turkish 1 4 Credits
courses.description: Intermediate study of speaking, reading, writing and listening comprehension skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Intermediate Turkish 2 4 Credits
courses.description: Improves speaking, reading, writing and listening skills by building upon language principles introduced in TUR 2220.

courses.name: Intensive Intermediate Turkish 5 Credits
courses.description: Immersive intermediate study of Turkish. Equivalent to, and substitute for, the second-year sequence of TUR 2220 / TUR 2221. Classes meet daily; see the weekly schedule of topics.

courses.name: Principles of Family, Youth and Community Sciences 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the study and practice of family, youth and community sciences. Presents analytic concepts used in the study of family, youth and community sciences. Emphasizes the vulnerabilities and needs of US children, youth, families, and communities, and describes human services that maximize human potential and minimize personal and societal costs. Introduces the roles and skills of the human service professional.

courses.name: Introduction to Personal and Family Financial Planning 3 Credits
courses.description: Management of personal and family financial resources throughout the life span. A study of individual and family finances as related to planning, credit, saving, investment, insurance, taxes, housing costs, transportation costs, retirement, and estate planning.

courses.name: Parenting and Family Development 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the challenges and changes associated with parenthood. Includes strategies, skills and resources for understanding parenting. Also addresses diverse family types and parenting risks.

courses.name: Contemporary Family Problems and Interventions 3 Credits
courses.description: The major social and family problems contemporary families face, including poverty, violence and care of dependent elders. Emphasizes family strengths and resiliency as well as social programs that help families withstand and overcome difficulties. Emphasizes the role of society, race and gender in constructing family problems.

courses.name: Human Services 3 Credits
courses.description: In-depth look at human services that assist children and families, with focus on income support, child protection, adoption and family support programs offered through human services agencies. Emphasizes professional development of helping skills for working directly with children and families.

courses.name: Foundations of Youth Development 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces youth development principles utilizing an ecological framework, including major theories relevant to domains of development. Then, major physical, cognitive, social and emotional changes experienced by youth in middle childhood through adolescence are explored. Application of youth development principles in context of family, school and community are also emphasized.

courses.name: Introduction to Social and Economic Perspectives on the Community 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the study of community in American society. Addresses the theoretical underpinnings of the concept of community and explores changes that have affected urban and rural communities. (S)

courses.name: Community Food Systems 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines theory and practice in food and agriculture from a social science perspective within the context of sustainable community food systems.

courses.name: Personal and Family Financial Counseling 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines family economics and resource management issues and impact on the well-being of family across the major transitions of the family life-cycle. The complex process of financial decision-making and the role of the financial counselor are addressed.

courses.name: Ethical Issues in Family, Youth and Community Sciences 3 Credits
courses.description: Ethics and ethical decision-making by professionals working individuals and their families is addressed. Emphasizes ethical issues related to family relationships and family life.

courses.name: Urban and Rural America in Transition 3 Credits
courses.description: Communities in America are being confronted with a number of significant changes. Such shifts are not felt in the same manner across various regions or communities in the US. Explore current and emerging issues that have differential consequences for urban and rural areas in this country.

courses.name: Youth and Family Relations 3 Credits
courses.description: Youth within the family system. Reviews basic theory and research on youth development and how it is intertwined with family development, family processes and extended family systems. Students also work with youth and their families.

courses.name: Positive Youth Development for the Youth Professional 3 Credits
courses.description: This course prepares youth development professionals to provide direct service to youth and emerging adults in non-formal settings. Emphasis is placed on the application of positive youth development principles, practices, and professional skills.

courses.name: Children: Trauma & Resiliency 3 Credits
courses.description: Evolving research on the developing child and the neurobiology of trauma has dramatically changed our understanding of adverse childhood experiences and its impact on the growing child. This course focuses on both areas: the nature of childhood trauma and intervention in an ecological context.

courses.name: Contemporary Youth Problems and Solutions 3 Credits
courses.description: Youth development and its ecology, emphasizing the challenges and issues facing adolescents/ youth, and the creation of communities that foster positive youth development and resiliency. Includes theoretical, methodological, empirical and practical issues regarding youth development issues and solutions. Also examines the ecology of youth development, focusing on the dynamics of interactions and reciprocal relationships between youth and various systems of the environment.

courses.name: Engaging Communities for Decision Making and Action 3 Credits
courses.description: Survey citizens and analyze data of scientific, technological, environmental, and societal issues at the community level. Implement and evaluate methodologically correct research that aids in the resolution of issues and improves decision-making skills as they relate to community issues.

courses.name: Organizational Leadership for Nonprofits 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the challenges for nonprofit leaders, incorporating leadership theories as they apply to these organizations. Provides the leadership skills needed to lead nonprofit organizations.

courses.name: Working with Nonprofit Organizations in Community Settings 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of nonprofit organizations, their functions and purpose, how they are organized and operate, and the basic structure of an incorporated nonprofit.

courses.name: Fund Raising for Community Nonprofit Organizations 3 Credits
courses.description: Contemporary fund raising practices in the nonprofit sector applied to community organizations.

courses.name: Risk Management in Nonprofit Organizations 3 Credits
courses.description: Foundation in the theory, principles and techniques associated with risk management. Topics include the nature and purpose of risk management; the general risk management exposures facing nonprofit organizations; and risk financing strategies for nonprofits.

courses.name: Non-Governmental Organizations 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the nature, role, operations and impacts of non-governmental organizations (NGOs) across the globe. Provides a foundation in understanding NGOs within the geographical, social, political and economic realities under which they operate. Lectures, reading assignments, student presentations and a group project are designed for a better understanding of NGO operations.

courses.name: Human Resource Management for Nonprofits 3 Credits
courses.description: Presents the various HRM activities such as recruitment, testing, selection, performance management, labor relations, volunteer management, compensation and training, for more effective management. Experiential exercises are used to simulate personnel/HRM tasks and issues that managers face in nonprofit organizations, such as conflict and leadership.

courses.name: Methods of Family Life Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Educational techniques for family life educators and human science providers who help individuals and families address key issues of development and human relationships at each stage of the life cycle.

courses.name: Planning and Evaluating Family, Youth and Community Science Programs 3 Credits
courses.description: Basic philosophy, theory and process of planning and evaluating family, youth and community programs.

courses.name: Family Policy 3 Credits
courses.description: Understanding how professionals can influence family policy and the impact of government policies on families.

courses.name: Applied Social Research Methods 4 Credits
courses.description: Understand and apply the principles of social science research methods. Learn a variety of research methods and have hands-on experience with data collection and analysis.

courses.name: Advanced Social Research Methods 3 Credits
courses.description: Design, implement, and interpret social research as part of an advanced team. Collaboratively conduct original social research under faculty supervision and produce a manuscript suitable for submission to a scholarly outlet.

courses.name: Supervised Extension Experience in Family, Youth and Community Sciences 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic extension experiences in agricultural and life sciences under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.name: Individual Study in Family, Youth and Community Sciences 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Selected topics and problems related to family, youth and community sciences and the student's specific area of interest.

courses.name: Supervised Research in Family, Youth and Community Sciences 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in family, youth and community sciences under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Honors Thesis Research in Family, Youth and Community Sciences 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Independent research in family, youth and community sciences leading to an honors thesis. Students are mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Personal and Family Financial Planning Capstone 3 Credits
courses.description: Critical thinking and decision making about personal and family financial management in the context of the financial planning process. Analyze and prioritize goals and make recommendations for a client in household accounting, taxes, investments, risk management, retirement planning and estate planning.

courses.name: Family, Youth, and Community Sciences Professional Development 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides a professional development experience for students in FYCS including: search for employment during their final semesters of undergraduate study and information regarding graduate education and research possibilities. Emphasis is placed on career placement, graduate education, practicum readiness, professional business etiquette and elements for a successful transition to the workforce.

courses.name: Special Topics in Family, Youth, and Community Science 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Special topics in Family, Youth, and Community Science.

courses.name: Practicum in Family, Youth and Community Sciences 3-6 Credits
courses.description: Supervised field work experience in a human/community services agency and a professional seminar to discuss student progress, workplace experiences, and the intersectionality of current topics and issues in society as they relate to families, youth, and communities. Required course assignments aid in processing and assessing the practicum experience and relate to professional issues and responsibilities.

courses.name: UF in Ireland Field Study 3 Credits
courses.description: Explore Irish culture through observation, participation, and reflection on a variety of Irish cultural experiences; participate, summarize, and report on a capstone project.

courses.name: Youth Development, Service-Learning and Irish Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides a transformative experiential learning experience in the context of youth development and Irish culture in Ireland. This course will facilitate youth development, service-learning, and cultural learning opportunities, along with collaborating with community-based organizations working to solve local issues and enhance community engagement. Part of a UF study Abroad Program.

courses.name: Visual Anthropology 3 Credits
courses.description: Uses photography and film as tools and products of social science. Ways of describing, analyzing and presenting behavior and cultural ideas through visual means. Projects and laboratory work with visual anthropology. (WR)

courses.name: Late Twentieth Century Art 3 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of mid-twentieth century art (ARH 4453). International art and American diversity in art from about 1970 to the present.

courses.name: History of Photography 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys major technical, stylistic, and critical directions in photography from the 19th century to the present. (H and N)

courses.name: Performance and Installation 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the complex relationships among object, body, site, space, and architecture using various visual media in the creation of installation and performance art.

courses.name: Video Art 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores video with an emphasis on editing and building a personal vocabulary through the electronic image.

courses.name: Video Art: Advanced Projects 3 Credits
courses.description: Focuses on the completion of larger scale student-directed projects with a special emphasis on pre-production planning and advanced editing techniques.

courses.name: Computer Art: Advanced Projects 6 Credits
courses.description: Advanced work in computer-mediated art, including animation and interactive works in both the physical and virtual domain, with special emphasis on completion of larger scale student-directed projects.

courses.name: Integrating Technology in the Elementary Curriculum 3 Credits
courses.description: Prepares elementary majors to effectively use technology in teaching and learning.

courses.name: The Movies as Narrative Art 4 Credits
courses.description: Examines movies as a mode of storytelling by emphasizing the difference between verbal and visual narration, and relation to contemporary thought and values.

courses.name: Introduction to Film: Criticism and Theory 4 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the principal theoretical and critical issues raised by the first century of the cinema.

courses.name: History of Film, Part 1 4 Credits
courses.description: History of film from its beginnings to the introduction of sound.

courses.name: History of Film, Part 2 4 Credits
courses.description: History of film from the introduction of sound to 1960.

courses.name: History of Film, Part 3 4 Credits
courses.description: History of film from 1960 to the present.

courses.name: Race and Ethnicity in Film 4 Credits
courses.description: Critical and historical study of films and videos by and about people of color in the Americas, Africa, Australia and Europe.

courses.name: Film Studies 4 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics provide in-depth study of film genres, notable film directors, and other significant topics on subjects related to film.

courses.name: Women and Film 4 Credits
courses.description: Studies the roles and function of women in mainstream and alternative cinema, including study of feminist film criticism and theories of gender.

courses.name: National Cinemas 4 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics study of the films of historically important national cinemas, such as American, French, German, Italian, Russian, Japanese.

courses.name: Film and Video Production 4 Credits
courses.description: Seminar on the independent and experimental uses of small-format film and video production.

courses.name: Television and Electronic Culture 4 Credits
courses.description: Explores the development of new modes of thought, forms of art, popular culture, and social practices based on the electronic technology of video and computers.

courses.name: French Cinema 4-8 Credits
courses.description: Critical, theoretical and historical study of French cinema. Topics will be announced. Content may include key directors, 1930s cinema, nostalgia and masculinity in 1980s films, World War II cinema, and Colonial and Postcolonial cinema. Open to French majors and non-majors and is taught in English. (H and N)

courses.name: Interdisciplinary Thesis Research 1-12 Credits
courses.description: Research accommodation for thesis. (WR)

courses.name: Italian Cinema 4 Credits
courses.description: Critical and historical study of Italian film and directors. Topics may vary. (H and N)

courses.name: Introduction to Japanese Film 4 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the formal and historical features of Japanese film that have given it a unique position in film history. Emphasizes formal and critical analysis as well as the intellectual stakes of studying non-western film.

courses.name: The Age of the Avant-Garde 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the revolutionary experimentalist aspects of modern and contemporary culture, such as cubism, surrealism, structuralism, and conceptualism.

courses.name: Photography: Color 3 Credits
courses.description: Consideration of the use and technique of color photography. Covers cameras, films, and darkroom developing techniques.

courses.name: Photography: Black and White 3 Credits
courses.description: Fundamentals of photography, operation of the camera and developing, printing, and enlarging. Principles of photography as a means of personal expression.

courses.name: Photography: Digital 3 Credits
courses.description: Studio methods and techniques in creating still images using electronic digital technology.

courses.name: Advanced Photography 6 Credits
courses.description: Use of the camera as a medium of individual creative expression. Experimental projects in black and white and color photography.

courses.name: Introduction to Lighting and Sound 4 Credits
courses.description: Introduces electricity and technical skills basic to lighting and sound technology.

courses.name: Acting 2: Analysis and Application 2 Credits
courses.description: Experimentation with scripted material: scene study, analysis, audition and performance.

courses.name: Directing 3 Credits
courses.description: Practical application of theoretical concepts of directing applied to scene study.

courses.name: Special Projects 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Projects related to finance as approved by the college.

courses.name: Introduction to Financial Planning & Wealth Management 4 Credits
courses.description: An examination of the financial planning process, professional conduct and regulation, and education planning. Students analyze personal financial information, construct financial statements, develop financial strategies, and understand the components of a written financial plan.

courses.name: Business Finance 4 Credits
courses.description: The acquisition and management of funds by business. A minimum grade of B is required in FIN 3403 to register for required finance major courses.

courses.name: Financial Plan Development 4 Credits
courses.description: Capstone course in financial planning. Covers retirement needs, individual, corporate, and government retirement plans, plus group benefits plans. Examines professional issues in financial planning, including ethical considerations, regulation and certification requirements, written and oral communication skills, and professional responsibility. Students develop a comprehensive financial plan.

courses.name: Estate & Tax Planning 4 Credits
courses.description: A focus on the fundamentals of estate planning, including the transfers of wealth by gift or at death. Trusts, guardianships and post mortem planning are covered. Also covers the taxation of income by federal government, focusing on the planning and preparation of federal tax returns around estate planning.

courses.name: Debt and Money Markets 4 Credits
courses.description: Examines financial markets, the institutions and instruments associated with debt funds, and the determinants of the general level and structure of interest rates.

courses.name: Honors Finance 2 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics providing opportunity for in-depth study of topics not offered in other courses.

courses.name: Financial Management 4 Credits
courses.description: An integrative examination of theory and practice of managerial finance, financing and investing decisions as affected by risk, timing and financial markets.

courses.name: Financial Modeling 4 Credits
courses.description: Demonstrates how intricate financial spreadsheet models, along with other modeling tools, can be developed and applied in value creating activities for businesses such as securities modeling, financial statement cash flow modeling, and derivatives modeling.

courses.name: Equity and Capital Markets 4 Credits
courses.description: Examines financial markets, the institutions and instruments associated with equity funds, the mechanics and mathematics of stock prices, security analysis, and the factors influencing stock values.

courses.name: Financial Derivatives 2 Credits
courses.description: The course defines the main kind of derivatives, shows how they are used to achieve various hedging and speculating objectives, introduces a framework for pricing derivatives and studies several applications of derivative-pricing techniques outside derivative markets.

courses.name: Independent Research 1-4 Credits
courses.description: A written report or reports will be required.

courses.name: Special Topics 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Special topics in entrepreneurship related fields of study.

courses.name: International Studies in Finance 1-4 Credits
courses.description: This course provides a mechanism by which coursework taken at a foreign university as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the transcript and counted toward UF graduation.

courses.name: Honors Thesis 1 Credit
courses.description: A thesis is required for award of magna cum laude or summa cum laude designation. To qualify for the thesis option, students normally will have completed 90 semester credits of coursework (exceptions may be made by the honors coordinator) and must have at least the 3.6 GPA required for high honors at the time they enroll. The thesis will be reviewed by at least one faculty member chosen by the honors coordinator from the student's major department.

courses.name: Special Projects 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Projects related to business real estate as approved by the college.

courses.name: Real Estate Analysis 4 Credits
courses.description: Principles of real estate decision making within the context of our economic, social, legal and political-government systems.

courses.name: Real Estate Investment Decision Making 4 Credits
courses.description: Explores real estate investment and the demands, skills and challenges of decision-making for those who make such investments.

courses.name: Independent Research 1-4 Credits
courses.description: A written report or reports will be required.

courses.name: Honors Thesis 1 Credit
courses.description: A thesis is required for award of magna cum laude or summa cum laude designation. To qualify for the thesis option, students normally will have completed 90 semester credits of coursework (exceptions may be made by the honors coordinator) and must have at least the 3.6 GPA required for high honors at the time they enroll. The thesis will be reviewed by at least one faculty member chosen by the honors coordinator from the student's major department.

courses.name: Risk Management and Insurance 4 Credits
courses.description: Identification of various types of risks; principles underlying selection of appropriate means of handling risks; introduction to life, health, property, liability and other area of insurance.

courses.name: Gaming War & Peace in the United States and South Africa 3 Credits
courses.description: Uses role-playing games to investigate conflict and its resolution by simulating the revolutionary chaos in New York (1775–76) and constitutional negotiations for post-apartheid South Africa (1993). Examines the role of the arts in remembering conflict, focusing on monuments.

courses.name: Net Art 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores practical and theoretical issues related to the Internet as a medium for making art rather than as a tool for delivering information. Emphasizes the creation of dynamic and interactive experiences on the web that integrate video, graphics, animation, sound, image, and typography.

courses.name: Advanced Experiments in Art and Technology 3 Credits
courses.description: Special topics course that explores new forms of digital media production. Topics reflect emerging forms of digital media.

courses.name: Graphic Design History II 3 Credits
courses.description: Investigates the diverse cultural functions and critical definitions of graphic design across places and times in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. Introduces broad stylistic movements common to western Europe and North America; interrogates and re-writes a received definition of graphic design which excludes globally diverse artifacts, designers, practices, and users.

courses.name: Compassion and the Arts 3 Credits
courses.description: Students will explore the historical, theoretical, and cultural roots of compassion – or how people respond through empathetic action. Works of art, music, performing arts, literature, philosophy, religion, and history will help students critically reflect on the role of compassion within the human experience including quality of life and citizenship.

courses.name: Introduction to the Arts in Medicine in a Global Context 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the field of arts in medicine in a global context, focusing on the many ways that the arts can be used to enhance health and wellbeing in healthcare or community settings and the relationship of culture to healing practices, systems, and health literacy in various regions of the world.

courses.name: Special Topics in Fine Arts 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics course exploring the interaction between various arts and between the arts and other disciplines.

courses.name: Visual Arts in Medicine 3 Credits
courses.description: Explore the intersections of the visual arts and health and investigate how the visual arts can support health and well-being. Acquire fundamental research and communication skills for scholarly discussion of arts in health as well as practical application.

courses.name: Music and Health 3 Credits
courses.description: Review music therapy and music in health research to assess, orally and in scholarly writing, how music can be utilized to enhance well-being, the intersections between music and psychology/cognition/human behavior, as well as health maintenance issues and medical challenges of performing artists.

courses.name: Applied Theater for Health II: Collective Creation Lab 3 Credits
courses.description: Apply knowledge acquired in Applied Theater for Health I to create an original project or workshop on a chosen health topic. Collaborate to research, develop, and conduct theater for health workshops in partnership with a community or campus organization.

courses.name: Arts in Medicine Practicum 1 2 Credits
courses.description: Provides basic to intermediate-level mentored practice in the arts in healthcare in a clinical or community environment. Emphasizes a primary discipline while deepening the understanding of the practice through documentation  self-assessment  and a culminating paper.

courses.name: Music in Medicine Capstone 3 Credits
courses.description: Culminating course in the Music in Medicine certificate. Conduct a thorough literature review and develop a capstone proposal and project related to the intersections of music and health in healthcare or community settings to assess, orally and in scholarly writing, and how music can be utilized to enhance wellbeing.

courses.name: Fine Arts Undergraduate Research 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides an opportunity for firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or creative application, depending on the topic. Projects are supervised by an advising faculty member or a grad student working under faculty supervision.

courses.name: Special Topics in Fine Arts 1-3 Credits
courses.description: An upper division general fine arts special/rotating topics on various subjects in the arts.

courses.name: Overseas Studies in Fine and Performing Arts 1-18 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study-abroad program can be recorded on the transcript and counted toward UF graduation.

courses.name: Programming for Artists 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces understanding interactivity as an art form, providing an in-depth exploration of the tools, theories and applications of interactive media as they are used for creative inquiry, research and production.

courses.name: Emergency Management Internship 3 Credits
courses.description: Gain experience in an emergency management situation to identify and apply best practices in the development of preparation, planning, responding, recovering, and mitigating disasters; participate in supervised disaster management work activities that provide experiential learning in emergency management.

courses.name: Political and Legal Foundations of Fire Protection 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the legal aspects of fire service and the political and social impacts of legal issues; reviews the American legal system and covers legal and political issues involving employment and personnel matters, administration and operations, and planning and code enforcement with regard to the fire service.

courses.name: Principles of Fire and Emergency Services Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Fundamentals of management underlying the solution of problems of organization and operation of fire and emergency services agencies. (S) (WR)

courses.name: FES Communication and Informational Technology 3 Credits
courses.description: Communications systems used in fire and emergency services such as high frequency voice/data, Internets and Intranets, satellite communications, GPS and GIS. An introduction, examination, equipment assessment, implementation program and maintenance management module are provided for each system covered.

courses.name: Foundations of EMS 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers the design and operation of EMS systems, service delivery, and echelons of care. The history of EMS, interface of public and private organizations and review of the various personnel who comprise these systems, will be examined in relation to their impact on the health care delivery system.

courses.name: Ambulance Operations 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of the application of management principles to the provision of medical transport services. Includes an analysis of the economic, geographic, temporal, and clinical characteristics of ambulance demand, the key processes for providing transport services, and an evaluation of industry best practices.

courses.name: EMS Safety and Risk Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the risk management principles of an EMS agency. Emphasizes safety from the perspective of the field provider.

courses.name: Public Safety Educator 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the EMS professional to the education system as it relates to EMS education. Explores issues in curriculum development, teaching, program direction, and development.

courses.name: Management of Emergency Medical Services 3 Credits
courses.description: Personnel and resource management issues in providing emergency medical services function. Quality assurance, utilization review techniques, and practices and techniques for delivery of services and distribution of resources are included.

courses.name: Advanced Leadership Issues in Emergency Medical Services 3 Credits
courses.description: Organizational development issues in providing emergency medical services function in the fire-based, hospital-based and third-service environments. Establishing and directing emergency medical services' work teams is also covered.

courses.name: Community Risk Reduction for Emergency Services 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides a theoretical framework for the understanding of the ethical, sociological, organizational, political, and legal components of community risk reduction, and a methodology for the development of a comprehensive community risk reduction plan.

courses.name: Strategic Planning for FES 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides the conceptual framework for the development of a strategic plan for emergency management, fire protection, and emergency medical service. Also provides guidance through the process of the needs, resources, and capabilities of the organization and how to establish a plan to achieve improved performance.

courses.name: Fire and Emergency Services Financial Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Planning, developing, presenting, funding and implementing a budget for a fire and emergency services agency. Additional topics include special taxing districts, bond issues and fund-raising campaigns.

courses.name: Analytical Approaches to Fire Protection 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the tools and techniques of rational decision making in fire and emergency services agencies, including data collection, statistics, probability, decision analysis, utility modeling, resource allocation, and cost benefit analysis.

courses.name: Applications of Fire Research 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines methodology for analyzing fire-related research; provides a framework for independent research in fire dynamics, fire test standards, fire safety, fire modeling, structural fire safety, life-safety, firefighter safety, automatic detection and suppression, risk analysis and loss control, applied research, and fire-related research trends.

courses.name: Multi-Agency Incident Command 3 Credits
courses.description: Managing complex incidents that may require response from fire-rescue, emergency medical services, law enforcement and/or other public safety sectors. Use of the incident management system is emphasized.

courses.name: Command and Control at Catastrophic Fire-Rescue Incidents 3 Credits
courses.description: Incident command at multiple-alarm incidents, emphasizing rapid fireground decision-making, safety, personnel accountability and communications. Settings for scenarios include multi-family occupancies, hotels, high-rises, healthcare facilities and large retail centers.

courses.name: Disaster Policy in Emergency Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Describes the functional demands that emergency managers should be aware of in crafting effective emergency management plans, policies, and programs. Addresses how public policy choices impact emergency planning and the consequences of a disaster event. Emphasizes the emergency planning process.

courses.name: Fire and Emergency Services Administration 3 Credits
courses.description: Demonstrates the importance of persuasion and influence, budgeting, anticipation of challenges and change, and management tools for analyzing and solving problems; explores how the leadership of a fire and emergency services department develops internal and external cooperation to achieve the department's mission.

courses.name: Foundations of Emergency Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the history and the principles establishing Emergency Management in the United States. Describes the "Four Phases of Emergency Management," relates processes to codes and laws governing Emergency Management, and examines Emergency Management and the terrorist threat.

courses.name: Fire and Emergency Services Ethical Practices and Leadership 3 Credits
courses.description: The role of agency leadership and its impact on the continuing professionalization of the fire and emergency services. Examines traditional and evolving definitions, practices and skills in leadership behavior, including discussions of power, influence, ethics and organizational behavior.

courses.name: Regulatory Issues in Fire and Emergency Services 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces safety, health and environmental regulations on the state and federal levels that impact the delivery of fire and emergency services. OSHA, EPA and NFPA regulatory requirements are introduced along with methods and techniques to implement compliance programs.

courses.name: Fire and Emergency Services Human Resource Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Major human resource management functional areas for fire and emergency services agencies. Topics include organizational employment planning, employment regulation, job analysis, performance assessment, recruitment and regulation, job analysis, performance assessment, recruitment and selection, training and development, employee/labor relations and compensation.

courses.name: Fire and Emergency Services Public Relations 3 Credits
courses.description: Implementation of principles and methods in advocating factual claims and policy proposals: prepositional analysis, evidence as demonstration, effective reasoning processes and ethics in controversy. Also focuses on public speaking and presentations, especially in the areas of technology, defense of budgets and political leadership.

courses.name: Management of Mass Casualty Incidents 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers systematic approaches to triage, treatment and transport in response to large-scale emergency medical services incidents. Resource planning and coordination with hospital systems is also emphasized.

courses.name: EMS Special Operations 3 Credits
courses.description: Discusses the various special roles in which EMS personnel may serve, such as hazardous materials, water rescue, and technical rescue.

courses.name: EMS Community Risk Reduction 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides a theoretical framework for the understanding of the ethical, sociological, organizational, political, and legal components of community risk reduction, and a methodology for the development of a comprehensive community risk reduction plan.

courses.name: Legal, Political, and Regulatory in EMS 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the EMS professional to the legal aspects of Emergency Medical Services. Explores issues in malpractice, consent and refusal of treatment, OSHA, employment issues, and risk management. EMS students gain insights into the legal liabilities in Emergency Medical Services.

courses.name: Quality Management and Research in Emergency Services 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the EMS professional to benefits of quality improvement, the history of quality in EMS, measuring quality, and the uses of quality in EMS.

courses.name: Management of Fire Prevention Programs 3 Credits
courses.description: Planning, promoting and executing fire prevention functions, including an emphasis on legal responsibilities, needs assessments, negotiation and planning activities.

courses.name: Fire Investigation and Analysis 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the technical, investigative, legal, and social aspects of arson, including principles of incendiary fire analysis and detection, environmental and psychological factors of arson, legal considerations, intervention, and mitigation strategies.

courses.name: Disaster Recovery and Mitigation 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides the opportunity to understand real world disaster response efforts through academic study and interactive applied activities. Topics include the Incident Command System (ICS), Emergency Operations Center (EOC) management, Resource Management (RM), and Command-Communications-Coordination (C3).

courses.name: Critical Incident Management for Emergency Managers 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines disaster planning and emergency management. Focuses on the four phases of planning, mitigation, response, and preparedness. Includes FEMA and federal government NIMS ICS-700 and ICS-800 certifications.

courses.name: Disaster Planning and Control 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines concepts and principles of community risk assessment, planning and response to fires and natural and human-caused disasters, including National Incident Management System--Incident Command Systems (NIMS ICS), mutual aid and automatic response, training and preparedness, communications, civil disturbances, terrorist threats/incidents, hazardous materials planning, mass casualty incidents, earthquake preparedness, and disaster mitigation and recovery.

courses.name: Natural Disaster Phenomena in Florida 3 Credits
courses.description: Natural disasters prevalent in Florida: past, present, and future, including hurricanes, flooding, freezes, and agricultural emergencies. Also addresses planning, operations, mitigation, recovery, and evaluation concerns.

courses.name: Introduction to Terrorism in Emergency Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the fundamental concepts, theories, principles, and practice of terrorism and terrorist events.

courses.name: Special Studies in Fire and Emergency Services 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Special areas of study in fire and emergency services adjusted to the needs of individual students.

courses.name: Current Issues in Fire and Emergency Services 3 Credits
courses.description: Information and direction for fire service administrators on current legislative, legal, labor and/or technology concerns facing fire and emergency services agencies.

courses.name: Sustainable Fisheries 3 Credits
courses.description: Fish biology, ecology, and habitats relevant to fisheries on both a global and regional (Florida) scale. Follows the fisheries occurring from cold mountain rivers to the depths of the oceans, with special topics (e.g., artificial reefs, fisheries bycatch, and aquaculture). Intended for non-science and science majors.

courses.name: Aquaculture I 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of the field of aquaculture, including water quality, production systems, nutrition, spawning, and the common fish and invertebrate groups cultured in the United States. Entirely web-based with narrated PowerPoint lectures followed by readings and other resources for each learning topic. Includes weekly topics in asynchronous class discussions.

courses.name: Field Ecology of Aquatic Organisms 3 Credits
courses.description: This field-oriented course is intended to introduce students to the diverse aquatic habitats found in Florida, their associated flora and fauna, and serve as an introduction to the management issues facing state and federal conservation agencies. Students will gain an understanding of plant and animal community structure across a range of ponds, lakes, rivers, and nearshore coastal systems. Extensive field trips are required and comprise approximately 75% of the total class time.

courses.name: Biology of Fishes 4 Credits
courses.description: The general biology of fishes, with emphasis on trends in their evolution, integrative and sensory biology, physiology, feeding ecology, reproduction, growth and population dynamics as they relate to fisheries.

courses.name: Marine Ecological Processes 3 Credits
courses.description: The ecology of marine organisms and habitats with focus on how general ecological principles, and those unique to the marine environment, drive patterns and processes.

courses.name: Invasion Ecology of Aquatic Animals 3 Credits
courses.description: Comprehensive overview of invasion ecology which highlights aspects related to aquatic animals, including ecological concepts and debates underlying this developing field; biology and life history of nonnative aquatic animals, including characteristics of successful invaders; risk analysis methodology; and the conservation and regulatory implications of nonnative aquatic species.

courses.name: Freshwater Ecology 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides an understanding of the concepts in freshwater ecology which are important for controlling the traits, distribution, and abundance of aquatic organisms. Focuses on the major groups of organisms found in freshwater habitats, the physical and chemical properties that are important for structuring freshwater communities, and the ecological processes that affect freshwater communities and ecosystems.

courses.name: Spatial Sciences for Marine Environmental Characterization 4 Credits
courses.description: Exploration of the geospatial technologies, concepts, and methods required to acquire, analyze, and manage geographic data used in a context of marine habitat mapping. Emphasizes understanding and appreciation of maps as a mean of communication between stakeholders with different backgrounds and expertise.

courses.name: Introduction to Fishery Science 3 Credits
courses.description: Principles of fish management in freshwater and marine systems. Includes field and laboratory techniques for aquatic habitat and fishery resource assessment, aquaculture practices and consideration of contemporary issues pertinent to sport and commercial uses of renewable fisheries resources.

courses.name: Marine Protected Areas 3 Credits
courses.description: Presents the history and logic of marine protected areas (MPAs) and their advantages and disadvantages. Explains the science of MPAs as well as an overview of traditional approaches of fisheries management. Also emphasizes the importance of ecological principles when creating an MPA. Finally, presents an overview of sampling theory and the need for empirical data to document the success or failure of MPAs.

courses.name: Marine Adaptations: Environmental Physiology 3 Credits
courses.description: Focuses on the responses of species and habitats to stressors encountered in the marine environment, such as the physiological responses to salinity, hypoxia, ocean acidification, thermal stress, pollutants, nitrogen stress, UV radiation, and noise. Explore these physiological stressors as drivers of marine ecological processes in a wide array of marine habitats, as well as societal, economic, and management implications.

courses.name: Aquariums, Water and Aquaculture 3 Credits
courses.description: Culture methods of fish and shellfish, species selection, biological and environmental principles, case histories and future trends.

courses.name: Supervised Extension Experience in Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic Extension experiences in fisheries and aquatic sciences under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.name: Individual Study 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Individual study of a selected topic in fisheries and aquatic sciences as contracted with the instructor at the start of the term.

courses.name: Supervised Research in Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in fisheries and aquatic sciences under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Honors Thesis Research in Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Independent research in fisheries and aquatic sciences leading to an honors thesis. Student will be mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Topics in Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Selected topics in fisheries biology, aquaculture and associated aquatic sciences not offered in other courses.

courses.name: Seminar in Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences 1 Credit
courses.description: Introduces contemporary topics in the field of fisheries and aquatic sciences and develops listening and writing skills.

courses.name: Openwater Scuba Diving 2 Credits
courses.description: Beginning scuba diving including compass navigation, openwater diving environment, dive preparation and five openwater dives. Payment of required additional course fees and successful completion results in national certification as Openwater Scuba Diver.

courses.name: Advanced Scuba Diving 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides advanced SCUBA training. Topics include physics, physiology, decompression, and oceanography/ecology. Pool sessions cover rescue, double cylinders, full facemasks, night/limited visibility techniques, search, recovery, salvage techniques, and underwater task loading. Completion results in NAUI certification in Advanced SCUBA, Enriched Air Nitrox, SCUBA Rescue, First Aid, CPR, and Oxygen Provider.

courses.name: Scuba Leadership I 1 Credit
courses.description: This 4-week course provides high-level recreational SCUBA training as well as introductory professional leadership level training in accordance with National Association of Underwater Instructors (NAUI) Divemaster standards. This course is taught consecutively following PEN 3139C and is a prerequisite for PEN 4145C and part of the progression for NAUI professional Instructor certification.

courses.name: Master Scuba Diver 3 Credits
courses.description: This 10-week course provides high-level recreational SCUBA training in accordance with National Association of Underwater Instructors (NAUI) Master Diver standards. This course is a prerequisite for PEN 4145C. Successful students can earn NAUI Master Diver credentials.

courses.name: Scuba Leadership II: Research Divemaster 3 Credits
courses.description: This 15-week advanced course builds upon the professional leadership level training of Scuba Leadership 1 in accordance with National Association of Underwater Instructors (NAUI) Divemaster standards. This includes gear repair and maintenance, planning and leading dives, conducting discover scuba sessions, and assisting with instruction. This course is part of the progression for NAUI professional Instructor certification.

courses.name: Aquatic Weed Control 3 Credits
courses.description: Florida's aquatic weed problems and methods of chemical, biological, mechanical and physical weed control. Topics include plant biology/ecology, herbicide residue, lake reclamation, fish-plant interactions and laws regulating aquatic weed control.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Biochemistry 4 Credits
courses.description: Introducing biochemistry with emphasis on intermediary metabolism.

courses.name: Community Nutrition 2 Credits
courses.description: Role of nutrition in promoting, maintaining and improving health in the community. Investigation of traditional aspects of the emerging health delivery systems, as well as entrepreneurial ventures in wellness. Study the financial, legislative, political, sociological, and scientific aspects of public and community health.

courses.name: Food Systems Management 3 Credits
courses.description: The management of human resources, food, equipment and facilities to provide a quality product and service to customers in a food service operation.

courses.name: Food Systems Management Laboratory 2 Credits
courses.description: The application of principles of food systems management, including purchasing, production, service, sanitation and safety.

courses.name: Medical Nutrition Therapy Applications: Part 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Part one of a 2-semester sequence focusing on application of the nutrition care planning process. Includes development of nutrition assessment skills and formulation of nutrition care plans for simulated patients, including those requiring enternal and parenteral nutrition.

courses.name: Medical Nutrition Therapy Applications: Part 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Part two of a 2-semester sequence that focuses on attainment of knowledge to make nutrition diagnoses, to develop and implement effective nutrition intervention strategies and to identify appropriate monitoring and evaluation plans for patients with common chronic diseases and disorders.

courses.name: Nutrition Counseling and Communication 2 Credits
courses.description: Application of principles of group dynamics and group and interpersonal counseling skills in dietetics practice settings. Provides hands-on experiences in counseling and in oral and written communication.

courses.name: Dietetics Seminar 1 Credit
courses.description: Capstone course for dietetic majors; focuses on professional issues, including ethics, legislative issues, advocating and marketing the profession.

courses.name: Supervised Extension Experience in Dietetics 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic extension experiences in dietetics under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.name: Problems in Dietetics 1-5 Credits
courses.description: Individual research work in various phases of dietetics.

courses.name: Supervised Research in Dietetics 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in dietetics under faculty member supervision. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Honors Thesis Research in Dietetics 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Independent research in dietetics leading to an honors thesis. Student is mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Topics in Dietetics 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Lectures, conference, laboratory or clinical experience covering selected topics in dietetics.

courses.name: Man's Food 3 Credits
courses.description: Discussion of current nutrition and food science topics concerning nutritional quality and safety of foods as they relate to one's health. For science and non-science students. (B)

courses.name: Introductory Food Science 3 Credits
courses.description: Commodities selected for human consumption and the methods used by food technologists to prolong shelf life, retard spoilage and ensure quality. Principles upon which the various processing methodologies are based. (B)

courses.name: Life After Graduation 1 Credit
courses.description: Overview of available opportunities for Food Science students after graduation, and tips and advice on how to be successful after graduation. Intended for all Food Science majors, especially those preparing to graduate within the academic year.

courses.name: Food Safety and Sanitation 2 Credits
courses.description: Lectures, discussions, demonstrations and field trips concerning microbial, chemical and biological safety of food, principles of sanitation for the food processing, food service and retail food industries.

courses.name: Food Microbiology 3-4 Credits
courses.description: Sources and types of biological contamination and its control during harvesting, processing and storage of foods; food fermentation; biotechnology sanitation; HACCP methods used to examine foods for microbial content.

courses.name: Food Microbiology Laboratory 2 Credits
courses.description: Methods to enumerate microorganisms in foods.

courses.name: Food and Environmental Virology 2 Credits
courses.description: An emerging topic in the field of microbial food safety, food virology explores the role of viruses as human pathogens; their interactions with bacteria; transmission to food, water, and contact surfaces; detection; and prevention strategies. Through this course, students can develop a competency framework within their discipline.

courses.name: Principles of Food Safety Systems 2 Credits
courses.description: This course is designed to cover 1) current issues in food supply chain including security and safety in domestic and international food industry, 2) various food safety control systems, 3) principles of HACCP and FSMA Preventive controls. The course also provides hands-on practice in developing a food safety plan.

courses.name: Experimental Foods Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Demonstrations and illustrations of the chemical and physical properties of foods. Shows the effects of processing, ingredients and storage on food quality and nutrient retention.

courses.name: Food Chemistry 3 Credits
courses.description: Relationship of composition to the properties of foods and the changes which occur during processing, storage and utilization.

courses.name: Food Chemistry Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Laboratory covering the relationship of composition to the properties of foods and the changes which occur during processing, storage and utilization.

courses.name: Flavor Chemistry 3 Credits
courses.description: Learn how flavor chemicals impact sensory perception of food; discuss flavor compounds used in foods, their production, isolation, analysis, and specific attributes.

courses.name: Food Analysis 4 Credits
courses.description: Principles and practice of physical and chemical methods for analyzing foods. (P)

courses.name: Introduction to Unit Operations in Food Processing 4 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the fundamentals of food processing for non-engineering students. Applies primary concepts in context of the field of food science, including Engineering Units, Food Properties, Microbial Death, Conduction, Phase Changes, Convection, Heat Exchangers, Steady-State-Heat-Transfer, Extrusion, Unsteady-State-Heat-Transfer, and Radiation.

courses.name: Principles of Food Processing 4 Credits
courses.description: Principles of processing foods: cooling, freezing, heating, dehydrating, concentrating, irradiating, fermenting and the use of chemicals.

courses.name: Food Product Development 3 Credits
courses.description: Capstone course integrating food science and related disciplines to value-added food products using traditional and novel commodity, ingredient and process combinations. Class projects emphasize technology, safety, health/nutrition, legal, quality and economic/ marketing considerations.

courses.name: Seafood Technology 3 Credits
courses.description: Processing principles and methods of preparation of various seafood products and control of product quality.

courses.name: Quality Control in Food Systems 3 Credits
courses.description: Measurement and control of the major quality parameters of foods, including sensory, color and texture.

courses.name: Government Regulations and the Food Industry 2 Credits
courses.description: Government laws regulating food wholesomeness; food handling, processing and distribution under sanitary conditions; food ingredients and labeling of food products.

courses.name: Special Problems in Food Science 1-5 Credits
courses.description: Individual research work in various phases of food science.

courses.name: Supervised Extension Experience in Food Science 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic extension experiences in agricultural and life sciences under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.name: Supervised Research in Food Science 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in food science under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Honors Thesis Research in Food Science 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Independent research in food science leading to an honors thesis. Student is mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Topics in Food Science 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Lectures, conferences or laboratory covering specially selected topics in food science.

courses.name: Full-Time Practical Work Experience in Food Science 1-3 Credits
courses.description: One-term employment in industry, including extra work according to a pre-approved outline. Practical work under industrial supervision as set forth in College of Agricultural and Life Sciences regulations.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Human Nutrition 3 Credits
courses.description: The properties, functions, requirements, interrelationships and metabolism of nutrients. (B)

courses.name: Nutrition through the Life Cycle 2 Credits
courses.description: Nutritional needs and concerns throughout stages of the life cycle including pregnancy and lactation, infancy, adolescence, adulthood, and aging; socioeconomic, cultural and psychological influences on food and nutrition behavior.

courses.name: Nutrition and Metabolism 3 Credits
courses.description: Metabolic relationships of nutrients with emphasis upon their functions in biochemical and physiological processes as well as variations in requirements in response to stress. Meets requirements of the American Dietetic Association.

courses.name: Nutrition and Disease: Part 1 2 Credits
courses.description: Part one of a two-semester sequence that focuses on the biochemical and pathophysiological bases of disease/conditions that require specialized nutrition support/medical nutrition therapy.

courses.name: Nutrition and Disease: Part 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Part two of the sequence that focuses on the biochemical and pathophysiological bases of disease/conditions that require specialized nutrition support/medical nutrition therapy.

courses.name: Laboratory Techniques in Molecular Nutrition 3 Credits
courses.description: Laboratory techniques relevant to the study of nutrition, ranging from biochemistry, molecular biology, genomics and bioinformatics.

courses.name: Supervised Extension Experience in Nutritional Sciences 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic extension experiences in agricultural and life sciences under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.name: Special Problems in Human Nutrition 1-5 Credits
courses.description: Individual research work in various phases of nutrition.

courses.name: Supervised Research in Nutritional Sciences 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in nutritional sciences under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Honors Thesis Research in Nutritional Sciences 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Independent research in nutritional sciences leading to an honors thesis. Student is mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Topics in Human Nutrition 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Lectures or laboratory covering selected topics in human nutrition.

courses.name: Full Time Practical Work Experience in Human Nutrition 1-3 Credits
courses.description: One-term employment in industry or the health field according to a pre-approved outline. Practical work under supervision as set forth in College of Agricultural and Life Sciences regulations.

courses.name: Economic Issues, Food and You 3 Credits
courses.description: The role of agriculture and economics: the how's and why's of their influence on food prices and the world food situation, the environment, natural resources and government policy; and economic issues, including inflation and money. (S)

courses.name: Economics of Resource Use 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces how economists value the environment and regulations designed to protect our natural resources from overuse and degradation. (S)

courses.name: Principles of Food and Resource Economics 4 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the field of food and resource economics, the principles of economics as applied to agriculture, and the economic problems of the agricultural industry and the individual farmer. (S)

courses.name: Introduction to Agricultural Computer Applications 1 Credit
courses.description: Introduces computer application with specific emphasis on applications used in agricultural businesses. Specific applications include spreadsheets, databases, word processing and DOS.

courses.name: Financial Planning for Agribusiness 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces basic financial and managerial decision-making for small agribusinesses.

courses.name: Principles of Agribusiness Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces agribusiness management principles, application of economic principles, budgeting techniques, and principles of strategy in agribusiness from management in the United States, particularly Florida. Emphasizes the financial and tax management strategies and the requirements imposed on agribusiness management by local, state and federal government regulatory agencies.

courses.name: Introduction to Agricultural Finance 3 Credits
courses.description: Basic financial statements, investment frameworks and theories of financial intermediation as applied to agricultural firms, along with an overview of financial institutions that provide capital to agriculture.

courses.name: Agricultural Macroeconomics 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the world economy from a macroeconomic perspective that focuses on the links that arise from international trade and capital flows in the agricultural sector.

courses.name: Agricultural and Food Marketing 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines agricultural and food marketing from a system and individual firm perspective. Explores problems and issues associated with marketing functions and institutions at the industry level and with objectives and strategies of farms and agribusiness firms that market agricultural commodities and food products.

courses.name: Futures Markets and Risk Management in Agriculture 3 Credits
courses.description: Basic elements and principles of agricultural commodity marketing with emphasis on the futures industry. Includes use of futures markets for speculating and risk management for agriculture and finance. Participation in a computerized futures trading game is required.

courses.name: Selling Strategically 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces professional selling techniques for all products with special emphasis given to food and agricultural products, technical systems and services.

courses.name: Introduction to Natural Resource and Environmental Economics 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces natural and environmental resource economics. Emphasizes understanding economic concepts such as resource scarcity, market failure, externality, property rights and common property resources and their application to studies of forest, land, water, energy and coastal resources.

courses.name: Quantitative Methods in Food and Resource Economics 3 Credits
courses.description: Develops understanding of finite mathematical tools used in economics and business decision making. Topics include linear equations, matrix algebra and calculus. Lectures and problems show how these tools are used to examine economic, financial and managerial problems.

courses.name: Agricultural Data Analysis in Food and Resource Economics 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces analysis of agricultural data. Incorporates statistical and agricultural economic theory into the analysis of agricultural problems. Knowledge in use of spreadsheets is assumed.

courses.name: Comparative World Agriculture 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the business and economic situations of the food and agriculture sector around the world. Focuses on the historical development, the current situation and the future outlook of the food and agriculture sector. (N and S)

courses.name: Food and Resource Economics Seminar 1 Credit
courses.description: Introduces the Department of Food and Resource Economics and career opportunities for its graduates.

courses.name: Agricultural Risk Management and the Law 3 Credits
courses.description: Develops an understanding of the basic concepts of common and statutory law. Identifies and addresses current legal issues of importance at the personal and professional levels. Develops an understanding of risk and the solutions for managing risk and relates the concepts of risk management and law in limiting exposure to legal liability.

courses.name: Agricultural and Natural Resource Law 3 Credits
courses.description: Legal aspects of agricultural rights, responsibilities and problems. Topics include agricultural estate and income taxation, zoning and land use planning, Capper-Volstead Act, international agricultural agreements, agricultural labor and consumer protection.

courses.name: Agricultural and Natural Resource Ethics 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the political, economic, environmental and ethical value issues involved in agricultural practices and policies, including agricultural research. (H or S) (WR)

courses.name: Advanced Agribusiness Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Integration of finance and management to solve problems faced by agricultural firms and agribusinesses. In addition to lectures, students will work in small groups to identify and to analyze case studies from agricultural and rural businesses.

courses.name: International Trade Policy in Agriculture 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the role of international trade policy in agriculture and examines the effects of trade policies on domestic and international prices, consumption, production, trade and government revenues. Addresses impact of current trade issues on the agricultural sector. (S)

courses.name: International Humanitarian Assistance 3 Credits
courses.description: Emergency assistance to developing countries to minimize losses and affect recovery. Includes legal/ethical bases; program designs promoting recovery, rather than dependence; cultural issues, including gender; and technical aspects. (N and S)

courses.name: International Development Policy 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies how factors such as poverty, population, technology, resources, trade, and the environment affect the human effort to develop. Discusses the roles of the public and private sectors as well as the process of policy formulation and implementation. Emphasizes the agricultural sector and its role in the process of economic development, especially in countries where problems of hunger, demographic pressure, and poverty are pervasive.

courses.name: Agricultural Marketing Strategies 2 3 Credits
courses.description: The strategic process of formulating and implementing marketing strategies unique to the agriculture industry.

courses.name: Food Wholesaling and Retail Marketing 3 Credits
courses.description: Food industry trends, issues and opportunities that exist in the US and the world. Guest lecturers and recent trade publications provide students with a command of wholesaling and retail food management.

courses.name: Contemporary Issues in Agribusiness Management 3 Credits
courses.description: A capstone course utilizing economic concepts to address the interaction between the political process that legislates domestic agricultural, environmental and international trade policy, micro and macro economic principles, private business decisions taken by firms in response to public policies, and ethical considerations in developing and implementing public policy.

courses.name: Agricultural Price Analysis and Consumer Behavior 3 Credits
courses.description: Quantitative measurement of factors affecting agricultural and resource prices; seasonal and cyclical fluctuations; index measures of price and quantity variables; theory and application of consumer behavior principles.

courses.name: Agribusiness and Food Marketing Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Application of marketing and management principles to agribusiness and food marketing problems faced by managers. Emphasis on case problems, group projects, oral presentations and written assignments.

courses.name: International Agribusiness Marketing 3 Credits
courses.description: Problems, issues, regulations, policies and procedures unique to the global agribusiness marketing of perishable and storable agricultural commodities and food products. Combines firm-level agribusiness marketing concepts with international agribusiness marketing and export management applications. (S)

courses.name: Advanced Agricultural Microeconomics 3 Credits
courses.description: Rigorous training in the fundamental mathematical models underlying the basic microeconomics principles; an in-depth analysis of key microeconomics concepts including consumer and producer theory, risk and uncertainty game theory, and asymmetric information. Uses mathematical and graphical methods to help illustrate the different concepts.

courses.name: Agricultural Marketing Strategies 3 Credits
courses.description: The decision-making activities necessary to launch a new agricultural product successfully. The marketing plan development for this course follows the guidelines of the National Agri-Marketing Association Marketing Competition.

courses.name: Human Resources Management in Agribusiness 3 Credits
courses.description: Issues involved in the strategic and effective management of human resources in agribusiness. Human resource management concepts and techniques designed to improve agribusiness organizational teamwork, productivity, performance and enterprise success. Course explores the unique aspects of labor management and includes application through use of case problems, triad and video techniques.

courses.name: International Agricultural Trade 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the economic forces associated with trade in food and agricultural products between the US and other countries. Applies economics principles and analytical techniques to international agricultural trade and multi-national markets.

courses.name: Supervised Extension Experience in Food and Resource Economics 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic extension experiences in agricultural and life sciences under faculty member supervision. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.name: Special Problems in Food and Resource Economics 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Individual study in selected problem areas of interest to the student and agreeable to the instructor.

courses.name: Supervised Research in Food and Resource Economics 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in food and resource economics under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.
