courses.description: Provides the skills to analyze data and construct simple numerical models to investigate problems in earth sciences. Topics include statistical/time series/geospatial analyses, dynamic systems modeling, and numerical solutions to differential equations.

courses.name: Individual Work 1-3 Credits
courses.description: For work in addition to that offered in regular courses in mineralogy, petrology, paleontology, stratigraphy, sedimentology and structural geology.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Geology 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in geology. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in geology.

courses.name: Special Topics in Geology 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Lecture, conferences or laboratory sessions covering selected topics of current interest in modern geology.

courses.name: Introduction to Oceanography 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the geological, physical, and biological characteristics of Earths marine realm. Includes discussion of scientific methods, the history of oceanography, and emphasizes understanding of the mutual interactions between humans and the ocean. (P)

courses.name: Geographic Information Systems 3 Credits
courses.description: Addresses GIS concepts, data sources, spatial references: GIS data modeling, management, and editing; surface modeling; and vector and raster analysis. Provides practical examples, tutorials, and projects serving the geomatics, natural resource management, and planning fields.

courses.name: Geospatial Analysis 3 Credits
courses.description: Process of identifying and analyzing patterns in geographic data and describing relationships between spatial features. Introduces techniques aimed at the analysis of spatial data. Topics include characterization of spatial data, geographic distributions, pattern identification (point and area objects), field data analysis, spatial modeling and interpolation, regression methods and cluster analysis.

courses.name: Geomatics 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces angle, distance and elevation measurement, as applied to engineering, boundary location, topography, forest management and construction. Covers error theory as well as horizontal and vertical curves.

courses.name: Visualization of Spatial Information 3 Credits
courses.description: Methods of mapping, modeling, communicating and visualizing spatial features. Includes boundary and topographical features, attributes, site modeling, site development and mapping using computer-aided mapping and design features.

courses.name: Photogrammetry 3 Credits
courses.description: Relates to use of aerial photographs to determine spatial information. Covers elementary techniques of photogrammetry to establish the foundation for SUR 4350 Advanced Photogrammetry.

courses.name: Measurement Science 3 Credits
courses.description: Theory of measurement errors, error propagation, variance and covariance, polynomial curve fitting, regression analysis, correlation and least squares adjustment.

courses.name: Survey Computations 3 Credits
courses.description: Principles of geometry applied to surveying computations. Computer methods in surveying.

courses.name: Route Geometrics and Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Geometric design of transportation systems, computer applications, and a comprehensive design project. Covers spiral curves, superelevation theory, and earthwork analysis.

courses.name: Advanced Photogrammetry 3 Credits
courses.description: Precise photogrammetric measurements, camera calibration, object space coordinate systems, analytical control extension, stereoplotter mapping, digital mapping and softcopy stereoplotters.

courses.name: Geospatial Applications of UASs 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers contemporary issues and common applications associated with small UASs (Unmanned Aerial Systems).

courses.name: Remote Sensing 3 Credits
courses.description: Remote sensing systems, ground truthing, image classification systems, mapping applications, applications in plant and animal science, urban planning, engineering, geology, and integration into geographic information systems.

courses.name: Cadastral Principles 3 Credits
courses.description: Cadastral systems, land boundaries, corners and areas; writing land descriptions and identification of land parcels; legal principles of boundary survey, office and business practices; professional standing.

courses.name: Surveying and Mapping Practice 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies land survey practice: the lot survey, the sectional survey and the water boundary survey. Also includes office and business practices and professional standing.

courses.name: Subdivision Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Design a medium-sized subdivision, including the master plan development, physical development considerations, legal requirements, comprehensive project, mock presentation and platting.

courses.name: Foundations of UAS Mapping 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers the fundamental components of small unmanned aerial systems (UASs) and how they are used to produce high resolution, spatially accurate, planimetric maps and 3-D models of the terrain.

courses.name: Geodesy and Geodetic Positioning 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces geometric and physical geodesy, ellipsoids, geodetic lines, computation or position, gravity and coordinate systems.

courses.name: Special Problems in Geomatics 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Special problems or projects in the student's major field of study.

courses.name: Supervised Research in Geomatics 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in geomatics under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Senior Project 1 Credit
courses.description: Laboratory, equipment, or literature investigations of surveying and mapping problems and concepts of current interest resulting in a written work. This foundational course is the second of a two-course sequence for senior Geomatics students to develop an experiential learning project focused on a self-selected surveying and mapping problem.

courses.name: Honors Thesis Research in Geomatics 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Independent research in geomatics leading to an honors thesis; mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Topics in Geomatics 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Selected topics in geomatics, including special issues and in-depth study of topics not discussed in other courses.

courses.name: Practicum in UAS Mapping 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides hands-on experience with flight planning and safe deployment of small UASs (Unmanned Aerial Systems) and the subsequent processing of the imagery acquired on these flights.

courses.name: Co-op Work Experience 2 Credits
courses.description: Practical field experience of sufficient academic rigor.

courses.name: Discover German 1 5 Credits
courses.description: First semester of a two-semester sequence that includes Discover German 2. In this innovative online course, students acquire basic skills in the German language and use the Internet as a resource to explore aspects of German culture and everyday life.

courses.name: Discover German 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of Discover German 1. Continue acquiring basic skills in the German language using the Internet to explore aspects of German culture and everyday life.

courses.name: Beginning Intensive German 1 5 Credits
courses.description: The first semester of the basic language sequence for beginning learners of German. Emphasis is on communicating in German through speaking, listening, reading, writing, and culturally related topics. Communication in German is enhanced by the use of various authentic texts, music, film, and other materials.

courses.name: Beginning Intensive German 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Second semester of the basic language sequence. Emphasis on communicating in German through speaking, listening, reading, writing and culturally-related topics. Communication in German is enhanced by the use of various authentic texts, music, film and other materials.

courses.name: Intermediate German 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Participants will improve their skills in the four basic areas (reading, writing, listening comprehension, speaking) by reviewing elements of grammar, particularly morphology (i.e., word forms), and by expanding vocabulary. Upon successful completion, students may go directly to Advanced German.

courses.name: Online Intermediate German I 3 Credits
courses.description: Employs web-based learning resources to develop B1-level proficiencies via the reinforcement of speaking and listening comprehension, reading, and writing skills, and an exploration of selected cultural topics. For self-starters who are comfortable and successful working individually and in groups in an online learning environment.

courses.name: Online Intermediate German II 3 Credits
courses.description: Develops language comprehension and production skills in work on German texts with various topics (historical, scientific, medical, artistic, etc.) and via online writing tasks and speaking exercises in biweekly synchronous student-instructor meetings.

courses.name: Intermediate German 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Objectives include improving reading and speaking skills at the intermediate level. Upon completion participants will be able to pronounce German words more accurately, listen with greater comprehension to German and respond to questions about a variety of recorded texts. Upon successful completion, students may go directly to Advanced German.

courses.name: Intermediate German Abroad 3-9 Credits
courses.description: A review of the major aspects of grammar in a context that enhances understanding of German and aims at a level of proficiency above the A2 level of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages.

courses.name: Reading German Texts 3 Credits
courses.description: Upon completion, students will be able to read literary and nonliterary texts and to identify the more common syntactical, stylistic and rhetorical elements.

courses.name: Writing German Texts 3 Credits
courses.description: Special focus on strategies, grammar and vocabulary involved in writing in German. Works toward a writing proficiency level that corresponds to the B1 level as defined by the European Framework of Reference for Languages and measured by the Goethe Institute exam Zertifikat Deutsch.

courses.name: German Language and Culture 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces German civilization through grammar review, vocabulary building, reading and essay writing. Upon completion, students will be able to discuss cultural and literary concepts in German. (H)

courses.name: Topics in German Film and Culture 1 Credit
courses.description: GER 3224 is taught as a FLAC accompaniment to various courses. A discussion forum covering different topics in German film and culture. All materials and class discussions will be in German.

courses.name: German Grammar Review 3 Credits
courses.description: An intensive semester-long review of German grammar.

courses.name: German Listening, Comprehension and Speaking 3 Credits
courses.description: Develops the ability to understand and produce basic kinds of speech (descriptions, simple stories, etc.).

courses.name: German in Business 3 Credits
courses.description: Study of Wirtschaftsdeutsch and the ability to read and write texts in German for international business transactions. Acquire the ability to communicate in German in professional business settings.

courses.name: Advanced German Abroad 3-9 Credits
courses.description: Practical, in-class communication exercises at an advanced level in comprehension, speaking, reading and writing. Prepares students to achieve a proficiency level above the B1 level as established by the Common European Framework for Languages.

courses.name: Cultural Identity and Intercultural Competence 3 Credits
courses.description: Listening comprehension and speaking ability in work involving German cultural identity, online and in class.

courses.name: Variable Topics in German Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Working with German media such as major newspapers, magazines, radio and television programs, students will refine their language skills to a level similar to the B2 level of the Common European Framework for Languages.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 1-15 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: German Literary Heritage 3 Credits
courses.description: Knowledge of German is not required. Upon completion participants will be able to discuss major works of German literature, mainly from the 18th to the 20th century. Texts and lectures in English. (H) (WR)

courses.name: German Culture and Civilization 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Knowledge of German is not required. Introduces German civilization from the earliest times to the beginning of the 19th century. Become acquainted with German literature, philosophy, art, music and architecture. Readings and discussions in English.

courses.name: Modern German Culture and Civilization 3 Credits
courses.description: Knowledge of German is not required. Introduces German civilization in the 19th and 20th centuries. Participants will be able to discuss developments in German literature, philosophy, art, music and architecture. Texts and lectures in English.

courses.name: Medieval Literary Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the German literary culture of the Holy Roman Empire during the Middle Ages in its broader European context. Examines literary culture in relation to Latin literary traditions, as well as to other cultural domains such as the arts, architecture, theology, and politics. (H) (WR)

courses.name: Early Modern Literary Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the early modern literary culture of German-speaking regions of the Holy Roman Empire in the broader European context. Examines this culture’s relation to pan-European developments, including the Renaissance, Humanism, the Reformation, and developments in the arts, architecture, theology, and politics.

courses.name: History, Literature and Arts of Berlin 3 Credits
courses.description: Gain a working knowledge of the history and culture of Berlin from 1871 to the present by exploring literature, painting, and film. Authors and artists include Mann, Brecht, Dix, and Wenders.

courses.name: Early German Cinema to 1945 4 Credits
courses.description: Historical overview of the most influential films of German classical cinema, including how they relate to the social reality of the 1920s and 30s.

courses.name: Representations of War in Literature and Visual Media 3 Credits
courses.description: Study of the shifting cultural representations of war (literature/art) in the 20th century, focusing primarily on European history, culture and politics. Primary sources include Mann, Remarque, Boll, Celan, Grosz, and Kiefer.

courses.name: Variable Topics in German Studies 3-9 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics in German Studies in English translation.

courses.name: New Cinema 1945 to the Present 4 Credits
Variable Topics in German Studies 3-9 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in German studies, in English translation.

courses.name: Variable Topics in German Studies 3-9 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics in German Studies.

courses.name: Introduction to German Drama and Theater 3 Credits
courses.description: Survey of German drama from the late medieval period to the present. Introduction to major forms, periods and authors such as Lessing, Goethe, Schiller, and Brecht. (H)

courses.name: Cities as Cultural Centers 3 Credits
courses.description: Study of German, Austrian, and Swiss cities as cultural centers. Employs online learning resources to expand knowledge of urban cultures in German-speaking Europe and to develop linguistic and cultural proficiency toward the B2 level according to CEFR standards.

courses.name: Modern German Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Major trends of German literature in the first half of the 20th century, including impressionism, expressionism, Neue Sachlichkeit, workers literature, and Nazi culture. Discusses works by Thomas Mann, Hermann Hesse, and Bertolt Brecht. (H)

courses.name: Contemporary German Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Learn to discern the major trends of post WW II German literature and recognize the key features of works by such German authors as Böll, Grass, Weiss, and Wolf, and by such Swiss and Austrian writers as Frisch, Dürrenmatt, and Handke.

courses.name: Women in German Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: The image of women in representative works of German literature. Study of the main themes and structures in selected works by major women writers of German-speaking countries and their unique contribution to German culture and literature. Students will use an interdisciplinary approach to literature and will learn the basic tools of gender studies. (H)

courses.name: Communities Writing in German 3 Credits
courses.description: Writings (prose, poetry, critical essays) of significant authors of non-German descent (i.e., Spaniards, Italians, Turks, Iranians) from the 1950s to the present. Insights into the lives and thinking of significant ethnic minorities in Germany during this period and the implications for German literary history and German identity. Films are also screened and discussed.

courses.name: Individual Work 1-3 Credits
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course. Available only by special arrangement.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in German 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in German. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in German.

courses.name: Seminar in Germanic Languages and Literatures 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in Germanic language or literature. (H)

courses.name: The Tales of King Arthur 3 Credits
courses.description: The great literary works of the Arthurian tradition and the manner in which the tales of King Arthur serve, from their 6th century Celtic origins to the present, to articulate the interests and values of different social groups throughout history. (H and N)

courses.name: Castles and Cloisters: An Introduction to Medieval Communities 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies monastic and courtly-chivalric communities as these evolved in the Middle Ages. Explores architecture, art, literature and music illustrate how different monastic and chivalric communities saw the world and their place in it. (H and N)

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Modern Greek Language and Literature 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Beginning Ancient Greek 1 4 Credits
courses.description: The basics of ancient Greek grammar, morphology, syntax and vocabulary.

courses.name: Beginning Ancient Greek 2 4 Credits
courses.description: The basics of ancient Greek grammar, morphology, syntax and translation, with special attention to irregular verbs.

courses.name: Accelerated Beginning Ancient Greek 1 5 Credits
courses.description: This course and its sequel, GRE 1131, constitute the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language.

courses.name: Accelerated Beginning Ancient Greek 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language.

courses.name: Beginning Modern Greek 1 5 Credits
courses.description: This course and its sequel, GRK 1131, constitute the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language.

courses.name: Beginning Modern Greek 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language.

courses.name: Intermediate Modern Greek 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Readings in modern Greek literature, history and culture. (H and N)

courses.name: Intermediate Modern Greek 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Additional readings in modern Greek literature, history and culture. (H and N)

courses.name: Modern Greek Literature Since 1830 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced study of representative modern Greek prose, poetry and drama in the original from independence (1830) to the present. The course combines the study of the modern Greek language with readings, analysis and discussion of major literary works.

courses.name: Individual Work in Modern Greek 1-4 Credits
courses.description: For advanced students who seek independent work not offered in another course. Must be arranged individually with Greek faculty.

courses.name: Intermediate Greek Prose 3 Credits
courses.description: Readings selected from Attic Greek prose authors designed to aid students in the transition from grammar to connected prose passages.

courses.name: New Testament Greek 3 Credits
courses.description: Reviews grammar and forms. Readings from several books of the New Testament. (H and N)

courses.name: Survey of Greek Literature 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies representative texts from various periods of Greek literature. (H and N)

courses.name: Greek Drama 3 Credits
courses.description: Selected plays of Aeschylus, Sophocles or Euripides.

courses.name: Plato 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies Plato's Meno and Apology. (H and N)

courses.name: Greek Lyric Poetry 3 Credits
courses.description: Translation and analysis of Greek lyric poetry, from Archilochus to Bacchylides. (H and N)

courses.name: Homer and Greek Epic 3 Credits
courses.description: Translation and analysis of selections from Homer's Iliad and Odyssey. (H and N)

courses.name: Greek Historians 3 Credits
courses.description: Translation and analysis of selections of Herodotus, Thucydides, Xenophon and Plutarch. (H and N)

courses.name: Greek Orators 3 Credits
courses.description: Translation and analysis of selections from Lysias, Demosthenes and Isocrates. (H and N)

courses.name: Individual Work 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Reading, conference and reports.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Greek Language and Literature 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Studies in Greek Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced study of a particular author, genre, period or subject.

courses.name: Introduction to Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the important role literature has played in individuals' lives and in society, presenting a range of literary styles and genres, from different countries and historical periods. Special attention paid to development of critical skills of analysis and interpretation. (H)

courses.name: Beginning Haitian Creole 1 5 Credits
courses.description: HAI 1130 and its sequel, HAI 1131, constitute the basic sequence for development of conversational skills and grammar essentials in the language.

courses.name: Beginning Haitian Creole 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Second part of the basic Haitian Creole sequence for development of conversational skills and grammar essentials in the language.

courses.name: Intermediate Haitian Creole 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Concentrates on conversation and readings and provides an introduction to Haitian culture through music and film.

courses.name: Intermediate Haitian Creole 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Continued concentration on conversation with added emphasis on reading and perspectives on issues related to the Haitian way of living.

courses.name: Haitian Culture and Society 3 Credits
courses.description: Central aspects of history, politics, environment and development are addressed, including gender relations, medicine, education, work, race and class. No knowledge of Haitian Creole is required.

courses.name: Individual Work 1-4 Credits
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course. Must be arranged individually with Haitian faculty.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Haitian Creole 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in language, linguistics, literature, culture in Haitian Creole. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Haitian Culture and Literature in Translation 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines representations of Haiti and its culture through Haitian literature, art, film, and music.

courses.name: Haitian Culture and Society 3 Credits
courses.description: Central aspects of history, politics, environment and development are addressed, including attention to gender relations, medicine, education, work, race and class. No knowledge of Haitian Creole is required. (H and N OR S and N) (WR)

courses.name: Introduction to Haitian Creole Linguistics 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the major sub-fields of linguistics by means of the Haitian Creole language. Introduces Haitian Creole syntax, morphology, phonology, semantics, and lexicon, as well as sociolinguistics, dialectology, language planning, bilingualism, and language contact.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in English, Haitian Creole or French 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application in some combination of English, Haitian Creole or French.

courses.name: Jamaican Creole, Reggae, and Rastafari 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies Jamaican Creole, reggae music, and Rastafari religion and culture; introduces the language, music, and religion of the Caribbean island. Methodology includes linguistics, ethnomusicology, and religious studies to read Jamaican Creole, interpret reggae songs, and analyze the Rastafari culture to which they link.

courses.name: Variable International Topics 1-6 Credits
courses.description: Provides the opportunity to study in a wide range of cultural settings.

courses.name: Foundations of Health Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Theory and practice in the health education profession.

courses.name: Personal and Family Health 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys personal health concerns: emotional health; aging and death; alcohol, tobacco and drug abuse; physical fitness; nutrition and dieting; consumer health; chronic and communicable diseases; human sexuality; and environmental health.

courses.name: Community and Environmental Health 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys community health organizations and contemporary health issues such as population growth, environment, poverty, medical care and disease.

courses.name: Health and Medical Terminology 3 Credits
courses.description: Develops a working knowledge of terminology related to the human body in health and disease through descriptive definitions, practical applications, understanding word roots, combinations and medical abbreviations.

courses.name: Human Sexuality Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Emphasizes content, issues, methodology and materials for the study of human sexuality. Prepares students to educate individuals and groups.

courses.name: Emotional Health and Counseling 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces theories of emotional well-being and health education, and the means of incorporating positive mental health practices into the health education programming and health counseling.

courses.name: Drug Education and Behavior 3 Credits
courses.description: Broad view of the elements of drug use and abuse, such as individual behavior, environmental factors and drugs. Drug taking is approached in a factual stance; i.e., what has been documented to date, so that participants can separate speculation and bias from fact. The emphasis is also placed on methods pertaining to the preventive aspects of drug use and abuse.

courses.name: Behavioral and Environmental Determinants of Obesity 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores interactions among individual, behavioral and environmental determinants of obesity. Focuses on the extent of the obesity problem primarily in the US from an epidemiological perspective. Ideas for prevention and control are discussed along with effective interventions to address obesity (policy development and implementation).

courses.name: Exercise Therapy, Adapted Physical Activity and Health 3 Credits
courses.description: Art and science of teaching exercise therapy effectively, including adapted physical activities and healthy living strategies. Presents medical and health characteristics of common disabilities and methods for prescribing appropriate exercise therapy programs. Also presents multiple adapted-equipment ideas to facilitate teaching in inclusive settings for all ages. Clinical experience with individuals with disabilities. (S and D)

courses.name: Patient Health Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces theories that apply to the practice of patient education in a variety of health care settings. Emphasizes placed on education for health promotion and lifestyle changes. Additionally, provides an overview of the US healthcare industry.

courses.name: Methods and Materials in Health Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Fundamental strategies for health science education including conceptualizing instruction, specifying instructional objectives, and planning units and lessons using various instructional methods, selecting and using instructional materials, and evaluating the effectiveness of health instruction in school and community settings.

courses.name: Health Promotion in Gerontology 3 Credits
courses.description: Addresses the dimensions of healthy aging. Examines the relevance of behavior change theory with older adults and provides specific tools to design and implement health programs with older adults.

courses.name: Nutrition Education for Special Populations 3 Credits
courses.description: Development of nutrition education programs for selected population groups. Emphasizes educational techniques utilized to inform special populations of changing nutritional needs. Discusses population groups such as ethnic minorities, the elderly, the pregnant female and the athlete.

courses.name: Women's Health Issues 3 Credits
courses.description: Women and men experience similar diseases, disorders, and causes of death, but women often experience these in different forms and at different stages in life. Explores current women's health issues and covers a broad range of health issues of special importance to women.

courses.name: HIV/AIDS Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Seminar examines the medical, social, legal and educational implications of HIV/AIDS on individuals and society. Includes lectures, guest and student presentations, videos and student-initiated discussions. Local, state and national experts in the fields of medicine, epidemiology, law, education and health promotion provide lectures.

courses.name: Minority Health Issues 3 Credits
courses.description: Addresses health issues confronting politically and socioeconomically disadvantaged groups and ethnic minority groups in America. Not intended to be a comprehensive treatment of all pertinent health problems affecting minorities, but does address some of the more salient health concerns.

courses.name: Trends in International Health 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of problems and practices in international health including disease patterns and prevalence, contributing factors, organizational and government initiatives and model programs with special emphasis on problems amenable to health education interventions. (S and N)

courses.name: Community Health Methods in Injury Prevention and Control 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces current theory and knowledge in the field of unintentional injury prevention; prepares students to critically analyze current intervention strategies and explores new directions for unintentional injury prevention and control. Topics include the importance of injury as a problem, historical and conceptual underpinnings of injury prevention, epidemiology of injury, mechanisms of injury, basic concepts of injury prevention, the role of the law in injury prevention and the role if injury surveillance on unintentional injuries.

courses.name: Health Communication for Consumers 3 Credits
courses.description: Health communication processes and practices for health consumers and health professionals who facilitate health consumers. (WR)

courses.name: Worksite Health Promotion 3 Credits
courses.description: Considerations in planning, implementing and evaluating comprehensive health education and health promotion programs at the worksite including health risk appraisal, program design and special educational strategies appropriate for the occupational setting.

courses.name: Planning and Evaluating Health Education Programs 3 Credits
courses.description: Frameworks, principles and strategies for planning, implementing and evaluating health promotion interventions.

courses.name: Health Education Professional Development 3 Credits
courses.description: Review and discussion of the health education field, including career opportunities, department policies for health education internship selection and registration, professional development information and preparation for future employment or graduate coursework in the health education field.

courses.name: Practicum in Health Education 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Health education practicum.

courses.name: Internship in Health Education 1-16 Credits
courses.description: Health education internship.

courses.name: Individual Study 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Supervised program of study to investigate problems significant to health professions.

courses.name: Supervised Research Experience 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Explores an area of interest in health research or the delivery and/or administration of health services through first-hand, supervised research experience.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research 0-5 Credits
courses.description: Provides health education and behavior undergraduates the opportunity to engage in supervised research. For this purpose, research is defined as an independent or team participatory experience that provides an opportunity to systematically investigate an existing or emerging health problem and to communicate the results of their work to others.

courses.name: Current Topics in Health Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics in health education.

courses.name: Introduction to Health Professions 3 Credits
courses.description: Lecture, discussion and group assignments provide the opportunity to learn about different disciplines making up a health care team and their role in both the science and practice of health care.

courses.name: Professional Development for the Health Sciences 1 Credit
courses.description: Fosters the professional development needed to transition into the health and public health professions. Enrichment activities include diversity training, presentation skills training, career planning, and developing an online portfolio.

courses.name: Individual Study 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Supervised program of study to investigate problems significant to health professions.

courses.name: Special Topics 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Special topics in health science. Refer to the department for specific topic information. Can be repeated with change in content for up to 12 credits.

courses.name: Honors Seminar in the Health Professions 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Philosophy and implementation of scientific work, including an introduction to faculty research. Provides the opportunity to explore and discuss potential honors thesis topics.

courses.name: Public Health and Health Professions Senior Honors Thesis 1-6 Credits
courses.description: Special project leading to the distinction of magna or summa cum laude at graduation. The project can be any creative work that focuses on a specific topic or issue in the health professions. The student develops an outline of the special project prior to project initiation and produces a final paper at project completion. The paper must be approved by the program and dean's office for the student to graduate magna or summa cum laude.

courses.name: Public Health Concepts 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the basic tenets, applications and foci of public health, including integrating public health with other health professions.

courses.name: Environmental Concepts in Public Health 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys major environmental health topics by examining sources, routes, media, and health outcomes associated with biological, chemical, and physical agents in the environment. Introduces the economic and legal frameworks associated with environmental health issues and public health.

courses.name: Special Topics in Public Health 1-6 Credits
courses.description: Exploration of a general or a specific area of public health.

courses.name: Human Physiology 3 Credits
courses.description: Functioning of human tissues, organs and organ systems, emphasizing the physical, chemical and mechanistic bases of normal physiology and the integrated function of the human body. Also introduces pathophysiological changes associated with human diseases.

courses.name: Issues and Concepts in Gerontology 3 Credits
courses.description: This multidisciplinary overview of the field of aging covers biomedical and health issues, psychosocial factors, applied aspects and policy issues.

courses.name: US Health Care System 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of organization, delivery and financing of health services in the US. Topics include health professionals, health care facilities, financing of health services, managed care, and current health policy issues.

courses.name: Healthcare Operations Concepts 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers several relevant topics related to the business end of healthcare, including business management principles for practitioners, healthcare reimbursement methodologies, and basic healthcare financial management such as simple budgeting and debt financing.

courses.name: Health Informatics & Emerging Healthcare Technologies 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides a fundamental understanding health informatics, healthcare information systems, and emerging healthcare technologies, starting with the core informatics competencies and the foundation of knowledge model.

courses.name: Introduction to Health Professions 3 Credits
courses.description: Lecture, discussion and group assignments provide the opportunity to learn about different disciplines making up a health care team and their role in both the science and practice of health care.

courses.name: Research Methods and Issues in Health Science 3 Credits
courses.description: Emphasizes four aspects of research: understanding research principles, evaluating journal articles, applying research findings to clinical settings and designing programmatic evaluation projects.

courses.name: Survey of Diseases and Disability 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of medical and psychosocial aspects of chronic diseases and disability.

courses.name: Therapeutic Communication Skills with Patients, Families and the Health Care Team 2 Credits
courses.description: Learn appropriate verbal and nonverbal behavior to be used with patients, families and the health care team through lecture, discussion and role play in large and small groups.

courses.name: Clinical Observation / Health Care Volunteer Work 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Learn about a specific health care field or gain knowledge about specific patient or client populations through direct observation and/or hands-on assistance.

courses.name: Professional Development for the Health Sciences 1 Credit
courses.description: Fosters the professional development needed to transition into the health and public health professions. Enrichment activities include diversity training, presentation skills training, career planning, and developing an online portfolio.

courses.name: Health Care Leadership: Skills and Styles 3 Credits
courses.description: Behavioral styles that contribute to leadership effectiveness. Studies specific styles for their contributions to motivating people and overall leadership effectiveness in health care.

courses.name: Disinformation and Misinformation in Healthcare 3 Credits
courses.description: Traces the interplay of misinformation and disinformation and the impact on personal and public health in the United States. Imparts understanding of the real world impact of misinformation on health outcomes and what can be done about it. Knowledge gained can be used to help understand how people are misinformed and lay the groundwork for being better informed future practitioners. Provides strategies to engage with people those influenced by misinformation or disinformation.

courses.name: Survey of Diseases and Disabilities 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of medical and psychosocial aspects of chronic diseases, including issues of disability management. This required course, combined with HSC 3502, covers all of the major disabling conditions.

courses.name: Psychiatric Disorders 3 Credits
courses.description: Study of major psychiatric syndromes and their management. The continuum of disorders from health to psychopathology.

courses.name: Critical Thinking in Health Care 4 Credits
courses.description: Develops critical thinking skills to solve problems in the health care environment.

courses.name: Ethical and Legal Issues in the Health Professions 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of ethical and legal issues in the health professions, including contemporary ethical issues in disease management.

courses.name: Individual Study 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Supervised program of study to investigate problems significant to health professions.

courses.name: Special Topics 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Special topics in health science. Refer to the department for specific topic information. Can be repeated with change in content for up to 12 credits.

courses.name: Honors Seminar in the Health Professions 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Philosophy and implementation of scientific work, including an introduction to faculty research. Provides the opportunity to explore and discuss potential honors thesis topics.

courses.name: Public Health and Health Professions Senior Honors Thesis 1-6 Credits
courses.description: Special project leading to the distinction of magna or summa cum laude at graduation. The project can be any creative work that focuses on a specific topic or issue in the health professions. The student develops an outline of the special project prior to project initiation and produces a final paper at project completion. The paper must be approved by the program and dean's office for the student to graduate magna or summa cum laude.

courses.name: Pathophysiology 3 Credits
courses.description: Basic understanding of pathophysiology as a change from normal physiological functioning of the various systems of the human body.

courses.name: The Nervous System and Disorders 3 Credits
courses.description: Comprehensive foundation in neuroanatomy, neurophysiology, and neuropathology.

courses.name: Introduction to Public Health 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of public health as a multifaceted field. Includes discussion of contemporary public health challenges with input from discipline experts.

courses.name: Critical Issues in Public Health 3 Credits
courses.description: Learn how to analyze, compare and contrast the most current complex public health issues in society. Students will comprehend and discuss the influence of personal bias, scientific evidence, and societal trends on a variety of public health issues.

courses.name: Public Health Concepts 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the basic tenets, applications and foci of public health, including integrating public health with other health professions.

courses.name: Special Topics in Public Health 1-6 Credits
courses.description: Exploration of a general or a specific area of public health.

courses.name: Service Learning Practicum 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers development of the role of a public health and human services provider in an agency setting.

courses.name: Therapeutic Communication Skills Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Laboratory for HSC 3661; includes hands-on practice of therapeutic communication skills using simulated patient scenarios.

courses.name: Rehabilitation Aspects of Substance Abuse 3 Credits
courses.description: Rehabilitation counseling implications of alcohol and drug use in society and the work place. Emphasis on detection, treatment and follow-up services for individuals in the rehabilitation process.

courses.name: Beginning Modern Hebrew 1 5 Credits
courses.description: Beginning Hebrew covers four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing. For those with no prior exposure to the language.

courses.name: Beginning Modern Hebrew 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continues beginning Hebrew, covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing.

courses.name: Intermediate Modern Hebrew 1 4 Credits
courses.description: Intermediate Hebrew study covers four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Intermediate Modern Hebrew 2 4 Credits
courses.description: Continues intermediate Hebrew covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing.

courses.name: Advanced Modern Hebrew 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing with attention to more complex structures. (H and N)

courses.name: Advanced Modern Hebrew 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Continues advanced Hebrew study of the four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing with attention to more complex structures. (H and N)

courses.name: Individual Work 1-5 Credits
courses.description: Individual work on an approved topic.

courses.name: Special Topics 3 Credits
courses.description: Proseminar of variable content providing an opportunity for in-depth study of special topics in Israeli literature, history, or culture.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 1-15 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: Introduction to Israeli Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Presentation and analysis of some key facets of Israeli culture. Topics include Jewish vs. Zionist (and Israeli non-Jewish) identities, Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Israeli-American relations, gender, and function of art in Israeli society.

courses.name: Identity and Dissent in the Hebrew Short Story 3 Credits
courses.description: Traces the tension between the individual and the collective in Zionist/Israeli society over the last 100-plus years as illustrated in Hebrew short fiction.

courses.name: Israeli History and the Contemporary Novel 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies Israeli history through the lens of the contemporary novel.

courses.name: Readings in Modern Hebrew Literature 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Readings in modern Hebrew novels, short fiction and poetry. While the study of literature is emphasized, some language work is presented to help with reading comprehension. Texts and instruction are in Hebrew.

courses.name: Readings in Modern Hebrew Literature 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Readings in modern Hebrew texts, including recently published stories and poems. Class is instructed in Hebrew.

courses.name: Special Topics in Hindi-Urdu 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in and in-depth study of prose or poetic genres in Hindi and/or Urdu. Supplementary critical readings in English.

courses.name: Africa in World History 3 Credits
courses.description: One-semester introduction to African history for undergraduates. Links the history of African societies with other world civilizations by focusing upon major historical themes. (H and N)

courses.name: Africa to 1800 3 Credits
courses.description: Ancient Africa, the expansion of Islam, savannah kingdoms, East African trading cities, maritime contacts with Europe, the slave trade. (H and N)

courses.name: Africa Since 1800 3 Credits
courses.description: End of the slave trade and the growth of  legitimate  commerce; Islamic renewal and revolution; the European partition and the colonial era; the growth of nationalism and the reemergence of independent Africa. (H and N)

courses.name: History of West Africa 3 Credits
courses.description: History of West Africa from the Ghana Empire to the contemporary period. (H and N)

courses.name: History of East Africa 1800-2000 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the history of East Africa from 1800 to the present. Focuses on the interconnected themes of ethnicity, the history of African states, gender and reproductive health.

courses.name: Special Topics in African History 3 Credits
courses.description: Selected variable topics in the history and culture of Africa.

courses.name: Modern Africa 3 Credits
courses.description: Selected topics in 19th and 20th century African development; pre-colonial conditions, colonial rule, nationalist movements and the problem of independence. (H and N)

courses.name: African Women in the Twentieth-Century 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores themes of politics, social structure, and cultural change by examining the historical experiences of African women.

courses.name: Southern Africa 3 Credits
courses.description: History of southern Africa from the pre-European era to the present. (H and N)

courses.name: History Research Seminar: Africa 3 Credits
courses.description: Through rotating content, this seminar has two distinct goals: historiography of a specific topic and production of a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence.

courses.name: Fight for Your Rights: The Long Civil Rights Movement 3 Credits
courses.description: A multidisciplinary examination of one of America’s most defining social justice movements, the long civil rights movement.

courses.name: United States to 1877 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys the development of the US from its colonial origins to the end of Reconstruction.

courses.name: United States Since 1877 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys the emergence of modern America as an industrial and world power; the Progressive Era; WWI; the Great Depression and the New Deal; WW II; and the Cold War era.

courses.name: History of Sustainability 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the history of sustainability as an idea and practice in the US from the time of European settlement to the near present.

courses.name: The Gilded Age 3 Credits
courses.description: Changes that occurred in America between 1877 and the advent of WWII, emphasizing the meaning of Americanism, conflicts between labor and capital, and the relations between historical events and race, gender and politics.

courses.name: America in the Sixties 3 Credits
courses.description: Social and political movements of the turbulent era of 1960s America, covering primarily the civil rights, feminist and anti-war movements.

courses.name: History of Disability in America 3 Credits
courses.description: How disabilities have been labeled, identified and treated over time and in light of broad social trends.

courses.name: Florida to 1845 3 Credits
courses.description: Exploration, settlement, and colonial history of Spanish and British Florida from US territorial days to statehood.

courses.name: Florida Since 1845 3 Credits
courses.description: Statehood and secession, Civil War, Reconstruction, reform and reaction, Progressive Era, boom and bust, diversification and growth of Florida since World War II. (H) (WR)

courses.name: US Urban History 3 Credits
courses.description: Analyzes the growth and development of urban civilization in the US, emphasizing how cities began and their impact on politics, economics, and culture.

courses.name: US Labor History 3 Credits
courses.description: Emphasizes the history of America's working-class people and addresses such issues as working class consciousness, theories of organized labor, methods of organization, and class relationships.

courses.name: American Foreign Relations and Expansion Since 1914 3 Credits
courses.description: Focuses on the origin, conduct, and consequences of American diplomacy during an era of global conflict and revolutionary upheaval. (H) (WR)

courses.name: US - Middle East Relations 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines US - Middle East relations in historical context, including culture, US - Israeli relations, nationalists, radicals, events, and issues that impact this relationship.

courses.name: The American Jewish Experience 1880-2000 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the major events and issues in American Jewish history and offers a sense of why Jews felt at home in America. Focuses on immigration, assimilation and collective survival.

courses.name: Constitutional History of the United States to 1877 3 Credits
courses.description: Analyzes the development of constitutionalism from English colonial origins to the end of Reconstruction, emphasizing the inherent tension between concepts of power and liberty. (H) (WR)

courses.name: Constitutional History of the United States Since 1877 3 Credits
courses.description: Continues AMH 3551, giving special attention to the way in which constitutionalism has adapted to the growth of an urban and industrial society, to the extension of civil liberties and civil rights, and to the growth of executive authority. (H) (WR)

courses.name: United States Legal History 3 Credits
courses.description: Nontechnical survey of American legal development from its English common law origins to the present. (H) (WR)

courses.name: American Women in the 19th Century 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines women's history during the 19th century with a focus on how women gradually entered the public arena as laborers, reformers, writers, and performers.

courses.name: Women in Modern US 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces major events, trends, and issues in the history of US women from the Civil War to the present.

courses.name: Diversity in American History 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the diversity of the American people and its changes over time from first European contact to the present. Focuses on the interaction between different ethnic groups in American history and how the changing notions of race have helped shape the contours of that history.

courses.name: African American and Latino Histories 3 Credits
courses.description: Comparative examination of the histories of African Americans and Latinos from the early 19th century to present. Major themes include the social construction of race, the development of state policies that enforced racial inequality, struggles for equal citizenship, cultural and social movements for change.

courses.name: Oral History 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the theory and practice of oral history. Examines key issues in historical memory, interviewing, and community-based fieldwork; also examines scholarly debates on oral history as a dialogic mode of knowledge production. Learn digital humanities production methods to bring historical knowledge to broader audiences.

courses.name: American Environmental History 3 Credits
courses.description: Substantive and interpretative inquiry of the historical roots of the nation's contemporary environmental issues. A comprehensive overview of the relationship between people and their natural physical surroundings from the Columbian explorations to the 1980s.

courses.name: Native American History to 1815 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the representations and realities of North American Indian history from the pre-Columbian period through the early 19th century. (H)

courses.name: Native American History Since 1806 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the representations and realities of North American Indian history from the early 19th century to the present. (H and D)

courses.name: African Diaspora in the Americas 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the centrality of Africa in the Americas by studying revolutions against slavery and colonialism in the African Diaspora from the 18th century to present with a special emphasis on the development of democratic ideologies among people of African descent in the Americas.

courses.name: American Slavery and Abolition 3 Credits
courses.description: History of American slavery and abolition from the 1600s through emancipation and the Reconstruction Era.

courses.name: Special Topics in American History 3 Credits
courses.description: Selected, variable topics in the history and culture of America.

courses.name: Early America 3 Credits
courses.description: Origin and development of an American society along the eastern seaboard of North America. (H) (WR)

courses.name: New World Encounters 3 Credits
courses.description: Analyzes the intellectual, cultural and social changes which resulted in a mixture of ideas and cultures from Europe, Africa, and native America. (H) (WR)

courses.name: American Revolutionary Era, 1760-1789 3 Credits
courses.description: Analyzes the background of, and reasons for, the American Revolution, the social, military, political, diplomatic aspects of the era, as well as the constitutional developments of these years. (H) (WR)

courses.name: The Early Republic, 1789-1848 3 Credits
courses.description: Social, political, cultural and economic history of America in its formative years. The Age of Jefferson (1789-1824) and the period of the first party system, including the policies and the wars of the Virginia dynasty. The second half, the Age of Jackson (1824-1848), discusses the rise of the Democratic and Whig parties, Indian removal, trends in religion and reform, further western expansion and the sectionally divisive Mexican War. (H) (WR)

courses.name: US World War I to World War II 3 Credits
courses.description: Post-World War I America: the Twenties, the Depression and the New Deal, WW II.

courses.name: US Since World War II 3 Credits
courses.description: Post-World War II America: America as world power, social revolution, Vietnam, Watergate and after.

courses.name: Violence and Social Conflict in American History 3 Credits
courses.description: Changing patterns and levels of violent behavior, including rioting, lynching, domestic violence, street violence, during the last four centuries of American history.

courses.name: History by Hollywood 3 Credits
courses.description: Compares Hollywood films with traditional historiographic accounts to explore the cultural and political history of the 1950s, '60s and '70s, including the Montgomery Bus Boycott, civil rights, the Vietnam War and political assassinations.

courses.name: Crime and Punishment in American History 3 Credits
courses.description: Historical development of crime and criminal justice in America with particular attention to the ways in which social, political and cultural forces have shaped legal institutions during the past four centuries.

courses.name: History of American Capitalism 3 Credits
courses.description: Political, economic and social contours of American capitalism from the late 18th century through the near present.

courses.name: The South to 1865 3 Credits
courses.description: Development of southern culture from the earliest settlements to the development of southern nationalism. (H)

courses.name: The South Since 1860 3 Credits
courses.description: Impact of Civil War and Reconstruction; economic, political and social development of the new South.

courses.name: Origins of the US Constitution 3 Credits
courses.description: The colonial origins, drafting, and ratification of the US Constitution and its application through 1819. Examines the political, economic, and intellectual influences that helped shape the constitutional system designed by the framers.

courses.name: American Civil War and Reconstruction 3 Credits
courses.description: Analyzes the political, social and economic transformation of the Union, highlighting the Presidency of Lincoln, the evolution of federal policies of Unionist loyalty and slave emancipation, the development of Union military leadership, and the tragically unsuccessful post-war attempt to provide justice to the freed people. (H) (WR)

courses.name: Civil Rights Movements 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the origins, development, and legacies of the African American civil rights and black movements in America, focusing primarily on the period between 1945 and 1980.

courses.name: Sport and American Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the place of sport in American society and culture from the time of European settlement to the present. Uses sport, in its institutional and recreational forms, to illuminate broader historical themes, urban and community life, economic development, social relationship, social mobility and popular and cultural processes.

courses.name: History Research Seminar: US 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the historiography of a specific topic and production of a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence. (WR)

courses.name: History of the Modern Middle East 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys the history, politics and society of the Middle East from the early 19th century until the present day. Topics include transformation of Islamic empire to post-colonial states, development of collective identities, the formation of new social classes and changing gender relations.

courses.name: Modern Japan 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys the social, political and economic transformation of modern Japanese society from 1800. (H and N)

courses.name: Special Topics in Asian History 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics in the history and culture of Asia.

courses.name: History Research Seminar: Asia 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics seminar with two distinct goals: introduce the historiography of a specific topic and produce a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence.

courses.name: Western Civilization: From Early Times to the Middle Ages 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces western civilization that studies the early cultures in Mesopotamia and Egypt, the Minoan-Mycenaean society, Greece, the Hellenistic period and the Roman Empire to the Barbarian invasions. (H and N)

courses.name: Western Civilization: From the Middle Ages to the Eighteenth Century 3 Credits
courses.description: Treats feudal, urban and religious institutions in Medieval society, Renaissance and Reformation, the Thirty Years' War, the Age of Louis XIV and the Age of Reason. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Western Civilization: From the Eighteenth Century to the Present 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores 18th-century revolutions, Napoleon, romanticism and reaction, national unifications and imperialism, competing ideologies, the world wars and Europe in the postwar era. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: History of the Holocaust 3 Credits
courses.description: Origins of anti-Semitism in central Europe and the execution of the Holocaust by Nazi Germany. Examines the ideology of the Nazi leaders and the role of the SS, Army, Police, and ordinary citizens in perpetrating genocide. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Nazi Germany 3 Credits
courses.description: Political and cultural analysis of the history of Nazi Germany examining Nazi ideology, the origins of the Nazi state, coercion and consent among ordinary Germans, persecution of the disabled and of Jews, resistance and non-resistance, and the course of World War II from the German perspective.

courses.name: Intellectual History of Europe, Renaissance to Modern 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines intellectual developments that have shaped modern views of human nature, society, the natural world and God.

courses.name: The Early Middle Ages 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the formation of the Medieval West from the dissolution of the Roman Empire to the year 1000 A.D. Emphasizes the ways in which Roman, Christian and Germanic traditions fused to form a new civilization. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: The High Middle Ages 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines European civilization from the 11th to the 14th centuries. Contrasts the urban and rural, northern and southern forms of economic social, cultural and political phenomena. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Renaissance 3 Credits
courses.description: Interpretations of the Renaissance: Italy's political, literary and artistic developments. The northern Renaissance and Christian Humanism. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: The Reformation 3 Credits
courses.description: Critical religious changes in Europe from the 15th to 17th centuries. Pays particular attention to the broad impact of religion on the social, cultural and political developments of the period. (H and N)

courses.name: Medieval Magic 3 Credits
courses.description: Assessment of the cultural, religious and political implications of the supernatural in late antique, medieval and early modern European society (400-1700 CE). Besides addressing the role of scapegoating in the persecution of marginalized groups, it suggests how belief in demonic magic co-existed with Christian belief in miracles.

courses.name: Medieval Archaeology 3 Credits
courses.description: Methods and theory of archaeology with particular emphasis on the Medieval period and the relation between the written and the archaeological evidence.

courses.name: Early Modern Europe, 1500-1700 3 Credits
courses.description: Development of Europe as it emerged from Middle Ages focusing on the growth of the modern state and the critical changes in politics, science, economics and religion. (H and N)

courses.name: Eighteenth-Century Europe 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies European politics, economics, society, ideas and institutions in the 18th century, including early modern forms of governance, the Enlightenment and the Age of the Revolution. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Nineteenth-Century Europe 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies European politics, society, ideas and institutions, including the French Revolution, emergence of modern politics, upheavals of 1848 and 1871, rise of nationalism, urbanization and socialism. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Twentieth-Century Europe 3 Credits
courses.description: Origins and outcomes of the two world wars, the varieties of European social and political ideologies, and the ever-changing pattern of national and trans-national identities. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Holocaust in the Courtroom 3 Credits
courses.description: Examination of major Holocaust trials and the conflict between justice, national identities, and historical narrative in Germany, Israel, France, the Soviet Union, and the US.

courses.name: Byzantine History 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys Byzantine history with emphasis on political, economic and religious institutions and the role of Byzantium in medieval Europe.

courses.name: Medieval Eastern Europe 3 Credits
courses.description: Eastern Europe from late Antiquity to the 15th century. Examines the major problems of medieval history, with special emphasis on the role of the region in the history of the continent.

courses.name: Late Modern Central and Eastern Europe 3 Credits
courses.description: Cultural, social and political survey of the Hapsburg Monarchy, Poland, and the Balkans from 1700 to 1918. Topics include absolutism, revolutionary nationalism, modernization, cultural flowering, ethnic violence, socialism and WWI.

courses.name: Pagans, Christians, Barbarians: the World of Late Antiquity 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys the history of the Mediterranean region from the second to the 7th century with a particular focus on religious and cultural developments that marked the rise of a Christian Roman Empire.

courses.name: Early Medieval Italy 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys economic, social and political developments in the Italian peninsula between 800 and 1100.

courses.name: Medieval France 3 Credits
courses.description: A chronological and topical introduction to the history of medieval France, from the abandonment of the Roman province of Gaul to the beginning of the Hundred Years War.

courses.name: The French Revolution 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines one of the most transformational events in European and world history. The French Revolution brought about the overthrow of a centuries-old monarchy, the rapid mutation of social relations, the abolition of slavery, and the end of the Christian calendar. Introduces the major events of the period and to the historiographical debates among historians who continue to debate its significance by examining the causes and the effects of the revolution.

courses.name: Medieval Germany 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys economic, social and political developments in Central Europe during the Middle Ages (500-1350).

courses.name: Medieval England 3 Credits
courses.description: Creation of a national society and culture in the time of England's constitutional development (to the 16th century). (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Early Modern England 3 Credits
courses.description: Development of a revolutionary tradition and of a parliamentary monarch in the period of England's cultural flowering (16th to 18th centuries). (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Modern Britain 3 Credits
courses.description: Social, political and economic developments in the19th and 20th centuries. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Colonies to Commonwealth: the History of the British Empire 3 Credits
courses.description: History of the British Empire from its origins in Ireland to the decolonization movements of the 20th century. Examines not only the ways in which the British established and extended the empire through the political, military, economic and cultural spheres, but also resistance to empire.

courses.name: Ireland in the British Empire 3 Credits
courses.description: Place of Ireland in the British Empire and the imperial experiences of the Irish people. Covers the main themes of Irish history from the Tudor conquest to the establishment of the Irish Republic, all the while being attuned to the broader imperial context.

courses.name: Central and Eastern Europe in the 20th Century 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers the collapse of Austro-Hungary, its successor states in the inter-war period, World War II, the Holocaust, the rise and fall of Communism in Central and Eastern Europe.

courses.name: Imperial Russia, 1700-1914 3 Credits
courses.description: Major institutional, political, social and economic issues confronting the Russian state, drawing on source materials and on Russian literature to illustrate these issues. (H and N)

courses.name: Twentieth-Century Russia to 1953 3 Credits
courses.description: Internal political, economic and social history of 20th-century Russia, including the impact of modernization, the rise of radical ideologies, the Bolshevik revolution and the evolution of the Soviet Union. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Jewish History from 711 to 1492 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys major historical developments in medieval Jewish society under Islam and western Christendom. Examines the interaction of Jews with the majority culture, political structure and economy, as well as changing cultural trends.

courses.name: Jewish History from 1492-1750 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys major trends in Jewish society from the f15th to the 18th century, focusing on community structures and interfaith relations.

courses.name: Modern European Jewish History 3 Credits
courses.description: Major events and themes of the Jews in Europe from 1650-1945.

courses.name: The History of Consumption 3 Credits
courses.description: Combines economic, social and political history to study the rise of consumer culture from the 18th century to the present. Primarily focused on Europe but includes the United States in the 20th century.

courses.name: Special Topics in European History 3-9 Credits
courses.description: Selected variable topics in the history and culture of Europe.

courses.name: Holy War in the Middle Ages 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the shifting terrain of historical and theological conceptions of war and holy war in the middle ages. Divided into four distinct sections: theological foundations, early medieval conceptions of war and community, the Crusades and changes in the high and late middle ages.

courses.name: The Viking Experience 3 Credits
courses.description: Scandinavian medieval history, including an examination of the profound changes brought by Christianization and the rise of the medieval states.

courses.name: History of the Second World War 3 Credits
courses.description: Analyzes World War II, covering the origins, politics, resistance movements, grand strategy and consequences. (H) (WR)

courses.name: History of Cold War Europe 3 Credits
courses.description: Cold War era in Europe, 1945-1991; emphasizes origins, social, economic and political aspects, and the historical consequences on Europe.

courses.name: History of Medieval Spain 3 Credits
courses.description: History of the Iberian Peninsula between Late Antiquity and the end of the Reconquista. Emphasizes Muslim Spain, the Christian kingdoms in the North, Christian-Muslim-Jewish interactions, cultural development and social differentiation.

courses.name: Jews of Medieval Spain 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores Jewish life and culture in the Iberian Peninsula from the early middle ages through the Expulsion of 1492. Analyzes interfaith relations and the role Jews played in shaping Spanish society and culture.

courses.name: Nineteenth-Century Germany 3 Credits
courses.description: Germany's political development toward nationhood in the 19th century, and the imperial policies of Bismarck and Wilhelm II. The social history of specific groups in German society. Germany's role in the outbreak of WW I. Offered alternate years. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Medieval Russia 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the history of Eastern Europe from ca. 500 to 1584. Focuses on interconnected themes of state formation, trade, conversion to Christianity and the impact of the Mongol conquest.

courses.name: Society and the Sexes in Modern Europe, 18C to the Present 3 Credits
courses.description: Gendered analysis of great historical events, political movements and ideologies. Other topics of social and cultural history are discussed.

courses.name: Modern European Revolutions: 1789-1989 3 Credits
courses.description: History of key European revolutions that occurred between 1789 and 1989. Emphasizes the economic, cultural and political conditions that gave rise to and accompanied the development of these watershed events.

courses.name: Terrorism and Political Violence in Post-War Europe: 1945-2000 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides a multi-country historical survey of the role terrorism and violence have played in European affairs in the post-Second World War era from 1945 to 2000.

courses.name: History Orthodox Christianity 3 Credits
courses.description: A chronological and topical introduction to the history of the Orthodox Church, from the beginning to the present. Emphasis is on the political circumstances leading to the separation of various churches, and the main aspects of Orthodox Christian life throughout history.

courses.name: History Research Seminar: Europe 3 Credits
courses.description: Through rotating in content, this seminar has two distinct goals: introduce the historiography of a specific topic and produce a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence.

courses.name: Racial Theories in Europe and the US 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces history of racial ideas and images from ancient to modern period.

courses.name: History of Science and Religion 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys the interaction between the religious and scientific communities in the West from the time of the early church to the present.

courses.name: Introduction, History of Science: Origins to Newton 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the emergence of scientific thought from its mythopoeic beginnings to the time of Newton. Focuses on the interrelationships among science, philosophy and religion in Greece, Islam and the Latin West. Emphasizes Copernicus, Kepler, Galileo, Descartes and Newton. (H and N)

courses.name: Introduction, History of Science: Renaissance to the Present 3 Credits
courses.description: General survey of the major issues in physical and biological science from the time of Galileo to the present. Emphasizes the impact of scientific development on society, culture and thought. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: The Scientific Revolution 3 Credits
courses.description: Emergence of modern science from Copernicus to Newton exploring the notions of empiricism, experiment, mechanism, materialism, and the historical concepts of continuity, change, revolution and progress. (H) (WR)

courses.name: The Nuclear Age 3 Credits
courses.description: History of the changing perception of the political and social significance of science since the discovery of nuclear fission.

courses.name: Evolution of Infectious Diseases 3 Credits
courses.description: Emergence of new infectious diseases in a historical and cultural context. Emphasizes the history of well-documented infectious diseases such as leprosy, bubonic plague, cholera, smallpox, yellow fever, tuberculosis, influenza, polio, venereal disease and AIDS, as well as the more recent Ebola viral-type outbreaks. (S)

courses.name: The History of Modern Biological Thought 3 Credits
courses.description: Selected areas of modern biological thought after 1800. Topics include Darwin, genetics, the Evolutionary Synthesis, molecular biology and sociobiology. (H) (WR)

courses.name: History and Public Policy 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the role of historical analysis and argument in the policy-making process. Introduces the ways in which decision-makers use and misuse history, and considers what it means to take history into account in public policy. Uses specific contemporary policy problems to illustrate the challenges of using history effectively.

courses.name: Special Topics 3 Credits
courses.description: Special topics in history. (H) (WR)

courses.name: History Practicum 3 Credits
