courses.description: Provides knowledge of different cultures, languages and identities that make up contemporary European cinemas.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in English Translation 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in English Translation. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in English Translation.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: Introduction to French Literature 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of French Medieval, Renaissance and classical literature and culture, with major literary, intellectual and historical trends through study of representative works from each period. Emphasizes close reading of texts to train students to read critically and to familiarize them with major authors, genres and interpretations. (H and N)

courses.name: Introduction to French Literature 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Selected readings of outstanding authors of prose fiction, poetry and theatre from the 18th to the 20th century. Provides the historical context for major literary movements and authors, and trains students to read and write critically. Generally organized thematically. (H and N)

courses.name: Rotating Topics in French and Francophone Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Selected topics in French literature.

courses.name: Readings in 17th Century French Prose 3 Credits
courses.description: Selected readings with an emphasis on the history of ideas, the moralistes and culture in the early modern period. Texts include Descartes, Cyrano de Bergerac, Pascal, Fontenelle, La Rochefoucauld, La Fayette, La Bruyère, and Svign.

courses.name: Readings in 18th Century French Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Rotating topics exploring the fiction, theatre or intellectual prose of the Enlightenment. Special emphasis placed on the cultural climate and productions of the ancient regime.

courses.name: Readings in the 20th Century French Novel 3 Credits
courses.description: Examination of representative novels in 20th century French literature from Proust to the New Novel and beyond. Emphasis may include study of genre, narrative techniques, literary modernism and major themes. Combines an historical approach with close textual readings. Authors frequently studied include Proust, Gide, Malraux, Cline, Camus, Sartre, Robbe-Grillet, Butor, Sarraute and Duras.

courses.name: Seventeenth Century French Drama 3 Credits
courses.description: Theory and practice of dramaturgy in the classical period as reflected in plays of Corneille, Molire and Racine. Close textual analysis to disengage aesthetic and ideological problematics posed by each play.

courses.name: Readings in 20th and 21st c. French theater 3 Credits
courses.description: A study of selected plays (by Anouilh, Beckett, Césaire, Duras, Genet, Ionesco, Jarry, Réza, Sarraute, Sartre, etc.), dramatic techniques and stage performances in 20th and 21st century French and Francophone theater.

courses.name: Modern French Poetry from Baudelaire to the Present 3 Credits
courses.description: Combines an historical approach with close readings of poetic texts; also introduces a number of theoretical and critical writings. Although traditional poetic texts are studied, the works of less frequently taught poets are also presented.

courses.name: Concepts of French Cinema 4 Credits
courses.description: A critical and historical study of the representation of gender and ethnicity in French cinema.

courses.name: Survey of French Romantic Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: A rotating topics tracing the development and the main tenets of 19th century French Romanticism. Concentrates on various themes and genres, including poetry, theater and the novel as well as the socioeconomic and cultural matrices that fostered the movement. Emphasizes the relationship between literature and the visual arts, constructions of gendered, cultural and artistic subjectivities, exoticism (spatial, temporal and mystical voyages) and representations of Paris and French society. Beginning with pre-Romantic authors, moves on to Lamartine, Stendhal, Hugo, Vigny, Balzac, Sand, Musset, Desbordes-Valmore, Nerval and Baudelaire.

courses.name: Introduction to Realism and Naturalism 3 Credits
courses.description: Rotating topics trace the development and the main tenets of latter 19th century literary, artistic, and cultural productions. Concentrates on various themes and genres, including poetry, theatre, and the novel as well as the socioeconomic and cultural matrices that fostered movements arising between 1850 and the Fin de siècle. Specific attention may be devoted to definitions of Realism, Naturalism, and Symbolism; representations of modern life and the industrialization of the literary market; the infiltration of scientific and mechanistic thought into literary productions (poetry or prose); and representations of women and the female body, of Paris and Parisian society.

courses.name: Readings in Francophone Literatures and Cultures (excluding the Caribbean and Sub-Saharan Africa) 3 Credits
courses.description: Rotating topics in the literatures and cultures of the Francophone world, including North America (Quebec), Europe (Belgium, Switzerland and regional France), Asia (Vietnam, Indian Ocean) and the Middle East.

courses.name: African and Caribbean Literatures 3 Credits
courses.description: The production of Sub-Saharan African writers from its inception to the present through examination of representative works and figures, genres (epics, poetry, drama, novels), discourses and critics that inform the productions. Particular attention is paid to historical, political and cultural issues that figure in the development and orientation of African literature in French. Occasional inclusion of Caribbean literature for purpose of comparison.

courses.name: Introduction to French Critical Theory 3 Credits
courses.description: Review and comparative analysis of approaches to literature from Romanticism to Deconstructionism. Reading and writing are examined through the eyes of Sainte-Beuve, Taine, Lanson, Bachelard, the Geneva School, Ricoeur, Bataille, Blanchot, Barthes, Foucault, Genette, Lacan, Kristeva, Todorov, Derrida and others.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Target Language 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Target Language. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Target Language.

courses.name: Senior Seminar in French Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Rotating topics for French majors and minors in the senior year. Topics rotate given research interests or field of specialization of the teaching faculty. Recent topics have included La Posie du Voyage; L'Écriture féminine; Le Discontinu chez La Rochefoucauld et La Bruyre; Charles Baudelaire: pote/critique de la vie moderne; Qu'est-ce que la Rvolte?

courses.name: Discover German 1 5 Credits
courses.description: First semester of a two-semester sequence that includes Discover German 2. In this innovative online course, students acquire basic skills in the German language and use the Internet as a resource to explore aspects of German culture and everyday life.

courses.name: Discover German 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of Discover German 1. Continue acquiring basic skills in the German language using the Internet to explore aspects of German culture and everyday life.

courses.name: Beginning Intensive German 1 5 Credits
courses.description: The first semester of the basic language sequence for beginning learners of German. Emphasis is on communicating in German through speaking, listening, reading, writing, and culturally related topics. Communication in German is enhanced by the use of various authentic texts, music, film, and other materials.

courses.name: Beginning Intensive German 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Second semester of the basic language sequence. Emphasis on communicating in German through speaking, listening, reading, writing and culturally-related topics. Communication in German is enhanced by the use of various authentic texts, music, film and other materials.

courses.name: Intermediate German 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Participants will improve their skills in the four basic areas (reading, writing, listening comprehension, speaking) by reviewing elements of grammar, particularly morphology (i.e., word forms), and by expanding vocabulary. Upon successful completion, students may go directly to Advanced German.

courses.name: Online Intermediate German I 3 Credits
courses.description: Employs web-based learning resources to develop B1-level proficiencies via the reinforcement of speaking and listening comprehension, reading, and writing skills, and an exploration of selected cultural topics. For self-starters who are comfortable and successful working individually and in groups in an online learning environment.

courses.name: Online Intermediate German II 3 Credits
courses.description: Develops language comprehension and production skills in work on German texts with various topics (historical, scientific, medical, artistic, etc.) and via online writing tasks and speaking exercises in biweekly synchronous student-instructor meetings.

courses.name: Intermediate German 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Objectives include improving reading and speaking skills at the intermediate level. Upon completion participants will be able to pronounce German words more accurately, listen with greater comprehension to German and respond to questions about a variety of recorded texts. Upon successful completion, students may go directly to Advanced German.

courses.name: Intermediate German Abroad 3-9 Credits
courses.description: A review of the major aspects of grammar in a context that enhances understanding of German and aims at a level of proficiency above the A2 level of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages.

courses.name: Reading German Texts 3 Credits
courses.description: Upon completion, students will be able to read literary and nonliterary texts and to identify the more common syntactical, stylistic and rhetorical elements.

courses.name: Writing German Texts 3 Credits
courses.description: Special focus on strategies, grammar and vocabulary involved in writing in German. Works toward a writing proficiency level that corresponds to the B1 level as defined by the European Framework of Reference for Languages and measured by the Goethe Institute exam Zertifikat Deutsch.

courses.name: German Language and Culture 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces German civilization through grammar review, vocabulary building, reading and essay writing. Upon completion, students will be able to discuss cultural and literary concepts in German. (H)

courses.name: Topics in German Film and Culture 1 Credit
courses.description: GER 3224 is taught as a FLAC accompaniment to various courses. A discussion forum covering different topics in German film and culture. All materials and class discussions will be in German.

courses.name: German Grammar Review 3 Credits
courses.description: An intensive semester-long review of German grammar.

courses.name: German Listening, Comprehension and Speaking 3 Credits
courses.description: Develops the ability to understand and produce basic kinds of speech (descriptions, simple stories, etc.).

courses.name: German in Business 3 Credits
courses.description: Study of Wirtschaftsdeutsch and the ability to read and write texts in German for international business transactions. Acquire the ability to communicate in German in professional business settings.

courses.name: Advanced German Abroad 3-9 Credits
courses.description: Practical, in-class communication exercises at an advanced level in comprehension, speaking, reading and writing. Prepares students to achieve a proficiency level above the B1 level as established by the Common European Framework for Languages.

courses.name: Cultural Identity and Intercultural Competence 3 Credits
courses.description: Listening comprehension and speaking ability in work involving German cultural identity, online and in class.

courses.name: Variable Topics in German Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Working with German media such as major newspapers, magazines, radio and television programs, students will refine their language skills to a level similar to the B2 level of the Common European Framework for Languages.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 1-15 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: German Literary Heritage 3 Credits
courses.description: Knowledge of German is not required. Upon completion participants will be able to discuss major works of German literature, mainly from the 18th to the 20th century. Texts and lectures in English. (H) (WR)

courses.name: German Culture and Civilization 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Knowledge of German is not required. Introduces German civilization from the earliest times to the beginning of the 19th century. Become acquainted with German literature, philosophy, art, music and architecture. Readings and discussions in English.

courses.name: Modern German Culture and Civilization 3 Credits
courses.description: Knowledge of German is not required. Introduces German civilization in the 19th and 20th centuries. Participants will be able to discuss developments in German literature, philosophy, art, music and architecture. Texts and lectures in English.

courses.name: Medieval Literary Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the German literary culture of the Holy Roman Empire during the Middle Ages in its broader European context. Examines literary culture in relation to Latin literary traditions, as well as to other cultural domains such as the arts, architecture, theology, and politics. (H) (WR)

courses.name: Early Modern Literary Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the early modern literary culture of German-speaking regions of the Holy Roman Empire in the broader European context. Examines this culture’s relation to pan-European developments, including the Renaissance, Humanism, the Reformation, and developments in the arts, architecture, theology, and politics.

courses.name: History, Literature and Arts of Berlin 3 Credits
courses.description: Gain a working knowledge of the history and culture of Berlin from 1871 to the present by exploring literature, painting, and film. Authors and artists include Mann, Brecht, Dix, and Wenders.

courses.name: Early German Cinema to 1945 4 Credits
courses.description: Historical overview of the most influential films of German classical cinema, including how they relate to the social reality of the 1920s and 30s.

courses.name: Representations of War in Literature and Visual Media 3 Credits
courses.description: Study of the shifting cultural representations of war (literature/art) in the 20th century, focusing primarily on European history, culture and politics. Primary sources include Mann, Remarque, Boll, Celan, Grosz, and Kiefer.

courses.name: Variable Topics in German Studies 3-9 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics in German Studies in English translation.

courses.name: New Cinema 1945 to the Present 4 Credits
Variable Topics in German Studies 3-9 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in German studies, in English translation.

courses.name: Variable Topics in German Studies 3-9 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics in German Studies.

courses.name: Introduction to German Drama and Theater 3 Credits
courses.description: Survey of German drama from the late medieval period to the present. Introduction to major forms, periods and authors such as Lessing, Goethe, Schiller, and Brecht. (H)

courses.name: Cities as Cultural Centers 3 Credits
courses.description: Study of German, Austrian, and Swiss cities as cultural centers. Employs online learning resources to expand knowledge of urban cultures in German-speaking Europe and to develop linguistic and cultural proficiency toward the B2 level according to CEFR standards.

courses.name: Modern German Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Major trends of German literature in the first half of the 20th century, including impressionism, expressionism, Neue Sachlichkeit, workers literature, and Nazi culture. Discusses works by Thomas Mann, Hermann Hesse, and Bertolt Brecht. (H)

courses.name: Contemporary German Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Learn to discern the major trends of post WW II German literature and recognize the key features of works by such German authors as Böll, Grass, Weiss, and Wolf, and by such Swiss and Austrian writers as Frisch, Dürrenmatt, and Handke.

courses.name: Women in German Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: The image of women in representative works of German literature. Study of the main themes and structures in selected works by major women writers of German-speaking countries and their unique contribution to German culture and literature. Students will use an interdisciplinary approach to literature and will learn the basic tools of gender studies. (H)

courses.name: Communities Writing in German 3 Credits
courses.description: Writings (prose, poetry, critical essays) of significant authors of non-German descent (i.e., Spaniards, Italians, Turks, Iranians) from the 1950s to the present. Insights into the lives and thinking of significant ethnic minorities in Germany during this period and the implications for German literary history and German identity. Films are also screened and discussed.

courses.name: Individual Work 1-3 Credits
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course. Available only by special arrangement.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in German 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in German. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in German.

courses.name: Seminar in Germanic Languages and Literatures 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in Germanic language or literature. (H)

courses.name: The Tales of King Arthur 3 Credits
courses.description: The great literary works of the Arthurian tradition and the manner in which the tales of King Arthur serve, from their 6th century Celtic origins to the present, to articulate the interests and values of different social groups throughout history. (H and N)

courses.name: Castles and Cloisters: An Introduction to Medieval Communities 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies monastic and courtly-chivalric communities as these evolved in the Middle Ages. Explores architecture, art, literature and music illustrate how different monastic and chivalric communities saw the world and their place in it. (H and N)

courses.name: Beginning Haitian Creole 1 5 Credits
courses.description: HAI 1130 and its sequel, HAI 1131, constitute the basic sequence for development of conversational skills and grammar essentials in the language.

courses.name: Beginning Haitian Creole 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Second part of the basic Haitian Creole sequence for development of conversational skills and grammar essentials in the language.

courses.name: Intermediate Haitian Creole 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Concentrates on conversation and readings and provides an introduction to Haitian culture through music and film.

courses.name: Intermediate Haitian Creole 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Continued concentration on conversation with added emphasis on reading and perspectives on issues related to the Haitian way of living.

courses.name: Haitian Culture and Society 3 Credits
courses.description: Central aspects of history, politics, environment and development are addressed, including gender relations, medicine, education, work, race and class. No knowledge of Haitian Creole is required.

courses.name: Individual Work 1-4 Credits
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course. Must be arranged individually with Haitian faculty.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Haitian Creole 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in language, linguistics, literature, culture in Haitian Creole. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Haitian Culture and Literature in Translation 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines representations of Haiti and its culture through Haitian literature, art, film, and music.

courses.name: Haitian Culture and Society 3 Credits
courses.description: Central aspects of history, politics, environment and development are addressed, including attention to gender relations, medicine, education, work, race and class. No knowledge of Haitian Creole is required. (H and N OR S and N) (WR)

courses.name: Introduction to Haitian Creole Linguistics 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the major sub-fields of linguistics by means of the Haitian Creole language. Introduces Haitian Creole syntax, morphology, phonology, semantics, and lexicon, as well as sociolinguistics, dialectology, language planning, bilingualism, and language contact.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in English, Haitian Creole or French 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application in some combination of English, Haitian Creole or French.

courses.name: Jamaican Creole, Reggae, and Rastafari 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies Jamaican Creole, reggae music, and Rastafari religion and culture; introduces the language, music, and religion of the Caribbean island. Methodology includes linguistics, ethnomusicology, and religious studies to read Jamaican Creole, interpret reggae songs, and analyze the Rastafari culture to which they link.

courses.name: Beginning Modern Hebrew 1 5 Credits
courses.description: Beginning Hebrew covers four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing. For those with no prior exposure to the language.

courses.name: Beginning Modern Hebrew 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continues beginning Hebrew, covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing.

courses.name: Intermediate Modern Hebrew 1 4 Credits
courses.description: Intermediate Hebrew study covers four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Intermediate Modern Hebrew 2 4 Credits
courses.description: Continues intermediate Hebrew covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing.

courses.name: Advanced Modern Hebrew 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing with attention to more complex structures. (H and N)

courses.name: Advanced Modern Hebrew 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Continues advanced Hebrew study of the four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing with attention to more complex structures. (H and N)

courses.name: Individual Work 1-5 Credits
courses.description: Individual work on an approved topic.

courses.name: Special Topics 3 Credits
courses.description: Proseminar of variable content providing an opportunity for in-depth study of special topics in Israeli literature, history, or culture.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 1-15 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: Introduction to Israeli Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Presentation and analysis of some key facets of Israeli culture. Topics include Jewish vs. Zionist (and Israeli non-Jewish) identities, Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Israeli-American relations, gender, and function of art in Israeli society.

courses.name: Identity and Dissent in the Hebrew Short Story 3 Credits
courses.description: Traces the tension between the individual and the collective in Zionist/Israeli society over the last 100-plus years as illustrated in Hebrew short fiction.

courses.name: Israeli History and the Contemporary Novel 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies Israeli history through the lens of the contemporary novel.

courses.name: Readings in Modern Hebrew Literature 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Readings in modern Hebrew novels, short fiction and poetry. While the study of literature is emphasized, some language work is presented to help with reading comprehension. Texts and instruction are in Hebrew.

courses.name: Readings in Modern Hebrew Literature 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Readings in modern Hebrew texts, including recently published stories and poems. Class is instructed in Hebrew.

courses.name: Special Topics in Hindi-Urdu 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in and in-depth study of prose or poetic genres in Hindi and/or Urdu. Supplementary critical readings in English.

courses.name: Beginning Italian 1 5 Credits
courses.description: ITA 1130 and its sequel, ITA 1131, constitute the basic sequence in Italian. Emphasis on the development of broad competence in the language. Oral-aural approach ensures competence in the four skills.

courses.name: Beginning Italian 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of the basic sequence in Italian. Emphasis on the development of broad competence in the language. Oral-aural approach ensures competence in the four skills.

courses.name: Intermediate Italian 1 4 Credits
courses.description: Enhances knowledge of Italian in all four skills: listening, reading, speaking and writing. The goal is to create communicative competence that enables students to advance to third year study and to benefit from their visits to Italy. (H and N)

courses.name: Intermediate Italian 2 4 Credits
courses.description: Completes second year sequence with emphasis on composition, literature and communication skills. (H and N)

courses.name: Accelerated Introduction to Italian 5 Credits
courses.description: Intensive course designed primarily for speakers or students with knowledge of another Romance language or strong linguistic abilities in another foreign language. Assumes no prior study of Italian and offers a complete four-skill (listening, speaking, reading and writing) introduction to the language.

courses.name: Italian Enhancement Section 1-5 Credits
courses.description: Italian-language reading and discussion to accompany and complement courses in other departments. Readings and discussions are in Italian to develop vocabulary and fluency related to the content of the companion course and to provide an international perspective on the issues of the main course. (N)

courses.name: Italian Conversation 3 Credits
courses.description: Develops and refines Italian oral and comprehension skills through exposure to and discussion of a range of topics relating to contemporary Italian society. Discussion and assignments address different registers of speech, from the colloquial to the formal. Active in-class participation is essential.

courses.name: Grammar and Composition 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Intensive language course designed to master grammatical principles, increase vocabulary and enhance writing and composition skills.

courses.name: Italian Civilization 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics introduce Italian civilization in historical, artistic, and literary contexts.

courses.name: Naples: Culture and History 3 Credits
courses.description: Historical, cultural, and socio-political exploration of the Italian city of Naples from its foundation by the Greeks to its present-day position within the Italian State. Readings, discussion, and analysis encompass the city’s rich literary, artistic, architectural, theatrical, and musical traditions as well as the socio-political history of Naples and the region of Campania.

courses.name: Contemporary Italian Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics focus on modern Italy through literature, art and mass media, and current events.

courses.name: Individual Work 1-4 Credits
courses.description: For advanced minors who seek independent work not offered in another course. Must be arranged individually with Italian faculty. Only three credits can count toward the minor.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Language or History/Culture in Italian 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Italian Literature and Film 3 Credits
courses.description: Study of modern Italian narrative and its adaptation to film by major Italian directors.

courses.name: Italy and Pilgrimages 3 Credits
courses.description: Through lectures, readings and discussions in English, ITT 3431 considers the continuing presence of Rome and other Italian cities as metaphors and focal points of Italian artistic and literary sensibilities. (H and N)

courses.name: Italian Cinema 4 Credits
courses.description: Critical and historical study of Italian film and directors. Topics may vary. (H and N)

courses.name: Murder Italian Style: Crime Fiction and Film in Italy 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores Italian crime fiction and film. Analysis considers specificity of Italian tradition while placing texts and films in a broader cultural and historical context, enabling critically and politically informed reading of the many applications and subversions of the generic formula. Taught in English.

courses.name: Gangsters and Godfathers: Italian Mafia Movies 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines Italian cinematic representations of organized criminality, in particular Sicilian Cosa Nostra and Neapolitan Camorra. Analysis considers specificity of Italian tradition while placing films in a broader history of the gangster genre to allow for a critically and politically informed reading of Italian generic subversions. Taught in English.

courses.name: The Demolition of Man: Italian Perspectives on the Jewish Holocaust 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores a sampling of Italy's texts on the Jewish Holocaust, centering on the work of survivor and theorist of the camps, Primo Levi. Material also encompasses the history of the Italian-Jewish community, as well as a selection of Italian films dealing with the realities and ethical implications of the camps.

courses.name: Special Topics in Italian Literature and Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Selected topics in Italian literature, civilization and culture, including crossover influence of media. Can focus on one epoch's influence on another.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Italian in English Translation 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 1-18 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: Introduction to Italian Literature 1 3 Credits
courses.description: The origins of early Italian literature, its central themes, and the cultural factors that influenced its development. Develops an ability to read critically in Italian.

courses.name: Introduction to Italian Literature 2 3-9 Credits
courses.description: The major Italian authors from the Renaissance through the 20th century.

courses.name: Boccaccio's Decameron 3 Credits
courses.description: Analysis of Giovanni Boccaccio’s canonical Decameron with a focus on the literary Dimension of Text as well as the political, historical, and religious context in which the work was written.

courses.name: Representing the Humble Italy: Literature and Cinema of the Italian South 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines texts and films that address the so-called Southern Question; namely, the socioeconomic and cultural disparities between northern and southern Italy. Explores or contests topics and concepts including southern exclusion from official history, southern fusion of religion and superstition, resistance to modernity and mafia-related political corruption. Taught in Italian.

courses.name: Delitto all'italiana: Crime Fiction and Film in Italy 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores a sampling of Italian crime fiction and film through the lens of a range of conceptual categories, including British intellectual model vs. American noir; rational inquiry vs. uncertainties of sensory perception; canon vs. popular; cosmopolitan vs. provincial; order vs. chaos; political conservatism vs. social critique. Taught in Italian.

courses.name: Italian Theater from the Renaissance to the Early Modern Era 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview and analysis of evolution of Italian theater, with focus on a selection of specific examples drawn from Italian theater from the Renaissance to the early modern era. Taught in Italian.

courses.name: Mad Love in Modern Italian Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Exploration of a sampling of modern Italian literary manifestations of a love that strays beyond the conventional. Language skills addressed through discussion, oral presentations, creative writing assignments, and short papers.

courses.name: Animals and Animality in Italian Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Presentation and exploration of the figure of the nonhuman animal in the work of several modern Italian authors and poets. Analysis addresses the literary dimension of the selected animal portraits as well as any philosophical and ethical questions raised by these literary animals. Taught in Italian.

courses.name: Dante's Inferno 3 Credits
courses.description: Semester-long, in-depth examination of Dante Alighieri's text, Inferno, with the support of a variety of visual materials and digital resources devoted to Dante and his world. Special attention paid to the political, historical, and religious context in which Dante wrote. Taught in Italian.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Literature in Italian 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Literature in Italian. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Literature in Italian.

courses.name: Beginning Japanese 1 5 Credits
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing. JPN 1130 has a strict attendance policy: if registered students miss two or more class meetings during drop/add, they may be dropped from the class upon notification by the instructor.

courses.name: Beginning Japanese 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar. JPN 1131 has a strict attendance policy: if registered students miss two or more class meetings during drop/add, they may be dropped from the class upon notification by the instructor.

courses.name: Intermediate Japanese 1 5 Credits
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar. JPN 2230 has a strict attendance policy: if registered students miss two or more class meetings during drop/add, they may be dropped from the class upon notification by the instructor.

courses.name: Intermediate Japanese 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study. JPN 2231 has a strict attendance policy: if registered students miss two or more class meetings during drop/add, they may be dropped from the class upon notification by the instructor.

courses.name: Advanced Japanese 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures. JPN 3410 has a strict attendance policy: if registered students miss two or more class meetings during drop/add, they may be dropped from the class upon notification by the instructor. (H and N)

courses.name: Advanced Japanese 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of advanced study. JPN 3411 has a strict attendance policy. If registered students miss two or more class meetings during drop/add, they may be dropped from the class upon notification by the instructor. (H and N)

courses.name: Business Japanese 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides grammatical structures and essential business vocabulary, develops conversation strategies and presentation skills, and raises awareness of the customs and cultural differences in Japanese business interactions.

courses.name: Language in Japanese Society 3 Credits
courses.description: Analysis of variation in regional dialects: gender-based differences, pragmatics of interpersonal communication, language acquisition and discourse structure. (S and N)

courses.name: Japanese Translation: Theory and Practice 3 Credits
courses.description: Key concepts and approaches of translation studies applied to the translation of Japanese to English, and English to Japanese, in a variety of media, genre, and text types.

courses.name: Structure of Japanese 3 Credits
courses.description: Linguistic analysis of modern standard Japanese. Topics include phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics and writing. Readings and discussions in English. (S and N)

courses.name: Individual Study 1-5 Credits
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course. Available only by special arrangement.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Language or Linguistics 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Language or Linguistics. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Language or Linguistics.

courses.name: Special Topics in Japanese Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in and in-depth study of special topics in Japanese studies.

courses.name: Senior Honors Thesis 3 Credits
courses.description: Select a Japanese faculty member to act as director for an independent research project that culminates in an honors thesis.

courses.name: Internship 3 Credits
courses.description: Faculty (or delegated authority) supervised internship. Requires a written post-internship report.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 1 1-15 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 2 1-15 Credits
courses.description: Revolving topics provide a mechanism for coursework taken at a foreign university as part of an approved study abroad program to be transferred to UF. Credits taken will be entered in the student's transcript and may or may not count toward graduation, at the discretion of major's advisors.

courses.name: Tales of Kyoto 3 Credits
courses.description: An investigation of literary texts from the 8th through the 17th centuries presented within the framework of Western literary and feminist criticism. (H and N)

courses.name: Modern Japanese Fiction in Translation 3 Credits
courses.description: A critical examination of stories, autobiographies and secondary criticism from the 19th century to the present. Become familiar with the forms and topics of criticism through Japanese and Western sources. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Contemporary Japanese Literature: Postwar to Postmodern 3 Credits
courses.description: Companion to JPT 3120 that reflects the increasing clarity with which contemporary Japanese literature (1945 to present) is emerging as a separate field with its own set of issues, major texts and significance for the American student of Japan. Writers range from Dazai and Oe Kenzaburo to Murakami Haruki, and issues range from subjectivity to cybernetics.

courses.name: Modern Women Writers 3 Credits
courses.description: Examination of narratives written by women who published during the Taisho (1912-25), Showa (1925-89) and Heisei (1989 to present) periods. (H and N)

courses.name: Classical Japanese Poetry 3 Credits
courses.description: Historical survey of traditional Japanese poetry (waka) from the 8th to the 16th century. (H and N)

courses.name: Samurai War Tales 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the historical and cultural stimuli that led to war, recorded later as war narratives. Supported by images of architecture, narrative picture scrolls, and extant military accoutrements. (H and N)

courses.name: Early Modern Japanese Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys Japanese literature of the Early Modern period (also called the Edo period), 1600-1868. Introduces and analyzes historically significant, foundational works of Early Modern Japanese literature and theater. Explores the history of the period and the development of print technologies and new genres, and introduces critical aesthetic and cultural concepts.

courses.name: Introduction to Japanese Film 4 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the formal and historical features of Japanese film that have given it a unique position in film history. Emphasizes formal and critical analysis as well as the intellectual stakes of studying non-western film.

courses.name: Japanese Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to Japanese culture with emphasis on tracing the origin and development of important aspects of Japanese literature, art, religion and society. All readings in English. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Japanese Visual Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores issues within Japanese visual culture, and uses visual-cultural products to explore Japanese political, cultural, social, and historical issues. Introduces and analyzes historically significant, foundational works of Japanese visual culture, unpacks genre and genre tropes in contemporary works, and analyzes several visual-cultural works that tackle significant social issues.

courses.name: The Tale of Genji 3 Credits
courses.description: Investigation of the 11th-century masterpiece and its pervasive influence on Japanese literature, past and present. (H and N)

courses.name: Japanese Folklore 3 Credits
courses.description: Study of native belief systems and the supernatural as reflected in the folk practice of ritual observance and in tales, myths, songs and proverbs. (H and N)

courses.name: Representations of Japan's Modern Empire 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines a variety of literary, historical, anthropological, and theoretical texts to explore racial and social issues related to Japan's imperial past. (H and N)

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in English Translation 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 1 1-15 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 2 1-15 Credits
courses.description: Revolving topics provide a mechanism for coursework taken at a foreign university as part of an approved study abroad program to be transferred to UF. Credits taken will be entered in the student's transcript and may or may not count toward graduation, at the discretion of major's advisors.

courses.name: Classical Japanese 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to classical Japanese texts with emphasis on reading comprehension, grammar analysis and translation.

courses.name: Classical Japanese 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Complex texts in classical Japanese with focus on comprehension, grammar, literature and culture.

courses.name: Readings in Japanese Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: A fourth-year language course based on literary texts, incorporating advanced reading skills and the analysis of literature in the original. (H and N)

courses.name: Japanese Texts and Contexts 3 Credits
courses.description: Complements JPW 4130, Readings in Japanese Literature, and focuses on contemporary issues as encountered in a variety of Japanese media.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Target Language 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Target Language. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Target Language.

courses.name: Beginning Korean 1 5 Credits
courses.description: Beginning study covering speaking, listening, reading, writing, and cultural interaction.

courses.name: Beginning Korean 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continued study of speaking, listening, reading, writing and cultural interaction.

courses.name: Intermediate Korean 1 5 Credits
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Intermediate Korean 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Special Topics in Polish Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics in Polish literature, culture and society. Taught in English.

courses.name: Introduction to Polish Language and Culture 1 5 Credits
courses.description: A two-semester Polish language sequence that introduces the basics of Polish language and culture.

courses.name: Introduction to Polish Language and Culture 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Second in the two-semester sequence. Helps to expand vocabulary, command of Polish grammar, and the ability to speak Polish.

courses.name: Intermediate Polish 1 4 Credits
courses.description: Improve speaking, reading, writing, and listening comprehension skills by reviewing and expanding the language principles introduced in POL 1130 and POL 1131.

courses.name: Intermediate Polish 2 4 Credits
courses.description: Improve speaking, reading, writing, and listening comprehension skills by reviewing and building upon the language principles introduced in POL 2220.

courses.name: Introduction to Russian Language and Culture 1 5 Credits
courses.description: RUS 1130 and its sequel, RUS 1131, offer a comprehensive introduction to Russian, using interactive methods to develop competence in speaking, listening, reading, writing and cultural interaction.

courses.name: Introduction to Russian Language and Culture 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of introductory language and cultural study.

courses.name: Intermediate Russian 1 4 Credits
courses.description: Intermediate study with exercises in sentence patterns, vocabulary building and oral and written discourse in Russian.

courses.name: Russian for Heritage Learners 3 Credits
courses.description: A practical overview of Russian grammar and writing for those with significant bilingual speaking and listening backgrounds. Devotes special attention to reading, writing and vocabulary development.

courses.name: Oral Practice in Russian 3 Credits
courses.description: Development of advanced speaking and listening skills in conversational Russian.

courses.name: Intermediate Russian 2 4 Credits
courses.description: Continued study with exercises in sentence patterns, vocabulary building and sustained oral and written discourse.

courses.name: Advanced Russian 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) with attention to more complex structures.

courses.name: Advanced Russian 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) with attention to more complex structures.

courses.name: Advanced Grammar and Composition 3 Credits
courses.description: Study of advanced grammar and composition in Russian.

courses.name: Advanced Oral Practice 3 Credits
courses.description: Continued development of advanced speaking and listening skills based on authentic written, audio and video texts from contemporary Russian culture.

courses.name: Russian Studies Research Seminar 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces significant trends and ideas in Russian literary, cultural, historical, and critical studies. Develop the ability to understand and produce critical scholarly argument in a variety of formats, including class discussion, formal presentation and a written research project.

courses.name: Language and Culture of the Russian Business World 3 Credits
courses.description: Combines advanced language training, a practical introduction to the language and culture of the contemporary Russian business world, and extensive practice translating and interpreting texts used in business settings. Focuses on issues such as starting companies and joint ventures, advertising, and setting up and conducting official meetings and telephone calls. Basic Russian business ethics are also studied.

courses.name: Theory and Practice of Russian-English Translation 1 3 Credits
courses.description: First part of a two-part translation series focusing on the theory and practice of conveying word semantics in Russian-English and English-Russian translation.

courses.name: Theory and Practice of Russian-English Translation 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Second part of the translation series focusing on the theory and practice of conveying sentence and paragraph semantics in Russian-English and English-Russian translation.

courses.name: Structure of the Russian Language 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to the phonology, morphology and syntax of contemporary standard Russian from a formal and semantic standpoint. Also includes the development of Russian word stress and a survey of the development of Russian verb tense, aspect and mood.

courses.name: Corrective Phonetics and Intonation 3 Credits
courses.description: Develops advanced-level phonetic and intonational skills via a variety of genres of authentic texts from Russian culture.

courses.name: Individual Work in Russian 1-3 Credits
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course. Available only by special arrangement.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Russian Language 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Russian Language. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Russian Language.

courses.name: Special Topics in Russian 3-9 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in Russian studies. New, experimental, or one-time offerings.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 1-15 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: Russian Masterpieces 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the Russian literature of the 19th-21st centuries. Read some of the most influential works by Pushkin, Gogol, Tolstoy, Dostoevsky, Chekhov, Nabokov, Pasternak and Sorokin, thereby gaining essential knowledge of Russian history, culture and the authors personal lives. Readings and discussions in English. (H and N)

courses.name: Tolstoy and Dostoevsky 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to the major 19th century Russian novelists and their contemporaries. Readings and discussions in English. (H)

courses.name: Themes from Russian Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: An examination of Russian everyday life and institutions of the 19th and 20th centuries through the media of literature and film. (H and N)

courses.name: War and Peace 3 Credits
courses.description: Offers a close reading of Tolstoys epic novel War and Peace. Examines the literary and historical origins of the novel, its reflection of Tolstoy's obsession with history, and the emerging picture it presents of Russian identity. Taught in English.

courses.name: Russian Literature of the Twentieth Century 3 Credits
courses.description: Authors, movements and genres in Russian literature from the Revolution of 1917 to the present. Readings and discussions in English. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Russian Cultural Heritage 3 Credits
courses.description: An introduction to the culture of pre-revolutionary Russia. Philosophical, religious, artistic and literary currents in relation to Western civilization. Readings and discussions in English. (H and N)

courses.name: Contemporary Russian Culture and Society 3 Credits
courses.description: Patterns of continuity and change in the philosophical and cultural values of Russian society as they explain the Soviet Union and contemporary Russia. Readings and discussions in English. (H)

courses.name: Violence and Terror in the Russian Experience 3 Credits
courses.description: An examination of the impact of violence and terror on the human condition as reflected and expressed in well-known works of Russian literature (fiction and historical narratives), art and film. Taught in English. No knowledge of other languages required. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Russia Today 3 Credits
courses.description: Patterns of continuity and change in the philosophical and cultural values of Russian society as they explain the Soviet Union and contemporary Russia. Readings and discussions in English. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Creative Lives: Writers, Artists, and Extraordinary People 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores Russian visions of creativity and creative people in Russian culture by placing them in dialogue with broader European and American models and considerations of creativity.

courses.name: Russian Fairy Tales 3 Credits
courses.description: A critical introduction to Russian fairy tales and folklore and an examination of the aesthetic, social, cultural and psychological values they reflect. (H and N)

courses.name: Russia through Film 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines Russian life, institutions, and the arts against the background of period-defining historical, political, and cultural events from the early twentieth century to the present day as reflected and refracted in some emblematic feature films, documentaries, and animated cartoon films produced in the Soviet Union and post-Soviet Russia.

courses.name: Russia's Struggle with Nature: Legacies of Destruction and Preservation 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores competing concepts of nature in modern Russian culture through works of Russian fiction and non-fiction in translation. Emphasis falls on environmental problems in Russia and the former Soviet Union (desiccation of the Aral Sea, pollution of Lake Baikal, the Chernobyl nuclear accident etc.) and their impact on Russian thought.

courses.name: The Twentieth Century through Slavic Eyes 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to the literature, film and culture of 20th century Eastern and Central Europe. (H and N)

courses.name: Variable Topics in Russian Studies 1-9 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics in Russian studies, taught in English translation.

courses.name: Pushkin and Gogol 3 Credits
courses.description: Major works of Russian literature written the first half of the 19th century. Readings and discussions in English. (H)

courses.name: Russian Modernism 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to the major artistic contributions of Russian modernism in the context of the political, social, and cultural upheavals of late Imperial to Stalinist Russia (1890 - 1939). (H and N)

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Russian Studies, English Translation 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Variable Topics in Russian Studies 1-9 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in Russian studies, taught in English translation.

courses.name: Reading Russian Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: In-depth study of the vocabulary, structures, reading strategies and cultural background needed for understanding and interpreting a broad range of Russian prose fiction.

courses.name: Russian Drama and Poetry 3-6 Credits
courses.description: Study of plays and poems by major Russian writers from the 19th and 20th centuries. Readings in Russian.

courses.name: Russian Media Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: In-depth study of the history and recent trends in the Russian mass media and web-based technology and their impact on culture and society.

courses.name: Russian Short Prose 3 Credits
courses.description: Critical study of selected Russian short stories. Readings in Russian. (H)

courses.name: Reading Eugene Onegin: Pushkin and Nabokov 3 Credits
courses.description: An in-depth study of one of Russia's most revered literary works, combining close readings of Pushkin's original with analyses of operatic, artistic and cinematic adaptations by Chaikovsky, Nabokov and others. Readings and discussions primarily in Russian.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Russian Studies, Target Language 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Selected Readings in Russian 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Special topic, author, genre or movement in Russian literature. (H)

courses.name: Swahili Oral Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces various genres of Swahili oral literatures and shows their importance, relevance and function within Swahili culture.

courses.name: Beginning Swahili 1 5 Credits
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.

courses.name: Beginning Swahili 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Intermediate Swahili 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Intermediate Swahili 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Advanced Swahili 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.name: Advanced Swahili 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.name: Individual Study 1-5 Credits
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course.

courses.name: Beginning Vietnamese 1 5 Credits
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.

courses.name: Beginning Vietnamese 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Intermediate Vietnamese 1 4 Credits
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Intermediate Vietnamese 2 4 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Vietnamese for Heritage Learners 1 4 Credits
courses.description: For those with significant speaking and listening skills, but limited reading and writing skills. Emphasis on developing latter two skills.

courses.name: Individual Study 1-5 Credits
courses.description: For independent work not offered in another course. Available only by special arrangement.

courses.name: Special Topics in Vietnamese Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in Vietnamese studies. Available only by special arrangement.

courses.name: Vietnamese Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of Vietnamese culture, language and history. Focuses on Vietnamese cultural norms, attitudes, values and culture through an examination of history, religious practices, language, literature, family structures, cuisine, daily life and the arts. (H and N)

courses.name: Beginning Wolof 1 5 Credits
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.

courses.name: Beginning Wolof 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Intermediate Wolof 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Intermediate Wolof 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study.

courses.name: Advanced Wolof 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.name: Advanced Wolof 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.name: Language in African Society 3 Credits
courses.description: The role of language in the development of African societies. Language and nation building. (S and N)

courses.name: Beginning Yoruba 1 5 Credits
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.

courses.name: Beginning Yoruba 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Intermediate Yoruba 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Intermediate Yoruba 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Advanced Yoruba 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.name: Advanced Yoruba 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.name: Individual Study 1-5 Credits
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course.

courses.name: Yoruba Diaspora in the New World 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to the scope and importance of Yoruban culture in the New World and its role and significance in the resilience of African cultures in North America, South America and the Caribbean. (WR)

courses.name: Readings in Yoruba Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Reading skills and the analysis of literature in the original language.

courses.name: Introduction to Latin American Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Interdisciplinary introduction to the study of Latin American societies and cultures. Provides general knowledge of Latin America and its people, preparing students for future coursework in Latin American studies. (H or S, and N)

courses.name: Drug Wars and Oil Fortunes in Latin America 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the historical, comparative, and current dynamics of two global commodities—illicit drugs and licit petroleum. Considers how the presumably separate spheres of legal and illegal commodity exchange have become intertwined and covers the linkages between the Drug War, petroleum extractivism, and United States—Latin America relations.

courses.name: Special Topics in Latin American Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics in Latin American studies.

courses.name: Individual Work 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Qualified students choose a topic in Latin American studies that cuts across disciplines. Students work under the supervision of a faculty member affiliated to the Center for Latin American Studies.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Latin American Studies 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Course provides firsthand, supervised research in Latin American Studies. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Latin American Studies.

courses.name: Latin American Area Seminar 3 Credits
courses.description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

courses.name: Latino Politics and Policy 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the political behavior of Hispanic Americans in the United States. Students discuss political and public policy issues that impact Hispanic/Latino communities, such as affirmative action, the Chicano movement, English-only movements, immigration, the presidency, racial profiling and urban politics.

courses.name: Beginning Latin 2 3 Credits
courses.description: The second part of the sequence for those with little or no background in Latin.

courses.name: Beginning Latin 3 3 Credits
courses.description: The third part of the sequence for students with little background in high-school Latin.

courses.name: Beginning Latin 1 4 Credits
courses.description: The first of a 3-semester sequence for students with little or no background in Latin. Others enrolling in the course will be required to take it for an S/U grade.

courses.name: Accelerated Beginning Latin 1 5 Credits
courses.description: This course and its sequel, LAT 1131, constitute the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language. Students are expected students to have little or no background in Latin. Others enrolling in the course will be required to take it for an S/U grade.

courses.name: Accelerated Beginning Latin 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language.

courses.name: Introduction to Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the important role literature has played in individuals' lives and in society, presenting a range of literary styles and genres, from different countries and historical periods. Special attention paid to development of critical skills of analysis and interpretation. (H)

courses.name: Introduction to Vergil 3 Credits
courses.description: Readings in Vergil's Eclogues, Georgics and/or the Aeneid, with emphasis on introducing Vergilian style, diction poetic techniques and basic genre differences. Review of Latin grammar and syntax. (H)

courses.name: Readings in Latin Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines various aspects of Roman life through readings in Latin literature (with a focus on either special subjects, authors, genres or periods) and a review of Latin grammar. (H)

courses.name: Latin Love Poetry 3 Credits
courses.description: Translation and interpretation of selected poems of Catullus and a thorough review of Latin grammar. (H and N)

courses.name: The Ancient Novel 3 Credits
courses.description: Readings from Petronius, Apuleius or the Historia Apollonii Regis Tyri. (H and N)

courses.name: Roman Drama 3 Credits
courses.description: Translation and analysis of the comedies of Plautus and Terence or the tragedies of Seneca. (H)

courses.name: Roman Elegy and Lyric 3 Credits
courses.description: Selected poems of Catullus, Horace, Tibullus, Propertius or Ovid. (H and N)

courses.name: Roman Satire 3 Credits
courses.description: Translation and analysis of the Roman satirists Horace, Persius, Juvenal or Martial. (H and N)

courses.name: The Roman Historians 3 Credits
courses.description: Readings in Latin from one of the Roman historians: Sallust, Caesar, Livy or Tacitus. (H and N)

courses.name: Medieval Latin 3 Credits
courses.description: Readings from Medieval Latin 350 - 1200 A.D. (H and N)

courses.name: Cicero 3 Credits
courses.description: Essays, speeches and letters of Cicero. (H and N)

courses.name: Vergil and Roman Epic 3 Credits
courses.description: Translation and analysis of selections from Vergil's Aeneid in the light of his epic techniques and the spirit of the Augustan Age. (H and N)

courses.name: Studies in Latin Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: A rotating topics course providing in-depth study of a particular author (e.g., Suetonius), genre (e.g., didactic poetry) or period (e.g., The Silver Age).

courses.name: Special Study in Latin 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Readings, conferences and reports.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Latin Language and Literature 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Language and Emotion 3 Credits
courses.description: Interdisciplinary study of the interface of emotion and language. Focus on vocal properties of emotion expression, how different languages conceptualize emotion, how those who are not neurotypical may differ in the expression of emotion, and implications of gender-differential expectations of emotion expression for self-presentation.

courses.name: Languages of the World 3 Credits
courses.description: Broad survey of the world’s languages, their genetic affiliations, and current status. Addresses issues related to linguistic diversity and provides an overview of the major subfields of linguistics by acquainting students with linguistic properties of diverse languages and language families.

courses.name: Language in the USA 3 Credits
courses.description: Focuses on linguistic diversity in the US, touching on American dialects, multilingualism in America, Native American languages, and sociolinguistic variation. Dialect analysis tools will be learned and applied in class projects.

courses.name: Language, Thought and Action: Language as a Cognitive System 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies language from the perspective of cognitive sciences. (S)

courses.name: Introduction to Linguistics 3 Credits
courses.description: Core areas of linguistics research: phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, sociolinguistics and language acquisition. (H)

courses.name: The Sounds of Human Language 3 Credits
courses.description: Emphasizes the sounds employed in languages of the world for a comprehensive understanding of the mechanism underlying the production of speech sounds and the ability to recognize, distinguish and phonetically transcribe speech sounds from an unfamiliar language. Includes investigation of the patterning and functions of sounds in languages of the world and application of the methods of analyzing a language sound system.

courses.name: The Structure of Human Language 3 Credits
courses.description: Investigates word formation processes (morphology) and sentence structure (syntax) in the world's languages. Focuses on vocabulary and tools used to discover and describe patterns in human language. Coursework emphasizes problem solving and working with a wide range of language data. (WR)

courses.name: World Englishes 3 Credits
courses.description: Investigates history and spread of English; varieties of English spoken around the world as a first, second, or foreign language, their characteristics at various linguistic levels (sounds, morphemes, syntax, lexicon), their use and status in different countries; issues of policy, teaching, and testing; and models categorizing World Englishes.

courses.name: Modern English Structure 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the grammar of current English from the viewpoint of modern linguistics.

courses.name: Stats for Linguists 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the concepts of probability and statistics, with examples chosen mainly from linguistics. Topics include descriptive statistics, comparing means, regression, t-tests, linear mixed models, and basic experimental design.

courses.name: Intro to Corpus Linguistics 3 Credits
courses.description: Key methods of corpus linguistics for research and teaching.

courses.name: Historical Linguistics 3 Credits
courses.description: Basic concepts of historical linguistics and their application to language data. Exploration of the history of individual languages and language families. Concepts of language relatedness, language change, and language evolution.

courses.name: Introduction to Data-driven Learning 3 Credits
courses.description: An overview of how data-driven learning is defined and what disciplines and theories it draws from, the way DDL has been applied in actual classroom research, and hands-on training using software and corpus data to develop instructional materials and student activities.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Phonetics 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies phonetics, including anatomy and physiology of the speech production apparatus, transcription and production of some of the world's sounds, basic acoustics, computerized methods for speech analysis, acoustic characteristics of sounds, stress and intonation and basic issues in speech perception. May be taught in conjunction with LIN 6208, Phonetics and Linguists, a graduate course.

courses.name: Introduction to Phonology 3 Credits
courses.description: Phonemics, syllabic and prosodic phenomena, neutralization, distinctive features, morphophonemic alternation, phonological systems and processes. Terminology and notational conventions of generative phonology and optimality theory, with problems from a variety of languages. May be taught in conjunction with a graduate course that bears the same title.

courses.name: Introduction to Morphology 3 Credits
courses.description: Theory of word structure, derivation and inflection, with examples and problems from a variety of languages. Includes the position of morphology in grammar, the relationship between morphology and grammar, typology, cultural and conceptual categories, and predictions of various theories of morphology. May be taught in conjunction with a graduate course that bears the same title.

courses.name: Introduction to Syntax 3 Credits
courses.description: Generative-transformational model of syntax: phrase structure, the lexicon, case and agreement, movement, locality relations and anaphora; emphasizes problem solving and linguistic argumentation. May be taught in conjunction with a graduate course that bears the same title.

courses.name: Survey of Sociolinguistics 3 Credits
courses.description: Major approaches to language in context: ethnolinguistic, sociological and linguistic. Applications of socio-linguistics to applied linguistics, social sciences and education. Collection and analysis of data. (N and S)

courses.name: Gender and Language 3 Credits
courses.description: Language in the construction of sex and gender roles within a culture. Grammaticalization of gender in languages of the world. Interaction of grammatical structures with gender stereotypes. Consequences of these interactions on grammatical structures. (S and D)

courses.name: Psycholinguistics 3 Credits
courses.description: Basic issues in psycholinguistics, including linguistic principles and psychological mechanisms in language production, comprehension, acquisition and development.

courses.name: Methods in Psycholinguistics 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides hands-on experience designing, running and analyzing data from various types of psycholinguistic experiments.

courses.name: Second Language Acquisition 3 Credits
courses.description: The neurolinguistic, psycholinguistic and sociolinguistic bases of second language acquisition in childhood and adulthood.

courses.name: Field Methods 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to linguistic fieldwork. Hands-on investigation of the phonetic, phonological, morphological, and syntactic structure of a lesser-known language and the techniques used in the elicitation and analysis of such linguistic data.

courses.name: Methods in Language Documentation 3 Credits
courses.description: Exploration of digital methods used in contemporary language documentation.

courses.name: Introduction to Computational Linguistics 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the study of natural language from a computational perspective. Discusses both applied (engineering) and theoretical (cognitive) issues, ranging from speech and language technology to formal aspects of theoretical linguistic models. Covers a brief introduction to programming in Python, and the basics of Natural Language Processing and their applications.

courses.name: Writing Systems 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces origin and typology of writing systems. Evaluates cognitive claims regarding second language reading acquisition and script type. Considers basic problems in the interface of phonology, script and natural language processing.

courses.name: Brain and Language 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces critical issues and terminology in brain and language research. Topics include brain imaging techniques, categorization, auditory perception, modularity, connectionism, semantic representation, laterality, innateness and plasticity.

courses.name: Introduction to Semantics 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies truth-conditional semantics as opposed to pragmatics, including basic notions in classical logic, since logic is assumed in truth-conditional semantics.

courses.name: Meaning and Use 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces pragmatics, the study of utterance meanings determined by situated uses of language and linguistic communication as a social activity. Explores role of linguistic and extra-linguistic contexts in the production and interpretation of utterances. Topics include deictic and anaphoric expressions, sense and reference, presupposition, implicature, speech acts and coherence.

courses.name: Formal Semantics 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced semantics within the Montague approach.

courses.name: Individual Study in Linguistics 3 Credits
courses.description: Individual study for linguistics majors.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Linguistics 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in linguistics. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in linguistics.

courses.name: Special Topics in Linguistics 3-9 Credits
courses.description: Variable content offered by faculty members in their areas of specialization. Some offerings may involve extensive writing, while others will deal with quantitative analysis or field methodology.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 1-15 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: Senior Thesis 3 Credits
courses.description: Accommodation for senior thesis.

courses.name: Introduction to Teaching English as a Second Language 3 Credits
courses.description: Historical overview of trends in language teaching technology, ranging from communicative approaches to techniques for teaching listening, speaking, reading and writing. Trains students to instruct small groups and individuals in English language skills.

courses.name: Pronunciation for Teaching English as a Second Language 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of sound system of North American English and its integration with listening, morphology and spelling. Pronunciation pedagogy based on current theory and practice, as well as diagnostic tools and assessment measures.
