courses.description: Synthetic biology is the construction and reconstruction of biological systems and its practical applications in research and industry. Examines advanced molecular biology tools for DNA assembly, the construction of biological pathways and circuits, genome editing, and strategies for transcriptional control.

courses.name: Independent Research in Bioinformatics 3 Credits
courses.description: Mentored research experience at the interface between computational and biological sciences; preparation for competitive graduate-school and industry positions in bioinformatics.

courses.name: Advanced Independent Research in Bioinformatics 3 Credits
courses.description: Mentored bioinformatics research experience that challenges students to develop a deeper understanding of bioinformatics methodologies, to frame biological questions, to evaluate primary scientific literature and to present their research in formal written and oral presentations.

courses.name: Microbiology 3 Credits
courses.description: Role of microorganisms in chemical transformations, disease, public health, and agriculture. Fundamental concepts are discussed, followed by beneficial and harmful actions of microorganisms as they affect our lives. Not acceptable for admission to advanced microbiology courses nor for the preprofessional curricula required for the medical/veterinary sciences.

courses.name: Microbiology Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Laboratory exercises demonstrate biochemical transformations and present methods for studying microbial properties. Not acceptable for admission to advanced microbiology courses nor for the preprofessional curricula required for the medical/veterinary sciences.

courses.name: Microbes without Borders 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the amazing world of microbiology; microbes play a significance role for individuals, for our communities, and for the whole planet. Readings, discussions, and activities provide a mind-opening, global journey to acknowledge the great things microbes do for us.

courses.name: Lab Skills Bootcamp 1 Credit
courses.description: Provides a foundation and advanced skills all biological science students should master. Emphasizes analytical, computational, communication and other lab skills above and beyond bench work.

courses.name: Basic Biology of Microorganisms 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the principles and techniques of microbiology, genetics, taxonomy, biochemistry and ecology and microorganisms. Also studies virology, immunology, and the pathogenicity of microorganisms. (B)

courses.name: Laboratory for Basic Biology of Microorganisms 1 Credit
courses.description: Laboratory exercises on the structure, nutrition, and growth of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. Includes isolation and classification of representative microorganisms.

courses.name: Principles of Microbiology 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the principles and techniques of microbiology, genetics, taxonomy, biochemistry, and ecology of microorganisms. Required of all majors and students who will enroll in more advanced courses in the Department of Microbiology and Cell Science.

courses.name: Principles of Microbiology Laboratory 2 Credits
courses.description: Laboratory techniques on the structure, nutrition, biochemistry, genetics, and growth of microorganisms. Required of all majors and students who will enroll in more advanced courses in the Department of Microbiology and Cell Science.

courses.name: Astrobiology 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the origin, evolution and future of life in our solar system. Include planetary habitability, astrobiogeochemistry, microbial life, and human space flight. (WR)

courses.name: Professional Development in Microbiology and Cell Science 1-2 Credits
courses.description: Assistance in making career decisions and organizing supporting academic credentials. Emphasizes the wide variety of career opportunities and professional development tools applicable to careers in professional schools, academia, industry, and alternative professions.

courses.name: Advanced Microbiology Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Application of immunological, molecular biological and microbial techniques to the isolation, identification, and characterization of bacteria and viruses.

courses.name: Careers for Impact in Microbiology and Cell Science 1 Credit
courses.description: Provides connections into a variety of microbiology and cell science careers, and hones essential networking and communication skills through practical application exercises. A portfolio will be created to identify and obtain suitable experiential learning and career opportunities.

courses.name: Innovation Project Management for Life Sciences 1 Credit
courses.description: Provides practical tools to manage innovation projects typical of life science research and development. Discusses challenges and methodologies associated with developing objectives, preparing project plans, establishing metrics, defining responsibilities, as well as mitigating risks and dealing with uncertainties. Also strengthens skills for strategic prioritization, time management, meeting facilitation, and communication to promote an innovative culture.

courses.name: Prokaryotic Diversity 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the diversity of bacteria and archaea. Discussions provide a conceptual and historical framework for understanding their origin and evolution; morphological, metabolic, and molecular characteristics; genetic and physiological diversity; importance in human, animal, and plant health; and roles in elemental cycling.

courses.name: Bacterial Pathogens 3 Credits
courses.description: Host-microbe relationships in the diseases of humans and animals, including the virulence characteristics of bacterial pathogens, the techniques used in their isolation/identification, and molecular approaches to the study of their virulence.

courses.name: Antimicrobial Resistance 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers content related to antimicrobial resistance: the origins of antimicrobial resistance, dissemination, mechanisms, therapeutics, and impact on healthcare, agriculture, and the environment. Mainly concentrates on resistance in bacteria, but will also discuss other organisms, including viruses, parasites, fungi, and cancer.

courses.name: Antimicrobial Resistance Lab 1 Credit
courses.description: This laboratory course covers content related to antimicrobial resistance: the origins of antimicrobial resistance, surveillance, dissemination, mechanisms, therapeutics, and impact on healthcare, agriculture, and the environment.

courses.name: Genetics of Microorganisms 3 Credits
courses.description: Molecular biology of bacterial gene expression, including DNA replication, mutation, genetic mapping using plasmids and phages, and recombinant DNA mechanisms.

courses.name: The Microbiome 3 Credits
courses.description: Increase knowledge, appreciation, and use of genomics pertaining to the breadth of microbial diversity across a wide variety of organisms and habitats using methods that do not require culturing of the myriad of inhabitants. Use tools, practice analysis, and interpretation of genomic data sets to analyze different microbiomes.

courses.name: R for Functional Genomics 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the Basics of the R Language and to state of the art methods for functional genomics data analysis. Learn how to write R scripts, choose appropriate statistical tools, and how to use Linux environments to analyze high-throughput genomics data.

courses.name: Prokaryotic Cell Structure and Function 3 Credits
courses.description: Analyzes the cell structure and physiology of bacterial cells. Extensive discussion of cell division and cell growth is provided along with descriptions of important bacterial cell structures (e.g. cell walls, membranes, flagella, etc.)

courses.name: Probiotics 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers the use of microorganisms to promote a health status in the host and provides a conceptual background in microbiology and immunology for the use of microorganisms for the prevention or treatment of animal and human diseases.

courses.name: General Virology 3 Credits
courses.description: Nature of viruses and mechanisms of infection and replication, including bacterial, animal, and plant viruses.

courses.name: Virology Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Laboratory course covering basic virology assays used to generate, propagate and enumerate viruses using cell culture and molecular methods.

courses.name: Environmental Microbiology 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of microorganisms in the environment including occurrence, abundance and distribution; processes of microbial interaction with the environment; and practices of applied environmental microbiology.

courses.name: Extremophiles 3 Credits
courses.description: The evolution, physiology, biochemistry, and molecular biology of extremophiles with emphasis on archaea and their viruses. Discuss principles of energy metabolism at the limits of life. Highlights research that incorporates cutting-edge techniques and biotechnology applications for using extremophiles to solve real world problems.

courses.name: Analysis, Interpretation, and Visualization of Microbiological Data 3 Credits
courses.description: Focuses on the analysis and interpretation of microbiological data using R language and other command line tools with a series of examples that range in complexity. Analyze various microbiological data, including RNA-Seq, 16SrRNA gene sequencing, direct and indirect measurements of microbial growth, and measurements of microbial bioproducts, among others. Finally, teaches good practices for data reproducibility.

courses.name: Independent Study 0-4 Credits
courses.description: Individual laboratory research under the guidance of a faculty member. Required of, but not limited to, candidates for high and highest honors. Not acceptable toward 25 credits of required department and elective credits.

courses.name: Supervised Research in Microbiology and Cell Science 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application..

courses.name: Honors Thesis Research in Microbiology and Cell Science 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Independent research in microbiology and cell science leading to an honors thesis. Student will be mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry,  design,  investigation,  scholarship,  discovery or application.

courses.name: Special Topics in Microbiology and Cell Science 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Supervised literature or historical study on current topics in microbiology and cell science. Not acceptable toward 25 credits of required department and elective credits.

courses.name: Microbiology and Cell Science Internship 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Internship in microbiology and cell science under supervision of the department.

courses.name: Genetics and Genomics in Health Care 2 Credits
courses.description: Genetics and genomics are advancing quickly and will play a greater role in health care as personal genome sequencing becomes available. Reinforces basic genetics and genomics concepts and exploring how genomics may affect health care.

courses.name: Exploring Your Genome 3 Credits
courses.description: How the genome sequence is analyzed and its implications on human health. Promotes genetic literacy (see syllabus for specific topics).

courses.name: Eukaryotic Cell Structure and Function 3 Credits
courses.description: Lecture and discussions in the field of cell biology with emphasis on the interrelation of structure and function, the regulation of metabolism and the specialized activities of plant and animal cells.

courses.name: Immunology 3 Credits
courses.description: Basic concepts in immunology, including specific components, development, and function.

courses.name: Molecular Genetics 3 Credits
courses.description: Molecular biology of prokaryotes and eukaryotes covering the fundamentals of genome organization and gene structure, regulation of transcription, DNA replication and repair, and RNA processing. Also includes discussion of strategies, vectors and applications of genetic engineering in higher plants and animals.

courses.name: Human Genomics 3 Credits
courses.description: Discusses how human genome sequence data is obtained, analyzed, and interpreted with an emphasis on what can be learned from an individual's genome. Genome-based strategies are used for the detection, treatment, and prevention of many diseases.

courses.name: Human Parasitology 3 Credits
courses.description: Host-parasite relationships of helminth and protozoan diseases important in health sciences and veterinary medicine.

courses.name: The Air Force Today 1 Credit
courses.description: Introduces the United States Air Force and Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps. Featured topics include mission and organization of the Air Force, officership and professionalism, military customs and courtesies, Air Force officer opportunities, group leadership problems and an introduction to communication skills.

courses.name: General Military Course (GMC) Leadership Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Air Force customs, courtesies, drills and ceremonies; issuing military commands; instructing, directing and evaluating the preceding skills; studying the environment of an Air Force officer; and learning about areas of opportunity available to commissioned officers.

courses.name: The Air Force Today 1 Credit
courses.description: Introduces the United States Air Force and Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps. Topics include introduction to flight, oral and written communication techniques and an overview of military services.

courses.name: General Military Course (GMC) Leadership Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Air Force customs, courtesies, drills and ceremonies; issuing military commands; instructing, directing and evaluating the preceding skills; studying the environment of an Air Force officer; and learning about areas of opportunity available to commissioned officers.

courses.name: The Evolution of USAF Air and Space Power 1 Credit
courses.description: Examines USAF air and space power from a historical perspective. Covers the earliest aircraft, both World Wars, the Korean and Vietnam conflicts, air and space employment during the Cold War.

courses.name: General Military Course (GMC) Leadership Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Air Force customs, courtesies, drills and ceremonies; issuing military commands; instructing, directing and evaluating the preceding skills; studying the environment of an Air Force officer; and learning about areas of opportunity available to commissioned officers.

courses.name: The Evolution of USAF Air and Space Power 1 Credit
courses.description: Continuation of AFR 2130 and the exploration of Air Force history, beginning with the Vietnam era and culminating with the application of air and space power in recent conflicts.

courses.name: General Military Course (GMC) Leadership Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Air Force customs, courtesies, drills and ceremonies; issuing military commands; instructing, directing and evaluating the preceding skills; studying the environment of an Air Force officer; and learning about areas of opportunity available to commissioned officers.

courses.name: Air Force Leadership and Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Leadership and quality management fundamentals, professional knowledge, Air Force doctrine, leadership ethics and communication skills required of an Air Force junior officer. Case studies examine Air Force leadership and management situations as a means of demonstrating and exercising practical application of the concepts studied.

courses.name: Professional Officer Course (POC) Leadership Laboratory 1 1 Credit
courses.description: Advanced leadership experiences planning and controlling military activities of the cadet corps, the preparation and presentation of briefings and other communications, and the interviews, guidance and information to increase cadet understanding, motivation and performance.

courses.name: Air Force Leadership and Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies leadership and quality management fundamentals, professional knowledge, Air Force doctrine, leadership ethics and communication skills required of an Air Force junior officer. Case studies examine Air Force leadership and management situations as a means of demonstrating and exercising practical application of the concepts studied.

courses.name: Professional Officer Course (POC) Leadership Laboratory 2 1 Credit
courses.description: Advanced leadership experiences planning and controlling military activities of the cadet corps, the preparation and presentation of briefings and other communications, and the interviews, guidance and information to increase cadet understanding, motivation and performance.

courses.name: Preparation for Active Duty 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the national security process, regional studies, advanced leadership ethics and Air Force doctrine. Topics focus on the military as a profession, officership, military justice and civilian control of the military. Within this structure, continued emphasis is given to refining communication skills.

courses.name: Professional Officer Course (POC) Leadership Laboratory 3 1 Credit
courses.description: Advanced leadership experiences planning and controlling military activities of the cadet corps, the preparation and presentation of briefings and other communications, and the interviews, guidance and information to increase cadet understanding, motivation and performance.

courses.name: Preparation for Active Duty 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines advanced leadership ethics, officership, preparation for active duty and current issues affecting military professionalism. Continued emphasis is given to refining communication skills.

courses.name: Professional Officer Course (POC) Leadership Laboratory 4 1 Credit
courses.description: Advanced leadership experiences planning and controlling military activities of the cadet corps, the preparation and presentation of briefings and other communications, and the interviews, guidance and information to increase cadet understanding, motivation and performance.

courses.name: Foundations of Officership 2 Credits
courses.description: Purpose and organization of the Army Reserve Officer Training Corps (ROTC) and the United States Army. Introduction to military customs and traditions, rank structure and the role of an Army officer. Each student must register for and attend a two-hour weekly leadership laboratory (MSL 1001L).

courses.name: Freshman Leadership Laboratory 0 Credits
courses.description: Laboratory consists of a two-hour block of instruction that directly supports freshman classroom instruction. Participation in at least one weekend field training session, one community service project and two army physical fitness tests are required.

courses.name: Basic Leadership 2 Credits
courses.description: Study and application of the Army ROTC Leadership Development Program (LDP). Instruction includes theory and application of leadership principles, competencies and dimensions. Individual leadership is developed through hands-on instruction in basic, individual military skills. Introduces students to leadership attributes and the application of those attributes in and out of the classroom. Students must register for and attend a two-hour weekly leadership laboratory (MSL 1002L).

courses.name: Freshman Leadership Laboratory 0 Credits
courses.description: Laboratory consists of a two-hour block of instruction that directly supports freshman classroom instruction. Participation in at least one weekend field training session, one community service project and two army physical fitness tests are required.

courses.name: Individual Leadership Studies 2 Credits
courses.description: The future leader through classroom instruction, laboratory application and an in-depth look at basic troop/organization leadership principles and skills. Provides training on the basics of rifle marksmanship and instruction on the principles of modern warfare and effective writing. Students must register for and attend a two-hour weekly leadership laboratory (MSL 2101L).

courses.name: Sophomore Leadership Laboratory 0 Credits
courses.description: Laboratory consists of a two-hour block of instruction that directly supports sophomore classroom instruction. Participation in at least one weekend field training session, one community service project and two army physical fitness tests are required.

courses.name: Leadership and Teamwork Techniques 2 Credits
courses.description: The future leader through classroom instruction, laboratory application and an in-depth look at basic troop/organization leadership principles and skills. Provides training on the basics of rifle marksmanship and instruction on the principles of modern warfare and effective writing. Students must register for and attend a two-hour weekly leadership laboratory.

courses.name: Sophomore Leadership Laboratory 0 Credits
courses.description: Laboratory consists of a two-hour block of instruction that directly supports sophomore classroom instruction. Participation in at least one weekend field training session, one community service project and two army physical fitness tests are required.

courses.name: Leadership and Problem Solving 3 Credits
courses.description: Instruction for the advanced ROTC cadet in infantry squad tactics and operations to broaden general military skills and enhance performance at ROTC Advanced Camp. Topics include the ROTC Leadership Development Program (LDP), land navigation and map reading, basic rifle marksmanship techniques, effective written and oral communication skills, troop leading procedures and infantry squad offensive and defensive operations. Cadets must attend a two-hour weekly leadership laboratory and participate in a physical fitness program given at times other than normal class sessions.

courses.name: Leadership and Ethics 3 Credits
courses.description: Improves cadet proficiency in those military subjects necessary to meet minimum standards of technical competence and self-confidence required of a junior officer in the US Army. Prepares cadets for participation at ROTC advanced camp. Major emphasis during course is physical training and field training exercises. Student must attend a weekly two-hour leadership laboratory and participate in physical fitness sessions given at times other than normal class sessions.

courses.name: Leadership and Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Designed to prepare cadets for duty as commissioned officers. Instruction centers on proficiency/familiarization with the military justice system, military administration, the officer professional management system, international laws of war and principles of management/leadership. Students also participate in a physical fitness program.

courses.name: Independent Study 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Readings and discussion in advanced topics of military science.

courses.name: Advanced Leader Training 4 Credits
courses.description: National advanced leader's course is the Army's 5-week leader internship conducted at Fort Lewis, Washington, from June through August. The camp places each cadet and officer candidate in a variety of leadership positions, many of which simulate stressful combat situations. Cadets are evaluated by platoon tactical officers and NCOs. Training is organized into separate committees in a tiered structure, including basic military skills, leadership development, tactical training, basic rifle marksmanship and situational training exercises. Evaluation is continual.

courses.name: Naval Science Laboratory 0 Credits
courses.description: Drill, basic commands, courtesies and honors, orientation and information.

courses.name: Introduction to Naval Science 2 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to the naval profession and to concepts of seapower. Instruction emphasizes the mission, organization and warfare components of the Navy and Marine Corps. Included is an overview of officer and enlisted ranks and rates, training and education and career patterns. Also covers naval courtesy and customs, military justice, leadership and nomenclature, and exposes the student to the professional competencies required to become a naval officer.

courses.name: Seapower and Maritime Affairs 3 Credits
courses.description: US naval history from the Phoenicians to the present with emphasis on major developments. Included is an in-depth discussion of the geopolitical theory of Mahan. Discusses present-day concerns in sea-power and maritime affairs, including the economic and political issues of merchant marine commerce, the Navys involvement in liberation and terrorist movements overseas and the massive changes in the US Navy due to the breakup of the Soviet Union.

courses.name: Naval Science Laboratory 0 Credits
courses.description: Drill, basic commands, courtesies and honors, orientation, and information.

courses.name: Naval Ships Systems 1: Engineering 3 Credits
courses.description: Basic power systems used in naval propulsion systems, a basic understanding of the thermodynamic process, a working knowledge of major auxiliary ship systems and basic consideration for ship design and stability. Basic electrical theory and damage control are also included.

courses.name: Naval Ships Systems 2: Weapons 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to the theory, characteristics and principles of operation of naval weapons systems. Includes coverage of types of weapons and fire control systems, capabilities and limitations, theory of target acquisition, identification and tracking, trajectory principles and basics of naval ordinance.

courses.name: Naval Science Laboratory 0 Credits
courses.description: Practical exercises dealing with the specifics of naval organizations and leadership.

courses.name: Navigation and Naval Operations 1 3 Credits
courses.description: A comprehensive study of the theory, principles and procedures of ship navigation and movements. Piloting and dead reckoning as well as principles of celestial and electronic navigation. In-depth exposure to the navigational rules-of-the-road and the international regulations for preventing collisions at sea and their application to effective safe navigation. Also includes practical lab work in charting and publication usage.

courses.name: Navigation and Naval Operations 2 3 Credits
courses.description: A continuation of navigation and naval operations. Relative motion theory and the use of a maneuvering board. An understanding of the force, techniques and concepts associated with ship handling, including shipboard watch organization, communication systems and environmental considerations. The role of leadership ethics is discussed while developing an understanding of the process of command and control, dealing specifically with information exchange, conflict resolution and crisis decision making.

courses.name: Evolution of Warfare 3 Credits
courses.description: The forms of warfare employed by great people in history, within the context of historical flow or continuity in the evolution of warfare. Course develops a basic sense of strategy, demonstrates alternative military actions and explores the impact of historical precedent on military thought and actions as practiced by the great leaders and military organizations. (S) (WR; 4000-word writing credit)

courses.name: Fundamentals of Maneuver Warfare 3 Credits
courses.description: Analyzes the United States Marine Corps as the overarching case study for the advent of maneuver warfare. The value is not simply to learn what has happened in the past, but to use these lessons as the basis for making practical judgments about the present and future.

courses.name: Naval Science Laboratory 0 Credits
courses.description: Practical exercises dealing with naval organizations and leadership.

courses.name: Leadership and Management 2 Credits
courses.description: The principles of naval administration, stressing the experimental approach to learning the principles of leadership and management. The student develops skills in the areas of communication, counseling, control, direction, leadership and management functions and responsibilities through active, guided participation in naval-based case studies, experimental exercises and situational problems. Total quality leadership and professional responsibilities are included.

courses.name: Leadership and Ethics 3 Credits
courses.description: Equips the NROTC student with the skills and abilities required for competence as a commissioned officer. This final capstone course in the NROTC curriculum builds upon and focuses the managerial, professional and ethical competencies developed during previous summer cruise training and naval science courses. Ethical philosophies and real-world situations are studied through lectures, exercises and case studies. Naval personnel management, the administration of discipline and human resource management are additional areas of focus.

courses.name: Independent Study 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Readings, assignments, student presentations and discussions on naval science.

courses.name: Assessment in Arts Education 3 Credits
courses.description: Broad foundation in all aspects of assessment as it is applied in the arts classroom, from learning theory to practical application of assessment techniques, data management, critical thinking, progress reporting, and portfolio building. Covers assessment task design in the artistic response modes; develops a series of assessments that can be implemented in the music/art classroom.

courses.name: Composition Skills 1 1 Credit
courses.description: Required for all majors in theory/composition. Workshop in composition techniques, exploring use of styles and devices of contemporary art music and presentation through the use of finale.

courses.name: Composition Skills 2 1 Credit
courses.description: Required for all majors in theory/composition. Workshop in composition techniques, exploring use of styles and devices of contemporary art music and presentation through the use of finale.

courses.name: Composition Skills 3 1 Credit
courses.description: Required for all majors in composition. Workshop in composition techniques, exploring use of styles and devices of contemporary art music and presentation through the use of finale.

courses.name: Composition Skills 4 1 Credit
courses.description: Required for all majors in composition. Workshop in composition techniques, exploring use of styles and devices of contemporary art music and presentation through use of finale.

courses.name: Composition 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Composition in simple and extended forms supplemented by analysis of selected compositions, from the standard repertoire and presentation through the use of finale.

courses.name: Composition 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Composition in simple and extended forms supplemented by analysis of selected compositions, from the standard repertoire and presentation through the use of finale.

courses.name: Composition 3 3 Credits
courses.description: Composition in extended forms supplemented by analysis of selection compositions, from the standard repertoire and presentation through the use of finale.

courses.name: Composition 4 3 Credits
courses.description: Composition in extended forms supplemented by analysis of selection compositions, from the standard repertoire and presentation through the use of finale.

courses.name: Introduction to Electroacoustic Music 3 Credits
courses.description: Survey of the techniques, history, literature and materials of electroacoustic music.

courses.name: Composition of Electroacoustic Music 3 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of MUC 4313. Projects in electroacoustic music dealing with real-time, interactivity, live-electronic and solo digital media music composition issues.

courses.name: Electroacoustic Music Composition: Digital 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of skills developed through MUC 4401, Composition of Electroacoustic Music.

courses.name: Electroacoustic Music Composition: Digital 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of skills developed through MUC 4441, Electroacoustic Music Composition: Digital 1.

courses.name: Senior Composition Recital 1 Credit
courses.description: Organization and presentation of a recital of original compositions.

courses.name: Exploring Music Teaching and Learning 1 Credit
courses.description: Introductory overview of music teaching as a profession. For those majoring in music education and those who are interested in a possible career as a music educator.

courses.name: Music Teaching as a Profession 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of philosophical, historical, psychological, and sociological perspectives on music education in schools. Discusses contemporary topics and trends including diversity, special needs students, and culturally responsive pedagogy; introduces the Florida Educator Accomplished Practices (FEAPs). Field experience in schools.

courses.name: Voice Skills 1 Credit
courses.description: Required of all music education majors. Basic technical competency and pedagogical technique for voice.

courses.name: String Skills 1 1 Credit
courses.description: Required of all music education majors. Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for the upper string instruments: violin/viola.

courses.name: String Skills 2 1 Credit
courses.description: Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for the lower string instruments: cello and double bass.

courses.name: Woodwind Skills 1 1 Credit
courses.description: Required of all music education majors. Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for clarinet and flute.

courses.name: Woodwind Skills 2 1 Credit
courses.description: Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for alto saxophone, bassoon and oboe.

courses.name: Brass Skills 1 1 Credit
courses.description: Required of all music education majors. Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for two brass instruments.

courses.name: Brass Skills 2 1 Credit
courses.description: Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for two brass instruments, other than those studied in MUE 3460.

courses.name: Percussion Skills 1 Credit
courses.description: Required of all music education majors. Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for percussion instruments.

courses.name: Percussion Skills 2 1 Credit
courses.description: Continuation of percussion teaching and performance skills.

courses.name: Music Learning with Technology 2 Credits
courses.description: Explores the role of digital technologies in creating, performing, and responding to music, with applications to the practice of K-12 music educators and the cultivation of lifelong music learning and participation.

courses.name: Music for the Elementary Child 2-3 Credits
courses.description: Helps meet state certification requirements for elementary classroom teachers. Function of elementary school music in aiding the developmental growth of children.

courses.name: Music in Elementary Schools 3 Credits
courses.description: Fundamental principles and procedures of music education in elementary school.

courses.name: Music in Secondary Schools 3 Credits
courses.description: Fundamental principles and procedures of music education in the secondary school.

courses.name: Materials and Methods of String Class Teaching 2 Credits
courses.description: The study of contemporary materials and methods suitable for use in public school string classes.

courses.name: Literature and Arranging for School Choirs 3 Credits
courses.description: Become familiar with techniques and approaches for selecting and programming literature for K-12 performing ensembles. Introduces fundamental techniques used to create arrangements of choral and vocal works in order to better meet the needs of individual singers or ensembles. Also addresses arranging for instruments.

courses.name: Literature and Arranging for Instrumental Ensembles 3 Credits
courses.description: Techniques for selecting, programming, and arranging music for school instrumental ensembles. Overview of repertoire and arranging techniques including genres, established works, composers, and publishers; pedagogical and practical considerations related to the selection and modification of music. Discussion of relevant copyright laws.

courses.name: Music Student Teaching Seminar 3 Credits
courses.description: Principles and practices of developing, teaching, and administering K-12 public school music programs.

courses.name: Teaching Secondary Choral Music 3 Credits
courses.description: Develop techniques and skills necessary to build and sustain a successful and comprehensive choral program in a secondary school setting. Students will synthesize and apply previous knowledge and skills related to vocal physiology and pedagogy, lesson and curriculum planning, sight-singing and musicianship, and other topics. Field experience in schools.

courses.name: Teaching Instrumental Music 3 Credits
courses.description: Develop musical and pedagogical knowledge, skills, and dispositions essential for teaching elementary, middle school, and high school instrumental music. Field work in schools.

courses.name: Marching Band Techniques 3 Credits
courses.description: Examination, evaluation and practical application of marching band techniques for the high school and college band director.

courses.name: Student Teaching in Music Education 9-10 Credits
courses.description: Student teaching in selected classrooms of public schools. Special seminars and continuous evaluation of teaching experiences.

courses.name: Internship in Music Teaching 3 Credits
courses.description: Build on the work done in previous music education coursework to develop competence in applying the principles of learning in K-12 music classrooms.

courses.name: Conducting 1 1-2 Credits
courses.description: Basic techniques of choral and instrumental conducting.

courses.name: Choral Conducting and Materials 2 Credits
courses.description: Basic techniques of choral conducting, score analysis, interpretation and use of basic choral materials.

courses.name: Instrumental Conducting and Materials 1-2 Credits
courses.description: Basic techniques of instrumental conducting, score analysis, interpretation and use of basic instrumental materials.

courses.name: Introduction to World Musics 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to musics of non-western cultures in comparison with music of Western European civilizations; the nature of music and the realm of ethnomusicology. (H and N)

courses.name: Popular Music in the USA: From Ragtime to Hip-Hop and Beyond 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys the musical styles, artists, audiences, and eras of American popular music in relation to the social, cultural, political, and historical contexts in which they emerged. Gives special attention to the diversity and intersecting nature of musical voices in the USA through the examination of musical styles including rock, rhythm and blues, country, punk, hip-hop, salsa, and beyond.

courses.name: Music History Survey 1 3 Credits
courses.description: A survey of music literature, styles, and techniques from antiquity to c. 1750. Examines representative repertoire from historical, theoretical, and cultural contexts and develops critical thinking skills in reading, writing, analysis, and listening.

courses.name: Music History Survey 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys music literature, styles, and techniques from c. 1750 to the present day, and examines representative repertoire from historical, theoretical, and cultural contexts. Also develops critical-thinking skills in reading, writing, analysis, and listening.

courses.name: Popular and Traditional Musics of Africa 3 Credits
courses.description: A study of traditional and popular African musical styles placed within their historical, social and cultural environments. (H and N)

courses.name: Music and Healing in Contemporary Africa 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the historical role of music in healing traditions across African by exploring practices based around dance, religion, ritual and modern health care methodologies. Outlines the changing historical perspectives of Western rational thought on art-based practices, contextualizing contemporary approaches throughout the continent.

courses.name: Latin American Music 3 Credits
courses.description: The variable musical expressions of Latin America (including the Caribbean), their historical formations and social importance. (H and N)

courses.name: Jewish Art Music in Western Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Cultural history of western art music inspired by Jewish subjects, Biblical and non-Biblical, composed by both Jewish and non-Jewish composers, and a survey of Jewish performing musicians from the Renaissance to the present. (H and N)

courses.name: History of Jazz 3 Credits
courses.description: From African, Latin American, and Black American sources through contemporary development.

courses.name: African Popular Music and Globalization 3 Credits
courses.description: This course engages with a wide variety of African popular musics in different contexts of transformation, with the main objective of developing and nuancing our understanding of what “popular music” means in Africa within histories of culture contact. The course will provide foundational understanding of the field of ethnomusicology and popular music studies, with particular attention to how African music has been impacted by globalization through its contact with the West.

courses.name: Jazz, Hip Hop, and African Connections 3 Credits
courses.description: Considers how African music and culture have influenced African American musical expression since the beginning of the transatlantic slave trade and up through the development of the blues, jazz, soul music, hip hop, and RB. Also considers how such cultural flows have moved in both directions, from the foundations of African American music in African aesthetics, to the ways that jazz and hip-hop musicians have made explicit reference or taken inspiration from Africa.

courses.name: Timbre: Critical Discussions 3 Credits
courses.description: Critically examines timbre by engaging with the following questions: What is timbre, and how is it related to sound? What scholarship has addressed timbre and in what ways? How can timbre be effectively discussed and written about? By exploring timbre in classical and popular music genres, as well as in specific works, and by considering timbre through lenses such as music education and race, seek to better understand what some scholars argue is a rather nebulous phenomenon.

courses.name: Music and Audience 3 Credits
courses.description: Considers the role and function of the audience in conjunction with the symphony, opera, and ballet. Historical readings cover what audiences were like in the Classical Period, Romantic Era, and the Twentieth Century, and major masterworks of those time periods are discussed. The modern audience is considered by discussing recent publications in various mediums and attending two live concerts.

courses.name: Special Topics in Music History 3 Credits
courses.description: Rotating topics of current or special interest to students or instructors.

courses.name: Experiencing Music 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines how we experience music and how it teaches us about ourselves and our world. Illuminates how music both shapes and is shaped by social, political, national, and cultural forces. Music from around the world demonstrates a variety of musical experiences within historical and contemporary cultural settings. (H and N)

courses.name: Baroque Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Compositions of Monteverdi, Gabrieli, Schultz, Buxtehude, Bach, Handel and others.

courses.name: The American Musical: Broadway and Beyond 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides non-music majors and music minors with an introduction to the history and development of the American musical, focusing on the genre's relationship to American culture and society. Topics include musical and dramatic features of specific works, principal creators and performers, commercialization and popularity, the genre's relationship to film, its role in the formation of America's national identity, and its communication of American values, attitudes and norms with regard to different cultures. (H)

courses.name: Renaissance Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Renaissance literature surveys the music from the period roughly 1430-1600, stressing the major genres of mass, motet, madrigal and chanson, and touching on less prominent regional practices and instrumental music. The music is placed into social and historical context. (H and N)

courses.name: Romantic Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Representative Romantic literature in such genres as the symphony, symphonic poem, opera, song, chamber music, piano music and sacred music. Composers from Beethoven through Mahler. (H and N)

courses.name: Contemporary Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Twentieth-century music literature, including works of Debussy, Ravel, Stravinsky, Schoenberg, Webern, Berg, Hindemith, Bartok, Copland, Sessions, Boulez and Stockhausen. (H and N)

courses.name: Piano Literature Seminar 2-3 Credits
courses.description: A survey of piano literature from early keyboard works to the present.

courses.name: Woodwind Literature Seminar 2 Credits
courses.description: An intensive, investigative study of representative repertoire for woodwind instruments.

courses.name: Brass Literature Seminar 2 Credits
courses.description: An intensive, investigative study of standard repertoire for brass instruments.

courses.name: Percussion Literature Seminar 2 Credits
courses.description: An intensive, investigative study of standard repertoire for solo percussion and percussion ensemble.

courses.name: Organ Literature Seminar 2 Credits
courses.description: A survey of the major trends and styles of organ composition from the Renaissance to the present.

courses.name: Song Literature Seminar 2-3 Credits
courses.description: The study and performance of representative literature for the voice from each style period.

courses.name: History and Literature of Opera 3 Credits
courses.description: Offered in Miami only.

courses.name: The Music of J.S. Bach 3 Credits
courses.description: Offered in Miami only. The works of Bach with special emphasis on the historical sources of his choral and instrumental styles and detailed study of a selection of his chief works.

courses.name: The Music of W.A. Mozart 3 Credits
courses.description: Offered in Miami only. The music, life and times of Mozart.

courses.name: Found Music Business 3 Credits
courses.description: This course is intended (1) to foster a comprehensive and chronological understanding of the music business, and (2) to observe how rapid changes in the global music industry challenge music professionals and music business organizations to become more entrepreneurial in their planning and practice.

courses.name: Music Entrepreneurship Dev 3 Credits
courses.description: This course is intended to equip music students with a comprehensive foundation, resources, and skill set for improving marketability and success as a music entrepreneur upon graduation. Students will develop various skills for understanding and engaging in business, legalities, communication arts, innovative content creation, and niche development within music entrepreneurship.

courses.name: Music Production in Commercial Media 3 Credits
courses.description: Equips music students with a comprehensive foundation, resources, and skill set for improving marketability and success as a music entrepreneur upon graduation. Students will develop various skills for understanding and engaging in business, legalities, communication arts, innovative content creation, and niche development within music entrepreneurship.

courses.name: Multimedia Production for the Music Industry 3 Credits
courses.description: This course is intended to develop independent music professionals’ skills for creating enthralling multimedia content and implementing strategic communication strategies for (1) applying effective target marketing via online platforms, (2) increasing employability for multimedia music presentations, and (3) expanding vocational opportunities within various sectors of the music industry.

courses.name: Capstone Project I 3 Credits
courses.description: Synthesizing vocational interests with theory and practice by engaging in music business/entrepreneurship-related research and practice in the early stages of development of, or refinement of, a business plan, Projects reflect a comprehensive application of music business and entrepreneurship concepts. First of two capstone courses.

courses.name: Capstone Project 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Synthesize vocational interests with theory and practice by engaging in music business/entrepreneurship-related research and practice in the final stages of development of, or refinement of, a business plan. Projects reflect a comprehensive application of music business and entrepreneurship concepts. Second of two capstone courses.

courses.name: Marching Band 1 Credit
courses.description: Performance of marching band literature.

courses.name: Concert Band 1 Credit
courses.description: Performance of general and popular band literature. (H)

courses.name: Symphonic Band 1 Credit
courses.description: Performance of traditional and contemporary band literature. (H)

courses.name: Wind Symphony 1 Credit
courses.description: Performance of wind ensemble literature. (H)

courses.name: University Orchestra 1 Credit
courses.description: Standard orchestra literature. (H)

courses.name: University Choir 1 Credit
courses.description: An advanced choral group providing specialized study performance opportunities for vocally qualified students. (H)

courses.name: Women's Chorale 1 Credit
courses.description: Vocal training and public performances of standard female chorus repertoire. (H)

courses.name: Men's Glee Club 1 Credit
courses.description: Vocal training and public performance of standard male chorus repertoire. (H)

courses.name: Percussion Ensemble 1 Credit
courses.description: The study and performance of ensemble literature for percussion instruments. (H)

courses.name: Chamber Music Ensemble 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Examination and performance of standard repertoire for chamber ensembles.

courses.name: Jazz Bands 1 Credit
courses.description: Standard and experimental jazz ensembles. A jazz laboratory. (H)

courses.name: World Music Ensemble – African Popular Music Ensemble 1 Credit
courses.description: Specializes in the popular music of the African continent, with a special focus on Afrobeat, highlife, soukous, African jazz, and the brass band traditions of Africa and the diaspora.

courses.name: Laptop and Electronic Arts Ensemble 1 Credit
courses.description: Explores composing and coding for and performance with live electronic musical instruments. Also covers fundamentals of sound synthesis, audio programming, instrument design, human-computer interaction, sound-driven multimedia, data sonification, and electronic concert production and documentation. Using the instruments that they design, students perform their electronic works and works of their colleagues during a two concert experiences over the course of the semester.

courses.name: World Music Ensemble 1 Credit
courses.description: The rehearsal and performance of folk and traditional musics of the world. (H)

courses.name: Commercial Music Ensemble 1 Credit
courses.description: Provides the tools and experience necessary to excel as musicians in the commercial music world. Analyze, study, arrange, and perform a variety of commercial styles including rock, pop, jazz, funk, alternative, country, soul, RB, Latin, World, and more.

courses.name: Marching Band 1 Credit
courses.description: Performance of marching band literature.

courses.name: Concert Band 1 Credit
courses.description: Performance of general and popular band literature.

courses.name: Symphonic Band 1 Credit
courses.description: Performance of traditional and contemporary band literature.

courses.name: Wind Symphony 1 Credit
courses.description: Performance of wind ensemble literature. (H)

courses.name: University Orchestra 1 Credit
courses.description: Standard orchestra literature. (H)

courses.name: University Choir 1 Credit
courses.description: An advanced choral group providing specialized study performance opportunities for vocally qualified students. (H)

courses.name: Women's Chorale 1 Credit
courses.description: Vocal training and public performances of standard female chorus repertoire.

courses.name: Men's Glee Club 1 Credit
courses.description: Vocal training and public performance of standard male chorus repertoire.

courses.name: University Chamber Singers 1 Credit
courses.description: Study and performance of early and contemporary vocal literature. (H)

courses.name: Two Piano Literature 2 Credits
courses.description: Offered in Miami only.

courses.name: Chamber Music 1-2 Credits
courses.description: Exploration of the assigned repertoire through weekly one-hour coaching sessions with the instructor, a minimum of three hours weekly of unsupervised group rehearsal and a final performance by each group on the class recital. Students will study the art of chamber music interpretation and performance and develop effective group rehearsal technique.

courses.name: New Music Ensemble 1 Credit
courses.description: Rehearsal and performance of repertoire for small ensembles written in the 20th and 21st centuries.

courses.name: Musical Theatre Ensemble 1 Credit
courses.description: Offered in Miami only. Examination and performance of standard repertoire for the musical theatre.

courses.name: Jazz Bands 1 Credit
courses.description: Standard and experimental jazz ensembles. A jazz laboratory.

courses.name: Jazz Chamber Music 1 1 Credit
courses.description: Small group ensemble performance experience in the jazz idiom. Students will memorize jazz standards and learn melody interpretation techniques, rhythmic techniques to communicate to other members of the ensemble and small group compositional techniques for harmonizing jazz standards and original compositions.

courses.name: World Music Ensemble 1 Credit
courses.description: The rehearsal and performance of folk and traditional musics of the world.

courses.name: World Music Ensemble - African Popular Music Ensemble 1 Credit
courses.description: Specializes in the popular music of the African continent, with a special focus on Afrobeat, highlife, soukous, African jazz, and the brass band traditions of Africa and the diaspora.

courses.name: Ensemble Participation 0 Credits
courses.description: Ensemble of variable instrumentation and/or voices performing traditional and contemporary repertoire. For upper-division students who have completed required credits of ensemble participation or elective credits for their degree program, this ensemble exists to allow them to continue performing in ensembles without impacting semester load credits, or excess hours credits. This course allows students from any degree to continue participation in ensembles in support of the university.

courses.name: Musical Theatre Instrumental Ensemble 1 Credit
courses.description: Provides an intermediate understanding of musical theatre instrumental styles and practices from the 1930s to the present. Incorporating one or more of these forms and techniques each semester, it’s recommended for musicians who would like to broaden their commercial repertoire and enhance their skills for professional engagements.

courses.name: Music Internship Ensemble 1 Credit
courses.description: Provides supervised, evaluated, and practical music business-related training in music ensembles on- and off-campus, such as facilitating audio and media products (recordings and promotional videos), marketing materials (flyers and social media advertisements), and managerial tasks that advance designated ensemble success.

courses.name: Opera Workshop 1 Credit
courses.description: Study and performance of works from opera and operetta.

courses.name: Music and the Catholic Church 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the music of the Catholic Church from historical and artistic perspectives and presents issues that have surrounded major changes in the church's music. Focuses on six historical periods in which the church was significantly focused on musical developments or changes. Views the music from various cultural perspectives, primarily US and European.

courses.name: Recital Attendance 0 Credits
courses.description: Attendance at concerts and recitals. Check the School of Music student's handbook for specific attendance requirements.

courses.name: Digital Musicianship and Production 2-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides the fundamentals of music technology in the context of its historical and cultural use. Addresses scientific foundations of acoustics, hearing, and digital audio as well as technical skills for music production; students will work on practical applications of these concepts and techniques. Furthermore, the instructor will encourage students to critically explore cultural aspects of music technology.

courses.name: An Echo of the Invisible World: Exploring the Relationship Between Music & Spirituality 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the relationship between music and spirituality, within and outside the context of organized religion. Consider the underlying philosophies in spiritual music and practices, compare them to contemporary American culture, and address their own beliefs and practices through selected case studies and projects.

courses.name: English Diction 1 Credit
courses.description: An English diction course for singers and choral directors to improve their capacity to respond with ease, accuracy and expression.

courses.name: French Diction 1 Credit
courses.description: A French diction course for singers and choral directors to improve their capacity to respond with ease, accuracy and expression.

courses.name: German Diction 1 Credit
courses.description: A German diction course for singers and choral directors to improve their capacity to respond with ease, accuracy and expression.

courses.name: Italian Diction 1 Credit
courses.description: An Italian diction course for singers and choral directors to improve their capacity to respond with ease, accuracy and expression.

courses.name: Language and Diction for Singers 2 2 Credits
courses.description: Offered in Miami only.

courses.name: Language and Diction for Singers 1 2 Credits
courses.description: Offered in Miami only.

courses.name: Projects and Problems in Music 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Individual work in music and music education.

courses.name: Supervised Research 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Individual guided research in music and music education.

courses.name: Introduction to Music Theory Rudiments 2 Credits
courses.description: The study of notation, scales, intervals, triads, aural skills, and keyboard skills.

courses.name: How Music Works 3 Credits
courses.description: Students gain an understanding of musics architecture on small and large scales. By learning both conceptual and applied approaches to rhythm, pitch and timbre, students prepare to analyze musical works from various times and places to be more informed, critical listeners and makers of music. Skills developed include notation, ear training and compositional techniques. (H)

courses.name: Music Theory 1 2 Credits
courses.description: Studies rhythms, intervals, motifs, phrases, melodies, chords and chord progressions, in the standard clefs through listening, playing, and writing. Chord study includes primary and secondary triads in root position and inversions, non-harmonic tones and seventh chords.

courses.name: Music Theory 2 2 Credits
courses.description: Rhythms, intervals, motifs, phrases, melodies, chords and chord progressions, in the standard clefs through listening, playing, singing and writing. Chord study includes primary and secondary triads in root position and inversions, non-harmonic tones and diatonic seventh chords.

courses.name: Theory of Music 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Rhythms, intervals, motifs, phrases, melodies, chords and chord progressions, in the standard clefs through listening, playing, singing and writing. Chord study includes primary and secondary triads in root position and inversions, non-harmonic tones and diatonic seventh chords.

courses.name: Theory of Music 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Rhythms, intervals, motifs, phrases, melodies, chords and chord progressions, in the standard clefs through listening, playing, singing and writing. Chord study includes primary and secondary triads in root position and inversions, non-harmonic tones and diatonic seventh chords.

courses.name: Jazz Aural Skills 1 1 Credit
courses.description: This course teaches students how to aurally recognize commercial chords, standard chord progressions and recognize the scales used in improvisation. This course is a hybrid course with only 7 in class meetings. The course utilizes online resources and instructional videos and online aural quizzes and weekly aural skills drills.

courses.name: Aural Skills 1 1 Credit
courses.description: First of a sequence of four courses that develop skills in sight singing and ear training. Singing techniques are taught at the beginning of the course.

courses.name: Aural Skills 2 1 Credit
courses.description: Second of a sequence of four courses that develop skills in sight singing and ear training.

courses.name: Jazz Fundamentals 1 2 Credits
courses.description: This course is fully online and provides a basic theoretical understanding of jazz harmony, jazz chord symbols, common jazz scales and modes, jazz articulations, blues forms and piano voicings. Online resources include online platform, flash cards, worksheets and 35 instructional videos.

courses.name: Jazz Fundamentals 2 2 Credits
courses.description: This course provides an intermediate theoretical understanding of jazz harmony, jazz chord symbols, common jazz scales and modes, jazz articulations, blues forms, piano voicings, the basics of tune writing and techniques in accurately memorizing jazz standards. Online resources include online platform, flash cards, worksheets and 35 instructional videos.

courses.name: Music Theory 3 2 Credits
courses.description: Using Roman numerals, analyze harmonically the music of the common practice period; includes all harmonic materials studied to date such as Borrowed chords, Neapolitan 6th chords, and Augmented 6th chords. The study of forms from the 18th and 19th Centuries.

courses.name: Music Theory 4 2 Credits
courses.description: The study of the materials and structures of tonal and post-tonal music through reading, listening, model composition, and music analysis.

courses.name: Theory of Music 3 3 Credits
courses.description: Modulation, secondary dominants, diminished sevenths, Neapolitan and augmented sixth, chords of the ninth, eleventh, thirteenth, sight singing and dictation.

courses.name: Theory of Music 4 3 Credits
courses.description: Modulation, secondary dominants, diminished sevenths, Neapolitan and augmented sixth, chords of the ninth, eleventh, thirteenth, sight singing and dictation.

courses.name: Commercial Aural Skills I 1 Credit
courses.description: Provides a comprehensive foundation in commercial aural skills by engaging in focused aural activities and exercises that fortify competencies to pursue a commercial music career. Topics include aurally identifying or transcribing commercial music elements such as harmony, grooves (rhythms and styles), repertoire, and audio production parameters.

courses.name: Commercial Aural Skills 2 1 Credit
courses.description: Builds on MUT 2213L by engaging in focused aural activities and exercises that fortify competencies to pursue a commercial music career. Topics include aurally identifying or transcribing commercial music elements such as advanced harmony, grooves (rhythms and styles), genres, and audio production parameters.

courses.name: Aural Skills 3 1 Credit
courses.description: Third of a sequence of four courses that develop skills in sight singing and ear training.

courses.name: Aural Skills 4 1 Credit
courses.description: Fourth in a sequence of four courses that develop skills in sight singing and ear training.

courses.name: Arranging for Voices and Instruments 3 Credits
courses.description: Study of voices and instruments, singly and by family, with basic scoring for standard ensemble combinations.

courses.name: Scoring for Band and Orchestra 3 Credits
courses.description: Transcribing and arranging for full band and orchestra, including preparation of parts for performance.

courses.name: Form and Analysis 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Analysis of melodic structures and homophonic forms of the common practice period including binary, ternary, rondo and sonata-allegro forms.

courses.name: Form and Analysis 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Analysis of contrapuntal forms of canon, motet and fugue; study of musical forms in the 20th century.

courses.name: Musical Data Structures 3 Credits
courses.description: Engage with computational methods for the analysis and generation of musical materials and structures to better understand how humans produce and interact with them. Topics covered include music representation and encoding, music information retrieval, corpus studies, machine improvisation, and procedural music generation. These techniques will be considered in the context of many different aesthetics, styles, genres, theoretical frameworks, and societal contexts.

courses.name: Jazz Arranging 1 2 Credits
courses.description: This course provides instruction in jazz composition and arranging as well as the basic techniques for commercial song writing. Students will study chord movement, melodic development and composition techniques for various styles of music. Students will complete several small group arrangements and original jazz compositions.

courses.name: Jazz Arranging 2 2 Credits
courses.description: This course provides instruction in jazz composition and arranging as well as the basic techniques for commercial song writing. Students will score a large group arrangement and a big band chart for eight brass, five saxophones and four rhythm section players.

courses.name: Counterpoint 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Addresses the practice of two-voice counterpoint in Renaissance and Baroque styles with additional focus on historical context. Through composition, study, performance and listening, students gain fluency in both strict and free two-part counterpoint, compound melody, canon, antiphon and inventions.

courses.name: Counterpoint 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Continues the study of counterpoint begun in MUT 4401, expanding two-voice composition and analysis into three and four voices. Straddling the late Renaissance and the Baroque, the techniques covered in this class prepare students to write and fully comprehend modal motets as well as tonal fugues. Through analysis, composition, study, performance and listening, students will gain competence in the strict techniques and idioms of multi-voiced imitative entrance, sequence and subject harmonization. Students will also familiarize themselves with Bach's The Well-Tempered Clavier both for its technical uses of counterpoint, exemplary and exceptional, and its historical significance. The course concludes with a brief excursion into the use of chromaticism in later contrapuntal styles.

courses.name: Modal Counterpoint 3 Credits
courses.description: Free and strict counterpoint in the 16th century modal style through listening, reading, playing, singing and writing.

courses.name: Tonal Counterpoint 3 Credits
courses.description: Counterpoint in the 18th-century style through listening, reading, playing, singing and writing.

courses.name: Score Reading 2 Credits
courses.description: Score-reading at the keyboard. Exercises in realization of music in two or more staves and clefs, and involving instrumental transpositions.

courses.name: Advanced Jazz Musicianship 2 Credits
courses.description: Instruction covers implementing jazz harmony, chord symbols, jazz scales and modes, jazz articulations, and techniques for accurately memorizing jazz standards. Lessons focus on implementing these concepts in jazz performances. This course uses the music of the blues, jazz standards, and contemporary music as "play along" tools.

courses.name: Junior Recital 1 Credit
courses.description: All music majors in the Bachelor of Music program must present a public recital during their junior year. See areas of emphasis for specific requirements.

courses.name: Brass Instruments Pedagogy 3 Credits
courses.description: An analysis of the principles, methods and practices currently used in the teaching of brass instruments.

courses.name: Senior Recital 1 Credit
courses.description: All music performance majors must present a public recital during their senior year. See areas of emphasis for specific requirements.

courses.name: Commercial Keyboard Skills 1 1 Credit
courses.description: Provides a comprehensive foundation in commercial keyboard skills by engaging in activities and exercises that fortify competencies to pursue a commercial music career. Topics include standard commercial chord progressions, eight-bar comping patterns and riffs, bass lines, ii-V-I progressions, and lead sheets.

courses.name: Commercial Keyboard Skills 2 1 Credit
courses.description: Provides a comprehensive foundation in commercial keyboard skills by engaging in activities and exercises that fortify competencies to pursue a commercial music career. Topics include advanced chord voicings, songs, improvisations, and lead sheets utilizing various commercial keyboard patches.

courses.name: Secondary Piano 3 1-3 Credits
courses.description: This course is required of all music majors, with the exception of keyboard majors. Levels (3) and (4) may be exempted by examination.

courses.name: Secondary Piano 4 1-3 Credits
courses.description: This course is required of all music majors, with the exception of keyboard majors. Levels (3) and (4) may be exempted by examination.

courses.name: Accompanying 2 Credits
courses.description: Instrumental chamber music, song, orchestral reductions and editions.

courses.name: Junior Recital 1 Credit
courses.description: All music majors in the Bachelor of Music program must present a public recital during their junior year. See areas of emphasis for specific requirements.

courses.name: Improvisational Keyboard Skills and Related Technology 2 Credits
courses.description: Study of improvisational skills, electric keyboard technology, and musical styles outside of the classical realm.

courses.name: Organ Pedagogy 3 Credits
courses.description: An analysis of the principles, methods and practices currently in the teaching of organ.

courses.name: Piano Pedagogy 3 Credits
courses.description: An analysis of the principles, methods and practices currently used in the teaching of piano.

courses.name: Senior Recital 1 Credit
courses.description: All music performance must present a public recital during the senior year. See areas of emphasis for specific requirements.

courses.name: Junior Recital 1 Credit
courses.description: All music majors in the Bachelor of Music program must present a public recital during their junior year. See areas of emphasis for specific requirements.

courses.name: Percussion Pedagogy 3 Credits
courses.description: Help future applied and classroom teachers develop the skills necessary to be successful. Teaching projects focus on applied teaching and requires group instruction. Required for Percussion Performance majors.

courses.name: Senior Recital 1 Credit
courses.description: All music performance majors must present a public recital during the senior year. See areas of emphasis for specific requirements.

courses.name: Class Guitar 1 Credit
courses.description: Introduction to playing the guitar which assumes no prior instruction. There is no previous experience required, and all students who have expressed a desire to learn how to play the guitar are welcome.

courses.name: Class Guitar 2 1 Credit
courses.description: Class Guitar 2 is an intermediate level group class teaching students that have had prior guitar experience or have taken Class Guitar 1 (beginner level). Prior experience or skill is necessary and the course is open to all students regardless of major.

courses.name: Guitar 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Courses offered under the MVS 1416, 2426, 3436, 4446 heading are intended to teach intermediate through advanced study of classical guitar and are available only through the permission of the instructor. Lesson times will be arranged at the beginning of each semester.

courses.name: Junior Recital 1 Credit
courses.description: All music majors in the Bachelor of Music program must present a public recital during their junior year. See areas of emphasis for specific requirements.

courses.name: Guitar 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Courses offered under the MVS 1416, 2426, 3436, 4446 heading are intended to teach intermediate through advanced study of classical guitar and are available only through the permission of the instructor. Lesson times will be arranged at the beginning of each semester.

courses.name: String Instrument Pedagogy 3 Credits
courses.description: An introduction to the teaching of basic string instrument techniques.

courses.name: Senior Recital 1 Credit
courses.description: All music performance majors must present a public recital during their senior year. See areas of emphasis for specific requirements.

courses.name: Junior Recital 1 Credit
courses.description: All music majors in the Bachelor of Music program must present a public recital during their junior year. See areas of emphasis for specific requirements.

courses.name: Vocal Pedagogy 1-3 Credits
courses.description: An analysis of various methods, principles and practices in the teaching of voice.

courses.name: Senior Recital 1 Credit
courses.description: All music performance and church music majors must present a public recital during their senior year. See areas of emphasis for specific requirements.

courses.name: Junior Recital 1 Credit
courses.description: All music majors in the Bachelor of Music program must present a public recital during their junior year. See areas of emphasis for specific requirements.

courses.name: Woodwind Instruments Pedagogy 3 Credits
courses.description: An analysis of the principles, methods and practices currently used in the teaching of woodwind instruments.

courses.name: Senior Recital 1 Credit
courses.description: All music performance majors must present a public recital during their senior year. See areas of emphasis for specific requirements.

courses.name: Engineering Directed Independent Research 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research with a faculty advisor or postdoctoral or graduate student mentor. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Prep for Success 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Freshman success course that includes academic preparation in calculus, chemistry, student success, and technical communications.

courses.name: Introduction to Nuclear Engineering 1 Credit
courses.description: Introduction to the nuclear engineering field and careers in the nuclear industry. Topics include engineering ethics, nuclear history, elementary nuclear and reactor physics, reactor types, nuclear safety, nuclear fuel cycle and radiation protection.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Nuclear Engineering 2 Credits
courses.description: Two one-hour lectures discussing fundamental concepts in nuclear engineering, including nuclear physics, nuclear reactors, careers in nuclear engineering and related fields, and current issues in nuclear engineering.

courses.name: Reactor Thermal Engineering 1 4 Credits
courses.description: Covers the first and second laws of thermodynamics and their applications to nuclear fission reactor systems, including power cycle analysis; steady-state and transient conduction with applications; and the current regulatory structure for nuclear fission reactors.

courses.name: Nuclear Engineering Analysis 1 4 Credits
courses.description: Continuous and discrete variable solution methods for the statistical, algebraic, differential and integral equations important in nuclear engineering. Topics covered include probabilities and statistics, basic programming, linear algebra.

courses.name: Nuclear Engineering Analysis 2 4 Credits
courses.description: A continuation of ENU 4001. Nuclear application contents: finite diff./geometries, numerical methods, differential equations and solution methods of relevance to nuclear problems, basic AI-components.

courses.name: Reactor Analysis and Computation 1: Statics 4 Credits
courses.description: Three one-hour lectures discussing neutron reactions, fission chain and criticality and neutron transport/diffusion for nuclear reactors. Neutron thermalization and thermal scattering kernels. Dynamic analysis of reactors including point and space-time models. Feedback and reactor dynamics and control. Short-term transient analysis and long-term time-dependence.

courses.name: Reactor Analysis and Computation 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of ENU 4103. Three one-hour lectures discussing neutron thermalization and thermal scattering kernels. Treatment of resonances and Doppler broadening. Dynamic analysis of reactors including point model and space-time models. Feedback and reactor dynamics and control. Short-term transient analysis and long-term time dependence.

courses.name: Reactor Thermal Engineering 2 4 Credits
courses.description: Covers single-phase flow and convective and radiative heat transfer topics for the analysis and design of light water reactors, as well the technology of existing pressurized water reactors

courses.name: Reactor Thermal Hydraulics 4 Credits
courses.description: Nuclear applications of fluid mechanics, heat transfer and thermodynamics. Two-phase flow and boiling heat transfer. Heat transfer mechanisms in reactor core and sub-channel thermal hydraulics. Steam generator, power cycles, and balance of plant. Introduction to thermal design for reactors.

courses.name: Nuclear Power Plant Reactor Systems 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Three one-hour lectures discussing the basis for light water reactor (LWR) design; the NRC design criteria for LWRs.
