courses.description: Must be taken in conjunction with other political science courses at the 3000/4000 level. Required for students pursuing the department honors program.

courses.name: Political Internship 3 Credits
courses.description: Internship in government and politics. Internships are available at all levels - local, state and federal - and in every branch of government - executive, legislative and judicial. Other internships are available with political parties, interest groups, lobbying organizations, international organizations and private companies engaged in governmental relations and issue research. Readings and paper required. Only three credits of POS /PAD 4940 credit may be counted toward the major.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 1-15 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: Senior Thesis 2-4 Credits
courses.description: One of three required courses for students who are writing an honors thesis. Students work under the supervision of their thesis advisor. Generally, this course is taken in the second semester of the one-year thesis process. Students receive a letter grade for their work.

courses.name: Introduction to Political Theory 3 Credits
courses.description: Basic principles of political thought. Examines the nature of the state and of the relationship between the individual and the state. Covers topics such as authority, consent, freedom and obligation. (H)

courses.name: Political Ideologies 3 Credits
courses.description: Seeks understanding of the contemporary spectrum of political beliefs from liberal democracy to the ideological ideas of the far right. Examines the effects of ethical, historical, political and psychological perspectives on these belief systems.

courses.name: Environmental Ethics and Politics 3 Credits
courses.description: An intensive investigation into the history and theory of environmental ethical and political thought.

courses.name: Great Political Thinkers: Ancient and Medieval 3 Credits
courses.description: Major early political theorists including Plato, Aristotle, St. Augustine and St. Thomas Aquinas. Emphasis on the principles of a just political order: natural law, civic virtue, constitutionalism. Analysis of church-state struggles and the emergence of the modern state. (H)

courses.name: Great Political Thinkers: Machiavelli to Marx 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies selected political theorists from Machiavelli to Marx. Emphasizes the ideas of authority and freedom, obligation and consent in the writing of Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, etc. Liberalism, conservatism, utilitarianism and idealism. (H) (WR)

courses.name: American Political Thought 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the history of American political thought, including an analysis of Thomas Jefferson and the Declaration of Independence, the federalist papers and the ideology of Thomas Paine. Also includes African American political thought, feminist political theories, liberalism, and the contribution of Mark Twain.

courses.name: Problems of Democracy 3 Credits
courses.description: The theory and practice of democracy, especially ideas that define a democratic order. Studies selected topics ranging from equality and majority rule to technology and the globalization of democracy. (WR)

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Political Theory 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Current Controversies in Public Policy 3 Credits
courses.description: Framework to understand the formation, adoption, budgeting, implementation and evaluation of public policy. This framework provides a basis for detailed discussions and debates about current policy issues. (S)

courses.name: Women in Politics 3 Credits
courses.description: Analyzes the roles women play in American politics, including political behavior and public policy issues.

courses.name: Florida Environmental Politics 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the politics of environmental transformation in Florida, including issues of water supply, growth management and Everglades restoration. Supplements the department's offerings in environmental politics. Can be used to satisfy requirements for the major or minor in political science, but it is also intended for (and accessible to) interested students in any major.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Public Policy 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Public Policy. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Public Policy.

courses.name: Introduction to Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the important role literature has played in individuals' lives and in society, presenting a range of literary styles and genres, from different countries and historical periods. Special attention paid to development of critical skills of analysis and interpretation. (H)

courses.name: Beginning Portuguese 1 5 Credits
courses.description: First course in the basic Portuguese language sequence, which emphasizes the language as spoken in Brazil. Develops basic communication skills in reading, writing, speaking and listening. Not open to proficient speakers of Spanish.

courses.name: Beginning Portuguese 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of the series in basic Portuguese, which emphasizes the language as spoken in Brazil. Develops basic communication skills in reading, writing, speaking and listening. Not open to proficient speakers of Spanish.

courses.name: Introduction to Portuguese and Brazil: Accelerated 5 Credits
courses.description: Designed for those with knowledge of another Romance language (usually Spanish) through study or home experience. A complete introduction to the language, assuming that students have no previous study of Portuguese. It also satisfies the CLAS and Journalism foreign-language requirement in one semester.

courses.name: Applied Portuguese 1-5 Credits
courses.description: Portuguese-language reading and discussions to accompany and complement courses of diverse content offered in other departments. Readings and discussions are in Portuguese to develop vocabulary and fluency related to the content of the companion course and to provide an international perspective on the issues of the main course. (N)

courses.name: Oral and Written Practice 3 Credits
courses.description: Intermediate-level course emphasizing all four skills; consists of printed and electronic readings, writing essays and taking notes, oral discussions and presentations, lab activities and grammar review.

courses.name: Composition and Conversation 3 Credits
courses.description: An intermediate-level course with continued expansion of vocabulary, review of essential grammar and structures and development of reading, writing and speaking skills.

courses.name: Introduction to Portuguese Translation and Interpretation 3 Credits
courses.description: Improve Portuguese language skills through application of the principles of translation while gaining information on professional opportunities in the field.

courses.name: Luso-Brazilian Civilization 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to the central historical events, political institutions, intellectual currents and artistic movements in the foundation and development of Portugal, Brazil and Lusophone Africa. Preview of topics studied in other literature and culture courses. (H and N)

courses.name: Brazilian Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to the study of modern cultural forms, including folk pageantry, performance arts, literature, film and television.

courses.name: Brazil Beyond the Beaches: Tourism and Brazilian Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the economic and cultural impacts of the multi-billion dollar tourism industry on the cultural products and practices of Brazil.

courses.name: Introduction to Portuguese Linguistics 3 Credits
courses.description: An introduction to the basic concepts and analytical techniques of linguistics, applied specifically to the Portuguese language. Practices the linguistic analysis of the sounds, words and sentences of Portuguese, with relevant comparisons to Spanish and English where applicable.

courses.name: Topics in Brazilian Culture and Civilization 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics in Brazilian culture and civilization, including racial identity, feminism, regionalism, music, film, art, religion, sports, and more.

courses.name: Internship in Portuguese 1-3 Credits
courses.description: This course complements the students' internship with guided reflection. Given the nature of our Portuguese program, students can complete their internship wherever there is interaction with Portuguese speaking communities. This program offers an open alternative so that they can customize their professional interests.

courses.name: Advanced Composition and Syntax 3 Credits
courses.description: A language course that distinguishes Portuguese from related Romance tongues, including the more difficult aspects of grammar and structure, specialized vocabulary, different stylistic registers, and application of these to translation and original composition.

courses.name: Honors Thesis 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Honors thesis preparation.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 3-6 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: Monsters of the Portuguese-Speaking World 3 Credits
courses.description: A survey of short narrative works from Portugal, Brazil, Angola and Mozambique with an emphasis on the effects of oppression and colonialism through the figure of the monster and the literary fantastic.

courses.name: Colonial Brazil: Cannibalism, Enslavement and Monarchy 3 Credits
courses.description: An interdisciplinary approach to Brazilian culture 1500-1900 to decolonialize the “myths” of the past and understand the complexities of Brazil’s society through film, art, history, anthropology and literature.

courses.name: Brazilian Short Story: Conflict and Citizenship 3 Credits
courses.description: An overview of 20th and 21st century short story by contemporary writers, with an emphasis on the social themes of conflict and citizenship.

courses.name: Dystopian Narrative in Brazil 3 Credits
courses.description: Examination of dystopian narrative as a unique vehicle for understanding the cultural and political consequences of modernity and social disparities in Brazil.

courses.name: Contemporary Brazilian Poetry 3 Credits
courses.description: A study of lyric, both literary and musical, in the second half of the 20th century, including experimental trends, political verse, popular music and youth movements.

courses.name: Brazilian Drama 3 Credits
courses.description: A survey of the milestones of Brazilian theatre with an emphasis on 20th century plays. In addition to the plays, the course also presents the theoretical framework and political context of theatrical production in Brazil. (H and N)

courses.name: The Modernist Movement in Brazilian Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Readings in fiction, poetry and essay of the nationalist and avant-garde decades of the 1920s and 1930s. Discussions are designed to situate Brazilian letters in diverse national and international contexts. Literary works are complemented by considerations of concurrent production in music and the arts.

courses.name: Becoming Brazil: Nineteenth Century to the Present 3 Credits
courses.description: A survey of nineteenth-century literature and history that examines the cultural figures, institutions and historical moments that have shaped modern Brazil and their continued relevance in contemporary Brazilian society.

courses.name: Contemporary Brazil Narrative 3 Credits
courses.description: Rotating topics may include studies in genre (the short story, the novel), theme (science fiction) or author (Rubern Fonseca, Clarice Lispector, Guimaraes Rosa). (H and N)

courses.name: Race and Gender in Machado de Assis 3 Credits
courses.description: A survey of the thought of the 19th century master of Brazilian letters Machado de Assis, with an emphasis on the themes of race and gender in his short stories, chronicles and essays.

courses.name: Deep Brazil: Culture of North and Northeast 3 Credits
courses.description: Study of the narrative and culture of the North/Northeast, including the complex histories and political conflicts of these culturally rich regions.

courses.name: Crime Fiction in Brazil 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys crime fiction and the adaption of the genre to portray Brazilian reality from 1920 to the present.

courses.name: Individual Work 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Individual work in Portuguese.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Portuguese 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Readings in Luso-Brazilian Literature and Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Diverse subjects in Brazilian and Portuguese studies, including the Brazilian Northeast, the Afro-Brazilian world, the culture of dictatorship, popular genres and popular music. In addition to readings of original texts, course may incorporate sound recordings and film.

courses.name: Soccer Explains The World 3 Credits
courses.description: Explore power dynamics and justice in soccer and understand how soccer exemplifies justice and power in society. Examine how soccer deals with problems of inequality such as racism, sexism, poverty, etc. and relate this to society in general. A multidisciplinary approach is followed.

courses.name: Brazilian Cinema 4 Credits
courses.description: Critical analysis of Brazilian film and the relationship of content to social and political forces.

courses.name: Special Topics in Lusophone Culture and Civilization 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics in Brazilian, Portuguese or Luso-African culture and civilization, including globalism, regionalism, song literature, film and video, negritude, women's movements and Amazonian discourse.

courses.name: Immersion in a Hispanic Community 3 Credits
courses.description: International service-learning course and immersion experience abroad. Comprises significant hours of community service in a Hispanic city, plus group discussions. Reflecting on learning is an important course component.

courses.name: Comparative Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Survey of approaches to and concepts of the study of animal behavior and psychology. (B)

courses.name: Personal Growth 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the concepts and techniques in psychology that apply to personal growth and development. All students have the opportunity to participate in research projects or alternative experiences. (S)

courses.name: Abnormal Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: The varieties of disordered experience and conduct, and their contribution to an understanding of more effective personal and social adjustment. Includes the neuroses, psychoses and psychosomatic and conduct disturbances. (S)

courses.name: Eating Disorders 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of the causes and treatments associated with the full range of recognized eating disorders, including anorexia, bulimia and binge eating disorder, as well as a variety of subclinical forms of problematic eating behaviors and their surrounding factors and issues.

courses.name: Developmental Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Theory and research on psychological development from prenatal stages through adulthood. (S)

courses.name: Infant Development 3 Credits
courses.description: Development from the prenatal period through three years of age with a focus on physical  cognitive and social-emotional processes. (S)

courses.name: Cognitive Development 3 Credits
courses.description: Basic principles and theories of cognitive development from infancy through early adolescence. Information-processing, Piagetian and neo-Piagetian theories are covered, as is language, memory, social cognition, concept formation, perception and attention.

courses.name: Adolescent Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Biological, psychological and sociological perspectives on adolescence, including the dynamics of socialization, self-concept and identity, peer groups and problems of adolescence. (S)

courses.name: Psychology of Aging 3 Credits
courses.description: Topics in gerontology from a life span developmental perspective, including the development of psychological problems of the aged and theoretical and methodological issues in the study of the aged. (S)

courses.name: Research Methods in Developmental Psychology 4 Credits
courses.description: Methodological approaches to the study of development including experimental and observational techniques. (S) (WR)

courses.name: Revolving Topics in Developmental Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced study in developmental psychology, including development of language and thought, social-personality development, gerontology and death and dying. Content varies; refer to the schedule of courses for the semester's topic.

courses.name: Principles of Behavior Analysis 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces and surveys the principles, methods, theories, and applications of the experimental analysis of behavior. Although EAB 3002 and EAB 3764 cannot both be taken to fulfill the Group A requirement, both courses may be taken, with one counting as an additional course toward the major. (S)

courses.name: Applied Behavior Analysis 3 Credits
courses.description: Extending learning principles to human problems in child development, education, mental health, mental retardation, behavioral medicine, business and industry, aging and environmental applications. Although students cannot take both EAB 3002 and 3764 to fulfill the Group A requirement, they can take both courses; one will count as an additional course toward the major. (S)

courses.name: Laboratory Procedures in Behavior Analysis 4 Credits
courses.description: General laboratory procedures and apparatus employed in the experimental analysis of animal behavior. Daily laboratory sessions focus upon experimental treatments, apparatus programming and data analysis. (S) (WR)

courses.name: Behaviorism and Contemporary Society 3 Credits
courses.description: Consideration of the applications of behavioral science and technology to contemporary society. Emphasis on the implications of behavior theory and the experimental analysis of behavior. (S)

courses.name: Applied Behavior Analysis with Animals: Survey of Applications 3 Credits
courses.description: Examination of applications of behavior analysis with domestic, exotic, and wild animals. Topics considered may include pet training, animal shelters, behavioral husbandry, service dogs, scent detection, and wildlife conservation.

courses.name: Laboratory in Applied Behavior Analysis 4 Credits
courses.description: Introduces research methods in applied behavior analysis. Computerized measurement and assessment of human behavior in ongoing field studies, data analysis and implementation of experimental techniques. (WR)

courses.name: Organizational Behavior Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of contemporary research and practice in the field of Organizational Behavior Management (OBM), including choosing performance targets, assessment, designing effective intervention, effective supervision, ethics, and common intervention systems such as token economies and behavior-based safety.

courses.name: Advanced Seminar in Behavior Analysis 3 Credits
courses.description: In-depth examination of topics related to behavior analysis. Some examples include developmental and intellectual disabilities, behavioral treatments for substance abuse, behavioral health and exercise, and ethics in behavior analysis. Content varies; refer to the schedule of courses for the semester's topic.

courses.name: Sensory Processes 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the human senses and their role in perception, how we sense the physical environment and what factors influence our perception of it. (B)

courses.name: Cognitive Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces human cognitive abilities, including perceptual and motor skill, attention, learning and memory, language and thinking, and the methods used to study these abilities. (S)

courses.name: Laboratory in Sensory Processes 4 Credits
courses.description: Collect, analyze, and evaluate data on specific problems related to sensory and perceptual abilities.

courses.name: Psychology of Learning and Memory 3 Credits
courses.description: Theoretical foundations of learning and memory and applications to various fields of psychology.

courses.name: Issues and Concepts in Gerontology 3 Credits
courses.description: This multidisciplinary overview of the field of aging covers biomedical and health issues, psychosocial factors, applied aspects and policy issues.

courses.name: Positive Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the history of positive psychology and its basic tenets before examining a wide range of topics that relate to happiness and well-being, including positive relationships, positive thinking, life meaning, religion/spirituality, gratitude, altruism, career development, and character strengths.

courses.name: Latinx Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: General overview of Latinx mental health concerns in the United States; examine the strengths and resilience of Latinxs; examination of structural and societal barriers in the United Sates that result in psychological distress for Latinx people.

courses.name: Advanced Seminar in Psychology of Women 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced seminar on psychological theories and research related to the psychology of women. Also integrates consideration of the intersections of gender, race/ethnicity, class, sexual-orientation, and other dimensions of diversity.

courses.name: Black Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Research, theories, and paradigms about the attitudes, behaviors, psychosocial and educational realities of Black Americans; psychosocial realities of Black Americans through an intersectionality lens.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Psychology of Health Disparities 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Seminar in Counseling Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced study in counseling psychology, including psychology of women, studies of the person and studies of self. (S)

courses.name: Psychology of Personality 3 Credits
courses.description: Development and organization of personality, description and assessment methods, results of research in personality structure and processes. (S)

courses.name: Physiological Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Survey of the biological basis of behavior with special relevance to psychology. Students cannot take both PSB 3002 and PSB 3340. (B)

courses.name: Behavioral Neuroscience 3 Credits
courses.description: Neuroanatomatical, chemical and electrophysiological studies in the biological basis of behavior. Students cannot take both PSB 3002 and PSB 3340 (PSB 3340 is recommended for IDS majors in neurobiological sciences). (B)

courses.name: Psychobiology of Abnormal Behavior 3 Credits
courses.description: Biological theories and models of developmental disabilities, schizophrenia and affective disorders, and the treatments of these conditions.

courses.name: Introduction to Cognitive Neuroscience 3 Credits
courses.description: The biological foundations of human cognition.

courses.name: Laboratory in Cognitive Neuroscience 4 Credits
courses.description: Practical training in the foundations of cognitive neuroscience with a strong focus on cognitive experiments with human participants. Engage in theoretical work and practical experiments addressing behavioral, cognitive, and physiological processes relationships between biological processes.

courses.name: Neurochemistry, Pharmacology and Behavior 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced discussion of neurotransmitters, neuromodulators and the action of neuroactive drugs in relation to behavior.

courses.name: Developmental Psychobiology 3 Credits
courses.description: Principles of neural and behavioral development stressing the correlations among structural, chemical, endocrine and behavioral events during maturation.

courses.name: Neurobiology of Learning and Memory 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced undergraduate seminar on neurobiological mechanisms of learning and memory, with concepts applied to the ways in which neuroplasticity underlies many aspects of behavior.

courses.name: Special Topics in Physiological Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Selected topics; precise content announced in advance. Provides an opportunity for in-depth study not offered in other courses.

courses.name: General Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduction to psychology; this course is the prerequisite for advanced courses. Emphasis is on psychology as a research enterprise. Students are required to participate as subjects in psychological research or to write a paper on a psychological research article. (S)

courses.name: Laboratory Methods in Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces experimental design in psychology, data analysis and interpretation of results, and literature reports.

courses.name: Psychology of Sustainability 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the psychology of sustainability and its impact on human behavior. Provides knowledge of social value orientation, environmental identity, altruism, social capital, and participatory action from a sustainability perspective.

courses.name: Introduction to Research in Psychology 1-3 Credits
courses.description: An introduction to current techniques used in psychology research. Students participate in on-going research.

courses.name: The Psychology of Pseudoscience 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the psychological causes and consequences of belief in "weird" things.

courses.name: Psychology of Eating and Obesity 3 Credits
courses.description: Comprehensive examination of theory and application of psychological and brain science principles to understanding eating behavior and the contemporary problem of overweight and obesity.

courses.name: Individual Work 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Qualified students and the instructor or supervisor choose a particular problem for investigation or studying psychology. A formal written report of the work is required.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Psychology 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Psychology. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Psychology.

courses.name: Special Topics in Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Topics in psychology that provide opportunity for in-depth study not offered in other courses.

courses.name: Introduction to Teaching in Psychology 0-3 Credits
courses.description: College-level teaching experience in psychology by serving as an undergraduate teaching assistant (TA). Each assistantship is unique, tailored to both the student's skills and knowledge and to the instructor's needs. Responsibilities may include facilitating discussion groups or study sessions, reviewing written assignments and providing evaluative feedback, and responding to student questions and inquiries.

courses.name: Internship in Psychology 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Credit is earned by completing a paid or unpaid internship with a community agency approved by the department. Students work 50 hours per credit earned. A minimum of 50 work hours is required for students enrolling for 0 credits.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 1 1-15 Credits
courses.description: This course provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: Senior Thesis 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Qualified students must write a formal research proposal to enroll in the course. They also must carry out individual research under the supervision of a faculty member and submit a formal written report.

courses.name: Social Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: A study of the social factors influencing individual behavior. Consideration of socialization, social influence and conformity, social interaction, decision-making, attitudes and opinions. (S)

courses.name: Research Methods in Social Psychology 4 Credits
courses.description: Laboratory training and basic experimental techniques and procedures used in the investigation of social-psychological processes. (S) (WR)

courses.name: Advanced Social Psychology (Revolving Topics) 3 Credits
courses.description: In-depth examination of topics in social psychology; refer to the schedule of courses to determine the topic covered each semester. Topics can include health psychology, social motivation, the self, self-presentation, group dynamics, conflict, population psychology, community psychology and the psychology of law. Content varies; refer to the schedule of courses for the semester's topic. (S)

courses.name: Psychology of Human Sexuality 3 Credits
courses.description: Examination of human sexuality in the United States from a psychological perspective, including but not limited to the following topics: Sexual desire and sexual responses, sexual development, sexual practices, sexual dysfunctions and sex therapy.

courses.name: Legal Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the interaction between individuals and the legal system; considers how the application of various psychological disciplines can inform the legal system.

courses.name: Supervised Research Experience 0-4 Credits
courses.description: An opportunity to explore an area of interest in health research or the delivery and/or administration of health services through a firsthand and supervised research experience.

courses.name: Global Public Health 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines global health threats, health production, and their relationship with social processes from an interdisciplinary perspective. Also examines how social and technical innovations provide new opportunities to address global health.

courses.name: Ethics in Artificial Intelligence: Who’s Protecting Our Health 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the ethical challenges of using artificial intelligence in Healthcare and the practice of Public Health. Students will examine predictive models used for making important health decisions, addressing factors that contribute to trustworthy artificial intelligence in health, and analyzing potential for bias, risk, and social inequity in assessing and delivering health and public health interventions.

courses.name: Global Health Disparities and Disabilities 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides students, interested in addressing health disparities among people living with disabilities, with the knowledge and understanding of health determinants that maintain their current health status globally. Special focus on low- and middle-income countries.

courses.name: Higher Thinking for Healthy Humans: AI in Healthcare and Public Health 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers history, foundational concepts and methods on artificial intelligence (AI), focusing on public health and healthcare applications, including hands-on practice on graphical/highlevel AI software. The course neither provides advanced statistical/machine learning training nor programming.

courses.name: Applied Epidemiology 3 Credits
courses.description: Principles and methods of epidemiological investigation focusing on both infectious and noninfectious diseases. Emphasizes outbreak investigations, field epidemiology and epidemiology careers.

courses.name: Introduction to Biostatistics for Health Science and Public Health 3 Credits
courses.description: Methods and public health applications for analysis of variance, correlation, simple linear regression, multiple linear regression, nonparametric and distribution-free statistical methods, and some basic concepts about survival analysis. Public health applications using statistical software. Writing data analysis reports.

courses.name: Public Health Management Leadership 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides knowledge relevant to leading public health organizations while effectively managing and motivating employees. Includes organizational behavior and theories to examine management, leadership, and application of skills in delivering public health programs.

courses.name: Environmental Concepts in Public Health 3 Credits
courses.description: Surveys major environmental health topics by examining sources, routes, media, and health outcomes associated with biological, chemical, and physical agents in the environment. Introduces the economic and legal frameworks associated with environmental health issues and public health.

courses.name: Data Visualization in the Health Sciences 3 Credits
courses.description: Learn the foundations of information visualization and sharpen skills in understanding, evaluating, and presenting AI-driven public health data. R is primarily used to explore concepts in graphic design, storytelling, data wrangling and plotting, biostatistics, and artificial intelligence.

courses.name: Introduction to Media and Communications 1 Credit
courses.description: Introduces the tools, resources and academic and extra-curricular activities offered by the College of Journalism and Communications. Includes lessons on the history and organization of the college and academic and career preparation.

courses.name: Writing Fundamentals for Communicators 3 Credits
courses.description: One-third of the course is to ensure students have sufficient skill in grammar and punctuation to write with clarity. In two-thirds of the course, students put principles of good writing into practice with short writing assignments that have real-world applications.

courses.name: Personal Branding for Communicators 1 Credit
courses.description: Professional development course that stresses how to communicate and connect as professionals. Emphasizes mastery of writing, speaking, presentation and employment-seeking skills, working with media, handling media interviews and using social media to establish a professional identity.

courses.name: Ethics and Problems in Mass Communications 3 Credits
courses.description: A cross-disciplinary introduction to ethics-relevant situations faced by media professionals. Topics include professional standards of conduct, audience representation and engagement and issues associated with the production, presentation and delivery of messages that reflect the best interests of audiences, clients and stakeholders.

courses.name: Media Entrepreneurship 1 Credit
courses.description: Introduces media entrepreneurship with a focus on how digital technologies are transforming industries. Work in teams to develop new digital media businesses. Develop and pitch ideas, explore market analysis, develop business and financial plans, and study social media strategies.

courses.name: Consumer and Audience Analytics 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides practical analytical skill-sets, benefiting those who plan careers in analytics/research, social media, media business, advertising/marketing, and public relations.

courses.name: Principles of Public Relations 3 Credits
courses.description: Nature and role of public relations in a democratic society, activities of public relations professionals, major influences that affect organizational behavior, and ethics and professional development of practitioners in the private and public sectors. Emphasizes management functions and developing effective public relations strategies.

courses.name: Diverse Voices 1 Credit
courses.description: Assesses the vital role of diversity, equity, inclusion, and access (IDEA) in public relations. Public relations professionals play a key role in telling stories that shape the perceptions of stakeholder groups. Gain insight and direction on ways to help create and support a diverse, equitable, and inclusive work environment.

courses.name: Sports Communication 3 Credits
courses.description: Instruction, analysis, and training in the principles and practice of public relations in sports organizations. Emphasizes media relations and skills essential for sports communication professionals, including handling media interactions across platforms, problems, crises, and integration of positive communications strategies with strategic goals of sports organizations.

courses.name: Public Relations Research 3 Credits
courses.description: Using principles of scientific research to establish, monitor and evaluate communications programs: research planning, theory, design - sampling, surveys, experiments, focus groups, content analysis and participant observation; qualitative and statistical analysis and reporting of research with advanced technologies.

courses.name: Social Media Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Social media management explores the use of the internet to build connections, market businesses, and engage audiences. With billions of people connected online, businesses are constantly cultivating new ways to join the online conversation. Highlights the various platforms and best techniques used in social media.

courses.name: Public Relations Strategy 3 Credits
courses.description: Develops skills in strategic public relations management based on an analysis of current and historical case studies.

courses.name: The Agency Immersion 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Gain credit while working for the advertising and public relations firm at the College of Journalism and Communications. Build expertise and gain experience in a hands-on environment by working directly with clients and industry professionals.

courses.name: Public Relations Writing 4 Credits
courses.description: Prepare to meet the demands of the marketplace for persuasive and professional public relations writing skills.

courses.name: Ethics and Professional Responsibility in Public Relations 3 Credits
courses.description: Ethical responsibilities of the public relations professional: identifying the moral dimensions of issues that arise in the practice of public relations, increasing the ability to employ reason as a tool for dealing with moral issues, providing knowledge and skills necessary to reach and justify ethical decisions, and eliciting a sense of personal and professional responsibility.

courses.name: Corporate Communication Essentials 3 Credits
courses.description: Focuses on why successful communication professionals must develop a fundamental understanding of business, whether they are in for-profit or nonprofit corporations, in-house or on the agency side, or aspire to creative or management roles. Delve into these and various other aspects of corporate communication with special emphasis on why they matter and what role tomorrow’s strategic communication professionals play.

courses.name: Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion for Public Relations Professionals 3 Credits
courses.description: Build awareness of the vital role of inclusion, diversity, equity, and access (IDEA) in public relations. While acknowledging the problems that have existed in the PR field and beyond, the goal is to provide students with the tools to be active stewards of IDEA pillars.

courses.name: Internal Communications 3 Credits
courses.description: This course focuses on the influential roles that communication managers play to address the issues, challenges, and opportunities facing internal stakeholders. Employees have long been recognized as the No. 1 stakeholder of the organizations.

courses.name: Industry Perspectives 1 Credit
courses.description: Provides insight into a particular industry topic area or focus within public relations.

courses.name: Crisis Communications 3 Credits
courses.description: Focuses on key elements of crisis and issues management: before, during, and after a crisis. In an age when a company’s every move is subject to instant, vivid, unfiltered, and global scrutiny and attack, the need for effective and proactive crisis management is greater than ever.

courses.name: International Public Relations 3 Credits
courses.description: Analyzes the impact of international activities on the public relations function.

courses.name: Principles of Fund Raising 3 Credits
courses.description: Fund raising: the high demand, low supply occupation unique to the charitable nonprofit subsector.

courses.name: Public Interest Communications 3 Credits
courses.description: Delves into strategies to drive social change, strategic planning process for social change communications campaigns, and tools and tactics that make these campaigns effective. Gain insight to the richness of the field and the power that communications has to address problems and profoundly affect peoples lives.

courses.name: Global Social Change Communication 3 Credits
courses.description: Explains core elements of strategic communications to support global social change through case studies and the application of theory. Taught from the practitioner's perspective, extensive real-life examples provide an opportunity to learn the critical functions of effective communications.

courses.name: Political Communication 3 Credits
courses.description: The political landscape is constantly evolving and the function communication plays in these shifts is essential. This course is designed to serve as an introduction to the role played by all forms of communication in contemporary American political communication.

courses.name: Social Media Listening and Analytics 3 Credits
courses.description: Social media provide a wealth of data that can help organizations better understand and build relationships with their publics. Learn to leverage social media data to draw insights about an organization and its publics, provide actionable, data-driven recommendations, and inform social media strategy. Gain hands-on experience analyzing native analytics, using measurement tools, developing evaluation plans, and building and presenting analytics reports.

courses.name: Corporate Reputation 3 Credits
courses.description: Focuses on key elements of corporate reputation which is one of the most important and yet least understood aspects of any company’s overall success and value. In today’s digital, global, highly interactive business ecosystem, where a company is subject to instant, vivid, unfiltered, and global scrutiny, the need for effective and proactive reputation management is greater than ever, and even more so recently as virtually all corporations navigate through multiple global crises.

courses.name: Integrated Communication 3 Credits
courses.description: The development of successful integrated communications programs is best described as a cross-functional process. Students learn to integrate communication elements (e.g. public relations, advertising, social media, sales promotion, event marketing, and media relations) to advance an organization’s success while building brand equity. Readings, current and historical case studies and exercises help students learn how to develop effective integrated communications approaches and plans.

courses.name: Public Relations Campaigns 3 Credits
courses.description: Utilizing the principles and techniques of public relations to create comprehensive campaigns for actual clients.

courses.name: Public Interest Communications Campaigns 3 Credits
courses.description: In this capstone experience, apply the principles and techniques of public interest communications to create comprehensive campaigns for an actual public interest client. Master the elements of a strategic communications campaign through direct experience as a practitioner. Working in teams, develop a robust, strategic, measurable, and actionable communications plan for an assigned client.

courses.name: Individual Problems 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Students and the instructor choose a problem or project which will give the student experience in their major.

courses.name: Public Relations Undergraduate Research 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides an opportunity for firsthand, supervised research. Mentored but self-directed work that enables individuals or a small group to explore an issue of interest and to communicate their results to others.

courses.name: Special Study 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Variable content provides opportunity for advanced study in the principles, processes and effects of public relations.

courses.name: Public Relations Internship 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Work with the instructor to select an appropriate work area in public relations for on-the-job training. There is a work minimum of 100 hours per semester for 1 credit; 200 hours per semester for 2 credits; 300 hours per semester for 3 credits. Requires progress reports and summary.

courses.name: Sight, Sound and Motion 3 Credits
courses.description: Visual literacy is a prerequisite for success in most areas of mass communication. Teaches fundamentals of design across print, web, and multimedia platforms. Also emphasizes how visual forms convey messages to readers.

courses.name: Indigenous Values 3 Credits
courses.description: The relation of Culture and Nature through the worldviews of indigenous people, who understand that their lives are part of, and inseparable from, the natural world. Through a variety of lectures, readings, films, and writing assignments, students explore how indigenous values offer insight on improving the quality of human futures.

courses.name: Places and Spaces 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the way humankind has shaped its world while framing particular relationships with nature and asks: what does it mean to make a mark upon the land? What does it mean to dwell, and what do the inhabited places mean to people?

courses.name: Self and Society in East Asia 3 Credits
courses.description: This interdisciplinary Quest 1 course prompts students to reconsider the nature of identities, both personal and social, as well as personhood itself, through a rigorous examination of traditional Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Vietnamese texts.

courses.name: East Asian Martial Arts Classics 3 Credits
courses.description: Prompts students to reconsider the nature of justice and power through a rigorous examination of East Asian martial arts literary and media classics. Identifies, analyzes, and compares the values and ethics embodied in these classics to better understand their—and our own—notions of justice and injustice.

courses.name: Medicine, Science, and the Dawn of Reason 3 Credits
courses.description: This interdisciplinary course invites students to examine the passage of humanity into the era of Reason and the Development of Medical Science and Ethics. As part of the “Nature and Culture” theme, it presents a historical narrative on the passage of humanity from superstition to the era of scientific inquiry

courses.name: Ethics and the Public Sphere 3 Credits
courses.description: Examination of the ways in which ethical concerns are aired and debated in the public sphere, including civic institutions, media organizations, and the market. Questions explored may touch on such topics as honesty in media, humility in the face of disagreement, and the pursuit of justice in a contentious society.

courses.name: Writing Life: Art, Drama, Film, Literature, Poetry, and You 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines how humanities-based texts (novels, films, plays, poems, and art) reflect and resonate with components of our personal, social, and cultural identities. To demonstrate your understanding of the course and its goals, you will write three essays and sit for two closed-book exams.

courses.name: Why Tell Stories? 3 Credits
courses.description: Exploring diverse stories in art, philosophy, literature, and film to discover how the creation and sharing of stories is a universal experience, one that is central to both humanness and existence.

courses.name: The Anim(e)ted World 3 Credits
courses.description: Uses the medium of Japanese animation (anime) to explore social, political, cultural, and economic issues of global relevance today. Examines anime containing commentary and critique relevant to some of the most pressing issues and challenges facing the contemporary world.

courses.name: An Echo of the Invisible World: Exploring the Relationship Between Music & Spirituality 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the relationship between music and spirituality, within and outside the context of organized religion. Consider the underlying philosophies in spiritual music and practices, compare them to contemporary American culture, and address their own beliefs and practices through selected case studies and projects.

courses.name: Conflict of Ideas 3 Credits
courses.description: Examination of conflict in the realm of ideas, including both factors (psychological, social, logical) that make conflicts difficult and methods that may help us engage in them in a principled and effective way. Readings are drawn from multiple disciplines, which may include philosophy, history, linguistics, sociology, and cognitive science.

courses.name: The Idea of Happiness 3 Credits
courses.description: Examination of the concept of happiness as explored in philosophy, literature, art, and other products of human culture. Readings drawn from both historical and contemporary sources are used both to articulate theories of happiness and to help students think about what kinds of lives they want to live.

courses.name: Cultural Animals 3 Credits
courses.description: Examination of the ways in which humans are products of both culture and nature, focusing on our moral and political practices. Topics may cover the evolutionary underpinnings (both biological and cultural) of our moral practices and political convictions as well as our treatment of and relationships with nonhuman animals.

courses.name: Religious Extremism 3 Credits
courses.description: What is religious extremism? Who are the extremists? This course digs into these and other questions and provides students with critical knowledge about what is called extremism within Islam, Christianity, Judaism, Hinduism, and Buddhism, while also investigating it in relation to topics such as nationalism, race(ism), and gender and sexuality.

courses.name: Autobiographical Literature & Performance 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores how modern and contemporary American artists and writers utilize self-examination as the basis for artistic creation. Often merging the factual with the theatrical or dramatic, autobiographical performance and literature personalizes the values, incidents and relationships that shape human experience and give life meaning.

courses.name: Climate Change Science and Solutions 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the evidence and effects of climate change and uses the issue of climate change to deepen student’s understanding of science and its role in society. Working collaboratively, students integrate insights from a variety of natural, social and engineering sciences to develop and evaluate climate change mitigation approaches.

courses.name: Fighting Food Waste and Loss 3 Credits
courses.description: For those interested in learning and reflecting upon the major future challenges of food and agriculture. Learn about postharvest biology, environmental and food sciences, and communication technology in reducing food waste.

courses.name: Chemistry in the Cocina Latina 3 Credits
courses.description: Cross-disciplinary exploration of the intersection between the science of chemistry and the culture of the Spanish-speaking world. Studies the chemical reactions inherent in cooking while considering the role of food in the development and maintenance of culture. Active learning in laboratory and kitchen settings enhance the course content.

courses.name: Human Physiology 3 Credits
courses.description: Functioning of human tissues, organs and organ systems, emphasizing the physical, chemical and mechanistic bases of normal physiology and the integrated function of the human body. Also introduces pathophysiological changes associated with human diseases.

courses.name: Issues and Concepts in Gerontology 3 Credits
courses.description: This multidisciplinary overview of the field of aging covers biomedical and health issues, psychosocial factors, applied aspects and policy issues.

courses.name: US Health Care System 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of organization, delivery and financing of health services in the US. Topics include health professionals, health care facilities, financing of health services, managed care, and current health policy issues.

courses.name: Introduction to Health Professions 3 Credits
courses.description: Lecture, discussion and group assignments provide the opportunity to learn about different disciplines making up a health care team and their role in both the science and practice of health care.

courses.name: Research Methods and Issues in Health Science 3 Credits
courses.description: Emphasizes four aspects of research: understanding research principles, evaluating journal articles, applying research findings to clinical settings and designing programmatic evaluation projects.

courses.name: Survey of Diseases and Disability 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of medical and psychosocial aspects of chronic diseases and disability.

courses.name: Therapeutic Communication Skills with Patients, Families and the Health Care Team 2 Credits
courses.description: Learn appropriate verbal and nonverbal behavior to be used with patients, families and the health care team through lecture, discussion and role play in large and small groups.

courses.name: Clinical Observation / Health Care Volunteer Work 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Learn about a specific health care field or gain knowledge about specific patient or client populations through direct observation and/or hands-on assistance.

courses.name: Professional Development for the Health Sciences 1 Credit
courses.description: Fosters the professional development needed to transition into the health and public health professions. Enrichment activities include diversity training, presentation skills training, career planning, and developing an online portfolio.

courses.name: Health Care Leadership: Skills and Styles 3 Credits
courses.description: Behavioral styles that contribute to leadership effectiveness. Studies specific styles for their contributions to motivating people and overall leadership effectiveness in health care.

courses.name: Disinformation and Misinformation in Healthcare 3 Credits
courses.description: Traces the interplay of misinformation and disinformation and the impact on personal and public health in the United States. Imparts understanding of the real world impact of misinformation on health outcomes and what can be done about it. Knowledge gained can be used to help understand how people are misinformed and lay the groundwork for being better informed future practitioners. Provides strategies to engage with people those influenced by misinformation or disinformation.

courses.name: Survey of Diseases and Disabilities 2 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of medical and psychosocial aspects of chronic diseases, including issues of disability management. This required course, combined with HSC 3502, covers all of the major disabling conditions.

courses.name: Psychiatric Disorders 3 Credits
courses.description: Study of major psychiatric syndromes and their management. The continuum of disorders from health to psychopathology.

courses.name: Critical Thinking in Health Care 4 Credits
courses.description: Develops critical thinking skills to solve problems in the health care environment.

courses.name: Ethical and Legal Issues in the Health Professions 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of ethical and legal issues in the health professions, including contemporary ethical issues in disease management.

courses.name: Individual Study 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Supervised program of study to investigate problems significant to health professions.

courses.name: Special Topics 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Special topics in health science. Refer to the department for specific topic information. Can be repeated with change in content for up to 12 credits.

courses.name: Honors Seminar in the Health Professions 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Philosophy and implementation of scientific work, including an introduction to faculty research. Provides the opportunity to explore and discuss potential honors thesis topics.

courses.name: Public Health and Health Professions Senior Honors Thesis 1-6 Credits
courses.description: Special project leading to the distinction of magna or summa cum laude at graduation. The project can be any creative work that focuses on a specific topic or issue in the health professions. The student develops an outline of the special project prior to project initiation and produces a final paper at project completion. The paper must be approved by the program and dean's office for the student to graduate magna or summa cum laude.

courses.name: Pathophysiology 3 Credits
courses.description: Basic understanding of pathophysiology as a change from normal physiological functioning of the various systems of the human body.

courses.name: The Nervous System and Disorders 3 Credits
courses.description: Comprehensive foundation in neuroanatomy, neurophysiology, and neuropathology.

courses.name: Introduction to Public Health 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of public health as a multifaceted field. Includes discussion of contemporary public health challenges with input from discipline experts.

courses.name: Critical Issues in Public Health 3 Credits
courses.description: Learn how to analyze, compare and contrast the most current complex public health issues in society. Students will comprehend and discuss the influence of personal bias, scientific evidence, and societal trends on a variety of public health issues.

courses.name: Public Health Concepts 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the basic tenets, applications and foci of public health, including integrating public health with other health professions.

courses.name: Special Topics in Public Health 1-6 Credits
courses.description: Exploration of a general or a specific area of public health.

courses.name: Service Learning Practicum 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers development of the role of a public health and human services provider in an agency setting.

courses.name: Therapeutic Communication Skills Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Laboratory for HSC 3661; includes hands-on practice of therapeutic communication skills using simulated patient scenarios.

courses.name: Rehabilitation Aspects of Substance Abuse 3 Credits
courses.description: Rehabilitation counseling implications of alcohol and drug use in society and the work place. Emphasis on detection, treatment and follow-up services for individuals in the rehabilitation process.

courses.name: North American Archaeology 3 Credits
courses.description: Interpretive survey of the ancient indigenous history of North America and archaeological approaches to its investigation.

courses.name: Anthropology of Religion 3 Credits
courses.description: Cross-cultural survey of beliefs and practices dealing with the supernatural, magic, and religion. Conceptualization of the supernatural. Sacred specialists, their function, and social position. Theories of comparative religion in light of anthropological data. (S and D)

courses.name: Religions of the Graeco-Roman World 3 Credits
courses.description: Development, importance and influence of Greek and Roman religion and cult practice. The main literary and epigraphical sources are read in translation. (H and N)

courses.name: Ethics and the Public Sphere 3 Credits
courses.description: Examination of the ways in which ethical concerns are aired and debated in the public sphere, including civic institutions, media organizations, and the market. Questions explored may touch on such topics as honesty in media, humility in the face of disagreement, and the pursuit of justice in a contentious society.

courses.name: Jewish Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics in the Jewish literary experience, from the biblical narrative and classical tales to Yiddish and Hebrew literature, the modern European novel, and American Jewish fiction. (H and N)

courses.name: Philosophy of Religion 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies problems in philosophical theology, including the nature of God, arguments for God's existence, the problem of evil and the relation between faith and reason, from both historical and contemporary perspectives. (H) (WR)

courses.name: Religion and Politics in the United States 3 Credits
courses.description: Investigates the role of religious institutions, values and communities in contemporary American political life. (WR)

courses.name: Nature, Spirituality, and Popular Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: The course examines nature-related global processes and the religious, spiritual, political dimensions of artistic productions and scientific representations in ‘popular culture.’ It illuminates the tributaries, hybridities, and controversies that flow from these processes in the ongoing struggle of humankind to understand its place in and responsibilities toward the living world.

courses.name: Religious Extremism 3 Credits
courses.description: What is religious extremism? Who are the extremists? This course digs into these and other questions and provides students with critical knowledge about what is called extremism within Islam, Christianity, Judaism, Hinduism, and Buddhism, while also investigating it in relation to topics such as nationalism, race(ism), and gender and sexuality.

courses.name: God, Humanity, and Evolution 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the language used to describe sciences and religions, focusing on Charles Darwin’s evolutionary theory through the writings of leading thinkers who portray the ways that evolution reshaped religion, and religion reshaped the sciences. Students are instructed in writing about foundational concepts in the sciences and the humanities.

courses.name: Sustainability and Religion 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the relationship between religion and sustainability and explores how the worlds different religious traditions address the social, economic and environmental dimensions of sustainability. Topics include social and environmental justice, sustainable consumption and sustainable agriculture. Case studies highlight multiple religious perspectives, especially in Latin America and south Asia. (H) (WR)

courses.name: Indigenous Religions of the World 3 Credits
courses.description: Describes and compares the religious traditions of indigenous peoples from several different areas of the globe in terms of their cosmogonies, cosmologies, inter-relationalities, and eschatologies.

courses.name: Environmental Ethics 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores competing secular and religious views regarding human impacts on and moral responsibilities toward nature and of the key thinkers and social movements in contention over them. (H) (WR)

courses.name: American Religious History 3 Credits
courses.description: Historical inquiry into the ideological origins and social context of American religious life. (H and D)

courses.name: Religion and Social Movements 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores religion’s role in movements for social change, including reasons movements form, strategies they use, and their impact. Focuses on the distinctive ways religion shapes social movement trajectories and outcomes. Pays special attention to recent changes such as the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and protests against police violence.

courses.name: Hebrew Scriptures 3 Credits
courses.description: History, literature, and beliefs of the Israelites from the Biblical text in the light of modern scholarship. (H)

courses.name: New Testament 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces various literary, social, and religious contexts of the books of the New Testament. (H)

courses.name: Introduction to World Religions 3 Credits
courses.description: Origin, historical development, and key figures, concepts, symbols, practices and institutions of Judaism, Christianity, Islam, Hinduism, Buddhism, and East Asian traditions, including Taoism, Shinto, and Confucianism. (H and N)

courses.name: Introduction to Hindu Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: History, performing arts, and cultural expressions of the Hindu traditions of India and in the diaspora.

courses.name: Religion in Asia 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the religious dimensions of human culture, focusing on Asia: Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Taoism, Shinto. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Introduction to Buddhism 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces doctrines, practices, and institutions that shaped the essential identity of Buddhism as a pan-Asian religion that transcended ethic, cultural, and linguistic boundaries. (H)

courses.name: Introduction to Islam 3 Credits
courses.description: Historical introduction to Islamic tradition. The foundational elements of the tradition, based on the life of Prophet Muhammad and the text of the Qur'an and on an examination of subsequent Islamic expressions. (H and N)

courses.name: Indigenous Religions of the Americas 3 Credits
courses.description: This course introduces the student to the historical and contemporary religious beliefs and practices of the indigenous peoples of the Americas. (H)(WR). This is a core course for the American Indian and Indigenous Studies Minor.

courses.name: Introduction to Christianity 3 Credits
courses.description: Includes origins and development of Christianity, beliefs and rituals, global diversity, Christianity-inspired literature, and engagement with contemporary cultural issues.

courses.name: Jews, Judaism, and Jewishness 3 Credits
courses.description: Multidisciplinary approach to the Jewish experience from its Biblical origins to modern times.

courses.name: Topics in Religion 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics at an introductory level. (H)

courses.name: Myth and Ritual 3 Credits
courses.description: Theory and method in the anthropological and religious studies of myths, rituals, religious specialists, and religious movements using examples from cultures throughout the world.

courses.name: Cults and New Religious Movements 3 Credits
courses.description: Investigates significant new religious movements such as the People's Temple and the Branch Davidians. The origins, internal structure, popularity, and functioning of these movements as well as claims of manipulation and discrimination. (S)

courses.name: Global Ethics 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores ethical dimensions of global social, political, and environmental issues. Introduction to and application of diverse theoretical approaches in philosophical and religion ethics to contemporary global issues such as human rights, war and peace, climate change, and public health.

courses.name: Religion Medicine and Healing 3 Credits
courses.description: Non-conventional healers and healing practices in religious traditions around the globe.

courses.name: Spirituality and Health Care 3 Credits
courses.description: Investigation of the relationship between religious and spiritual beliefs, alternative and traditional medical practice, and Western biomedicine, in historical and contemporary context.

courses.name: Religion and Food 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the relationship between food and religion by investigating food in the context of specific religious traditions, such as Hinduism, and examines food as a moral and ethical category in religious and secular contexts, e.g., organic and locavore. (D and H) (WR)

courses.name: Religion and the American Immigrant Experience 3 Credits
courses.description: Survey of the roles that religion has played in some significant movements of people into and out of the US from the pre-Colonial period to the present.

courses.name: Global Religions in the United States 3 Credits
courses.description: Investigates the religious lives of post-1965 Hindu, Muslim, Buddhist and Global Christian immigrants from Latin America, Asia, the Middle East, and Africa and their interactions with American society.

courses.name: African American Religion 3 Credits
courses.description: Interdisciplinary study of African American religious experience from its beginnings in the 17th century to the present.

courses.name: Religion and Society 3 Credits
courses.description: Interaction of religion and social institutions; the ways religious groups influence and are influenced by the socio-cultural environment. (S) (WR)

courses.name: Religion and Violence 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the problem of violence that springs from religious roots in Western, Asian, African, and Native American traditions. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Religion and Science 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the relationship between religion, science, and philosophy in different religious traditions, focusing on the West. (H) (WR)

courses.name: Ethics in America 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines ethical issues facing contemporary US society, with a focus on cultural and religious diversity. Introduces major religious and philosophical frameworks as ways of understanding and addressing these issues.

courses.name: Death and the Afterlife: Perspectives from World Religions 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines conceptions of death and the afterlife from the perspectives of various religious traditions and popular culture. Considers certain ethical issues related to death and how some American religious traditions engage with such issues.

courses.name: Hebrew Bible as Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Intensive introduction to the literary study of the Hebrew Bible within the context of ancient Near Eastern literature and history.

courses.name: The Christian Gospels 3 Credits
courses.description: Redaction-critical study of selected portions of the canonical Gospels with particular attention to the development of traditions about Jesus in the earliest church. (H) (WR)

courses.name: Acts, Paul, and Early Christianity 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the narrative of the beginning of Christianity according to the Book of Acts, especially as it describes the career of Paul. The second half focuses on the letters of Paul as an alternative source for understanding the earliest forms of Christianity. (H) (WR)

courses.name: Gender and the Hebrew Bible 3 Credits
courses.description: Critical examination of the literary representation and historical realities of gender and sexuality in ancient Israel through close readings of selected texts from the Hebrew Bible.

courses.name: Apocalypticism 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores Jewish and Christian apocalypticism through a survey of apocalyptic texts from the Hebrew Bible, Second Temple Jewish literature (including the Dead Sea Scrolls), and the New Testament. (H)

courses.name: Chinese Religions 3 Credits
courses.description: Comprehensive historical survey of the main religious traditions in China, with focus on Confucianism, Taoism, and Buddhism.

courses.name: Early Judaism and Christianity 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the Jewish-Christian encounter. The historical interaction between Judaism and Christianity including how each group symbolized the other, and the practical implications of the representations. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Religions of India 3 Credits
courses.description: Historical look at the major religious traditions of the Indian subcontinent. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Religion in Modern India 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies religious traditions of India and their interpretation in relation to conditions of the modern world. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Religions of Africa 3 Credits
courses.description: Religion and culture in Africa, the encounter of Islam and Christianity with indigenous religions, and diasporic reformulations. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Religion in Latin America 3 Credits
courses.description: Main religious traditions in Latin America: native religions, Catholicism in its various forms, Protestantism, and African-based religions. (H and N)

courses.name: God: Beliefs, Concepts, Issues 3 Credits
courses.description: Investigates central issues connected with the concept of God in Western religious traditions. Topics include arguments for the existence of God, the problem of evil, theodicy, faith, and reason. (H)

courses.name: Religion Ethics and Nature 3 Credits
courses.description: Religious perspectives on nature and the environment that focus on different theological understandings of the natural world; approaches to using natural resources and efforts to understand human responsibility for the realm of nature. (H)

courses.name: Junior Seminar 3 Credits
courses.description: Intensive introduction to the study of religion. Required of all religion majors during the junior year.

courses.name: Special Topics in Religion 3 Credits
courses.description: Special topics in religion. (H) (WR)

courses.name: Ethics, Utopias, and Dystopias 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines relationships between ethics and utopias in literature, religious communities, and millenarian movements.

courses.name: Religion and Nature in North America 3 Credits
courses.description: Investigates ways that religion and nature have evolved and influenced one another during the cultural, political, and environmental history of North America since European contact. (H)

courses.name: Religion and Social Change 3 Credits
courses.description: Investigates diverse relations between religion and processes of social change. Uses both theoretical and ethnographic case studies to explore issues raised by religion's social role in the U.S., Britain, Asia, Latin America, and Africa. (S) (WR)

courses.name: Gender, Women, Sexuality, and Religion 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the ways that gender and sexuality are experienced and interpreted in different religious traditions.

courses.name: Environmental Values and Practice 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the ethical, religious, and political dimensions of the relationship between ideas and practices, including the divergence between expressed values and actual practices, and some possible reasons for this divergence.

courses.name: Dead Sea Scrolls and Early Jewish Literature 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the varieties of literature that arose within Judaism from 250 BCE to 220 CE, including selections from the Dead Sea Scrolls, the OT Pseudepigrapha, Philo, and Josephus. (H)

courses.name: The Pentateuch 3 Credits
courses.description: In-depth study of the Pentateuch (Genesis-Deuteronomy) in light of modern biblical scholarship.

courses.name: Buddhist Meditation 3 Credits
courses.description: Theory and practice of Buddhist meditation; focuses on the systems of meditation practice developed by the Theravada school in Sri Lanka and the main traditions of Chinese Buddhism.

courses.name: The History of Islam in the Modern World 3 Credits
courses.description: History of Muslims from the 18th century to the present with particular attention to certain critical issues and interpretations in relation to conditions of the modern world. (H and N) (WR)

courses.name: Global Islam 3 Credits
courses.description: Addresses the need for a deeper understanding of the diversity of Muslim cultures/societies in the contemporary global context; combines topical and geographical approach and studies Islam as it intersects with broader social, cultural, political, and economic dynamics.

courses.name: Islam in Africa 3 Credits
courses.description: Development of Muslim societies in Africa from the 7th to the early 20th century with a focus on the religious dynamics that led to the formation of a multitude of African Muslim cultures.

courses.name: Religion and Politics in Latin America 3 Credits
courses.description: Relationship between religion and politics in Latin America from a variety of perspectives and approaches. Addresses millenarian movements, gender, ethnicity and class, as well as church-state dynamics. (S and N)

courses.name: Islam in the Americas 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides knowledge of Islam in the Americas from the 15th century to the present. (H) (WR)

courses.name: Religion and Psychology 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers history of philosophy and religion on psychological theories of consciousness, intelligence, cognition, as well as the mind’s role in the construction of knowledge, ignorance and morality, and it facilitates students in articulating their psychological models to explain human experience, belief, and well-being.

courses.name: Individual Work 1-5 Credits
courses.description: Majors or other advanced undergraduates who wish to supplement regular coursework by individual studies under guidance may apply to a member of the faculty for individual work.

courses.name: Special Topics in Religious Thought 3 Credits
courses.description: Special topics in religious thought.

courses.name: Thesis Seminar in Religion 3 Credits
courses.description: Thesis preparation option for honors-level students.

courses.name: The Comparative Study of Religion 3 Credits
courses.description: The history and major methods that have contributed to the modern study of religion.

courses.name: Special Topics in Religious Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Advanced study for those with proper preparation of selected topics involving one or more religious traditions. (WR)

courses.name: Overseas Studies 1-18 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.name: Beginning Sanskrit 1 4 Credits
courses.description: First of a two-semester series that introduces the Sanskrit language through the Devanagari Script.

courses.name: Beginning Sanskrit 2 4 Credits
courses.description: Second of a two-semester series that introduces the Sanskrit language through the Devanagari Script with an emphasis on reading, writing, grammar and oral recitation.

courses.name: Intermediate Sanskrit 1 3 Credits
courses.description: Intermediate study of Sanskrit to increase knowledge of vocabulary by developing reading and translation skills.

courses.name: Sociology of Religion 3 Credits
