courses.description: Overview of the travel and tourism industry; covers historical, behavioral, societal, and business aspects of travel and tourism.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Tourism Planning 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines the planning of tourism services and facilities, including the identification, planning and use of the physical, social and economic resources necessary to develop and support tourism.

courses.name: Leadership in Recreation and Leisure Services 2 Credits
courses.description: Opportunity to explore and develop leadership and abilities to successfully implement recreation programs and services in leisure delivery systems.

courses.name: Resort and Destination Development 4 Credits
courses.description: Studies resort and destination development and management in resort planning, development and management. Includes current examples from the industry itself as well as laboratory experience for on-site research and study.

courses.name: Hospitality Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of the hospitality industry, including hotel management, food and beverage operations, business and leisure travel markets, convention services, hospitality trends, quest-based customer service strategies and career opportunities.

courses.name: Recreation Program Design and Leadership 3 Credits
courses.description: Focuses on designing and staging leisure experiences using a servant leadership approach. Provides information and practical experiences required to successfully translate agency vision, philosophy and policies into the design, implementation and program evaluation of recreation program and services in community or commercial contexts.

courses.name: Field Experience in THEM 3 Credits
courses.description: Practical field experience in tourism, hospitality, and event services delivery. Apply skill and knowledge as volunteers and utilize leadership and management skills to enhance participant involvement and agency operations. Prepare a resume, investigate agencies as potential internship sites, and submit the appropriate forms for approval of an internship site.

courses.name: Ecotourism 3 Credits
courses.description: Studies the components, history, practice and current issues of nature-based tourism. Explores principles and problems of ecotourism for natural resources and host populations and includes rural tourism, economic impacts, tourism life cycle and case studies.

courses.name: Management & and Supervision of THEM Facilities 3 Credits
courses.description: The management process as it relates to planning and operation of leisure service facilities. Subjects include traditional and contemporary management theory, the management process, legal and financial aspects, risk management and contemporary issues in leisure services management. Facility topics include feasibility studies and design issues.

courses.name: Legal Aspects of Tourism, Events and Recreation 3 Credits
courses.description: Concentrates on the legal aspects of recreation, tourism, hospitality and event management. Enables students to better understand the law as it pertains to their area of specialization and improves risk management practice.

courses.name: Research Methods in Tourism, Hospitality and Event Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Lays out the foundations for conducting research in tourism, hospitality, event management, sports, business, and social sciences in general. Introduces diverse aspects of research, from setting the theoretical background, to evaluating the results of analyses.

courses.name: Variable Topics 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Offered upon request to meet special interests not adequately provided in other courses, such as Multidisciplinary Perspectives of Gerontology and Health and Physical Aspects of Aging.

courses.name: THEM Research 0-5 Credits
courses.description: Participate in supervised research experiences. For this purpose, research is defined as an independent, self-directed experience that enables the investigation of an issue in tourism, hospitality, event management and other leisure settings and then to communicate the results to others.

courses.name: Internship in THEM 1-15 Credits
courses.description: Practical field experience in selected off-campus tourism, hospitality, and event service agencies. Normally taken during the last semester before graduation.

courses.name: Practicum in Tourism, Hospitality and Event Management 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides practical experience for Tourism, Hospitality and Event Management majors who will maintain part-time work in an approved setting appropriate to their specialization.

courses.name: Beginning Turkish 1 5 Credits
courses.description: This course and its sequel, TUR 1131, constitute the introductory sequence in Turkish.

courses.name: Beginning Turkish 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Second semester of the introductory sequence in Turkish.

courses.name: Intensive Beginning Turkish 5 Credits
courses.description: An intensive introduction to Turkish, using the proficiency method. This course is equivalent to, and substitute for, the UF's first-year Turkish sequence (TUR 1130 / TUR 1131).

courses.name: Intermediate Turkish 1 4 Credits
courses.description: Intermediate study of speaking, reading, writing and listening comprehension skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Intermediate Turkish 2 4 Credits
courses.description: Improves speaking, reading, writing and listening skills by building upon language principles introduced in TUR 2220.

courses.name: Intensive Intermediate Turkish 5 Credits
courses.description: Immersive intermediate study of Turkish. Equivalent to, and substitute for, the second-year sequence of TUR 2220 / TUR 2221. Classes meet daily; see the weekly schedule of topics.

courses.name: Overview of Historic Preservation 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of historic preservation and its relationship to historic communities. The course covers terminology, theory, legal, design, social issues and community assessments.

courses.name: Cities of the World 3 Credits
courses.description: Comparative case studies of contemporary cities in the US and a series of foreign countries, both industrialized and developing. Special consideration is given to energy consumption.

courses.name: Preview of Urban and Regional Planning 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of the comprehensive planning process for those considering a career in urban and regional planning or pursuing studies where some knowledge of the planning process is desirable.

courses.name: 3D Modeling, Visualization, and Simulation 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces a variety of methods and techniques to interactively model and visualize physical urban environments in two, three, and four dimensions through a hands-on approach using computer software.

courses.name: Survey of Planning Information Systems 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces concepts and theories associated with Geographic Information Systems (GIS) as related to urban and environmental planning. Requires lectures, class assignments, and homework assignments.

courses.name: Automation for Geospatial Modeling and Analysis 3 Credits
courses.description: Covers methods and techniques for automating geospatial modeling and analysis for planning and built environment by using visual models, computer programming, and custom-built applications and tools that utilize Geographic Information Systems (GIS) technology in the context of planning information systems.

courses.name: Sustainable Urbanism in Europe 3 Credits
courses.description: Explores the diverse urban places that make up modern Europe, its historic development since the pre-industrial city, challenges and accomplishments of urbanization in Europe in recent decades and current accomplishments in achieving sustainable development.

courses.name: Housing and Urban Development 3 Credits
courses.description: Concepts and theories about the economics of the housing market, land development and home building process, and the growth of cities.

courses.name: Neighborhood Planning 3 Credits
courses.description: An overview of the neighborhood planning process situated within the larger city planning framework.

courses.name: International Perspectives in Urban and Regional Planning 3 Credits
courses.description: Presents contemporary global and critical issues in urban and regional planning by carefully selecting critical topics such as inequality, immigration, and segregation, as well as case studies from around the world. Also encourages the evaluation and development of different strategies and corrective courses of action.

courses.name: Defensible Space and CPTED in Urban Design 3 Credits
courses.description: Explore the history, theory, application, and possibilities associated with crime prevention planning. Investigate theories and strategies in the planner's toolkit and how police, planning, and other agencies interact to implement them. Also focuses on real-world applications and students will visit sites that offer teaching and research opportunities.

courses.name: Exploration and Directed Study 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Exploration and directed study.

courses.name: Special Topics 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics; lecture, studio, and seminar explore current issues in urban planning

courses.name: Community Service 3 Credits
courses.description: Provides an opportunity to work directly with a community service agency. Public sector agencies, such as a city or county office and nonprofit organizations, qualify as community service agencies. In lieu of meeting in a classroom, students will be placed in a community service agency and will work as volunteers for a minimum of 60 hours during the academic semester.

courses.name: The Dog 3 Credits
courses.description: Designed for students planning careers in veterinary medicine and veterinary technical programs. Students who want to learn more about dogs will be introduced to a number of topics, including evolution, domestication, anatomy, role in society, physiology, behavior and health of the dog.

courses.name: Aquatic Animal Conservation Issues 3 Credits
courses.description: Controversial conservation issues surrounding aquatic species, from invertebrates to marine mammals.

courses.name: Aquatic Wildlife Health Issues 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces the natural history, anatomy, physiology, behavior and health issues of aquatic wildlife: marine mammals, sea turtles, crocodiles and some fish and invertebrates.

courses.name: Manatee Health and Conservation 3 Credits
courses.description: Introduces undergraduate students to manatee natural history, anatomy, physiology, behavior, conservation and health issues. Students will be exposed to current experts in these fields, be able to name and to describe common health and mortality issues and be able to explain current management strategies.

courses.name: Livestock Health/Disease Prevention 2 Credits
courses.description: The principal diseases of livestock and practical methods for their prevention and control.

courses.name: Problems in Veterinary Science 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Study, research and investigation of an approved problem in veterinary medicine.

courses.name: Beginning Vietnamese 1 5 Credits
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.

courses.name: Beginning Vietnamese 2 5 Credits
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Intermediate Vietnamese 1 4 Credits
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Intermediate Vietnamese 2 4 Credits
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.name: Vietnamese for Heritage Learners 1 4 Credits
courses.description: For those with significant speaking and listening skills, but limited reading and writing skills. Emphasis on developing latter two skills.

courses.name: Individual Study 1-5 Credits
courses.description: For independent work not offered in another course. Available only by special arrangement.

courses.name: Special Topics in Vietnamese Studies 3 Credits
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in Vietnamese studies. Available only by special arrangement.

courses.name: Vietnamese Culture 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of Vietnamese culture, language and history. Focuses on Vietnamese cultural norms, attitudes, values and culture through an examination of history, religious practices, language, literature, family structures, cuisine, daily life and the arts. (H and N)

courses.name: Wildlife Issues in a Changing World 3 Credits
courses.description: The biological and ecological basis of wildlife issues and the pathways humans use to resolve these issues. Topics include major animal phyla; evolutionary history of vertebrates; state, federal and international agencies that manage wildlife worldwide; and the impact of human activities on wildlife. (B)

courses.name: Biodiversity Conservation: Global Perspectives 3 Credits
courses.description: The relationship between humans and the global biotic environment that supports them. This course explores human patterns of resource use and population biology that determine the status of the earth's biodiversity resources. Helps students understand how today's human society affects global life support systems, and how individuals can make lifetime contributions to environmental solutions. (B and N)

courses.name: Wildlife Colloquium 1 Credit
courses.description: Wildlife ecology and conservation as a major and career.

courses.name: Wildlife Ecology and Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Wildlife as a natural resource with emphasis on principles of conservation, ecology and management.

courses.name: Wildlife of Florida 3 Credits
courses.description: The diversity of wildlife species in Florida with emphasis on amphibians, reptiles, mammals and birds.

courses.name: Wildlife of Florida Laboratory 1 Credit
courses.description: Laboratory exploring the diversity of wildlife in Florida's ecosystems with emphasis on field identification, natural history and ecology of birds, mammals, amphibians and reptiles.

courses.name: Natural Resource Ecology 3 Credits
courses.description: Application of ecological principles and natural history information to conserve and sustainably manage natural resources with an emphasis on animals and plants.

courses.name: The Ecology of Climate Change 3 Credits
courses.description: Provide a broad overview of the ecological responses to climate change on the Earth. Students will learn about ecological processes, spanning genetics, physiology and behavior, morphology, phenology and distribution, and up through species interaction, communities and ecosystems and how climate change impacts them.

courses.name: Tropical Wildlife 3 Credits
courses.description: An interdisciplinary course that teaches the ecology of animals and the socio-economics of wildlife use. The first part of the course deals with the biology of tropical wildlife and the second with the historical, economic and political aspects of the use and management of tropical wildlife.

courses.name: Introduction to Conservation Genetics 4 Credits
courses.description: Types of molecular polymorphisms found in nature, including how genetic information is organized, what evolutionary and demographic forces act to shape genetic polymorphisms, and how and why genetics are useful in population conservation and management.

courses.name: Landscape Ecology and Conservation 3 Credits
courses.description: Central constructs and methods of landscape ecology are applied to wildlife ecology and conservation.

courses.name: Large Mammal Ecology and Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Large mammals are fascinating creatures that interact with the coupled human and natural systems that they occupy in complex ways. Abiotic and biotic conditions as well as human impacts drive their dynamics, while they in turn play significant roles in shaping the diverse landscapes they inhabit. Take a critical approach to examining current advances and controversies involving large mammals.

courses.name: Wildlife Habitat Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Application of land management practices and their effects on wildlife habitats in Florida.

courses.name: Wetland Management 3 Credits
courses.description: Prepare students for basic monitoring, field research, and management of wetlands, using ecological principles and knowledge of community variation in relation to stressors. Identification, monitoring techniques, and management and restoration techniques will be taught through a combination of class lectures and hands-on field exercises and labs.

courses.name: Wetland Wildlife Ecology 4 Credits
courses.description: Ecological principles of conservation and management of wildlife in wetland environments, including a survey of the structure and function of major wetland types.

courses.name: Ecology of Bird Introductions and Invasions 3 Credits
courses.description: Ecology and conservation implications of introductions and invasions of birds. The course covers the invasion pathway model as well as the four levels of factors that can influence introduction outcomes.

courses.name: Introduction to Wildlife Population Ecology 3 Credits
courses.description: The dynamics and regulation of biological populations and life-history theory.

courses.name: Human Dimensions of Natural Resource Conservation 3 Credits
courses.description: Local and international models are used to provide an interdisciplinary overview of the theory and practice of conservation education, environmental communication and integrated resource management and conservation.

courses.name: Avian Field Techniques 2 Credits
courses.description: Intensive advanced field experience in scientific study design and ecology of wild bird populations and communities.

courses.name: Diverse Perspectives in Conservation 3 Credits
courses.description: As the population of the United States becomes increasingly diverse, the integration and participation of diverse communities is essential with respect to successful management and conservation of wildlife and natural resources. Examines current and historical factors that influence the interaction of marginalized communities such as indigenous and communities of color with the natural environment, including natural resource management decision-making structures.

courses.name: Conservation Biology 3 Credits
courses.description: Overview of the major problems in conservation and of the biological principles and theories to preserve this diversity.

courses.name: Wildlife Behavior and Conservation 3 Credits
courses.description: Concise, current, and thorough grounding to the field (theory, practice, and relevance) of animal behavior, with a strong focus on applications of wildlife behavior to achieve successful wildlife conservation gains.

courses.name: Quantitative Wildlife Ecology 3 Credits
courses.description: Concepts and applications of quantitative techniques in ecology and wildlife management.

courses.name: Supervised Extension Experience in Wildlife Ecology and Conservation 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic extension experiences in agricultural and life sciences under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.name: Individual Problems 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Individual study of a selected topic related to wildlife ecology and conservation as contracted with the instructor at the start of the term.

courses.name: Supervised Research in Wildlife Ecology and Conservation 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Honors Thesis Research in Wildlife Ecology and Conservation 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Independent research in wildlife ecology and conservation leading to an honors thesis. Student will be mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.name: Topics in Wildlife Ecology and Conservation 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Variable current issues and in-depth study in wildlife, forestry, range, recreation and fisheries issues not covered in other courses.

courses.name: Internship in Wildlife Ecology and Conservation 1-12 Credits
courses.description: Practical teaching, research, and extension experience in the field of wildlife ecology and conservation. Offered every semester.

courses.name: Wildlife Techniques 3 Credits
courses.description: Evaluate the theories, strengths, and weaknesses behind the use of standard wildlife techniques by researchers and managers. Major topics covered include study design, radio telemetry, passive monitoring techniques, animal capture and handling, sexing and aging wildlife, population estimation, and habitat selection.

courses.name: Field Wildlife Techniques 1 Credit
courses.description: Students will examine and apply the wildlife techniques used by managers and researchers when working with wildlife. Major topics covered in the course include: animal capture and handling, sexing and aging wildlife, radio telemetry, population estimation methods, passive monitoring techniques, quantifying vegetation, and habitat usage.

courses.name: Expository and Argumentative Writing 3 Credits
courses.description: The principal elements of writing clearly, efficiently, and effectively. Also focuses on writing logical arguments, building research skills, and developing critical thinking through reading, writing, and discussion. (C) (WR)  Completion of this course with a grade of “C” or better is linked to earning the Fundamentals of Written Communication digital badge.

courses.name: Argument and Persuasion 3 Credits
courses.description: Writing techniques and forms of argument in a range of disciplines. For their major writing assignment in this course, students will write an extensively researched and well-documented research paper, learning professional and academic writing conventions and developing their critical thinking skills. (C) (WR)

courses.name: Analytical Writing and Thinking 3 Credits
courses.description: Advances students critical thinking and writing skills beyond first-year composition. With wide-ranging themes in areas such as languages, political science, anthropology or biology, this course exposes students to the advanced analytical techniques and communication strategies that professors in all disciplines expect them to know. (C) (WR)

courses.name: Professional Communication for Engineers 3 Credits
courses.description: Students master a variety of communication strategies and genres of writing relevant to engineering, such as composing email, memos, letters, technical descriptions, instructions, academic research reports and professional proposals. Students also respond to complex rhetorical situations, thus preparing for work in their professional communities. (C) (WR)

courses.name: Writing for Strategic Communication 3 Credits
courses.description: Effective writing strategies for pitching, planning, and delivering content on behalf of organizations and within professional communities. Rhetorical analysis of strategic communication in content-rich marketing published via digital platforms. Intended for public relations, advertising, and telecom majors.

courses.name: Professional Writing in the Discipline 3 Credits
courses.description: A communication course adjusted to a specific professional discipline, the discipline to be determined by need. Covers major elements of organizational communication with emphasis on composition of reports, proposals, letters and memos, manuals, and oral presentations. Course materials and assignments are relevant to the specific discipline. (C) (WR)

courses.name: Writing in the Health Professions 3 Credits
courses.description: Designed to help students master a variety of communication strategies and genres of writing relevant to the health professions. Students learn to compose clear messages to professionals, patients, and the public, preparing them for upper-division courses and building a foundation for work in their professional communities.

courses.name: Writing in the Medical Sciences 3 Credits
courses.description: Training in advanced literacy skills for medical practitioners, including the use of medical databases and the presentation of medical research to professional and lay audiences. Work in teams that are typical of medical practice to learn techniques for effective patient interaction. (C) (WR)

courses.name: Writing in the Social Sciences 3 Credits
courses.description: Designed to help students master a variety of communication strategies and genres of writing relevant to the social sciences. Conducting original research, students learn the relationship between clear, simple prose and thoughtful social analysis. Students write literature reviews, develop methodologies, present results, analyze data, and draft graduate or internship applications.

courses.name: Writing in the Law 3 Credits
courses.description: Designed to help students master a variety of communication strategies and genres of writing relevant to law, with special emphasis on legal reasoning and logic. Students write legal briefs, a legal memorandum, business correspondence, and law school applications and are introduced to legal research and moot court debate.

courses.name: Writing in the Communication Sciences 3 Credits
courses.description: For communication science professionals who interact with audiences that range from school counselors to caregivers and colleagues, excellent writing an essential skill. Focus is on writing in graduate school and as practitioners: research-based reports, clinical documents, and career portfolios. (C) (WR)

courses.name: Writing in the Physical Sciences 3 Credits
courses.description: Designed to improve writing skills necessary for success in the physical sciences, both in graduate school and the workplace. Investigating an area of special interest, students learn advanced library research, correct documentation, stylistic conventions for their major fields, and how to present research effectively. (C) (WR)

courses.name: Special Topics in Rhetoric and Writing 3 Credits
courses.description: Designed to advance students’ ability to write in specific genres or to develop their understanding of special topics related to the field. Specific sections will be tailored to the expertise of the faculty members teaching the course.

courses.name: Writing the Science Thesis 3 Credits
courses.description: In this course, students learn to write an academic thesis and a publishable version of their research, preparing them for both academic and scientific audiences. Assignments include a literature review, thesis, research report, and conference poster. Frequent peer review prepares students for collaboration, a necessary skill in contemporary science.

courses.name: Peer Tutoring in Rhetoric and Writing 2 Credits
courses.description: Examines the theories and best practices used by writing tutors with the goal of preparing to be peer writing tutors. Includes preparation on conducting needs assessments, prioritizing advice, and giving effective writing feedback. Observe experienced tutors and be guided through the first tutorial sessions.

courses.name: Directed Independent Study in Rhetoric and Writing 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Designed for the advanced student who wants to pursue in depth an area of study not provided in regularly offered courses. Independent study can involve independent reading or projects under faculty guidance.

courses.name: Special Topics in Rhetoric and Writing 1-3 Credits
courses.description: Designed to advance students' ability to write in specific genres and to develop their understanding of special topics related to the field. Specific sections will be tailored to the expertise of the faculty members teaching the course.

courses.name: Modes of Inquiry 3 Credits
courses.description: Strategies for dealing successfully with various media types common to the college experience (web-based, film, traditional readings, etc.). Through reading, writing, research and small group discussion, students will develop and refine reading, writing and speaking skills. Modes of Inquiry employ a cross-discipline approach so that student encounter reading and writing as it happens in the humanities, social sciences and business. Course also utilizes the electronic classroom, giving students the opportunity to polish computer skills and take advantage of online resources. The critical thinking, reading and writing skills learned in this course enhance the communications skills needed for a successful college career. (WR)

courses.name: Writing Life: Art, Drama, Film, Literature, Poetry, and You 3 Credits
courses.description: Examines how humanities-based texts (novels, films, plays, poems, and art) reflect and resonate with components of our personal, social, and cultural identities. To demonstrate your understanding of the course and its goals, you will write three essays and sit for two closed-book exams.

courses.name: Why Tell Stories? 3 Credits
courses.description: Exploring diverse stories in art, philosophy, literature, and film to discover how the creation and sharing of stories is a universal experience, one that is central to both humanness and existence.

courses.name: Reading and Writing Content Area 1-7 Credits
courses.description: Covers the fundamentals of beginning college writing and critical reading skills.

courses.name: Life in the Universe 3 Credits
courses.description: The origin of life on Earth and the possibility of life elsewhere. A multidisciplinary approach is followed. Conditions for life to form and the likelihood that such conditions may exist elsewhere in the universe are discussed. Also considered are schemes proposed for the search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI). (P)

courses.name: Theory and Practice in the Biological Sciences 2 Credits
courses.description: Presents the scientific method, in its many formulations, from historical, philosophical and sociological perspectives. Explores generation and presentation of data, formulation of hypotheses and theories and dissemination of results. Also examines the ethical implication of biological research.

courses.name: Paleontology 4 Credits
courses.description: Investigation of the history of life on earth, including aspects of invertebrate and vertebrate paleontology, micropaleontology and paleobotany.

courses.name: Genetics 4 Credits
courses.description: Fundamental properties of inheritance in eukaryotic organisms emphasizing examples in humans. Develops basic concepts for the nature, organization, transmission, expression, recombination, and function of genetic materials, and principles derived for genetically characterizing populations.

courses.name: Cellular and Systems Physiology 4 Credits
courses.description: How cells, organs, and higher level systems are integrated and coordinated in the functions of humans and other animals. Emphasizes the use of model organisms, mathematical models, and the physical sciences to understand the mechanistic basis of normal physiology and dysfunction.

courses.name: General Ecology 4 Credits
courses.description: Ecological processes and organization in terrestrial and aquatic habitats. Laboratory and field exercises emphasize techniques of ecological analysis.

courses.name: Evolution 4 Credits
courses.description: Processes and mechanisms of evolution, including population genetics, speciation, patterns of evolution and molecular evolution.

courses.name: Comparative Biomechanics 3 Credits
courses.description: Reviews physical principles governing the form and function of organisms.

courses.name: Physiology and Molecular Biology of Animals 4 Credits
courses.description: Processes and mechanisms of maintenance, activity, and integration in animals with emphasis on vertebrates. Laboratory experience in quantitative methods and techniques of physiological investigation.

courses.name: Animal Behavior 4 Credits
courses.description: The causes, origins and evolution of animal behavior emphasizing field observations and experiments on the behavior of a variety of animal groups.

courses.name: Evolutionary Developmental Biology 4 Credits
courses.description: Analysis of embryonic development, underlying genetic mechanisms and how these processes have driven the evolutionary diversification of animal body plans.

courses.name: Functional Vertebrate Anatomy 4 Credits
courses.description: The form and function of chordates accompanied by laboratory work dealing with a selected series of chordates.

courses.name: Invertebrate Biodiversity 4 Credits
courses.description: Comparative biology of invertebrates, emphasizing morphology, evolution, ecology and life history.

courses.name: Vertebrate Biodiversity 4 Credits
courses.description: Comparative biology of vertebrates, emphasizing morphology, evolution, ecology and behavior.

courses.name: Marine Biology 4 Credits
courses.description: Survey of major marine taxa, systematics of local marine fauna and flora, with familiarization of the marine environment. Laboratory emphasizes field work and independent projects.

courses.name: Avian Biology 4 Credits
courses.description: The basic biological characteristics of birds, which, as exceptionally unique flying vertebrates, are confronted with a spectrum of problems in terms of anatomy, physiology, behavior, migration and population ecology.

courses.name: Individual Studies in Zoology 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Qualified students and the instructor concerned may choose a particular topic or problem for study.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Zoology 0-3 Credits
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.name: Special Topics in Zoology 1-4 Credits
courses.description: Lectures, conferences or laboratory sessions covering selected topics of current interest in zoology.

courses.name: Practical Experience in Teaching Zoology 2 Credits
courses.description: Participation in teaching approved Zoology courses with practical experience in instructional procedures, testing and grading, course and laboratory preparation, and laboratory assistance. Cannot be used to satisfy the minimum credit requirement for Zoology majors.

courses.name: Overseas Studies 1-18 Credits
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.
